webTitle: Dundee warms to Caniggia the great

fields.headline: Dundee warms to Caniggia the great
fields.standfirst: Club's exotic overhaul wins fans' approval, writes  Graham Spiers
fields.trailText: There's a revolution going on at Dundee, and Claudio Cannigia is at the centre of it. Graham Spiers on how the club's exotic overhaul has won the fan's approval ahead of today's Tayside derby.
fields.body:
If Salvador Dali had ever desired to capture some representation of football on canvas he would surely have visited the Tayside derby this afternoon. The old city of Dundee has not been this mind-boggled since the days when Sinatra and the Beatles arrived in town. The reason for it is found in a remark made by a little boy to his mother last week. "Look," says the lad. "There's Claudio Caniggia over there."

Bizarre is not the word to describe the almost unfathomable overhauling of Dundee FC from a downtrodden, financially emaciated club to one now managed by a former Serie A player and overrun with exotic imports. Nor does surrealism do justice to the presence of Caniggia who, if his sore rib withstands a biting Tayside workout this morning, will play in a venue traditionally reserved for Rabs and Boabs when he turns out against Dundee United this afternoon.

Six weeks have now passed since jaws, which had long since ceased dropping in Jute City, went slack at the announcement made by Ivano Bonetti, the Dundee manager. "My aim is to bring Claudio Caniggia to Dens Park."

The only other Bonetti to have been anywhere near either Tannadice or Dens was the old cat himself, the much-maligned former England goalkeeper, Peter, whose brief career with United in the mid-1970s was mercifully ended when he continued almost without stopping in a north-westerly route to open a B&B on the island of Mull.

The contemporary Bonetti is a much more fascinating figure. Italians by the pizza-parlour load seem to have been arriving to sign for Dundee, as have the Georgian international, Giorgi Nemsadze, and the ultimate coup, Senor Caniggia himself.

Exactly 12 months ago Dundee's then hard-working and talented, though, alas, merely Scottish manager, Jocky Scott, was told by the club's owners there was not a single ha'penny to spend on players. Caniggia is now on £12,000 a week until the end of the season. This at a club attracting gates of around 6,000. It is a stupendously mind-bending scene.

Not only this, but the smouldering, beautiful Caniggia spouse, the famed Marianna, has also been in Dundee, brazenly announcing that they both love the industrial sprawl - presumably in comparison to dank, miserable, grey-skied Italy. La Caniggia was reported two weeks ago to be searching for a castle for her family to settle into.

Dundee have not always been seen as the old coalman of the Scottish game. In the post-war boom they were one of the country's big clubs - in the early 50s, for instance, provoking gasps around Britain when they brought Billy Steel back to Scottish football from Derby County for an unheard-of £17,500.

Under Bill Shankly's brother, Bob, they also won the Scottish championship in 1962. But some rot has since set in. Dens Park began to crumble. A previously large support by the 1ate 80s had been pared down to a bitter rump who watched amid acrimonious shouting as Dundee dipped in and out of Premier League existence. Those who experienced Dens on these irate winter afternoons quickly came to the conclusion these were the angriest pews in British football.

Ivano Bonetti, though, has wiped away these bitter tears with a magical flourish. Two weeks ago, following on from Caniggia's arrival, came a goalkeeper, Marco Roccati, signed from Bologna, having previously arrived at that Italian club in a £1.3m deal.

Dundee have recently had a core support of only 4,000, though not surprisingly this figure has started edging up as these people are now clapping their eyes each week on Roccati, Marrocco, Bonetti, Artero, Carranza, Nemsadze, Romano and the blessed Caniggia.

Football, and Scottish football in particular, seems to be prone to hiring exotic old pros still just a few furlongs short of being clapped out. Hibs astoundingly signed George Best in 1979 - just before the winger completely succumbed to the bevvy. But Caniggia is a different case. Lately, after a career with River Plate, Atalanta and Benfica among others, he had been back training with Atalanta and, at 33, still looked in good condition.

Amid the colourful bedlam surrounding the arrival of a player once banned for cocaine use, nothing too damning can be offered. First, because Scottish football can boast this Dali-esque fact - Dundee matches are now being piped live to South America. Second, because Caniggia himself still looks lithe, eager and fit - although his hair is thinning which requires him to gingerly tend it beneath his hairband prior to kick-off. But third, and most importantly, because he can still bang in goals.

Two weeks ago we glimpsed the Caniggia of old in Dundee's televised game against Motherwell. The head characteristically down, the body strangely bent forward as he rushed with the ball, he encroached to the edge of Motherwell's box before scooping the ball up as if with a mashie niblick to float it over Stevie Woods and into the net. Last week against Hibs he was also haring here, there and everywhere - two goals in 3 games isn't bad.

But enough of dull football. Caniggia is on Tayside - as apparently, more frequently, will be the beguiling Marianna. As one Dundee fan said last week: "It's as if a Christmas tree has been lit up prematurely."

The last and ultimate scene to be fulfilled here is surely Diego Maradona, genuinely one of Caniggia's best friends, arriving to toast his pal with the words: "It has always been my dream to come to Dundee." Scottish football is running out of unrealistic fantasies.

fields.headline: Ginola renews attack on Graham
fields.trailText: Never one to let bygones be bygones, David Ginola has predicted George Graham may not hold on to his job much longer as Aston Villa prepare to face Tottenham.
fields.body:
David Ginola has reopened his rift with George Graham on the eve of Tottenham's visit to the Frenchman's new club Aston Villa.

Ginola, who spent three seasons at White Hart Lane, blames the Spurs manager for his departure to Villa Park in the summer and yesterday predicted Graham may not hold on to his job much longer.

Graham has been under pressure from a section of supporters who have called for him to be sacked in the light of Tottenham's unspectacular start to the season. While the protests were muted last week by Spurs' 2-1 win over Sunderland, Ginola has expressed his sympathy for their stance.

"Spurs fans will never accept George because they will always see him as a former manager of Arsenal, their arch-rivals, and this is the worst thing that could happen to their club," he said. "A lot of people said he would go before me but I couldn't stay at a club and wait for the manager to go. But I think if George has a bad season he could go - maybe it is heading that way."

"I loved the Tottenham fans and had a special relationship with them. They understand that I did not want to leave the club."

Ginola, 33, has yet to play a full match for Villa since his £3m move. He has started four games and been used as a substitute in two others but has been hampered by back and thigh injuries. He is now fit again although will probably start on the bench today.

While Graham would not be drawn into a slanging match, Villa's manager John Gregory admitted that Ginola would have extra motivation for the match. "He feels as if he was branded as the guilty party when he left Spurs," Gregory said. "He didn't feel he got the credit he deserved for what he did for Tottenham."

Another player lining up against his former club today is Paulo Wanchope, although he is expecting a more hostile reception from the opposing fans. The Manchester City striker was targeted by a section of the West Ham fans throughout his spell at Upton Park and is prepared for similar treatment on his first return since his £3.65m move.

"This sort of thing is normal maybe for them - making things hard for ex-players," he said. "But it will be good for me if they do that because it will keep me going. I'm a player who is going there to win the game with my team-mates."

Newcastle United have taken the former Crystal Palace left-back and China international Sun Jihai on trial from Dalian Wanda with a view to a permanent move.

Jihai, 23, made 23 league appearances for Palace before rejoining Dalian in July 1999. He is currently serving a 12-month ban from his national side for head-butting an assistant referee after China's 1-0 Olympic qualifying defeat to South Korea last October.

United will be without Carl Cort, a £7m summer signing from Wimbledon, until the new year following surgery on a hamstring injury. The striker has started only five games since moving to St James' Park, scoring two goals.

Arsenal's goalkeeper David Seaman will also be missing for the next few weeks after spraining his ankle in training. The England keeper has missed Arsenal's last four games with a shoulder injury.

Italy's coach Giovanni Trapattoni has named the Inzaghi brothers, Simone and Filippo, in his squad for Wednesday's international against England in Turin. The major surprise is the inclusion of the 23-year-old Atalanta midfielder Damiano Zenoni, who had never played in Serie A before this season.

Italy: Buffon (Parma), Toldo (Fiorentina); Bertotto (Udinese), Cannavaro (Parma), Nesta (Lazio), Pancaro (Lazio), Iuliano (Juventus), Maldini (Milan); Ambrosini (Milan), Albertini (Milan), Gattuso (Milan), Coco (Milan), D Zenoni (Atalanta), Di Biagio (Internazionale), Di Livio (Fiorentina), Fiore (Udinese); Totti (Roma), Delvecchio (Roma), Del Piero (Juventus), F Inzaghi (Juventus), S Inzaghi (Lazio).

fields.headline: Angry Caddick 'insulted umpire'
fields.standfirst:
Governor's XI 224 and 115-4
England 315
Scoreboard
fields.trailText: Third Day Andy Caddick provided a timely reminder of this tour's potential for controversy when he was reported to have "insulted the umpire" during a day of drudgery in Peshawar.
fields.body:
England received the strongest possible reminder of this tour's potential for controversy when Andrew Caddick was reported to have had words with an umpire during play here yesterday.

According to Sajjad Asghar, who was standing at Caddick's end while he was bowling to the left-handed batsman Akhtar Sarfraz, the fast bowler "insulted my country" after the umpire had refused an appeal for a catch behind the wicket. Although there has been a match referee appointed for the game, he has no jurisdiction other than to report such incidents to the Pakistan cricket board once an official complaint had been made in writing.

After play had finished for the day, however, Farrukh Zaman, a former Test player himself, confirmed he had received no such complaint and so the chances are that the incident will go no further. If so, England can breathe a sigh of relief. They will have escaped lightly.

During the morning session, a hot-air balloon had been inflated on an adjacent sports field and disappeared to the north towards the mountains. On the cricket field, however, the balloon did not go up until late into the final session as the evening haze descended and the light closed in.

A fine partnership between Sarfraz and the bulky right-hander Naumanullah Khan had rescued the Governor's side from 13 for three and was already worth 86 when Sarfraz, missed at slip by Graham Thorpe off Darren Gough's bowling when 16 and now 46, appeared to offer a straightforward edge to Alec Stewart. Certainly there was a loud noise.

Caddick's celebrations were curtailed, however, by the umpire's lack of interest. Almost immediately the bowler commenced a stream of rhetoric that was to last several overs, directed for the most part at the batsman but, it is now apparent, at the umpire as well.

Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, dismissed this as acceptable sledging (if there is such a thing) and a sign that his side showed "passion". According to Asghar, a 46-year-old retired banker who speaks excellent English, it was rather more than this.

"He said something bad about my country," he said. "I can't tolerate that. He can abuse me and he can abuse my decisions but he shouldn't say things about my country. He is a guest here. I don't want to report what he said because it would cause problems for him in other parts of the country."

There speaks a sensible man and would that Shakoor Rana could have employed the same commonsense approach 13 years ago. Now it is to be hoped that Caddick, trivial though he may think all this is, understands a little more the sensitivity that prevails in this part of the world and plays his part by swallowing his pride and apologising to Asghar for any offence caused. The bowler was trying his socks off but he went too far.

The team know now that without compromising their competitive edge, they must tread carefully from hereon in. There is, for example, still an undercurrent of dissatisfaction here that the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, Lord MacLaurin, will not be attending an England tour for the first time since he took up his appointment three years ago.

The fact that it has been decided instead to send the board's deputy chairman, David Morgan, a good man and a top administrator, to the last Test in Karachi will do little to camouflage the perception that the head honcho is ducking out. There may be some apologising needed on that front too.

At least the fracas on the field provided a diversion from what was, apart from a fierce and vastly improved new-ball burst from Gough and Caddick, a day of drudgery and substandard England performance. From 241 for five overnight, Graham Thorpe (48) and Craig White (22) started brightly enough but the innings stagnated after both were out, White to a brilliant catch on the long leg boundary as he hooked.

Ashley Giles and Ian Salisbury ground out an excruciating and meaningless partnership of just eight that took 55 balls, and when the last wicket fell shortly before lunch just 75 further runs had accrued in 2 hours giving a lead of 91.

While the England opening pair bowled with such verve at the start, a win inside three days looked a possibility. Once the ball lost its newness, however, Sarfraz (53 not out) and Naumanullah, who was caught at short midwicket from bat and pad for 50 shortly before bad light stopped play with 13 overs left, played extremely well, making the spinners Giles and Salisbury look worryingly ordinary.

Pakistan's selectors meanwhile have named a preliminary squad of 18 players, captained by Moin Khan, for next week's first Test in Lahore. It includes no fewer than five spinners, three of them wrist spinners, with the young legspinner DanishKanaria apparently in the frame to oust Mushtaq Ahmed, however unlikely that may sound.

 The International Cricket Council's anti-corruption unit is to investigate allegations about 15 foreign players made in the Indian police's report on match-fixing. But the unit said investigations involving non-Indian players could take "a number of weeks to complete".

New Zealand's authorities have appointed a three-man team to look into allegations that their former captain Martin Crowe took money from an Indian bookmaker.

webTitle: 70,000 Bangladeshis defy floods to cheer debut Test

fields.headline: 70,000 Bangladeshis defy floods to cheer debut Test
fields.trailText:
A massive crowd of excited souls saw Bangladesh reach 239 for six against India. Expect willpower to help the country overcome horrendous difficulties and become a force in the game, writes Mike Selvey
Scoreboard
fields.body:
If the quality of Bangladesh's cricket will remain questionable for a long time to come, the level of support for the game in the youngest Test nation can hardly be overstated. After one day of Test cricket they have already drawn a crowd substantially higher than England can ever hope to command.

Some 70,000 excited souls packed into Dhaka's Bangabandhu national stadium yesterday to see Bangladesh reach 239 for six against India, and that is enough to encourage the belief that the problems posed by limited facilities, funds and a shortage of true international calibre players will all eventually be conquered by a massive tide of enthusiasm.

Bangladesh are the most ill prepared Test nation since South Africa's elevation more than a century ago. Even the greatest occasion in their cricket history - the 66-1 upset of Pakistan in the World Cup last year, which brought an immediate public holiday - has since been tarnished by suspicions of Pakistani match-rigging.

Expectation on an immense scale is justification enough for the 10th Test nation. England's flood disruption is nothing compared with the annual horror in Bangladesh, where six weeks ago an estimated one million people were left homeless. Festivities have been drastically reduced as a consequence. But since Test status was granted in June, every spare piece of wasteland in the capital Dhaka has become a cricket pitch filled by barefoot children wielding rudimentary bats.

Bangladesh's elevation is even presented as the first stage in a huge Asian expansion. The Asian Cricket Council is embarking upon a £20m expansion programme designed to make it the predominant cricketing region in the world.

The game was introduced to Bangladesh by the British nearly 200 years ago, and the MCC tour of 1976-77 did much to assist their graduation as associate members of the International Cricket Conference. But England, unwilling to add a further commitment to an exhausting Asian winter programme, shunned the offer to provide the opposition in their debut Test.

It has taken more than two decades for Bangladesh to develop from associate members of the ICC to full Test nation, and the completion of the journey is a triumph. Soon after independence in 1971, achieved only after much bloodshed, the stadium in Dhaka had fallen into disrepair, the square having sunk several inches and the Press Club bar riddled by shells.

The first day itself was satisfying for two former Bangladesh captains, as an unpenetrative Indian attack laboured on a placid surface. Akram Khan hit the game's first six then was dismissed attempting a second, while Aminul Islam achieved their first Test half-century. As Bangladesh's chief executive, Hossain Chowdery, pointed out, that was better than India, Pakistan or Sri Lanka achieved at the first time of asking.

After one day of Test cricket they have already drawn a crowd substantially higher than England can ever hope to command. Some 70,000 excited souls packed into Dhaka's Bangabandhu national stadium yesterday to see Bangladesh reach 239 for six against India, and that is enough to encourage the belief that the problems posed by limited facilities, funds and a shortage of true international calibre players will all eventually be conquered by a massive tide of enthusiasm. Bangladesh are the most ill prepared Test nation since South Africa's elevation more than a century ago. Even the greatest occasion in their cricket history - the 66-1 upset of Pakistan in the World Cup last year, which brought an immediate public holiday - has since been tarnished by suspicions of Pakistani match-rigging. Expectation on an immense scale is justification enough for the 10th Test nation. England's flood disruption is nothing compared with the annual horror in Bangladesh, where six weeks ago an estimated one million people were left homeless. Festivities have been drastically reduced as a consequence. But since Test status was granted in June, every spare piece of wasteland in the capital Dhaka has become a cricket pitch filled by barefoot children wielding rudimentary bats. Bangladesh's elevation is even presented as the first stage in a huge Asian expansion. The Asian Cricket Council is embarking upon a £20m expansion programme designed to make it the predominant cricketing region in the world. The game was introduced to Bangladesh by the British nearly 200 years ago, and the MCC tour of 1976-77 did much to assist their graduation as associate members of the International Cricket Conference. But England, unwilling to add a further commitment to an exhausting Asian winter programme, shunned the offer to provide the opposition in their debut Test. It has taken more than two decades for Bangladesh to develop from associate members of the ICC to full Test nation, and the completion of the journey is a triumph. Soon after independence in 1971, achieved only after much bloodshed, the stadium in Dhaka had fallen into disrepair, the square having sunk several inches and the Press Club bar riddled by shells. The first day itself was satisfying for two former Bangladesh captains, as an unpenetrative Indian attack laboured on a placid surface. Akram Khan hit the game's first six then was dismissed attempting a second, while Aminul Islam achieved their first Test half-century. As Bangladesh's chief executive, Hossain Chowdery, pointed out, that was better than India, Pakistan or Sri Lanka achieved at the first time of asking.

webTitle: Nasty surprise on the cards for Eriksson

fields.headline: Nasty surprise on the cards for Eriksson
fields.trailText: England's problems lay less with an excess of gambling than a lack of technique. With overhit passes and poor control the norm, does Sven-Goran Eriksson really know what he will be taking on?
fields.body:
It might sell fewer newspapers but a more pertinent debate about the England football team would be concerned with how they pass the ball, not how they pass their time.

Earlier this week Arsène Wenger, the Arsenal manager, cut through all the froth and fuss about card schools and heavy betting when he remarked that England's problem lay less with an excess of gambling than a lack of technique.

Quite so. If Peter Taylor's caretakership achieves nothing else in Wednesday's friendly against Italy in Turin his Pan's People of a team can at least show that the acceptable standards of passing and movement which he brought to the England Under-21 side during his three years in charge can be restored at senior level.

Before, during and after this summer's European Championship Kevin Keegan complained consistently about the regularity with which his England team gave the ball to their opponents. At Liverpool Keegan was brought up to treat the ball as a prized possession not yielded lightly.

With the recent influx of foreign players and coaches the passing in the Premiership is better than it was. But it will have to improve further still to reach the levels of other European leagues.

Does Sven-Goran Eriksson really know what he will be taking on when he takes over the England team next July? On television the English game comes over as quick, competitive and exciting with plenty of goalmouth incidents. That is why it is such a TV attraction overseas.

Seen live, however, the flaws are more apparent. Eriksson has spent much of his coaching career in Serie A, where it is taken for granted that the last thing a player receiving the ball will worry about is his ability to control it. Even as the ball is in flight he will be weighing up his options for a pass, run or shot and such is the positional discipline of the Italian game that he will know instinctively the movements of those around him.

Watch Manchester United, Arsenal, Liverpool, Leeds or Chelsea on their good days and one can see similar things happening. The same applies to other teams with good footballing habits - Ipswich, Charlton and West Ham for example.

All too often, however, and as much through carelessness and laziness as poor technique, the passing is sloppy. The ball is put into places where a team-mate might be, not where he actually is. Overhit passes, demanding from the recipient the speed of an Olympic sprint champion, are the norm rather than the exception.

In Italy or Spain a poor pass will be shrilly derided by the crowd. In England it is either ignored or even applauded, if only for the effort taken to kick the ball a long way. English spectators have been brought up to expect less. An Italian crowd is as likely to cheer an overhit pass as it would relish a tin of chopped spaghetti in tomato sauce.

One of the reasons that passing in England is still not as good as it should be is that when teams are giving the ball to each other the importance of possession is reduced. This is why the opponents of Manchester United or Arsenal look so lost when they cannot get the ball back and play so nervously when they have got it.

In Wednesday's Champions League game against Dynamo Kiev, Manchester United's performance fell away dramatically after half-time because the Ukrainians' passing began to dominate the play, which is a rare experience for United in the Premiership.

There is no reason why the overall quality of passing in the Premiership should not be better. The Scots may have pioneered the passing game but English teams of the past have set new standards in the use and delivery of the ball.

In the early 50s the push-and-run style which Arthur Rowe introduced at Tottenham brought the championship to White Hart Lane with distinction and in 1968 Manchester City, the last all-English side to win the title, passed the ball as sweetly as any team before or since.

No England team has matched the standards of passing set by Sir Alf Ramsey's side of 1969 and 1970 or the one Ron Greenwood built 10 years later. English footballers, caught young and properly coached, are capable of using the ball as well as anyone.

On Wednesday at Old Trafford, for example, Teddy Sheringham's pass out of defence to Andy Cole, which instigated the move from which Sheringham himself scored United's winning goal, was made under pressure and when he was off balance. Yet it was a ball worthy of Michel Platini.

The last time England played a game in Italy, the scoreless draw in Rome three years ago which ensured that Glenn Hoddle's side would go straight into the 1998 World Cup without a play-off, they achieved the result they wanted because the quality of their passing enabled them to retain possession and anaesthetise the match. It was not pretty but in the context of the game it was still pretty good.

One needed to remember this last Sunday after watching the bovine efforts of Everton and Aston Villa compared with which, Paul Merson's audacious winning goal apart, even the TV programme that has a group of stooges quizzed and derided by a red-headed Dalek in a trouser suit did not seem so much of a weak link in the week's viewing.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Sorting the eggheads from the prawn-eaters

fields.headline: Sorting the eggheads from the prawn-eaters
fields.trailText: Roy Keane's right. United fans need a spelling test to gain admission to Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Roy Keane's assertion after Wednesday night's Champions League game that many of those watching at Old Trafford don't know how to spell football, never mind understand it, must have been addressed to the three men sitting behind me.

Apparently over-dosing on the prawn butties which Keane blames for clouding judgment, in short order they managed to assert that David Beckham was "useless", Ryan Giggs "a joke" and Keane himself "shite". Indeed. And it never rains in Manchester, Westlife are worthy heirs to the Beatles and Virgin trains always run on time.

Following Keane's considered comments, it is clear that some sort of spelling test is required at our major grounds to ensure only the knowledgeable gain admittance. Spelling "catenaccio" correctly gets you into the stands, "cheque" opens doors to the executive boxes, while only those who can spell "gamblers" and "anonymous" are allowed access to the dressing room.

 My apologies to Alan Green for my chronology in an article last week about Sir Alex Ferguson's war of silence with Match of the Day. I wrote that an accommodation had been reached after the England-Germany match, only for Ferguson to be enraged by extracts about him taken from Green's book in a paper the next day, which stalled negotiations. In fact, the book was serialised well before that England game, so Green cannot be held responsible for the current dispute. Many apologies.

webTitle: Robson's gloom shows no sign of lifting at Old Trafford

fields.headline: Robson's gloom shows no sign of lifting at Old Trafford
fields.trailText:
Man Utd v Middlesbrough
The pessure's on for Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson. After four defeats out of four and talk of crisis gripping the Riverside, a trip to Old Trafford does not auger well for the future.
fields.body:
With four successive league defeats behind him and discontent mounting, Bryan Robson travels to Manchester United this afternoon conscious that the immediate future is likely to be grimmer still.

The Middlesbrough manager, who enjoyed 13 years as a Red Devil, spent last week geeing up his beleaguered players - no easy feat after the River Tees, swollen by the recent deluge, burst its banks and flooded their training complex. Robson must hope his side's defences are better equipped to repel the champions and Premiership leaders.

"You can't go to Old Trafford afraid of the game," he said yesterday. "They'll turn you over if you do. But if you go there to enjoy the challenge and try and frustrate United, you've got a chance. Everybody expects us to be beaten, but I don't write games off."

When Boro won 3-2 at Old Trafford on December 19 1998, it was the last time United were beaten in the Premiership at Old Trafford. Since that defeat, they have taken 90 points from a possible 102 at home.

"Hopefully we'll be the team to destroy that home record," said Robson. "You can catch them on a bad day, or have a bit of fortune. If that happens, they're not invincible."

As they wallow in the relegation zone, luck appears to have deserted Boro. Robson, backed by his chairman Steve Gibson, has lost the support of some of the more vocal fans and, for all the pluck shown in last week's defeat to Arsenal, Boro have not won at home since March.

"He's under pressure, but he's coping well," said Dean Gordon, the Boro defender whose left-foot volley past Peter Schmeichel helped secure that win at Old Trafford two years ago. "We're third from bottom and if you're in that position at Christmas it is difficult to pull out. It gets colder and you're sucked in - from there it's a struggle to escape.But he knows we can climb out of it, a couple of results are all we need."

In 1995-96 Boro suffered eight consecutive league defeats under Robson during a 13-match winless run and recovered to finish 12th, but the supporters are reluctant to put up with such mediocrity this term.

"It's becoming a crisis, it's at that level now," said Lance Vickers, a season-ticket holder who attended his first Boro match in 1931 and will be among the away support today. "Injuries may have stopped Bryan picking his strongest team, but he lacks a bit of tactical knowledge and £78m is a lot of money to take you to third bottom in the league."

With Brian Deane and Hamilton Ricard vying for striking roles, all three Boro scorers from that 1998 win may feature today, although Gordon will start on the bench.

The 27-year-old twice experienced relegation from the Premiership with Crystal Palace but he insisted "I haven't seen the same signs here."

"Every fan has written them off, but if the lads put up a committed, fair show we won't mind," added Vickers. "Over the years I've watched us sink into the Third Division and almost go bankrupt. At the start of the season I was hoping for a European place. Now keeping away from the relegation zone would satisfy me."

Criticism of Manchester United's supporters continued yesterday when Sir Alex Ferguson publicly backed Roy Keane. The captain's assertion that some United fans "could not even spell football, never mind understand it" has provoked a caustic reaction from many supporters.

But although United's manager opted for a more diplomatic choice of words, the message was just the same. "Roy's frustration is understandable," he said. "We know 90% of our supporters wholeheartedly want us to win but supporters, by nature, like to moan.

"The last thing we want is the supporters turning against the team. After everything they have achieved these players deserve much better than that."

Keane was angered by the fans' apathy during United's 1-0 Champions League defeat of Dynamo Kiev, a result that saw them qualify for the competition's second phase.

"Look at the difference between the supporters' reaction when we were losing 3-0 five minutes into the second half against Real Madrid last season and when we were beating Kiev 1-0 with 15 minutes to go on Wednesday," added Ferguson. "I know which position I would rather be in.

"Given the consistency we have shown over the last few years I think we warrant a bit of patience, especially in the Champions League. You cannot dominate matches in Europe for 90 minutes anyway and let's not forget Kiev made it very hard for us. They were certainly no mugs."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: On efforts to kick-start Derby's season, Fifa's Stalinist tendencies, poetry and players and a whole lot more you never thought possible.
fields.body:
 Don't let anyone tell you Derby are bereft of ideas. Surinder Grewal, for example, is brimming with them. More than anything, she is trying to persuade the club, with the help of a scoreboard message at Highbury today, to put out a version of Aqua's Barbie Girl. It's called (you guessed it) Derby Girl, and would ideally feature the former Coronation Street star Tracy Shaw on lead vocals and (it gets better) Darryl Powell's dad rapping. "There is," Surinder says, "obviously an aspect of pure stupidity and sheer brilliance about it." Which may be at least half right.

 If Jim Smith is less than keen, it may be because his side have already had one horrible clash with popular culture this year. You may remember Mart Poom broke his cheekbone while playing as a guest for Flora Tallinn against an Iron Maiden XI in the summer. Accounts smuggled out of Estonia now suggest Poom sustained the injury after coming up for a corner when Flora were 8-0 up, which didn't go down too well with the Old Maidonians (as they are known around Ilford). How did he get hurt? "Our goalkeeper is adamant he was going for the ball," our source maintains. "But then he is a solicitor's clerk."

 Even on the internet, there is a delightfully nostalgic whiff of Stalinism about Fifa's publications. Commenting on the game's rule-making body, former referee Michel Vautrot wrote this week: "The Board goes about its task like an Impressionist painter, making little touches here and there... webTitle: Viduka cash allows Knights another day in Sunshine

fields.headline: Viduka cash allows Knights another day in Sunshine
fields.standfirst: Melbourne Croats revel in Leeds striker's success, writes  Peter Hanlon
fields.trailText: After beginning his career with Melbourne Knights, there were doubts Mark Viduka could make the move up to big European leagues, but his home-town Croats are now relishing the Leeds striker's success, writes Peter Hanlon.
fields.body:
As the family, friends and fans of Mark Viduka sat down last Saturday to watch what would become his finest hour and a half, one venue was strangely quiet. Deep in west Melbourne's blue collar suburb of Sunshine, above a disused quarry on an industrial estate littered with the shells of burnt-out trucks and cars, the television was off and the Croatian Sports Club deserted. Five years ago, the Melbourne Knights had the best young striker in the country. Now, they don't even have Sky TV.

Down the road in Keilor, Joe and Rose Viduka had a dozen people over to celebrate Rose's birthday. The early kick-off at Elland Road was a bonus, and by 10.30pm they were camped in front of the box. What followed was a present beyond mum's wildest dreams: her son 4, Liverpool 3.

The party would have been a good deal bigger had the group of mates who call themselves the Croatian Golf Club not been enjoying a weekend on the Murray River. Of the 70 on board, almost everyone had known Viduka since he was a boy. Several glasses were raised for each of his goals; fittingly, the barman poured them off to bed at four.

Viduka's journey from Sunshine to gold dust began when he joined the Knights as a six-year-old. Three years later, he netted 13 goals in one match. A year was spent at the Australian Institute of Sport before he returned to Melbourne, aged 17, and scored a double on his senior debut.

In a flash he had twice led the national league in goalscoring, twice been named player of the year, won the Knights a championship, and had Real Madrid, Juventus and Sporting Lisbon beating a path to his door. Eventually, he succumbed to the urgings of the late Croatian president Franjo Tudjman and signed for Dynamo Zagreb. He was 19 when he left home for the home his parents had left as teenagers.

Three seasons running, with Viduka up front, they won the league and cup double. He grew up a lot too, living in a country ravaged by the Balkans war - hostilities in which he lost an uncle.

The awakenings continue. His arrival at Leeds, as in Glasgow before that, was greeted by doubts that he could reproduce previous feats in loftier surrounds. At Celtic there was the added burden of a protracted transfer dispute with Zagreb which so affected Viduka that, still to play a game in Scotland, he retreated to the comfort of his family.

One night back in Melbourne, with all and sundry questioning his commitment 12,000 miles away, Viduka wandered into the Celtic supporters club. He won them over; a season as leading goalscorer and players' player of the year silenced doubters at the coalface.

Already in the Premiership he has scored nine times from eight games. It would doubtless be more had he not in sisted that Australia's fateful Olympic campaign should take precedence over club duties. His former teammate and now Knights coach Vlado Vanis says: "If he has to give his life for his country, he will." It is perverse to think that checking such passion could be David O'Leary's greatest challenge.

As for the Knights, their focus is on survival. Manchester City's Danny Tiatto and Leeds reserve keeper Danny Milosevic have also passed through their gates, but Viduka has been the cash cow - in all the club has made about £700,000 out of his three transfers. According to the board member Tonci Prusac: "Without him, we wouldn't be around." All that can be afforded in return is to paint "Mark Viduka Stand" on the lone building that runs alongside the pitch.

When Viduka steps out against Chelsea tomorrow, Joe and Rose will be watching again. No matter that it will be 3am in Melbourne. As he left the pitch last Saturday, Viduka looked down the barrel of the Sky camera and beamed: "Hi mum!" Rose returned the greeting by phone the next morning, as she and Joe do every other day. Most often they call him, "because it's cheaper for us to ring from Australia". A mother never stops being a mother, even when her son is worth £10m.

fields.headline: Ridsdale reopens Hasselbaink wound
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink faces his former club for the first time tomorrow when Chelsea play Leeds at Stamford Bridge. And Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has chosen has marked the occasion with a timely broadside at the Dutchman.
fields.body:
Leeds United's chairman Peter Ridsdale has revealed the "outrageous" demands which precipitated Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink's acrimonious departure from Elland Road.

Hasselbaink faces his former club for the first time tomorrow when Chelsea play Leeds at Stamford Bridge. And Ridsdale added spice to the proceedings by making public the talks which preceded the striker's sale to Atletico Madrid 15 months ago.

Ridsdale claims an offer which would have made Hasselbaink the club's best-paid player and allowed him to leave for £10m at the end of last season with a 10% cut of the fee was turned down in less than three minutes.

"The first time I met his agent for talks I got the firm impression that Jimmy did not want to stay with us because his demands were so outrageous, and I don't mean just the financial ones either. The conditions he wanted were really quite amazing," Ridsdale says in a new book, Inside Leeds: The Story of the Millennium Season.

"One was that he always had to be the highest paid player at the club. Another was that any bid we may get for him of £6m or more we had to accept, even if he had signed his deal with us. He also wanted a personal bonus scheme, in addition to the team bonus, which was payable only to him. These were conditions that we just could not accept."

Hasselbaink has said he felt Leeds did not want him to stay, while his agent Humphrey Nijman insisted the Dutchman "never wanted to leave" and it was "never about money".

With 11 goals for Chelsea, Hasselbaink has picked up where he left off and was recalled by Holland this week.

Chelsea's manager Claudio Ranieri yesterday likened the 28-year-old's predatory instinct to a "shark", and Leeds' boss David O'Leary admitted he would "still love to have him".

fields.headline: Houllier wary of Greek test
fields.trailText: Liverpool face a tough test to progress in the Uefa Cup after drawing the Greek champions Olympiakos in the third round.
fields.body:
Liverpool face a tough test to progress in the Uefa Cup after drawing the Greek champions Olympiakos in the third round yesterday.

The Piraeus-based side, who dropped out of the Champions League after finishing behind Valencia and Lyon in group C, have a formidable home record: in 27 league and European home games since the start of last season they have lost only once, to Juventus.

Lyon, Valencia and Heerenveen have already been beaten in Greece this season and Liverpool will be glad the legs have been switched, meaning they play away first, because Panathinaikos are at home in the Champions League during the week of the second leg.

Having squeezed unconvincingly past Rapid Bucharest and Slovan Liberec, Gérard Houllier's side will need to improve. "This is a very hard draw," Houllier said. "They have already beaten Valencia and Lyon, and both those teams are quality opposition. They are a very skilful side."

Olympiakos' Brazilian forward Giovanni has been banned from training with the first team after throwing his shirt to the floor and yelling abuse at the coach Yiannis Matsurakis after being substituted this week in Lyon.

Rangers play Kaiserslautern, hoping to succeed where they failed against another German side, Borussia Dortmund, last season.

Third-round draw: Rangers v Kaiserslautern; Osijek v Slavia Prague; AEK Athens v Bayer Leverkusen; Club Bruges v Barcelona; Hertha Berlin v Internazionale; Nantes v Lausanne Sports; Alaves v Rosenborg; Feyenoord v VfB Stuttgart; Parma v 1860 Munich; Bordeaux v Werder Bremen; Shakhtar Donetsk v Celta Vigo; PSV Eindhoven v PAOK Salonika; Roma v Hamburg; Olympiakos v Liverpool ; Lokomotiv Moscow v Rayo Vallecano; Espanyol v Porto. First leg November 23, second leg December 7.

fields.headline: Back to Bach
fields.standfirst: David Ward marks the 250th anniversary of the composer's death by visiting the city in which he is buried
fields.trailText: David Ward marks the 250th anniversary of the composer's death by visiting the city in which he is buried.
fields.body:
As the ICE express slid effortlessly out of the station towards the flat lands of Saxony, the bass soloist began singing his big aria from Johann Sebastian Bach's cantata 96. "Safely by Thy pathway lead me, straight to Heaven's portal speed".

With no hills in the way, the path was straight; there was certainly plenty of speed; safety had to be taken on trust.

This was an autumn Saturday of bright sun in the year that has seen the 250th anniversary of Bach's death; the next day would be the 18th Sunday after Trinity, for which cantata 96 was written. And on that Sunday evening it would be performed in the Thomaskirche in Leipzig, the church where Bach now lies buried.

That every word of the cantata was audible on the CD player is a tribute to the soundproofing of German trains, in which doors glide open to reveal blue carpets, yards of fine wood and quietly contented passengers. This train was named after the painter Lucas Cranach and it paused for a while in his home town of Wittenburg.

Half-an-hour later, Lucas Cranach came to an unjuddering halt in Leipzig's hauptbahnhof, the largest terminus in Europe with 27 platforms, one for every year that Bach spent in the city.

The traffic-free city centre, famed for its trade fairs since 1497, is contained within the ring road on the line of the old city walls and a stroll from one side to other takes barely 15 minutes. Strolling is mandatory; Leipzigers do not rush, not least because there are so many diversions down the courtyards of the trading houses in which merchants sold their wares. Try Barthels Hof, with its lofty baroque bay windows. Stop for a coffee and gaze about. Then have a look at the only extant Bach portrait in the magnificent old city hall of 1556.

And you have to stop for another coffee at the Coffee Baum café and coffee museum, founded in 1619 and reopened after restoration only a couple of years ago. Downstairs, the floorboards are bare and the wooden tabletops are scrubbed white; the chairs lack luxury and match the hard benches; the walls are a sober cream. The waitresses are kitted out in amber peasant frocks, the coffee is excellent, the atmosphere tranquil. Robert Schumann used to come here with his friends and there is a plaque on the wall to prove it.

Music has always thrived in Leipzig: Wagner was born here and is commemorated on a plaque on the walls of a department store; Mendelssohn has a house on Goldschmidtstrasse; the orchestra of the Gewandhaus (a concert hall that looks like a designer version of a nuclear bunker) is the oldest of its kind in Europe.

There are literary associations, for Leipzig has always been bookish: in Auerbachs Keller, a restaurant in the Madler passage, murals carry 19th-century versions of scenes from Goethe's Faust and a huge barrel is a replica of the one on which Faust rode from the cellar in 1525. Drink too much of the white wine drawn from it by baggy-shirted waiters and you too will sell your soul to Mephistofeles.

But we are here for sober Bach. He has a statue outside the Thomaskirche (the guides say his pockets are turned out because, with 20 children to support, he was always broke) and there is a museum in his honour across the way. It is a little worthy, especially if your German does not extend much beyond einbahnstrasse. The best bit is the listening room, where CDs play snatches of the fourth Brandenburg concerto and the cantata Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott: the man is in the music, not the display cases.

The city's musical instrument museum is more entertaining. Press a button and listen to a tape of the nearby hammerflugel, the world's oldest surviving fortepiano; press other buttons to hear a musical clock, a polyphon (an early jukebox), a Schweizer walzenspieldose (a musical box with bells on). There is an abundance of crumhorns, viols and a glass harmonica (for which Mozart wrote one or two numbers).

Back to Bach: it's concert time at the Thomaskirche, de-Baroqued 110 years ago and returned to a neo-Gothic style the composer would never have known. Lofty and long, it remains a shrine where Bach's successors direct its famous boys' choir. But tonight the boys have the night off.

The Bach Cantata Pilgrimage, led by Sir John Eliot Gardiner and featuring his Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists, has arrived for the 48th concert in a peregrination around Europe (and eventually the US) in which all 198 surviving cantatas will be performed on their appointed days.

After 10 months on the road and at least one concert a week, they are used to setting up and tuning up; they take their own chamber organ almost everywhere they go. (Because plans for concerts in Latvia and Estonia have had to be abandoned, the pilgrims play in London tonight and tomorrow.)

Bass soloist Gotthold Schwarz sings the aria heard at 110mph the previous day; the evening also includes cantatas 116 and 169 and the church is sold out, every stern post-reformation pew packed; the best seats are, curiously, at right angles to the chancel.

Some pilgrimage groupies, veterans of several concerts, have made the trip; one row is full of musical tourists from Manchester; across the way is the director of the Bolton Chamber Choir, which is making its own shorter pilgrimage to Bach's city.

The next day Bolton's singers will perform in the Nikolaikirche. It's less austere than the Thomaskirche, proclaims itself "open to all" and has played its part in history. In the years leading to the autumn of 1989, Christians and non-Christians gathered every Monday to talk, debate and protest. The government of the old GDR responded with road blocks and arrests. On October 9 1989, it looked as if a violent showdown was coming when 600 party members entered the church.

The event is documented in the chilling museum dedicated to the follies of the Stasi, the hated secret police, and in a leaflet available in many languages at the Nikolaikirche, the pastor explains how the government stooges found themselves listening to the Sermon on the Mount on that revolutionary night. Protest leaders appealed for calm. "As we - more than 2,000 people - came out of the church, tens of thousands were waiting outside in the square," writes the pastor. "They all had candles in their hands. If you carry a candle, you need two hands - you have to prevent the candle from going out. You cannot hold a stone or a club in your hand."

The GDR collapsed and a member of the old regime said: "We had planned everything. We were prepared for everything. But not for candles and prayers."

Bach's cantata 96 ends with a prayerful chorale: "Awake us through Thy grace that we put on the new man, the old man's power efface."

Six of the best ... kellers and cafés

Auerbachs Keller: A subterranean experience not to be missed; bold soups and hearty entrées in a Faustian setting.

Café Concerto: Opposite the Thomaskirche. Plush red seats, etching of the Brandenburg concertos on the walls. Wide range of teas; sticky cakes.

Café Kandler: Close to the Thomaskirche. Even stickier cakes. At lunchtime, try a beer and a huhnchenpuffer - a potato cake loaded with mushrooms and cheese.

Café Riquet: An art nouveau riot dating from 1909. Chinese pagoda on top; tiled panels with peacocks and elegant Chinese ladies; two elephant heads above the entrance. Tea, coffee and more cakes.

Barthels Hof: Restaurant in the courtyard of the same name. Eat inside or out. Solidly bourgeois with occasional Wildfest with das grosses Wildbuffet .

Weinstock: Café-restaurant on the sunniest corner of the central market square overlooking the old city hall. Caesar salad with shrimps for a mere £6.

The practicals

Berlin-Leipzig on the ICE express, second class return, costs £43.40 from Deutsche Bahn (0870 2435363). Strolling is mandatory; Leipzigers do not rush, not least because there are so many diversions down the courtyards of the trading houses in which merchants sold their wares. Try Barthels Hof, with its lofty baroque bay windows. Stop for a coffee and gaze about. Then have a look at the only extant Bach portrait in the magnificent old city hall of 1556. And you have to stop for another coffee at the Coffee Baum café and coffee museum, founded in 1619 and reopened after restoration only a couple of years ago. Downstairs, the floorboards are bare and the wooden tabletops are scrubbed white; the chairs lack luxury and match the hard benches; the walls are a sober cream. The waitresses are kitted out in amber peasant frocks, the coffee is excellent, the atmosphere tranquil. Robert Schumann used to come here with his friends and there is a plaque on the wall to prove it. Music has always thrived in Leipzig: Wagner was born here and is commemorated on a plaque on the walls of a department store; Mendelssohn has a house on Goldschmidtstrasse; the orchestra of the Gewandhaus (a concert hall that looks like a designer version of a nuclear bunker) is the oldest of its kind in Europe. There are literary associations, for Leipzig has always been bookish: in Auerbachs Keller, a restaurant in the Madler passage, murals carry 19th-century versions of scenes from Goethe's Faust and a huge barrel is a replica of the one on which Faust rode from the cellar in 1525. Drink too much of the white wine drawn from it by baggy-shirted waiters and you too will sell your soul to Mephistofeles. But we are here for sober Bach. He has a statue outside the Thomaskirche (the guides say his pockets are turned out because, with 20 children to support, he was always broke) and there is a museum in his honour across the way. It is a little worthy, especially if your German does not extend much beyond einbahnstrasse. The best bit is the listening room, where CDs play snatches of the fourth Brandenburg concerto and the cantata Ein feste Burg ist unser Gott: the man is in the music, not the display cases. The city's musical instrument museum is more entertaining. Press a button and listen to a tape of the nearby hammerflugel, the world's oldest surviving fortepiano; press other buttons to hear a musical clock, a polyphon (an early jukebox), a Schweizer walzenspieldose (a musical box with bells on). There is an abundance of crumhorns, viols and a glass harmonica (for which Mozart wrote one or two numbers). Back to Bach: it's concert time at the Thomaskirche, de-Baroqued 110 years ago and returned to a neo-Gothic style the composer would never have known. Lofty and long, it remains a shrine where Bach's successors direct its famous boys' choir. But tonight the boys have the night off. The Bach Cantata Pilgrimage, led by Sir John Eliot Gardiner and featuring his Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists, has arrived for the 48th concert in a peregrination around Europe (and eventually the US) in which all 198 surviving cantatas will be performed on their appointed days. After 10 months on the road and at least one concert a week, they are used to setting up and tuning up; they take their own chamber organ almost everywhere they go. (Because plans for concerts in Latvia and Estonia have had to be abandoned, the pilgrims play in London tonight and tomorrow.) Bass soloist Gotthold Schwarz sings the aria heard at 110mph the previous day; the evening also includes cantatas 116 and 169 and the church is sold out, every stern post-reformation pew packed; the best seats are, curiously, at right angles to the chancel. Some pilgrimage groupies, veterans of several concerts, have made the trip; one row is full of musical tourists from Manchester; across the way is the director of the Bolton Chamber Choir, which is making its own shorter pilgrimage to Bach's city. The next day Bolton's singers will perform in the Nikolaikirche. It's less austere than the Thomaskirche, proclaims itself "open to all" and has played its part in history. In the years leading to the autumn of 1989, Christians and non-Christians gathered every Monday to talk, debate and protest. The government of the old GDR responded with road blocks and arrests. On October 9 1989, it looked as if a violent showdown was coming when 600 party members entered the church. The event is documented in the chilling museum dedicated to the follies of the Stasi, the hated secret police, and in a leaflet available in many languages at the Nikolaikirche, the pastor explains how the government stooges found themselves listening to the Sermon on the Mount on that revolutionary night. Protest leaders appealed for calm. "As we - more than 2,000 people - came out of the church, tens of thousands were waiting outside in the square," writes the pastor. "They all had candles in their hands. If you carry a candle, you need two hands - you have to prevent the candle from going out. You cannot hold a stone or a club in your hand." The GDR collapsed and a member of the old regime said: "We had planned everything. We were prepared for everything. But not for candles and prayers." Bach's cantata 96 ends with a prayerful chorale: "Awake us through Thy grace that we put on the new man, the old man's power efface." Six of the best ... kellers and cafés Auerbachs Keller: A subterranean experience not to be missed; bold soups and hearty entrées in a Faustian setting. Café Concerto: Opposite the Thomaskirche. Plush red seats, etching of the Brandenburg concertos on the walls. Wide range of teas; sticky cakes. Café Kandler: Close to the Thomaskirche. Even stickier cakes. At lunchtime, try a beer and a huhnchenpuffer - a potato cake loaded with mushrooms and cheese. Café Riquet: An art nouveau riot dating from 1909. Chinese pagoda on top; tiled panels with peacocks and elegant Chinese ladies; two elephant heads above the entrance. Tea, coffee and more cakes. Barthels Hof: Restaurant in the courtyard of the same name. Eat inside or out. Solidly bourgeois with occasional Wildfest with das grosses Wildbuffet . Weinstock: Café-restaurant on the sunniest corner of the central market square overlooking the old city hall. Caesar salad with shrimps for a mere £6. The practicals Virgin Express (020-7744 0004, www.virgin-express.com) flies from London to Berlin for £103 return. Berlin-Leipzig on the ICE express, second class return, costs £43.40 from Deutsche Bahn (0870 2435363). A night at Hotel Fürstenhof, Tröndlinring 8 (0049 3411400) costs DM270 single (£83), DM320 double. webTitle: Who lost their heart in Victoria Falls?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Victoria Falls
fields.standfirst: Gaby Roslin
fields.trailText: Gaby Roslin
fields.body:
Why: It is one of the truly magical places in the world and somewhere I have been to many, many times. My father was born in Zimbabwe, and we used to go every Easter to see my grandparents and cousins. As a child, I remember that feeling of liberation when I took my shoes off and ran around barefoot. Also seeing the animals just wandering through the bush. They say that everyone who goes to Africa leaves a part of themselves there; it's true. It is the place where my husband proposed to me, where my cousin got married, so it is somewhere I hope to take my children.

Victoria Falls itself is extraordinary. You get the feeling that you are in the heart of Africa and realise how amazing it is that nature could create something like this. Standing by the edge of the Falls, letting the spray soak you is wonderfully cleansing and almost spiritual. It is also the one place where, if you catch the sun at the right time, you can actually stand at the end of a rainbow. Although I've been to Zimbabwe so many times, I'm not blasé about it. I always try to persuade people to visit the Falls and whenever I hear that someone is going I get terribly excited and tell them where they should go and what they should see.

The area around Victoria Falls is incredibly natural, not built up or a tacky tourist resort. It's about a 10-minute walk down from the Victoria Falls Hotel - which is where everyone stayed before the war - down through bush until you get to a railway track, where kids gather and try to sell you water. Then, over the railway track, is the entrance with a display telling you the history of the discovery of the Falls. To the left is a statue of Livingstone and to the right the path down to the edge of the Falls. It is quite rickety, and you see monkeys and the tracks left by snakes.

The path leads to the Devil's Cataract and you just look down and gasp. It is awe-inspiring rather than scary. The noise of the water, the smell and the taste are indescribable. You can't capture the Victoria Falls in a photograph or on film properly, so you just have to stand there and let it imprint itself on your memory.

What's the best thing? Just standing on the path, and literally, letting the Falls soak in, taking deep breaths and tasting the freshness of the water.

My advice: Obviously there are problems in Zimbabwe at present, but hopefully things will quieten down. When they do, you should fly to Harare, spend a day recovering from the flight then go out into the bush on a safari. Visit Kariba and stay in a lodge made of floating rafts, and just watch the elephants and hippos. Then fly up to Victoria Falls and stay in the Victoria Falls Hotel. It is pretty expensive, but worth it for the views. The minute you arrive, go out on to the veranda at the back, order a drink and just sit and watch the spray. Then get changed and go straight down to the Falls.

How do I get there? Trailfinders (020-7938 3939) offers return flights from Heathrow to Victoria Falls via Johannesburg with Virgin and seven nights' B&B accommodation at the Victoria Falls Hotel for £1,445. A wide range of excursions are available, including a helicopter flight over the Falls for £56 and an elephant safari for £94.

 Gaby Roslin presents BBC Children In Need with Terry Wogan this Friday on BBC1.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Turned on
fields.body:
Turned on

Once Billie Piper has switched on the Christmas lights in London's Regent Street at 6pm on Tuesday, followed by Jerry Hall in Bond Street at 7pm on Wednesday, you'll know that the silly season has begun.

Free. London W1.

Northern star

Billed as the entertainment centre of the future, The Printworks opens in the centre of Manchester today - a heady mixture of bars, cafés, restaurants, shops, a health complex and the largest Imax cinema in the country.

Open 24 hrs. Admission free except Imax. Exchange Square, Manchester (www.theprintworks.com).

Master class

Barbara Hepworth, Paul Nash, Stanley Spencer, LS Lowry and Lucian Freud star in the Rugby Collection of 20th-century British art.

Open daily except Monday. Tues and Thurs10am-8pm, Weds and Fri till 5pm, Sat 4pm, Sun 1pm-5pm. Free. Rugby Art Gallery & Museum, Little Elborow St, Rugby, Warwickshire (01788 533203).

Work in progress

At the new Brilliant exhibition, visitors can play Big Brother as they click on theculture company.co.uk and watch seven artists in action in a wide range of styles.

Open Mon-Sat 9.30am-5.30pm. Exhibition begins Nov 16. Free. Impressions Gallery, 29 Castlegate, York (01904 654724).

Show business

The Lord Mayor's Show begins at 11am with a procession from Gresham Street to Princes Street, continues with bands, a military parade and a fair in Paternoster Square and culminates in a firework display on the Thames at 5pm.

Free. Info: www.lord-mayors-show-org.uk. Tubes: Bank, St Paul's, Moorgate or Barbican.

Venus rising

Romp around the vaulted chambers, battlements, staterooms, indoor Riding House and garden statuary at17th-century Bolsover Castle. Its recently-restored Venus Fountain is the high point.

Open Weds-Sun 10am-4pm. £4.20/ £2.10. Bolsover, nr Chesterfield, Derbys, tel: 01246 822844, www. bolsover.gov.uk/bolsover_castle).

Cycle line

Thames Water has provided the missing link in the East London section of the National Cycle Network. The Crossness Pathway skirts the river beside the Crossness water-treatment plant, and you can now ride off-road from the Woolwich Ferry right through to Erith.

Copies of the London Thames Cycle Route Map are available for £5.99 plus £2 p&p from 0117 9290888 (www. sustrans.org.uk).

fields.headline: Travelling to North Korea
fields.standfirst:
I want to travel to North Korea. Is it possible? How easy is it to obtain a visa? Will I have to travel with an organised group? How expensive is it?
Roy Lane
fields.trailText: I want to travel to North Korea. Is it possible? How easy is it to obtain a visa? Will I have to travel with an organised group? How expensive is it?
fields.body:
 My partner James and I went to North Korea two years ago, and it was one of the most fascinating experiences we have ever had.

Fortunately, a good friend of ours lives in Beijing and organises trips to North Korea from there. His name is Nick Bonner (e-mail: northkorea8@hotmail.com, website: www.koryogroup.com). He is a brilliant person to travel with - he has loads of enthusiasm and experience - and we would recommend highly the tour he runs.

You cannot enter the country unless you are in an organised group and you do have to have a visa, but Nick organises all that as part of the package.

If you are thinking of going, do it soon, as it would seem that big changes are afoot, and it really is a one-off place in so many staggering ways.
Carolyn Shrosbree

 Koryo Tours' eight-day, six-night tour of North Korea costs $1,490pp including transport from Beijing to Pyongyang and in North Korea, all accommodation and meals, but excluding flights from UK to Beijing.

webTitle: Bradley, S Club 7: Stereo | Video camera | Diamond cross

fields.headline: Bradley, S Club 7, never travels without...
fields.standfirst: Stereo | Video camera | Diamond cross
fields.trailText: Stereo | Video camera | Diamond cross
fields.body:
A necessity: My stereo so that I can catch up with new things when we're on tour; my mobile phone so that I can keep in contact with my mates; and my GameBoy. I need lots of distractions.

A luxury: I bring my video camera and film the rest of the band and the places we go. It's a great way of keeping a record of what we've done and fun to watch when we get back home.

A good-luck charm: I have a platinum and diamond cross which I bought last year. I'm quite a spiritual person and I like knowing I have it with me.

If only: A teleporter so that I could travel back to my mates after gigs. It's them and doing things with them that I miss most when we are away.

 Never Had a Dream Come True, the Children in Need official single by S Club 7, will be performed by the group this Friday.

Sarah Gardner is planning a holiday in the interior of Jamaica. We will be staying in very basic accommodation and ticks are a big problem. Does anyone know of an effective tick repellant that can be used on my child who is one year old?

webTitle: Race for lottery reaches final stage

fields.headline: Race for lottery reaches final stage
fields.trailText: Camelot and Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery entered what should be the final stages of bidding for the next licence to run the National Lottery.
fields.body:
Camelot and Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery yesterday entered what should be the final stages of bidding for the next licence to run the National Lottery.

Both companies were judged to have answered the National Lottery Commission's outstanding concerns and the bids now face weeks of scrutiny based on their ability to raise money for good causes.

The commission will hope to have drawn a line under the controversy which has surrounded the bidding process. A decision on which company wins the licence is expected by mid-December.

A spokeswoman for Camelot said the announcement justified the company's battle to get back into the process after being excluded by the previous commissioner. "It vindicates our decision to go to the High Court to challenge why we were not originally given the same opportunity as the People's Lottery," she said.

The former commissioner Dame Helena Shovelton announced in August that uncertainties surrounding both bids meant neither company could be awarded the licence.

Dame Helena precipitated her own downfall however by excluding Camelot from further talks to proceed exclusively with Sir Richard. The decision was later overturned by the High Court.

In the case of the People's Lottery, extra assurances on the financial security of the company were sought. The anxiety over Camelot, which has run the game for six years, centred on the propriety of its chief software supplier G-Tech which had attempted to cover up problems which left some winners short-changed. Camelot has convinced current commissioner Lord Burns of its fitness by buying the UK operation of G-Tech.

A statement from the Commission said that over the next month the two bids would be assessed "without any conclusions reached before the announcement of August 23".

Dame Helena precipitated her own downfall however by excluding Camelot from further talks to proceed exclusively with Sir Richard. The decision was later overturned by the High Court. In the case of the People's Lottery, extra assurances on the financial security of the company were sought. The anxiety over Camelot, which has run the game for six years, centred on the propriety of its chief software supplier G-Tech which had attempted to cover up problems which left some winners short-changed. Camelot has convinced current commissioner Lord Burns of its fitness by buying the UK operation of G-Tech. A statement from the Commission said that over the next month the two bids would be assessed "without any conclusions reached before the announcement of August 23".

fields.headline: Suunto Metron high tech watch
fields.trailText: It has a tough lightweight-aluminium casing with a leather strap, a scratchproof glass face, and more features than the cockpit of a jumbo.
fields.body:
I'm looking for the ultimate urban wristwatch, cutting edge and classy. You're in luck. Suunto has just brought out the Ferrari of the gadget watch. It has a tough lightweight-aluminium casing with a leather strap, a scratchproof glass face, and more features than the cockpit of a jumbo.

So what does it do? You can take a bath - up to 30m deep - watch it tick at -20C or +60C or test its heart monitor, barometer, altimeter, thermometer, electronic compass and enormous memory. It's easy to see in the dark and the battery lasts 18 months. And you can programme it to metric or imperial units.

Can I find out if it's ever going to stop raining? The barometer and thermometer will predict the weather changes and has such a wide range that even a hurricane won't stop it working.

The Suunto Metron, which will be available from the end of November, retails for £219.95 or £249.95 with sensor/ transmitter belt. The Vector altimeter, barometer, compass watch costs £139.95. For stockists tel Viking Optical 01986 875315
