fields.headline: My top 10
fields.standfirst: Professor Fred Inglis has written the definitive history of the holiday from the grand tour to the package. So where does the expert like to go?
fields.trailText: Professor Fred Inglis has written the definitive history of the holiday from the grand tour to the package. So where does the expert like to go?
fields.body:
The clocks have gone back. It is dark before five. Global warming turns out to mean heavy grey clouds, tumultuous rain, driving winds. It is time to dream about the summer holiday.

We ask so much of them, and so much that is contradictory. They are our very own, they are our "free" time (so that's why we spend a fortune on them). They must not include work, or rather, not the kind of work we do every day. The places we go to may be strange, exotic, foreign; they may be beloved, familiar, familial; best of all, they may be both. They must be as beautiful as possible, and they must offer the chance of luxury and licentiousness.

The holiday must be safe and it must be (a bit) dangerous: a risky sailing expedition, a scramble up the mountain. It must restore us to mother nature and the natural life clad in the birthday suit. The holiday must be good for body and soul: 20 lengths followed by a visit to the art gallery. It must provide sociability and friendship with perfect strangers. It must provide solitude, space, dream-time.

It must be fondly memorable. It must give rise to family recollection and communal jokes ("Do you remember when . . . ?"). It must keep our folk tales tender and touch our hearts, if possible, with what is best in us . . .

1 Northumberland, England

My first best place is a Last Homely House, planted solidly on a shelf of dolorite on the splendid Northumbrian coast just south of Bamburgh. A little ell of 18th-century stone cottages fronts the Farne islands a mile offshore, the great sweep of sand curving in front of its windows, the kindly eye of the Farne lighthouse keeping the night watches safe and sound above the unplumb'd, salt, estranging sea. My daughters, forever in miniature, patrol the rocks for sea-urchins, two RAF Hawker Hunters tear between the gulls.

Brockburn, Monkshouse, Northumberland: Pat Thompson 01661 860165

2 Apennines, Italy

Behind Cortona, a hamlet of agriturismo cottages hangs on the hill edge overlooking the vast, husbanded plain of the Val de Chiana. The flat land, the olive groves, the lake are all exactly "as they appear" in the corners of the sacred scenes painted by the local Renaissance master, Luca Signorelli, whose radiant pictures hang in the tiny town gallery, to be called on after coffee in the bustling piazza, or before fat Tuscan sausages and porcini-with-truffles for five quid down a blind alley at Il Grotto.

Up at the houses, the stout padrone Mario bawls genially to all Anglophones in GCSE French, and the unyielding Tuscan sun beats on the blue of the swimming pool and its imperturbable wasps.

Frances Mayes's little place is a step away, her postcard prose by now a part of one's sensibility . . .

Borgo Elena near Cortona: Simply Tuscany, 598-608 Chiswick High St W4 5RT, tel: 020-8995 8277.

3 Pennsylvania, US

When unrespectable Philadelphia wanted to go out on the tiles and gamble and drink and gaze down Jersey Lily's corsage, it built a railroad to the coast and put Atlantic City there. When genteel Philadelphians sought an alcohol-dry resort beside the wet sea they went a little further down the seaboard to the very tip of their state, and erected a wooden fantasy town every bit as fairytale as Hollywood was to build a couple of decades later.

Cape May is a kind of living Trumpton, its two-mile promenade lined with pastel-painted, lavishly bargeboarded, stoup-adorned clapboard hotels in cobalt, vermilion, ochre and emerald.

Punctuating this sedulous and bewitching anachronism are the reassuringly elderly bits and pieces of 1940s seafront - clock golf, pinball arcades, picture palaces, low bars, gift shops, Redcar transported whole to New Jersey. At the top end of the three-street-deep little watering place there is an ample, amiable, wholly democratic marina with massive boardwalks and trays of fat, cringing oysters at seven bucks the dozen.

Kelly's Celtic Inn, 24 Ocean, Cape May, New Jersey 08204, tel: 001 609 898 1999.

4 Paris, France

Stand at the door of the dignified Hotel Delavigne in the sixth arrondissement , the quarter where once upon a time the international language was Latin. Up the road and to the left is the Polydor restaurant where you share a red and white gingham tablecloth with strangers come, like you, to breathe the savoury air sniffed by Verlaine and Valéry. Round the corner is the Rue de L'Odéon where Sylvia Beach first opened Shakespeare and Company and loaned out her stout Tauschnitz volumes to Joyce and Hemingway. Straight down the road is the Boulevard St Germain, then across to the knotted little streets around the unbelievable plenitude of the Rue Buci market with its shapely, towering banks of strawberries and tomatoes.

Turn right in Rue Buci and thread your way through to the river, gazing across from the left bank, home of scholarship, the intelligentsia, criticism, the very Left itself, at the settled emblems of power and state, Bourse, Louvre, Hotel de Ville.

Stroll down to a rendezvous on the Pont Neuf and step into the Henri IV, jammed, cramped, delightfully worn, and blow a mere fiver on a plate of cheeses, a plate of hams, and - for another, trifling £2.50 a glass of calm, commanding Loire red wine.

Hotel Delavigne, rue Casimir-Delavigne, 6ieme Paris, tel: 0033 1432 93150

5 Venice, Italy

Venice, of course, has no business being placed fifth in such a list. Venice is simply the biggest success story we can find to prove the immortality of great cities, rescued from war, pollution, erosion, bankruptcy and drowning.

This, however, is the greatest city-treasure, a city that proves Ruskin's pathetic fallacy to be no fallacy at all, for it has a character of complete and varied integrity, features of unequalled beauty . . . the hell with it. Only Henry James got near the heart of the place in words, but try, instead, the painters: Turner, Monet, Sargeant, Ruskin himself, Whistler, Piper (father and son). Buy, for £50, one of the pretty little oil paintings it is still easy to find at Mazzuchi's by local artists still holding, in their modest way, to the line of that mighty and unkillable tradition.

Just a couple of minutes' walk from San Marco, up a very narrow calle is the Hotel San Zulian. They have an exquisite attic room (en-suite, naturally) with a balcony overlooking the roofs of Venice, overlooked by the campanile. Stay right there.

Hotel San Zulian, San Marco 35, Venice 30124, tel: 0039 0415 225 872.

6 Bali, Indonesia

In the kindly old New Yorker cartoon, the man rushes breathlessly into the travel agency, bursting out with "Is Bali . . . still Bali?"

I went to Bali transfixed, like so many others, by the tales about it of that great anthropologist Clifford Geertz. I went to gaze at its "high gorgeousness", to discover the mysterious workings of the irrigation co-operative, to hear, if possible, its "ground-bass of passionless horror", to see "the cataracts of long black hair" on its unforgettable young women.

I missed the horror but not by much: civil war is punctual there. I saw the waterworks, and the girls as well, and I stayed in a rush-and-bamboo cabin on the beach, while the ocean splashed softly outside and Dallas played, in Balinese, at the beach bar.

Lauda Air flies London to Bali, via Vienna from £568 return. Book through Bridge the World, tel: 0870 4447474.

7 Sefrou, Morocco

Sefrou is hardly a holiday spot, though plenty of people go to Casablanca or Marrakesh. It's a gritty, windy little town crouched under the Atlas mountains some 15 miles from Fez. As you drive towards it over satisfyingly dusty and potholed roads, the low, orderly line of its walls and towers and rectilinear houses stands clear, first on the skyline and then close in front of you, as though cast in calcium light.

You are going to the souk. But don't go in scruffy four-by-four gear. Wear a shirt and trousers. Drink the tiny cups of fierce coffee and watch the hectic order of the day's exchanges, much of it barter, all of it bargained, and a great deal still conducted outside the heavily-bureaucratised, indisputable formalities we assume to be the one right way to price and pay.

This is a lesson in difference, even in danger. Receive it carefully. Smile respectfully. And go back to the dusty Franco-Moroccan hotel with a bathroom down the corridor and giant's footsteps to stand on in the loo. Then downstairs from a shady, bare, yellow bedroom for chicken with dusty dates and honey all wrapped in filo.

Hotel Sidi Lakcen El Youssi, Sefrou (00212 55683428). For tailor-made trips to Morocco try CLM Morocco Made to Measure (020-7235 0123).

8 Melbourne, Australia

Melbourne is the reallest city. Everybody loves Sydney just now, and well they might. But Melbourne is high, wide and handsome. It is exhilaratingly egalitarian, vividly polyglot.

Inside the lovely light-coloured sandstone opera house, the great Nolan has painted a whole wallful of watercolours of the myriad desert flowers that bloom for a few hours in the bush when the rare rains fall. The builders of the opera house each got opera tickets for life, for Melbourne is a place where chippies go to Cosi.

It is also a city where Victorian architecture and Modernism stand in mutual respect; where river and towpath are bright with the colours of a population always on the edge of a holiday even when at work; where the big parks look English at first sight until you see the grey, ghostly trunks of the gum trees. Down the broad boulevards clatter the sturdy old trams, holding together the immense flat geography of the place.

Flights to Melbourne start at £560.10 including all taxes, flying with Gulf Air. Accommodation starts at around £30pp per night. For reservations, call Travelbag on 0870 7377781 (www.travelbag.co.uk)

9 Friesland, Netherlands

Pacing beside the holidaymakers are the books and pictures that took them there in the first place. Up at the further tip of the Netherlands, just before you turn the corner into the Kiel Canal is Friesland where that haunting novel The Riddle of the Sands begins.

It is a mighty landscape of parallels and monochrome. Long, flat, grey and restless seas, long grey sandbanks and the huge grey, shadowless sky. The Friesian cows are startlingly colourful in their black and white, the little grey inns with amiably remote grey-faced and grey-clad publicans startlingly cheap. You walk the immense sandbanks carefully, keeping an eye on the tide, looking out at the dark bulk of a few fishing boats, hearing only the grey-white gulls and the one-toned shallow sea, and it will all stalk your imagination long after the ghastly mandolins of Corfu have died away.

North Netherlands Board of Tourism, tel: 0031 512585079

10 Markwick's, Bristol

The end of every good holiday is a vast meal. A great meal out simply is, for that evening, a three-hour holiday. My perfect evening holiday is spent at Markwick's restaurant in Bristol's narrow Corn Street, where the Exchange building was inspired by Sansovino's library in Venice. Down marble steps reposes that perfect combination of the familiar (heavy wooden counters, low dim room, cordial welcome, classic cuisine) and the foreign (shy, authoritative patron, rare dishes, unexpected juxtapositions of taste and colour) which is the matrix of the holiday.

Markwick's Restaurant, 43 Corn St, Bristol BS1 1HT, tel: 0117 926 2658.

Happiness and fulfilment unfold in one's heart as a match between one's desires and the experience in front of you. It can happen in an evening, a weekend, a fortnight. Even a life.

The Delicious History of the Holiday, by Professor Fred Inglis, is published by Routledge at £16.99.

fields.headline: Travel tips
fields.trailText: Always carry a bottle of water, toothbrush and toothpaste in your hand luggage or day-sack.
fields.body:
Always carry a bottle of water, toothbrush and toothpaste in your hand luggage or day-sack. The journey from hell can be made that little bit more bearable if you can clean your teeth occasionally.

Georgina High

When visiting an Islamic country, carry a copy of the Koran or some other Islamic literature. Brilliant for winning the respect of suspicious officials.

Lee Christie

Xavier Chevillard and Anthony Woodrow have written to say that the November 4 Travel Tip is wrong and that Visa will still charge interest and commission on all cash withdrawn abroad.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Europe
fields.body:
Europe

UK : A day's golf on a championship course with lunch for £17.50. Old Thorns Hotel, Golf and Country Club (01428 724555, www.oldthorns.co.uk) near Liphook in Hampshire is running a Golf for Less programme every weekday until March 31. Four golfers can play a four-ball round and have a snack lunch in the clubhouse for £70. Free pick up from Liphook station, under an hour from Waterloo.

Italy : Consort Travel (01709 701701) is offering a 10-day coach tour to Lake Garda. Choice of dates between April 6 and October 19. Modern air-conditioned coaches and guaranteed no overnight continental travel. Stay B&B in a French hotel on the journey out and back and half-board three-star hotel accommodation at Lake Garda. Excursions to Venice and Verona. Departures from more than 200 pick-up points in England and Wales. Pick-ups in Scotland £10 extra.

Turkey : Spend Anzac Day at Gallipoli on a seven-night guided tour with battlefield specialist Midas Tours (01932 407000, www.midastours.co .uk). Departing April 22, the tour costs £1,144 including flights and half-board accommodation in Istanbul and Troy.

Venice : Lakes and Mountains Holidays (01329 844405, www.lakes-mountains.co.uk) offers a three-night city break during carnival time with tickets to the Casanova Masked Ball and a guided walking tour of the city. Departing February 16, the holiday costs £699pp including return scheduled flights from Gatwick, four-star B&B accommodation and dinner at the ball.

GIbraltar : Activity Holidays (01932 867418, www.activity- holidays.co.uk) is offering year-round live-aboard sailing courses from beginner to expert. Six-day courses cost from £590 including return flights and can be extended with shore-based accommodation and bareboat charter.

Asia

Nepal : Trek in the Himalayas with Sherpa (020-8577 2717, www.sherpa-walking-holidays). January to April departures cost £1,320pp including return flights from Heathrow to Kathmandu, transfers, 14 nights' accommodation (hotels with breakfast in Kathmandu, the remainder half-board lodging in tea houses) and the services of a support team and guide.

Malaysia : Book by February 28 and get a free accommodation upgrade at the Tanjong Jara resort on the east coast of Malaysia. For departures in April, May or June, a five-night holiday costs £826 including scheduled Malaysia Airlines flights from Heathrow, private transfers and room-only accommodation. Magic of the Orient (01293 537700, www.magicoftheorient.com).

fields.headline: News
fields.standfirst: Leg room dashed by tax reform
fields.trailText: Package holidaymakers look certain to be denied the option of paying for extra legroom on some flights because of a ruling by Customs & Excise.
fields.body:
Package holidaymakers look certain to be denied the option of paying for extra legroom on some flights because of a ruling by Customs & Excise.

From April 1 they will be charged twice the normal air passenger duty (APD) - or £40 on flights outside the European Economic Area - which comprises the European Union countries plus Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. That is the same charge faced by those flying in business class, many of whom have their tickets paid for by their company.

Tour firms fear this will be enough to deter many customers. As a result, First Choice says it may have to abandon its recently-announced premium-class on medium-haul trips, such as flights to Cyprus and Turkey, while Thomson, which had been working on a plan to offer something similar, has also been forced to think again.

With unfortunate timing, First Choice was told its appeal against the decision had been rejected only four days after news emerged that a 28-year-old woman had died of deep vein thrombosis, apparently triggered by sitting for long hours on a flight home from Australia.

This labyrinthine tale begins with a decision by the European Commission that the British Government could no longer charge lower duty on domestic flights than on those to and from other EU countries. APD, it ruled, was a tax on departures from UK airports, so if Britain was levying £10 on a London-Brussels fare, it should be charging UK domestic passengers £10 each way.

But £20 on a domestic fare would have looked a disproportionate amount of tax, particularly to passengers buying cheap tickets on low-cost airlines such as easyJet. So the Government decided to lower the duty on international flights within the EU instead. That meant economy class passengers and those in the usual, more cramped charter seats, would pay £5 less. To balance the books, however, it announced premium-class passengers would pay double.

The charter problem arises because of the wording of the regulation. Customs & Excise has defined "premium" as anything other than the lowest class on any aircraft. A Customs & Excise spokeswoman said: "The criteria had to be drawn somewhere. We spoke to the charter airlines and they told us the maximum proportion of passengers paying premium fares is only 5%. Also, for those passengers who pay extra for a seat with more space near an emergency exit, the lower rate of duty still applies."

fields.headline: Hapless Hackney faces £40m meltdown
fields.standfirst: Rubbish piles up, hundreds face rent arrears misery as officials from other areas try to help sort out years of infighting and incompetence
fields.trailText: Rubbish piled high in black bags and boxes outside houses and shops awaits the elusive council dust cart. The grubby streets, swirling with the remains of bursting refuse sacks and last week's takeaways, are rarely swept. "It's easier to spot the rats than find the binman," jokes an elderly woman, laden with shopping bags, as she stumbles between the high rises.
fields.body:
Rubbish piled high in black bags and boxes outside houses and shops awaits the elusive council dust cart. The grubby streets, swirling with the remains of bursting refuse sacks and last week's takeaways, are rarely swept. "It's easier to spot the rats than find the binman," jokes an elderly woman, laden with shopping bags, as she stumbles between the high rises.

Around the tower blocks, in an area dominated by council housing, the walkways are crumbling and the window frames rotting. "In 20 years we haven't had a lick of paint," yells Rose Richardson, a 78-year-old who chairs a community association on the Trelawney estate. "They make promises, but they always put it back. They treat us terribly badly."

Pensioner Ted Edwards says he told the council last week that a window frame in his 11th floor flat was falling out. "They told me they'd be round to fix it, then called back and said all work was being suspended because they'd stopped all spending - something about running out of money."

This is something of an understatement. The borough, torn apart by poisonous political infighting for much of the past 18 years, official incompetence, a string of highly damaging reports from government inspectorates, allegations of corruption and racism, and mass resignations, appears to be heading in a direction which even eluded Militant-led Liverpool in the mid-80s. It is facing a £40m deficit by the end of March.

Welcome to Hackney. Statistically the fourth most deprived borough in England, with unemployment running at 14% - over twice the London average - its 5,000 east end acres retain a cultural richness from 40 languages in a series of communities which belies the underlying poverty of many citizens and the financial chaos in the town hall.

The relative harmony between Hasidic Jew, muslim from Turkey and Kurdistan, Cypriot, African-Caribbean, and the white working class - not to mention up to 15,000 asylum seekers - has rarely been replicated in the council chamber. Yet with some services collapsing, such as council tax and rent collection, and thousands of the poorest tenants facing eviction through a failure to pay housing benefit, Labour and Tory councillors finally sank their differences seven months ago to form an unprecedented coalition.

But even this was not enough to save Hackney from further ignominy this week when the council faced up to years of mismanagement after a savage report from the audit commission's new local government inspectorate. Outlining the potential deficit of £40m, with severe financial problems not yet under control, it said the authority could not meet its statutory commitments such as education and social services without big spending cuts. "These problems are so serious that they threaten the council's ability to function satisfactorily," it warned.

Exactly how Hackney got into such a mess is open to question. Years of political turmoil, which began with a hard left takeover in 1982, took their toll, compounded by a split in the Labour group, a brief Lib Dem administration, and a decision to devolve budgets to individual departments without proper central control. But matters finally came to a head with the preparation of this year's budget which, in the words of the local government inspectorate, contained "two especially grave risks".

Council officials assumed they could collect 96% of council tax, when their previous best performance was only 75%. They also budgeted for substantial cost cutting in street cleaning and refuse collection when they had no plan to deliver the economies. Result? Financial meltdown, with that most visible, third world symbol of a municipality in crisis: piles of uncollected rubbish on the streets.

The crisis only slowly came to light when another town hall spending watchdog, the district auditor, warned the council's new managing director, Max Caller, of his grave concern in a letter on October 10. Seven days later, the authority responded with an order to staff freezing all spending. It even told senior officers to hand over 300 mobile phones to save £120,000. This week the Labour-Tory administration shaved over £22m from the budget this year and next to meet some of the deficit. Up to 500 jobs could go from the 9,000 workforce - 250 fairly quickly - while an outside contractor will take over the collapsing street cleaning and refuse collection service next month.

Mr Caller, who joined the council four months ago on £150,000 a year after a long period as chief executive of Barnet, north London, believes the deficit will be much less than £40m. Hackney's salvation rests on the government permitting the borrowing of extra cash to keep it afloat while other efficiency measures are introduced. Other authorities have also launched an unprecedented rescue operation, led by the chief executive of Nottingham, with key officials seconded from other town halls.

Outwardly Mr Caller exudes calm. "There will be no subsidy from the government," he insists. "Hackney has to put its own house in order and pay its way in the world." Unfortunately, many of its poorest citizens are unable to pay their way thanks to incompetence before Mr Caller arrived. At present 17,000 housing benefit claims are awaiting assessment by a private contractor who was handed the council's revenue service two years ago.

Hundreds, maybe thousands, of people have been served with eviction notices by landlords, including the council's own housing department, because they are in arrears, and unable to pay the full rent because the benefit has not arrived.

The full impact of the chaos can be found across the road from Hackney town hall in the citizens' advice bureau. Manager Osi Okponobi says they process more than 200 housing benefit complaints each month; council inefficiency is so deep he has resorted to faxing the town hall outstanding cases which they should have recorded. "This far outweighs any other problem we have to tackle," he laments. "People are under such mental stress."

The turmoil led to street protests this week when Hackney Tenants' Convention, representing 29,000 council tenants, lobbied the council meeting surrounded by riot police. For good measure, those elusive refuse trucks and street sweeping vehicles inexplicably joined the protest, bringing the streets to a standstill.

Linda Hibberd, who chairs the convention, cannot contain her anger: her 75-year-old mother Matilda Owen (a former Labour councillor for 26 years) has been served with an arrears notice. "She hasn't received her benefit and can't pay the full amount and it made her shake with worry. A lot of older people are distraught."

Yet Jules Pipe and Eric Ollerenshaw, Labour and Tory leaders respectively, insist they are confident that Hackney has turned the corner. "The real message Eric and I want to drive home is that while we disagree politically, there are things that need sorting out - getting street cleaning, and refuse collection right, for instance - that need not be a political football."

Time is not on their side. Unless the council's recovery programme satisfies the local government inspectorate, the axe will finally fall on the borough next year. The government will then order someone else to take over council services.

Timetable: 18 years of turmoil


1982 Hard left takes over.

1985 Council, with several Labour authorities, refuses to set a rate in protest at Tory spending cuts. Agrees after months of brinkmanship.

1981-88 Mark Trotter, a paedophile working in the children's unit, becomes a Labour election agent and is shortlisted for a council seat. After his death from Aids there are allegations of a cover-up and a conspiracy.

1994 A housing director, hailed for launching an anti-fraud campaign, is sacked and then reinstated.

1995 Government education hit squad, first of its kind, sent to run Hackney Downs school.

1995 Council in turmoil as 17 councillors split from ruling Labour group.

1998 Election leaves no party in control of 60-strong council.

1998 Inquiry into Trotter affair highlights incompetence and a poisonous political culture in town hall.

1998 Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, says Hackney "set new standards in disorganisation and bureaucratic waste".

1999 District auditor sets alarm bells ringing about council overspending.

2000 Local government inspectorate calls for appointment of up to 10 new "financial managers". Gives council until February 2001 to get its house in order.

webTitle: Expert boarder  Danny Burrows' favourite resorts

fields.headline: Sweep the board
fields.standfirst: Expert boarder  Danny Burrows  has scoured the world in search of the best powder, funparks and halfpipes. Here, he brings you his favourite resorts
fields.trailText: Expert boarder Danny Burrows has scoured the world in search of the best powder, funparks and halfpipes. Here, he brings you his favourite resorts
fields.body:
Over the last decade, snowboarding has transformed from the blight of the slopes to a respected and ever more popular alternative to skiing. Everyone - from skate kids and octogenarians to our very own future monarchs - seems to be going board mad.

But the snowboarders' domain is different to that of their pole bearing counterparts. They scour the slopes for funparks, halfpipes and elusive fresh powder, for which a board is the ideal vehicle.

Happy riding.

Mayrhofen is the principal resort of the Ziller Valley, in the Austrian Tyrol, and is home to many of the country's top snowboarders. It is easily accessible from Innsbruck airport as well as from Munich, to where cheap flights from the UK are readily available.

Although the area is rather low (below 2,500m) and the snowfall unreliable, the vastness of the terrain will keep even the most adventurous of riders happy. A Zillertal superskipass entitles use of 145 lifts covering an area of 462km, so there's plenty of secret powder stashes to be found. Even if good snow is not forthcoming, you can always head to the Hintertux Glacier and play on the multitude of both natural and man-made jumps and drops.

There's a funpark and halfpipe on the Horberg, while those seeking a little privacy should investigate the backcountry accessible from the top of the Penkenjoch or down the valley at Zell.

Bars and clubs: Scotties Pub, Arena Nightclub

More information: www.mayrhofen.com

Getting there: Host of next April's British Snowboarding Championships to which Thomson (0870 6061470) is offering special all-inclusive snowboard packages and has snowboard academies. Seven nights in January start at £305, including flights.

Other operators: Neilson 0870 5141414, Equity Total Ski 01273 298298, Motours 01892 677770.

Axamer Lizum . Off the mountain, Axamer is hardly the most attractive of resorts, consisting of four hotels and a carpark. But the actual ski area is a gem as far as snowboarders are concerned. Close to Innsbruck, it is easily accessible although lift queues can be long at weekends.

The resort's 10 lifts service the two peaks of Hoadl and Pleisen, which have hosted the winter Olympics twice, so the pistes are challenging to say the least. There is a pipe and park in the resort although they are not well maintained. The rider should not find this a problem, though, as the natural terrain is littered with obstacles and good freeriding. When ascending the mountain in the main gondola, advanced riders should check out possible tree runs to the left and right of the lift line; they won't be disappointed. Alternatively, powder hounds can search out trails 3, 4 and 10 to the right of the top chair. Remember, when riding the backcountry, be conscious of the environment and don't not destroy freshly-planted saplings.

Bars and clubs: (in Innsbruck) Jimmy's, the Couch Bar

More information: www.axams.at or www.austria-tourism.at

Getting there: Hourmont Ski Direct (01273 220777) is offering seven days, six nights' full board for £349 travelling by Snowcoach. For flights, add £80-£120.

Red Mountain is neither the most popular nor the most accessible of resorts in Canada, but it is a snowboarding experience that cannot be missed. If you brave the small prop plane that flies between Vancouver and Castlegar, or take the seven-hour coach transfer, you will be greeted by a snow-bound experience from a bygone age. There are no crowds, no high-speed quads and no rambling resort complexes at the base of the mountain. But there is plenty of snow and it's mostly untracked.

The resort consists of two mountains: Grante -which is the larger - and Red. Together, they cover an area of 1,100 acres. The face of Red Mountain is extremely steep and fast but there are plenty of tree runs off-piste. Additionally, if accompanied by a guide, you can ride some of Canada's most incredible backcountry bowls here. But be warned: the danger levels are high. Grante has the lion's share of groomed runs and a plethora of natural jumps and tree runs. Try to hook up with some locals though as the majority of Red Mountain's delights lie beyond the resort boundaries.

Bars and clubs: The Powder Keg, Rafters.

Getting there: Frontier Ski (020-8776 8709) offers seven nights' B&B in the Ram's Head Inn starting at £799, based on two people sharing. Children aged six and under ski free.

Other operators: Ski Safari 020-7740 1221, Skisar US 01959 540796.

Chamonix is a Mecca for mountain sports enthusiasts of every persuasion, and the crème for snowboarders who crave the delights of off-piste riding. It is a 45-minute drive from Geneva airport to which many low-cost airlines now fly.

Even from the town, the mountains are impressive in their size and severity and, after hearing countless tales of crevasses and hidden cliff drops, you will hesitate before venturing on to the lift system. But fear not, Chamonix has something for everyone in its 11 rideable areas (it has the largest linked terrain in the world). From the mellower inclines of Le Tour with its natural jumps, to the rolling playgrounds of Brevent, both freeriders and freestylers will find enough to keep them happy for at least a season. And for those who want to take their riding to new extremes, there's always Argentière. Be warned though: Chamonix's backcountry is extensive and dangerous, so always enlist the help of guides and be prepared for any eventuality.

Bars and clubs: La Cantina, The Pub, Le Terras.

More information: www.chamonix.net

Getting there: EasyJet flies to Geneva. Kommunity Snowboard Camps (01546 830243), started by former British Snowboard Champion Neil McNab, runs freeride and extreme back-country weeks. The latter include glacier and crevasse training taught by qualified mountain guides. Prices start at £600, excluding flights. The snowboard camps are for three levels of riding.

Other operators: Collineige 01276 24262, Airtours 0870 1577775, First Choice 0870 7543477.

Méribel , at the "heart" of the Three Valleys ski area, provides the avid snowboarder with a huge amount of terrain, including 600km of piste serviced by 200 lifts. It is also easily accessible for the traveller, the best point of entry being Turin, which is an hour's drive away.

The snowboarding facilities are comprehensive and include two pipes, two parks and one of Europe's best boarder-X tracks. With so much to play on, it has become a regular hangout for many of the Continent's best riders. The main pipe and park are located below the Plattières 2, while the second is tucked away near the Tougnette mid-station. Another funpark has recently been built at Biolley.

For the most challenging and beautiful off-piste riding, head for Mont du Vallon. To the east of the town are the Col de la Loze and Saulire, beyond which lie the Bozel Valley and Courchevel; to the west, one can ride a long ridge with access to the areas of Belleville Valley and the resorts of Val Thorens, Les Menuires and St-Martin-de-Belleville.

Bars and clubs: Capricorn Bar.

More information: www.meribel.net

Getting there: This winter, Club Med (0700 2582633) opens two new chalet-style villages. The starting price for seven nights' full board, flights, transfers,and insurance is £826.

Other operators: Simply Ski 020-8541 2209, Erna Low 020-7584 2841, Mark Warner 0870 8480482, Ski Total 020-8948 3535.

Davos has played host to many a snowboarding contest in its time so is well versed in catering to those who ride sideways. In the past, the maintenance of snowboard-specific facilities has been limited to contest dates, although in recent years this has changed. There are now two well-cut pipes and a park on the Parsenn slope, one of which is within hiking distance of the premier snowboarders' bar and hotel, the Bolgenschanze.

Probably the greatest disadvantage about this mountain is actually getting up to the higher slopes due to a rather slow funicular from Davos Platz and Dorf, but the riding is well worth the hassle.

From the top station, the freeriding opportunities are endless although if heading out of bounds, it is advisable to take a guide. There are some amazing tree runs to be found off to the left of the cat track that leads down to the mid-station while another free-riders' paradise is on the run from the top of the Jakobshorn to Teufi. Don't be afraid to investigate the entire catchment area of Davos as there is a free bus service included in your lift pass.

Bars and clubs: Bolgenschanze Hotel

More information: www.davos.ch

Getting there: Inghams (0208-780 4433) is offering a two-for-one lift pass at hotels in Davos for some dates during January. The starting price for a seven-night, half-board stay at the three-star Hotel Bristol in January is £444, including flights.

Other operators: Elegant Resorts 0870 3333336, Kuoni 01306 742500, Swiss Travel Service 01992 456143, White Roc 0207-792 1188

Laax is the home of Swiss snowboarding and a popular site for contests on the International Snowboard Federation's calendar. The resort authorities are therefore committed to keeping the snowboard-specific facilities in top condition. It is a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Zurich airport or a 10-hour drive from Calais.

There are two pipes in Laax, the main one of which is located on the Crap Sogn Gion under the Gondola. The second has been carved into the Vorab glacier and is as good as, if not better than, the main one. Running alongside the pipe on the Vorab glacier is Laax's gargantuan funpark, which will test riders of all standards.

But Laax is not only a freestylers' paradise; the backcountry is vast and varied in its delights. Take the draglift to the top of the Vorab and descend to your right. Here you will find limitless fields of powder dissected by natural gullies and chutes. There are also plenty of tree runs below the main gondola that lead down to the resort base.

Bars and clubs: The Crap bar.

More information: www.laax.ch Switzerland Travel Centre: 00800 10020030

Getting there: Momentum Travel (020-7371 9111).Seven nights in Flims, a lovely village that shares the Laax ski area, staying in the Sunstar Hotel starts at £799pp.

Other operators: Made to Measure 01243 533333, Plus Travel 020-734 0383, Ski Choice 01491 837607,

Mammoth Mountain, in California, is one of North America's largest ski resorts. The nearest airport is Reno, although, for the sake of seeing some of the US, you could rent a car and drive from either LA or San Francisco.

The larger of the two funparks , "The Unbound", is accessible from the Thunder Bound Express quad and features a vast array of spines, hips and kickers as well as two half pipes. The area is floodlit most nights until 9pm. The second smaller park and pipe are at the Canyon Lodge.

For those who like their terrain a little more natural, there's Dragon's Back and Hemlock Ridge as well as the natural pipe of Upper Dry Creek.

If you want to escape the weekend crowds that flock to the resort from LA and San Francisco, head for June Mountain, a 20-minute drive away. There is a fun park and pipe as well as sparsely- populated open runs down the mountain's main face.

Bars and clubs: Whisky Creek, Chick and Pizza.

Further information: www.visitmammoth.com

Getting there Crystal (0870 84870003) offers seven nights' B&B at Jagerhof Lodge starting at £559, including flights and transfers. Children aged six and under ski free.

Other operators: Ski the American Dream 020-8552 1201, Ski Activity 01738 840888, Ski Independence 0870 6001462

Baqueira Beret Spain is not the most likely place to go for snow, but this resort near Viella, on the northern side of the Pyrennes, is well worth a visit. It is an easy two-hour drive from Toulouse.

The snowboard scene in Spain is not huge but its stronghold is located here. This is in part due to the pipe that the resort has built for the past two years, although it is worth taking your own spade to shape the walls, as the maintenance is sporadic to say the least.

The resort is made up of four separate mountains that are all well linked by 37 modern lifts. Bonaigua provides the best terrain for freeriding although come spring it is also the worst affected by the sun. After a fresh fall of snow, head for an area called Argulls located between Bonaigua and Baqueira as there are plenty of powder stashes to ride here. For those who like their riding steep, there are also plenty of options in the northern parts of the resort, including the aptly-named couloir of "Where Goats Tumble".

Bars and clubs: Jai Aran, Era Crin.

Getting there: Ski Miquel (01457 821200) offers seven nights in the Chalet Hotel Salana starting at £319 and including breakfast, tea, three- course dinner, wine, flights and transfers.

Madonna di Campiglio is neither Italy's most glamorous nor its largest resort, but it is the heartland of the country's snowboarding scene. This is due to the commitment shown to the sport by the resort authorities and because it has hosted many international snowboarding events in the past. It is located in the narrow valley of Brenta Dolomites, a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Verona.

The resort consists of three separate areas, which are linked at the base by a web of ridable paths. The majority of the resort runs are suited to the intermediate snowboarder, although if you are looking for a little more adventure you should buy a "superskirama" lift pass and access the resorts of Folgarida and Marivella. There is a snowboard park, boarder-X track and well-maintained pipe in the Goste area, which is about the only part of the resort that is above the treeline. The only disadvantage about this area is that it is not fenced off to stray mountain users, so be observant.

There are plenty of natural obstacles to be found on the mountains, while freeriders should check out the Spinale and Fortini to take advantage of some awesome terrain.

Bars and clubs: Disco Zangola, The Cliffhanger

Further information: www.campiglio.net

Getting there: Interhome (020-8891 1294) offers a week's ski-drive holiday in a two-room apartment for two-five people sharing from £636, including ferry crossings.

Other operators: Inghams 020-8780 4433, Crystal 0870 8487000, Thomson 0870 6061470.

fields.bodyText: Over the last decade, snowboarding has transformed from the blight of the slopes to a respected and ever more popular alternative to skiing. Everyone - from skate kids and octogenarians to our very own future monarchs - seems to be going board mad. But the snowboarders' domain is different to that of their pole bearing counterparts. They scour the slopes for funparks, halfpipes and elusive fresh powder, for which a board is the ideal vehicle. Happy riding. Mayrhofen is the principal resort of the Ziller Valley, in the Austrian Tyrol, and is home to many of the country's top snowboarders. It is easily accessible from Innsbruck airport as well as from Munich, to where cheap flights from the UK are readily available. Although the area is rather low (below 2,500m) and the snowfall unreliable, the vastness of the terrain will keep even the most adventurous of riders happy. A Zillertal superskipass entitles use of 145 lifts covering an area of 462km, so there's plenty of secret powder stashes to be found. Even if good snow is not forthcoming, you can always head to the Hintertux Glacier and play on the multitude of both natural and man-made jumps and drops. There's a funpark and halfpipe on the Horberg, while those seeking a little privacy should investigate the backcountry accessible from the top of the Penkenjoch or down the valley at Zell. Bars and clubs: Scotties Pub, Arena Nightclub More information: www.mayrhofen.com Getting there: Host of next April's British Snowboarding Championships to which Thomson (0870 6061470) is offering special all-inclusive snowboard packages and has snowboard academies. Seven nights in January start at £305, including flights. Other operators: Neilson 0870 5141414, Equity Total Ski 01273 298298, Motours 01892 677770. Axamer Lizum . Off the mountain, Axamer is hardly the most attractive of resorts, consisting of four hotels and a carpark. But the actual ski area is a gem as far as snowboarders are concerned. Close to Innsbruck, it is easily accessible although lift queues can be long at weekends. The resort's 10 lifts service the two peaks of Hoadl and Pleisen, which have hosted the winter Olympics twice, so the pistes are challenging to say the least. There is a pipe and park in the resort although they are not well maintained. The rider should not find this a problem, though, as the natural terrain is littered with obstacles and good freeriding. When ascending the mountain in the main gondola, advanced riders should check out possible tree runs to the left and right of the lift line; they won't be disappointed. Alternatively, powder hounds can search out trails 3, 4 and 10 to the right of the top chair. Remember, when riding the backcountry, be conscious of the environment and don't not destroy freshly-planted saplings. Bars and clubs: (in Innsbruck) Jimmy's, the Couch Bar More information: www.axams.at or www.austria-tourism.at Getting there: Hourmont Ski Direct (01273 220777) is offering seven days, six nights' full board for £349 travelling by Snowcoach. For flights, add £80-£120. Red Mountain is neither the most popular nor the most accessible of resorts in Canada, but it is a snowboarding experience that cannot be missed. If you brave the small prop plane that flies between Vancouver and Castlegar, or take the seven-hour coach transfer, you will be greeted by a snow-bound experience from a bygone age. There are no crowds, no high-speed quads and no rambling resort complexes at the base of the mountain. But there is plenty of snow and it's mostly untracked. The resort consists of two mountains: Grante -which is the larger - and Red. Together, they cover an area of 1,100 acres. The face of Red Mountain is extremely steep and fast but there are plenty of tree runs off-piste. Additionally, if accompanied by a guide, you can ride some of Canada's most incredible backcountry bowls here. But be warned: the danger levels are high. Grante has the lion's share of groomed runs and a plethora of natural jumps and tree runs. Try to hook up with some locals though as the majority of Red Mountain's delights lie beyond the resort boundaries. Bars and clubs: The Powder Keg, Rafters. Getting there: Frontier Ski (020-8776 8709) offers seven nights' B&B in the Ram's Head Inn starting at £799, based on two people sharing. Children aged six and under ski free. Other operators: Ski Safari 020-7740 1221, Skisar US 01959 540796. Chamonix is a Mecca for mountain sports enthusiasts of every persuasion, and the crème for snowboarders who crave the delights of off-piste riding. It is a 45-minute drive from Geneva airport to which many low-cost airlines now fly. Even from the town, the mountains are impressive in their size and severity and, after hearing countless tales of crevasses and hidden cliff drops, you will hesitate before venturing on to the lift system. But fear not, Chamonix has something for everyone in its 11 rideable areas (it has the largest linked terrain in the world). From the mellower inclines of Le Tour with its natural jumps, to the rolling playgrounds of Brevent, both freeriders and freestylers will find enough to keep them happy for at least a season. And for those who want to take their riding to new extremes, there's always Argentière. Be warned though: Chamonix's backcountry is extensive and dangerous, so always enlist the help of guides and be prepared for any eventuality. Bars and clubs: La Cantina, The Pub, Le Terras. More information: www.chamonix.net Getting there: EasyJet flies to Geneva. Kommunity Snowboard Camps (01546 830243), started by former British Snowboard Champion Neil McNab, runs freeride and extreme back-country weeks. The latter include glacier and crevasse training taught by qualified mountain guides. Prices start at £600, excluding flights. The snowboard camps are for three levels of riding. Other operators: Collineige 01276 24262, Airtours 0870 1577775, First Choice 0870 7543477. Méribel , at the "heart" of the Three Valleys ski area, provides the avid snowboarder with a huge amount of terrain, including 600km of piste serviced by 200 lifts. It is also easily accessible for the traveller, the best point of entry being Turin, which is an hour's drive away. The snowboarding facilities are comprehensive and include two pipes, two parks and one of Europe's best boarder-X tracks. With so much to play on, it has become a regular hangout for many of the Continent's best riders. The main pipe and park are located below the Plattières 2, while the second is tucked away near the Tougnette mid-station. Another funpark has recently been built at Biolley. For the most challenging and beautiful off-piste riding, head for Mont du Vallon. To the east of the town are the Col de la Loze and Saulire, beyond which lie the Bozel Valley and Courchevel; to the west, one can ride a long ridge with access to the areas of Belleville Valley and the resorts of Val Thorens, Les Menuires and St-Martin-de-Belleville. Bars and clubs: Capricorn Bar. More information: www.meribel.net Getting there: This winter, Club Med (0700 2582633) opens two new chalet-style villages. The starting price for seven nights' full board, flights, transfers,and insurance is £826. Other operators: Simply Ski 020-8541 2209, Erna Low 020-7584 2841, Mark Warner 0870 8480482, Ski Total 020-8948 3535. Davos has played host to many a snowboarding contest in its time so is well versed in catering to those who ride sideways. In the past, the maintenance of snowboard-specific facilities has been limited to contest dates, although in recent years this has changed. There are now two well-cut pipes and a park on the Parsenn slope, one of which is within hiking distance of the premier snowboarders' bar and hotel, the Bolgenschanze. Probably the greatest disadvantage about this mountain is actually getting up to the higher slopes due to a rather slow funicular from Davos Platz and Dorf, but the riding is well worth the hassle. From the top station, the freeriding opportunities are endless although if heading out of bounds, it is advisable to take a guide. There are some amazing tree runs to be found off to the left of the cat track that leads down to the mid-station while another free-riders' paradise is on the run from the top of the Jakobshorn to Teufi. Don't be afraid to investigate the entire catchment area of Davos as there is a free bus service included in your lift pass. Bars and clubs: Bolgenschanze Hotel More information: www.davos.ch Getting there: Inghams (0208-780 4433) is offering a two-for-one lift pass at hotels in Davos for some dates during January. The starting price for a seven-night, half-board stay at the three-star Hotel Bristol in January is £444, including flights. Other operators: Elegant Resorts 0870 3333336, Kuoni 01306 742500, Swiss Travel Service 01992 456143, White Roc 0207-792 1188 Laax is the home of Swiss snowboarding and a popular site for contests on the International Snowboard Federation's calendar. The resort authorities are therefore committed to keeping the snowboard-specific facilities in top condition. It is a two-and-a-half-hour drive from Zurich airport or a 10-hour drive from Calais. The second has been carved into the Vorab glacier and is as good as, if not better than, the main one. Here you will find limitless fields of powder dissected by natural gullies and chutes. There are also plenty of tree runs below the main gondola that lead down to the resort base. fields.headline: Tickets to freedom
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor gives the lowdown on how to negotiate the world's underground systems
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor gives the lowdown on how to negotiate the world's underground systems
fields.body:
Could the days of buying the wrong ticket, getting caught in the rush hour and making the wrong connection be over? Only, perhaps, in Paris.

London Transport
London Transport does a good job of explaining the complexities of ticketing (in 16 languages) and reporting delays on the network.

Newly-launched www.thetube.com does have an impressive journey planner for the Underground, but Netscape users may have problems with it.

Subway Navigator
Type in your starting-point and destination stations to plan the journey and estimate the length of time needed to complete it. Sixty cities are included, including Tokyo, Budapest and St Petersburg.

New York City Transit Subway
A ticket to any subway station costs $1.50 in NY, unless you buy a MetroCard - but while the fares are easy to understand, the lines can seem complex. All the maps and running times can be downloaded and printed off, and the site links to local bus and railroad information.

RATP
The Paris metro and bus site doesn't just calculate journeys between stations. Admirably, it will work out the best route between addresses and famous buildings, too.

The Noctambus night bus network is also available - particularly useful given the dearth of taxis in the city.

BVG.de
A rather impenetrable effort from Berlin's transport network. The BVG movies are notably unenlightening and only the "tariff overview" (ticket prices) is likely to be of much help to the visitor.

Barcelona
A useful route planner and details of the memorably named Nitbus nocturnal service are the best features of Barcelona's site.

Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transport Authority
An impressive attempt to simplify LA transport, MTA is aimed at locals rather than tourists.

Moscow Metro
The Moscow metro doesn't have its own site, but this one goes a little way towards explaining the system. The map here uses the English rather than Cyrillic script for station and line names, and translates a few common signs.

fields.headline: Games without frontiers
fields.standfirst: In one of the most remote corners of the Earth, author Stanley Stewart finds the descendants of Genghis Khan living up to their wild reputation with a bout of wrestling, horse racing and drinking
fields.trailText: In one of the most remote corners of the Earth, author Stanley Stewart finds the descendants of Genghis Khan living up to their wild reputation with a bout of wrestling, horse racing and drinking
fields.body:
Mongolians are not very good at towns and Hovd was no exception. The capital of a province the size of Scotland, it felt like an abandoned outpost at world's end. Dead things littered what passed for streets - the hooves of deceased horses, the bones of butchered sheep, the carcasses of jeeps.

In fairness, Hovd was not a bad effort for people who hate towns. The last domain of the nomads who once terrorised Asia, Mongolia is a pristine landscape traversed by clouds and camels and gangs of unruly sheep. It could be God's preliminary sketch for Earth, not so much a country as the ingredients out of which countries are made: grass, rock, water and wind. In these virginal steppes, where round white tents sprout as suddenly and as mysteriously as mushrooms, towns were a blight.

I was crossing the country by horse, a thousand miles from Bayan Olgii to Dadal, the birthplace of Genghis Khan, and I rode into Hovd like a cowpoke looking for supplies and excitement - rice, beer and a night on the tiles. Normally this would have been a tall order for a Mongolian town. But in Hovd I got lucky. I arrived on the eve of the annual Naadam festival, when the town becomes a magnet for the nomads from outlying districts. The Naadam is a celebration of Mongolian culture as expressed in four national sports: horse racing, wrestling, archery and drinking. It was party time in Hovd, and when Mongolians party, says a Chinese proverb, the rest of Asia locks its doors.

Mongolia's towns are a recent phenomenon. They are all composed of the same ingredients, as if officials, unfamiliar with towns, were working to a checklist: a barren-looking square, a town hall, a theatre, a museum, a school, a hospital, a sports stadium. In their drabness they are barely distinguishable from one another. Mix in a few potholes and a sprinkling of animal bones, add a lot of waste ground and a handful of Russian-style tenements in an advanced state of dilapidation, and the desolation is complete.

The Naadam got off to a gentle start down at the stadium with the wrestling bouts. Between open terraces and two small pavilions the pitch was overgrown with wild flowers. At its centre, where the Red Flag used to fly, was a group of nine poles topped with yaks tails, the standard of Genghis Khan. The tails were white, which was just as well. Black meant war.

Crowds milled about in their best silk and velvet dels, the traditional sashed robes of Mongolia. Everyone was in a good mood and a hat. Men and women alike were partial to handsome fedoras and trilbies. A few of the more august figures wore bowlers.

Naadam was a great occasion for medals. To keep the long-suffering herdsmen sweet, the former communist government had doled out gongs with abandon. The result was medal inflation. Medals that were once great honours quickly became worthless and new ones had constantly to be minted. There was the Order of the Red Banner, the Order of Sukhbatur, the Order of the Pole Star, and the Best Worker in the Fifth Five Year Plan Medal. Men got medals for acts of courage like party membership and high livestock yields. Women got them for bearing children. One old woman proudly showed me "The Order of Glorious Motherhood, First Grade", a Victoria Cross of motherhood. Pinned to her formidable bosom, it celebrated the fact that she had had more than 10 children.

The loudspeakers were droning with speeches by local dignitaries. No one seemed to listen, not even the band who struck up a catchy dance tune in the middle of the governor's peroration on civic duty. Eventually he gave up, and retreated to the reviewing stand. Most Mongolian politicians are ex-communists forging new careers, somewhat shakily, as democrats. They are struggling to get used that most fundamental ingredient of democracy: the right to ignore politicians. Beneath their bowler hats, they sat darkly in a row muttering about the good old days.

A frisson went through the crowd as the wrestlers were introduced according to their status: Falcon, Elephant, Lion, and Giant, last year's champion. Most of the participants were of the Sumo tendency - huge fellows who looked like they got through half a yak at breakfast. Among the big stomachs were a scattering of slim men looking understandably nervous.

The wrestlers' costumes appeared to have been designed for a dance troupe: boots with elfin toes, pointed hats, short sparkly jackets, and pretty embroidered Y-fronts. One by one, the big men trotted out into mid-field where they performed the Eagle Dance, flapping their arms in slow motion and bowing before the standard of Genghis Khan.

I asked an old fellow next to me the reason for the curious design of the jackets - long sleeves but an open front that left the chest bare.

"Keeps the women out," he muttered. In Outer Mongolia women wrestlers are much feared. The annals of Mongolian wrestling are full of stories in which devious viragos disguised their sex, entered the wrestling competition and destroyed all the best heavyweights. Marco Polo related a tale of a Mongolian woman who decided she could only marry a man who could throw her. Despite a succession of muscle-bound suitors, she remained a spinster. The idea of the open-fronted jacket is that it allows the more alert judges to spot a woman straight away and hustle her out of the competition before she causes any damage.

As the wrestling got underway, it was quickly evident that the slim fellows were cannon-fodder for the guys with the big bellies. The early bouts were full of action as large men threw small men with satisfying thumps. As the small men were gradually weeded out, the competition became stiffer and the contests duller. Locked together like stalled bulldozers, the big men could go 15 rounds without moving. The only action came between rounds when the seconds straightened the wrestlers' Y-fronts and patted their bottoms.

The horse races were better value, and the following morning I set off in a jeep, bouncing across the empty steppe to where a large crowd had assembled at a finish line in the middle of nowhere. Naadam races are run cross-country over marathon distances, 20 miles in the case of the Hovd races. People milled about in their hats, greeting one another with elaborate salutations. Many of the men had arrived in the same straw fedora whose hat bands bore the bewitching legend: Strength Through Milk.

While we waited for the runners and riders to arrive, drinking parties were springing up on all sides. Mongols unpacked elaborate picnics of petrified cheese, dumplings and bottles of vodka with the brand-name of Genghis Khan. In no time, everyone was roaring drunk. I fell in with Ganbold, the local history teacher. Twenty years of teaching 14-year-olds about the glories of the communist revolution had honed his conversation to laborious banalities. Ganbold was a connoisseur of the obvious, never happier than when explaining something you already knew.

The approach of the field was announced by a distant cloud of dust.

"The horses are coming," Ganbold explained helpfully.

The vodka-sodden crowds pushed forward towards the finish line where three inebriated policemen threw stones at them to try to hold them back. As the horses began to emerge from the dust, a steward ran forward waving an enormous red flag to guide the riders to the unmarked finish line. A crescendo of whoops and whistles rose from the crowd. Young men hollered, women shrieked, old men stamped their feet, and babies, waving fat arms, burst into tears.

The jockeys were children, both boys and girls, few of them older than eight, who had completed the course bareback and barefoot. In their paper race hats they looked as if they were returning from a rather jolly children's party, dazed with too much cake. As the first finishers crossed the line, the crowds broke ranks, overrunning the policemen and engulfing the lathered horses. Fathers caught hold of the bridles, sisters started frantically wiping the sweat from the flanks with special paddles, and mothers lifted their child jockeys down from the horses to revive them with fermented mare's milk.

One horse collapsed a few yards from the finishing line. Its rider, a young girl of about seven, picked herself up and began to kick the horse in the chest, apparently the Mongolian equivalent of an equine kiss of life, meant to revive the poor creature. The owner had a more traditional remedy. He ran out from the crowd, produced a bottle of Genghis Khan from the folds of his del and poured the contents down the horse's throat. The effect was immediate. The animal leapt to its feet and hared off back towards Hovd, rider-less, without bothering to cross the finishing line. A steward's inquiry presumably disqualified the beast: "retired, drunk".

Back at the stadium in the afternoon, the wrestling final was underway, when a great party of dishevelled horsemen arrived - the Naadam winners, their owners, their trainers, and their pals. To the roar of the crowd, they cantered round the arena beneath the terraces in a couple of laps of honour burying the wrestlers in veils of dust.

For the presentation, the riders gathered beneath the equivalent of the royal box where the politicians were seated. Professional praise singers sang the praises of the horses, the races and riders in thrilling nasal arias. The governor, pleased at last to be the centre of attention, handed out the prizes - Chinese carpets and bricks of Russian tea - as if he had bought them himself. The grand prize, in this land of horsemen, was a Russian motorcycle. Actually, it was a promissory note for a motorcycle. Though ordered some months ago, the governor explained, the machine had yet to arrive. The winning trainer gazed at the note with the sceptical look of a man familiar with politicians' promises.

Then amidst further whoops the horsemen galloped out of the stadium and we rediscovered the wrestling final. Not a lot had happened in the interval. The two colossi were as we had left them, like mating dogs that had got stuck. They might have been posing for a statue.

We were rescued by a spectacular storm. Thunder rolled in from the mountains, rain swept round the terraces and the crowds fled.

"It's raining," Ganbold explained, pulling his trilby down over his ears.

Within minutes, the stadium was empty save for the two immobilised wrestlers and a panel of judges sheltering beneath a leaky canopy.

Hunched against the rain, the Mongolians ran to their horses, tethered in long rows in the horse park. Riding out of the dismal town, they cantered away towards the shelter of distant tents, laughing and calling to one another across the glistening plains.

The next morning I followed them, turning my horse away from the dreary town into an enormous sweep of landscape. Ahead of me lay a thousand miles of Mongolia.

The practicals

Flights via Beijing with Air China are available from the Airline Network (0800 727747; www.airnet.co.uk) and start from £698. Steppes East (01285 810267) is the most experienced of the tour operators in Mongolia. Its 15-day Riding with Eagles group tour includes Hovd and the Altay mountains, with a visit to the Kazakh eagle hunters.

Running from August 9 to 23, it misses the Naadam festival and prices start from £2,180 including flights. The 11-day Mongolia Classic Tour, from July 5 to 16 includes the national Naadam in Ulan Batur and starts from £1,815. In the Saddle (01256 851665) offers a 12-day riding tour that concentrates on the Terelji area north-east of Ulan Batur.

The late June early July tour can be extended to take in the national Naadam in Ulan Batur and prices start from £1,100. Discovery Initiatives (01285 810621) has an 18-day riding tour in the Hovsgol region in northern Mongolia, which usually includes a local Naadam as well as the national Naadam in Ulan Batur. fields.headline: Journey's end
fields.standfirst: In the cemeteries of the Somme, Hilary Macaskill finds a fitting monument to the dead of the war that ended 82 years ago today
fields.trailText: In the cemeteries of the Somme, Hilary Macaskill finds a fitting monument to the dead of the war that ended 82 years ago today
fields.body:
The sheer scale of what had happened was brought home to us in Rancourt. For miles, we had followed the poppy-emblazoned signs of the Road of Remembrance over the flat plains of the Somme, an eternity of battlefield sites and memorials to the war that didn't end wars: the deep Lochnagar Crater blasted out by mines, the simple poppy-bedecked cross of Captain Dickens, grandson of Charles Dickens, alone in a field.

Here in Rancourt, a hamlet that one would have scarcely noticed, great tracts of beautifully-tended land were given over to the dead, with three cemeteries: British, French and German. In the French one, we started calculating the number of graves, laid out in a grid, the occasional curved head stone inscribed in Arabic breaking the uniformity of the gleaming crosses, but we gave up at 5,000.

This is the largest French war cemetery on the Somme. Next to it is a chapel, the only monument to the French participation in the battle. But it is not the result of an official initiative - as the inscription over the door explains, it is a memorial created by the Du Bos family for their son and his comrades.

Close by is the German cemetery with four bodies to each grave. A motorised mower is busy on its perpetual task of keeping the lawns immaculately shorn. There are books of names at each cemetery gate, and books for visitors to sign. Their comments include: "They were just like us," and "Let this never happen again."

Our teenage daughter wanted us to take this tour after she had read Birdsong by Sebastian Faulks, which had brought home to her as no history lesson ever could the tragedy and desperation of the first worldwar.

We had started near Compiègne at the "Clearing of the Armistice" - its twin train tracks preserved in the forest, The actual carriage where the peace treaty was signed serves as a tiny museum. But it was the cemeteries themselves that kept commanding our attention. Their very orderliness somehow underlined the chaos and carnage of that time. We spent hours walking round them.

Then there was the Thiepval Memorial to the Missing: this vast arch, built by Lutyens and visible for miles around, is inscribed with the names of men whose bodies were never found. There were 73,000 names. The Smiths alone filled several columns.

At Beaumont-Hamel, a section of the battlefield has been preserved, trenches carved out in curving zig-zags to prevent a shell travelling the full length of the trench. Nearby are the remains of dug-out shelters and fire-steps. Now it is all grassed over, undulating gently, a theme-park approximation, with bicycles thoughtfully provided to tour the site. It is impossible to imagine the mud, the noise and the stench.

In the end, it was a tiny British cemetery on the outskirts of Roye that still sticks in the mind. Such care had been invested in this small walled square; bushes of lavender and roses at the end of the neat rows filled the air with fragrance. Butterflies clustered round buddleia.

In the visitors' book at the gate, some of the comments were still raw in their emotion: "I came to find the grandfather I had never known." But most, like us, noted the peace and the beauty.

Maps and guides

The Somme: Remembrance Tour of the Great War, with map, routes and historical background is available from local tourist offices, price Ffr5. The tour starts from Péronne, at the Historial of the Great War museum, which uses videos, posters, newspapers and everyday objects to show life at the front, and at the rear (tel: 00333 2283 1418, www.historial.org/us/home_b.htm).

Michelin's yellow maps 51, 52 and 53, overprinted by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, have full details of cemeteries and memorials. Available (£3, including postage) from CWGC, 2 Marlow Road, Maidenhead, Berkshire SL6 7DX, tel: 01628 634221.

War Walks: from Agincourt to Normandy by Richard Holmes, (BBC Worldwide, £10.99) points out places of interest in the battlefields as they are today and puts them in their historical context.

Organised tours

Somme Battlefield Tours 19 Old Road, Wimborne Dorset BH21 1EJ, tel: 01202 840520 (www.btinternet.com/~sommetours). Conducted tours (of up to 10 people) or self-drive tours.

Hellfire Corner Battlefield Tours , (www.hellfire-corner.demon.co.uk/welcome.htm or e-mail: tom@hellfire-corner.co.uk). Conducted tours of around six people; smaller groups are possible.

Flanders Tours , PO Box 240, Ellington, Huntingdon, PE28 8YE, tel: 01480 890966.

Military History Tours with Experts , Red Lion Building, 1 Liverpool Road North, Maghull L31 2HB, tel: 0151-526 0075 (www.tours-with-experts.com).

Midas Battlefield Tours PO Box 376, West Byfleet, Surrey KT14 7FB, tel: 01932 407000, http://www.midastours.co.uk).

Accommodation

Places to stay can be found through the Hellfire Tours website (see above) or Somme, A Land of History (www.anzac.org), a site set up to help Aussies and Kiwis plan tours.

Useful addresses

Departmental Committee for Tourism in Somme has full information on the area, including guides in English: 21 Rue Ernest Cauvin, 8000 Amiens, tel: 0033 322 71 22 71.

Websites: Commonwealth War Graves Commission: www.cgwc.org. Has sections on architecture and horticulture policy.

Great War - western battlefield guide: www.greatwar.co.uk.

For real enthusiasts, an extensive annotated list of links can be found at the Unfortunate Region site: www.igr.nl/users/vandenheuvel

fields.headline: Radical departures
fields.standfirst: Relaxing in Somerset,  Paddy Ashdown MP knows that history and politics are never far away
fields.trailText: Relaxing in Somerset, Paddy Ashdown MP knows that history and politics are never far away
fields.body:
There's an apt mixture of military history, political anecdote, and radicalism to be found on the route of Paddy Ashdown's favourite walk, a four-mile loop that starts and finishes in the Somerset village of Norton Sub Hamdon, near Yeovil, where he has had his constituency home for the past 30 years.

The military history emerges almost the moment the former Liberal-Democrat leader leaves the village, usually accompanied by his wife Jane and their dog Luke. They pass the beautiful church of St Mary's - which has a bell but no clockface because the squire didn't want his labourers to waste time clock-watching - and cross two fields called Shootalong and the Butts. The fields are reminders of the 13th-century law that required the men of every village to practise archery in preparation for war against the French.

Then comes a sharp climb up Ham Hill to what Ashdown calls "one of the great views of Britain".

Ham Hill is an ancient, steep-sided neolithic earthwork, later used as a Roman garrison and an important location in Arthur's Britain. From here, in one sweep, you can see the lowland of the Somerset Levels, the Mendip Hills, Glastonbury Tor, Cadbury Castle and the distant Alfred's Tower, marking the site where Alfred the Great defeated the Danes.

"Ask me to choose the best time," says Ashdown, "and I would say a late November evening when there's a frost and the mist is gathering down on the levels and you've got that slightly orange but steely light."

There is an amphitheatre, believed to be Roman in origin and known locally as "the frying pans". Here, Gladstone and Lloyd-George addressed open-air meetings, and here, in 1997, Ashdown and his campaign manager, Lord Holme, decided they would work towards abandoning the long-established policy of "equidistance" between the two main parties.

The route passes the northern point of the flat-topped hill where a tall obelisk commemorates the dead of the first world war. From there, it skirts the disused quarries which supplied the honey-coloured Ham stone for many local villages, and along the edge of Hedgecock Hill Wood to look down on the elegant chimneys and gardens of Montacute House.

Its many claims to fame include a visit from Ashdown's favourite poet John Donne, a connection with the Gunpowder Plot, and a starring role in the recent film version of Jane Austen's Sense and Sensibility.

One of his favourite political anecdotes concerns the Conservative foreign secretary Lord Curzon spending the weekend at Montacute in the 1920s when he was called for on the occasion of the dissolution of the previous government. "He was kept waiting at Yeovil station - not an unusual experience - and arrived at Waterloo expecting to be summoned to the King. Instead, he was met by the King's messenger who said, more or less, you took such a long time coming that we've asked Baldwin to do it instead. It wasn't quite like that, but that's the story."

St Michael's Hill at the side of Montacute is believed to be the site of the last Saxon rebellion against the Normans, which was bloodily repressed: now it bears nothing more dramatic than an architectural folly. From here, the Ashdown route resolutely bypasses the King's Arms and turns south past the site of a Roman villa and the traces of the medieval village of Whitcombe.

More political history lurks nearby in Pit Plain and Pit Wood, where you still find the rides and avenues designed by William Pitt the Younger, prime minister from 1783, when he lived at Montacute. Freshwater oysters, originally cultivated by the Romans, can still be found in a pond in the woods.

Next comes the radicalism and Norton Covert, where Ashdown pauses to pay his respects to the Bubblers, a new-age community set up about seven years ago with the permission of South Somerset District Council: "I made myself, I'm afraid, very unpopular with some in my village by supporting their application, and now they live in structures called yurts in the woods.

"People said they'd lower the price of property - absolute nonsense. Their kids go to the local schools, and I think it's given a quality to the village it wouldn't otherwise have had."

The community takes its name from the Bubble, a natural spring on the way from Norton Covert to Little Norton. The Ashdown party might stop for a drink at the spring before pressing on to finish the walk with something a little stronger at the Lord Nelson.

"This really is one of the most glorious pieces of countryside in England," he says. "I sometimes stand on Ham Hill and watch people on the A303 hurtling down to Cornwall, and I'm glad they're missing us out.

"Walking used not to be much of a pastime, and I can remember in 1970 we had to more or less cut the paths as we went. Now half the world seems to be walking. The change is phenomenal."

The Ashdown Diaries: Volume One 1988-1997 is published by Penguin at £20.

fields.headline: Feltham damned in report
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Campaign for Racial Equality is to launch an investigation into racism in the prison system following the murder of an Asian prisoner by his cellmate at Feltham young offender institution.
fields.body:
The Campaign for Racial Equality is to launch an investigation into racism in the prison system following the murder of an Asian prisoner by his cellmate at Feltham young offender institution.

The move comes as a damning internal inquiry into Zahid Mubarek's death, conducted by the prison service, can be revealed by the Guardian.

Mr Mubarek, 19, was beaten to death by his racist cellmate, Robert Stewart, 20, in March, hours before Mubarek was due to be released. Stewart, a serial offender with a history of violence and mental health problems, was jailed for life this month.

The CRE is expected to announce an investigation into Feltham and two other insti tutions early next week. The circumstances surrounding Mr Mubarek's death are understood to have caused concern within the CRE. Earlier this year Paul Boateng, the prisons minister, asked the CRE to look into the issue of racism in the prison service, and earlier this month he said the service was "institutionally racist".

On Monday, Mr Mubarek's family are to press Mr Boateng to ensure any inquiry is carried out in public.

The call came after a leaked internal inquiry conducted by a prison service investigator was found to conclude that a catalogue of errors by staff and management at Feltham led to Mr Mubarek and Stewart sharing a cell without sufficient security checks taking place.

It adds that poor manage ment and the breakdown of basic screening procedures led to evidence of the danger Stewart posed to others being missed or ignored. The risk he posed to his cellmate was never properly assessed, states the report, which does not attribute blame to any individual members of staff.

The report also reveals that Stewart's letters, in which he expressed admiration for the killers of Stephen Lawrence and predicted the murder of his cellmate, were not monitored sufficiently despite the fact he was on remand facing charges of sending racially motivated malicious communication.

The report is also highly critical of procedures at Feltham, concluding that there was "an absence of a systematic, auditable set of operating in structions in place in the establishment" and that contingency plans were "outdated and inaccurate". Management lacked stability, were struggling to cope with three action plans and a "culture of blame" existed within the institution.

Imran Khan, solicitor for the family, said openness was crucial: "The murder of Zahid Mubarek demands urgent answers with regard to the prison service's culpability and responsibility. Someone is responsible for placing Zahid with a known racist."

The prison service declined to comment yesterday but confirmed that it would listen to representations from Mr Mubarek's family before taking a decision on whether to disclose the report's contents.
