fields.headline: Getting the welcome mat
fields.standfirst:
We need Irish pub landlords. And Spanish nurses. And quite a lot of other foreigners

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: We need Irish pub landlords. And Spanish nurses. And quite a lot of other foreigners.
fields.body:
All racists should be hospitalised. I say this not just on principle but because it is very hard to maintain racial prejudice while being cared for by the national health service.

The reason why there are so many ethnic minority nurses is partly that governments have always imported workers at times of labour shortage. Britain has imported Irish nurses, canal diggers and railway builders. And in most of our major cities, where one can walk into a pub and not hear the words, "You'm not be from rounds these parts, be thee?", one finds a tendency for pub landlords to be Irish.

The Ministry of Labour must have at some time realised that there was a major skills shortage in the licensing trade and that what was needed was an Irish publican movement. The English are not as well suited to the task for the simple reason that, whereas the Irish are determined to give people a drink and will use any means to do so, English landlords seem mainly concerned that people in their pubs should leave as soon as possible. The stroke of 11pm is merely the excuse they have been looking for all day. Conversely, if an Irish barman says: "Come along now people, it's nearly half eleven", it's because he's about to open up again for the lunchtime trade.

After the second world war Britain trawled the colonies, mostly for workers to do low-paid jobs. This was in the days when a person who came to Britain to work was not abused as an "economic migrant". It was accepted then that people have always moved around the world for economic reasons. But now reporters search for the home villages of migrants, hoping to uncover evidence that people are not being seriously persecuted but actually come for the cynical, self-serving reason that they are destitute.

And yet, at the same time, public officials are trawling the globe for nurses, teachers and the computer literate. Flustered immigration officers, who have spent the last few years charged with the responsibility of discounting evidence of persecution, now have new criteria: "I'm sorry this application is unfounded. The truth is you've been tortured; you have no IT skills whatsoever."

At the British Embassy in Khartoum, visa applicants are being asked whether they have ever been questioned by police or security, arrested or tortured. This is not for the purpose of providing safe haven for those who answer "Yes"; quite the reverse. The clue to the reason for the questions lies in a sign in Arabic. It translates thus: "Some of the questions we ask you may be too personal but our aim is to ensure that you will not become a burden on the British taxpayer." Applicants must sign a declaration that they will not apply for asylum in the UK.

If anyone doubts the claims of asylum seekers from Sudan they should read this year's Amnesty International report. And if fuel protesters knew what the oil companies do to keep the stuff pumping, they might find more important things to kick up about than the cost of diesel. Not all governments make weak-kneed concessions to guarantee fuel supplies. Some use gunships. But despite the hideous things going on in Sudan, refugees, who are forced to lie and travel using false documents, arrive in this country to face detention or dispersal. They'd do better to play down the human rights abuses and ring the Home Office direct to say: "Let me in, I understand computers. I can even help you buy one that works."

I do not know how many nurses, teachers, data processors, professors, poets or architects are living on vouchers in B&Bs around Britain. I don't suppose the Home Office takes the trouble to find out. Shipping them out as quickly as possible is the overriding aim. Meanwhile, nurses are brought in from Spain and teachers from Australia, and we are very grateful to them.

If the government won't offer decent wages and conditions to people already here, if it can't hold on to trained staff, people will have to be imported. Education ministers and schools inspectors are more skilled than immigration officers when it comes to driving people out. Vouchers have failed. But nothing was ever calculated to divide, demoralise and humiliate more than performance management. Lord Woodhead as refugee tsar would have them leaving in droves.

Apart from such an obvious exception, everyone living or arriving in Britain has something to offer. It's just that government is arbitrary in recognising it. Praise is political. The government likes to put people through hoops, so it's just as well people from abroad are more athletic.

It's possible that a refugee who barely scrapes in today will be lauded in 10 years' time for how he's performed, the contribution he's made, his donation to a political party. The government gives people a market value. It is not concerned with the right to decent pay, safety, freedom of movement. It treats people as goods and then gets indignant when they turn up in crates on the backs of lorries.

Contact: comment@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Failings at Feltham ended in racist murder

fields.headline: Failings at Feltham that ended in racist murder
fields.standfirst:
System missed signs of killer's violent tendencies
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An internal prison service investigation into the murder of Zahid Mubarek by Robert Stewart, a racist psychopath with whom he was sharing a cell at Feltham young offender institution, reveals a place beset by failings.
fields.body:
An internal prison service investigation into the murder of Zahid Mubarek by Robert Stewart, a racist psychopath with whom he was sharing a cell at Feltham young offender institution, reveals a place beset by failings.

The report, conducted in October by Ted Butt, a senior investigator, concludes that poor management and communication, outdated contingency plans, a failure in the prisoner screening operation, failures by staff to follow basic operational procedure and a staffing crisis led to clear evidence of the danger Stewart posed to others being missed or ignored.

It concludes that while it would be "inappropriate and unfair" to single out individual officers for criticism, clear evidence of racism and violent tendencies on Stewart's part were missed.

Mr Mubarek, 19, was killed by Stewart, 20, in the early hours of March 21, five hours before he was due to be released after serving 40 days for handling stolen goods. Stewart had been in custody almost constantly for three years and had a history of mental health problems, violence against fellow prisoners and disruption. He was on remand on a charge of sending racially motivated malicious communications, an offence under the Harassment Act. He wrote hundreds of racist letters in which he revered the killers of Stephen Lawrence, fantasised about planting nail bombs and predicted the murder of his cell mate. He had scrawled KKK on a board in his cell. But he was allocated the same cell as an Asian petty thief.

Following Stewart's conviction this month, Mr Mubarek's family asked: what did the prison service know when their son was allocated the same cell as the violent racist who was to kill him? The answer, as outlined in the 48-page report, is that while there was plentiful evidence that Stewart was racist and a danger to himself and others, it was not seen or was ignored by staff making crucial decisions about cell allocation.

The investigation team found there were four key areas where a lack of staff intervention had a direct impact on the decision to allow Robert Stewart to share a cell with Zahid. They were:

There was no effective medical screen ing of Stewart on reception and induction

At no time during his stay at Feltham was Stewart seen by a psychiatrist despite a history of problems. In 1997 at another institution he was sent on three occasions for healthcare assessments coinciding with a period of disruptive and disturbed behaviour, including bouts of self-harm. In November 1999, four months before the attack on Mr Mubarek, he was seen by a registered mental health nurse who concluded he had a "long-standing deep-seated personality disorder" and that he showed "a glaring lack of remorse, feeling, insight, foresight or any other emotion."

The report concludes that there is no effective medical screening system at Feltham and no effective management checks. In addition, there was no reception board.

Specific procedures in relation to the Harassment Act were not carried out on reception

As Stewart had been charged with offences under the Harassment Act 1977 all his correspondence and telephone calls should have been monitored. In addition, details of his offence should have been written on the front page of his prisoner escort record. These safeguards were not in place and Stewart's racist mail went largely unchecked.

One racist letter written by Stewart was intercepted in January but details were not entered into the relevant log and the letter held on his record.

Security information from Stewart's current and past sentences was not considered

"Although there were no current entries on his file, Robert Stewart's past records were substantial," the report states. These included two attempts to escape from custody, repeated damage to cells, stabbing another inmate below the eye, threatening to take another prisoner hostage and he was "strongly suspected" of being involved in the fatal stabbing of another prisoner.

Stewart's full custodial record, including the period of most disruption in 1997, should have been reviewed, the report concludes, as his record while at Feltham contained "little that would have caused alarm."

Away from the specifics of Stewart's case, the report identifies crippling management deficiencies at Feltham. There was an absence of a systematic auditable set of operating instructions, poor communication between staff, no clear way of "cascading" information to staff on the wings and contingency plans were outdated and inaccurate.

Feltham is also infected by a "culture of blame" the report states. And the duty governor on the night of the killing was not sufficiently trained and not compelled to collate and hold incident reports. In one damning passage, the investigation reveals that when police requested the night patrol's report it was said to have been lost.

Mr Butt also concludes that management oversight at Feltham "had been poor for many years" and that the institution is currently struggling under the weight of three separate action plans ordered following inspections; "too many ... to deal with effectively" he writes.

fields.headline: Video
fields.standfirst: Toy Story 2 |  Young Frankenstein | Donald Cammell's Wild Side
fields.trailText: Toy Story 2 | Young Frankenstein | Donald Cammell's Wild Side | Joan of Arc
fields.body:
Toy Story 2 (1999, PG, Disney, VHS/DVD, Retail/Rental)
Even better than the 1995 computer-generated cartoon masterpiece Toy Story, this sequel assumes a familiarity with cowboy Woody, astronaut Buzz Lightyear and the other inhabitants of little Andy's middle-American nursery. Woody is kidnapped by a sinister dealer who's noticed his value as a collector's item and ex-rival Buzz leads a rescue. The result is a movie dazzlingly inventive in its graphic detail that raises complex issues about identity, growing up and mortality. A true family film with jokes about Star Wars kids will love and a touching reference to John Ford's The Searchers for parents.

Young Frankenstein (1974, PG, Fox Video, VHS/DVD, Retail) Mel Brooks's send-up of 1930s horror movies is a mixed, always amiable affair, beautifully shot in monochrome with loving attention to detail. Some of the jokes are pretty crude (which doesn't mean they aren't funny) and there are two outstanding sequences - Gene Wilder and his creature (Peter Boyle) performing 'Puttin' on the Ritz' to impress fellow scientists and a reworking of the monster's famous encounter with the blind hermit (Gene Hackman) from James Whale's The Bride of Frankenstein.

Donald Cammell's Wild Side (1995, 18, Tartan, VHS/DVD, Retail, Rental)
Cammell, one of the truly wild men of British cinema, committed suicide in Hollywood in 1996 shortly after this, his fourth movie, was butchered by producers and sent straight to cable. This restored director's cut isn't in the same league as Performance, his masterpiece, but it has an astonishing central performance from Christopher Walken as an out-of-control financial crook. His chauffeur is a psychotic undercover agent, his Chinese wife (Joan Chen) is having an affair with a lawyer (Anne Heche) who moonlights as a hooker and the quartet play bizarre, often risible power games. It's crazy from start to finish, and the stuff on which cults are founded.

Joan of Arc (1999, 15, Col Tri-Star, VHS/DVD, Retail/Rental)
Luc Besson's English-speaking French movie stars Milla Jovovich as a shrieking, neurotic Maid who looks alternately like Sharon Stone and Leonardo DiCaprio. The French cast is joined by John Malkovich (the Dauphin), Faye Dunaway (Yolande of Aragon) and a self-important Dustin Hoffman as the personification of Joan's conscience. The film is less tedious than Rivette's Jeanne la Pucelle, but a long way behind Dreyer, Bresson and Shaw.

webTitle: 170 die in Austrian ski train blaze

fields.headline: 170 die in Austrian ski train blaze
fields.standfirst:
Kirzsteinhorn ski resort (in German)
Map of the ski slopes in the area
fields.trailText: At least 170 people died today when a train transporting skiers to an Austrian glacier resort caught fire, trapping them inside a burning car.
fields.body:
At least 170 people died today when a train transporting skiers to an Austrian glacier resort caught fire, trapping them inside a burning car.

Fire broke out at 9.30am in a train travelling within the Kirzsteinhorn mountain, about 50 miles south of Vienna. Rescuers were unable to reach the train compartment, but eight survivors managed to escape by smashing a rear window.

The packed compartment was carrying about 180 skiers on their way up to the slopes. Salzburg governor Franz Schausberger has declared a day of mourning in the province after the worst skiing accident since 1976, when 42 people died in Italy after a cable snapped.

All the people on board are believed to have suffocated. Many of the passengers were children.

The train was reported to be around 600 metres inside the mountain when the fire started, hampering rescue efforts. It enters the mountainside after being hoisted up a steep ramp, supported by metal struts. State television said that the massive steel cable pulling the cars up the slope apparently broke before the fire broke out.

Three people in the passenger area of the tunnel also died after inhaling smoke.

"I do not know anything about who is left on board the cable train but it is very difficult, because it is continuing to burn," said Gottfried Gamsjaeger of Salzburg police. "We cannot get access to the carriages. It is still too early to know anything about the nationalities."

It is not yet known whether any Britons were on board the train. A foreign office spokeswoman said they were in contact with the local authorities.

Local mayor Norbert Karlsboeck said that the fire continued burning more than three hours after it broke out, sending smoke spewing out from the bottom of the tunnel. "We do not know anything about the reason for the fire, only that it broke out on the train," Mr Karlsboeck said.

The resort is a popular summer and early winter skiing area. Built in 1974, the cable railway was first the first of its kind to burrow through a mountainside. Experts interviewed on television said it was supposed to be fireproof.

Thirty-nine people died last year in an inferno in the Mont Blanc road tunnel between France and Italy that began after a truck caught fire.

Austrian police have issued an emergency hotline number for anyone concerned they may have relatives on the train. The number is 0043 654 720000.

webTitle: Venetia Stanley, Lady Digby, on her Deathbed, Van Dyck (1633)

fields.headline: Venetia Stanley, Lady Digby, on her Deathbed, Van Dyck (1633)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Anthony Van Dyck (1599-1641), the brilliantly talented painter from Antwerp painter. Recognised as a master while still a teenager, he was appointed court painter to Charles I and painted sensual, self-consciously flattering and seductive portraits of the English aristocracy on the eve of the Civil War.

Subject: Venetia Stanley (1600-33), celebrated for her beauty and gossiped about for her sexually adventurous past, so infamous that when the soldier, scholar and writer Sir Kenelm Digby married her in 1625 it had to be without his family's knowledge. "A wise man, and a lusty," he insisted, "could make an honest woman out of a brothell-house." In another painting of her, commissioned by Digby from Van Dyck, and now in the National Portrait Gallery, she is represented as Chastity crushing Cupid beneath her foot.

Distinguishing features: She looks asleep, head resting in her hand, pale, but with a little pink in her cheeks. The painting is an intimate view, that of her husband about to kiss her. Swathed in blue and white silk, with a rose casually dropped on the sheet, she seems to be dreaming sweetly. Yet when Van Dyck drew her for this portrait, Lady Digby had been dead for more than 24 hours.

It was completely unexpected; a servant found the 33-year-old woman like this. Her distraught husband wanted to freeze the moment, so he summoned a maker of death masks; he also called for Van Dyck, whose portraits were usually far grander performances. Van Dyck sketched her on the spot and finished the painting in a few weeks. The only thing he added, according to Digby, was the rose. He explained that its beauty, just starting to wither, "is a fitte Embleme to express the state her bodie was then in".

Other than that, wrote Digby, who dedicated years to mourning his wife, the painter had captured her appearance precisely. He and his servants found her already cold, but by rubbing her cheeks brought colour to them. Digby certified that Van Dyck "hath altered or added nothing about it".

Portraits as emblems of mortality make regular appearances in the brooding metaphysical poetry of 17th-century England, along with flowers and skulls. According to the metaphysical poets, to have one's picture made was to become all the more aware of the flesh's decay in comparison to the eternally young portrait. "Here take my Picture," wrote John Donne in the same year as this painting. "'Tis like me now, but I dead, 'twill be more/When wee are shadowes both, than 'twas before."

This painting is a contrast to Van Dyck's portraits of cavaliers and their ladies strutting their stuff at court, yet perhaps not completely opposed. The society he painted was about to be convulsed by civil war and, as his subjects tended to be on the losing side, even his most flamboyant portraits have acquired a plaintive air. Here is Charles I on horseback, his head not yet severed from his shoulders. Here are Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart in a double portrait, two cocky cavaliers, both to die in the Civil War.

Inspirations and influences: The genre of the deathbed portrait was popular in Reformation Europe, especially in Britain. Examples include John Souch's Sir Thomas Aston at the Deathbed of his First Wife in Manchester City Art Gallery and David Des Granges's The Saltonstall Family (c 1636-37) in Tate Britain, in which Saltonstall's first wife lies on her deathbed while his second wife and children from both marriages stand before her.

This might seem a primitive kind of painting, yet it persists in modern art. Claude Monet painted his wife as she lay dying at the age of 32; Camille on Her Deathbed (1879) has flowers on the bedclothes just like Van Dyck's portrait of Lady Digby. Monet's obsession with the temporal in art is at its most disturbing in this work, which he never showed in his lifetime.

Where is it? Dulwich Picture Gallery, College Road, London SE21 (020-8693 5254).

fields.headline: The Hoste Arms, King's Lynn
fields.trailText: An award-winning 16th-century inn, almost as busy in winter as it is in summer.
fields.body:
Address: The Green, Burnham Market, King's Lynn, Norfolk PE31 8HD.
Tel: 01328 738777
Web address: http://www.hostearms.co.uk

First impressions: Award-winning 16th-century inn, almost as busy in winter as it is in summer. Heavy beams, foot-wide oak floorboards, log fires. Friendly, informal and very professional service.

What are the rooms like? Twenty-eight in all in the old inn, the converted stables and a modern extension. Some have four-posters.

The bed test: Firm but comfortable. Pillows could have been softer.

The restaurant: The best local ingredients, simply cooked with occasional Mediterranean and south-east Asian flourishes. Six local oysters £5.75, English lamb £13.95. Plenty for vegetarians. Very reasonable winelist. Local kippers and smoked haddock for breakfast. Hard to imagine eating better anywhere in Norfolk.

What is there to see within walking distance? In summer, if you're lucky, somewhere to park. At any time of year, you are unlikely to hear many Norfolk accents. Burnham Market is seriously upmarket, full of expensive weekend and retirement homes. Forty-five shops, all privately-owned, particularly good for food, clothes and second-hand books.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? One of the most beautiful and unspoilt stretches of coastline in England. Vast skies, wildfowl, windmills, salt marshes, snaking estuaries, deserted beaches, very few ugly houses. You can play golf at the Royal West Norfolk, Brancaster (01485 210616), sail (01485 210236), ride (01328 820796) or join Ray Kinber's bird-watching expeditions (01485 210265).

How much a night? Two-night weekend breaks from £90pp B&B. Midweek two-night breaks from £75 including dinner.

Would you go back? Definitely.

webTitle: Nato tensions delay plans for EU force

fields.headline: Nato tensions delay plans for EU force
fields.standfirst: Insiders warn of French agenda to distance Europe from alliance
fields.trailText: Tensions between France and Nato and bitter opposition from Turkey are holding up ambitious plans for the EU to develop a common European defence force, diplomats say.
fields.body:
Tensions between France and Nato and bitter opposition from Turkey are holding up ambitious plans for the EU to develop a common European defence force, diplomats say.

With a vital agreement between the EU and the western alliance due to be signed at a summit next month in Nice, unresolved problems over relations between the two sides are piling up.

British officials said that they fear a sudden attempt by Jacques Chirac, the French president, to push EU defence too far away from Nato - fuelling longstanding anxiety in London and Washington that the alliance could be weakened.

France, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, has long been ambivalent about its role in Nato.

Alexander Vershbow, the US ambassador to Nato, warned of "new political frictions in the transatlantic relationship" if the EU creates a planning unit for its fledgling defence policy.

"The French agenda is to minimise Nato's input and there are anxieties about this," said one well-placed diplomat.

Talks in Brussels on Thursday between the EU's security policy committee and Nato ambassadors failed to finalise an agreement for Nice, though the secretary-general, Lord Robertson, denied he had warned Tony Blair that the project was heading for crisis.

Pioneered jointly by Britain and France, plans for EU defence have been developing quietly since 1998, but they were given a boost by the Kosovo crisis, which highlighted the weakness of Europe's military compared with that of the US.

At last December's summit in Helsinki, EU leaders pledged to build a 60,000-strong rapid reaction force by 2003. The force would be deployed if Nato as a whole did not wish to get involved in a new crisis in, for example, the Balkans or Africa.

Officials involved in negotiations complain that France has been trying to keep Nato "at arm's length" and worry that the Nice summit could adopt proposals leading to the sort of duplication the alliance insists must be avoided.

Most European members of Nato want the EU to have automatic access to alliance planning - based at Mons, Belgium - in order to avoid the danger that Brussels will create its own structures.

Lord Robertson said after Thursday's meeting that one of the key precepts of the defence effort was to ensure that there would be "no unnecessary duplication".

But serious disagreements revolve around how tightly the EU should be locked into Nato in return for being able to borrow military assets such as specialist aircraft and intelligence capabilities.

An important test comes later this month when EU defence ministers meet to announce their national contributions to the reaction force. After Nice there are plans for the first ever joint meeting of foreign ministers from the EU and Nato.

Washington backs the goal of a European security and defence identity but it has repeatedly warned the EU not to decouple transatlantic ties or discriminate against non-EU Nato allies.

Of these the most important is Turkey, always sensitive about its poor relationship with Europe, which has been blocking EU requests for sensitive Nato documents.

But one idea now under consideration is to "sweeten" the Turks by asking them to host one of the three permanent military headquarters planned for the future European force.

"People are well aware that deadlines are looming and that there is still a lot of work to be done," one alliance official said last night.

Lord Robertson said after Thursday's meeting that one of the key precepts of the defence effort was to ensure that there would be "no unnecessary duplication". But serious disagreements revolve around how tightly the EU should be locked into Nato in return for being able to borrow military assets such as specialist aircraft and intelligence capabilities. An important test comes later this month when EU defence ministers meet to announce their national contributions to the reaction force. After Nice there are plans for the first ever joint meeting of foreign ministers from the EU and Nato. Washington backs the goal of a European security and defence identity but it has repeatedly warned the EU not to decouple transatlantic ties or discriminate against non-EU Nato allies. Of these the most important is Turkey, always sensitive about its poor relationship with Europe, which has been blocking EU requests for sensitive Nato documents. But one idea now under consideration is to "sweeten" the Turks by asking them to host one of the three permanent military headquarters planned for the future European force. "People are well aware that deadlines are looming and that there is still a lot of work to be done," one alliance official said last night.

webTitle: London or bust:  protesters head south

fields.headline: 'I want 26p off a litre of fuel. We'll do this again and again until Blair gets the message'
fields.standfirst:
London or bust: protesters head south
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Albert Storey was bringing up the rear of the convoy in a 38 tonne powder tanker. He was doing an easy 20mph past flooded fields down the A1(M) to Wetherby, with two meat pies, two sausage butties, a bacon roll and two cans of Coke for sustenance.
fields.body:
Albert Storey was bringing up the rear of the convoy in a 38 tonne powder tanker. He was doing an easy 20mph past flooded fields down the A1(M) to Wetherby, with two meat pies, two sausage butties, a bacon roll and two cans of Coke for sustenance.

He wore aviator shades in the sunshine. "It's a beautiful day for it, like," he said.

Mr Storey, known to his fellow truckers as The Wanderer, had got up at 5.30am to leave Maryport, in Cumbria, in time to join the protesters at Birtley ruck stop, in Tyneside.

He had driven 70 miles to reach the convoy, and another 100 miles in the go-slow, including one loop round Newcastle at 5mph. Then he headed south on the A1(M) behind 30 lorries at 25mph. He had a union flag in his windscreen, emblazoned with the message: "United we stand against Blair and Brown".

Mr Storey, 48, has been in haulage for 26 years. He had never personally suffered from high fuel prices except in his own car. His boss asked him to join the convoy on full pay on Friday but without wages on Saturday.

"I am here because it needs doing. I want 28p a litre off fuel. I used to vote Labour, but not anymore."

All was going well till he hit Pontefract at 3.25pm. Mr Storey was following his mate, Johnny - "the man who would get us lost in his own front drive". Johnny had taken a wrong turning two minutes after the convoy had set off, collided with a Range Rover and got himself on the news as the first accident. Suddenly Mr Storey realised he was behind Johnny on the M62. They had broken off from the convoy and were lost.

But this time, it wasn't Johnny's fault, said Mr Storey. It was the police. The convoy was supposed to come off at Wetherby, but all the exits on the A1 were sealed by officers on motorcycles or vans full of riot police. The police were setting the speed and would prosecute anyone who did not drive at an even pace. They were speeding up the convoy and speed meant a collapse of the plan.

"Christ, we're going like a bloody rocket," said Mr Storey over the CB radio, panicking. "No-one knows where we're going. It's all gone out the window, like."

The drivers only got back on track after calling each other on mobile phones.

Earlier in the day - at about 1.45pm, just south of Gateshead - the hauliers reached a consensus, via radio: Brynle Williams was "an arse". The Welsh farmer had gone on Radio 4 to tell hauliers to call the convoy off. "I wonder who has been at him," asked Mr Storey.

By 2pm, it was "London or bust" over the CB radio. No-one was worried that Tony Blair had said no more concessions. "We will just have to do this again and again until he gets the message," said Mr Storey.

Nor were the drivers put off by the prospect of police blocking off London. "Aha, the government is panicking," said Mr Storey. "We knew they would. Our barristers will sort it out."

Morale was at a peak. "We feel happy. We feel prosperous," said Mr Storey.

Public support in the centre of Newcastle and down the A1 had been very high. Children came to the bottom of playgrounds to shout "lower fuel prices". Thirty lorries grew to 50 as truckers on the motorway joined the protest.

"I ain't going home, I'm joining. My missus is all for it," came a message via radio. The protesters were all men, bar a haulier's wife and 12-year-old daughter, and a Volvo crammed with farmers' wives waving union flags. By 4.30pm it was all over, at Ferrybridge services. There was relief at not having to spend the night at a Wetherby airfield, as had been feared.

"If we were on an airfield, how were we going to get a pint?" asked one driver.

webTitle: Police plan London exclusion zone for protesters

fields.headline: Police plan London exclusion zone as fuel protest divisions grow
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Police last night revealed plans to create a tightly monitored exclusion zone around London to prevent militant fuel protesters from using their lorries to disrupt traffic flows in the capital next week.
fields.body:
Police last night revealed plans to create a tightly monitored exclusion zone around London to prevent militant fuel protesters from using their lorries to disrupt traffic flows in the capital next week.

Although senior officers insist the government has not bullied them into taking tougher action against the protesters, forces yesterday revealed they intended to be much firmer in their efforts to prevent a repetition of the unexpected chaos caused by September's demonstrations.

Some Labour MPs believe the police are exceeding their powers. But the home secretary, Jack Straw, is satisfied that, while the right to stage a peaceful march and demonstration must be upheld, that does not extend to the major disruption of traffic by "slow spontaneous convoys" of heavy lorries, which would amount to a breach of public order.

As the police tightened their grip, there were further signs of division within the protesters' ranks in the wake of the £2.5bn worth of concessions announced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in his pre-budget report. Tony Blair yesterday described them as being "as much as we responsibly can" do to appease the protesters.

The north Wales farmer Brynle Williams, a key figure in the first demonstrations, appealed for this weekend's convoy protest of lorries driving southwards to London to be called off in favour of lobbying ministers directly. "A lot of doors have been opened this past week, an awful lot of doors," he said.

In remarks addressed to David Handley, the more militant leader of the People's Fuel Lobby, Mr Williams said: "What David is doing he is doing, I believe, for, he believes, the right motives. But at the moment I think it is maybe not quite the thing to do, this slow march to London."

Such talk was dismissed by protesters who reacted to the midday announcement by the Metropolitan police by saying it would only make their determination stronger. "If that is the way the police want to do it they can, but this is another nail in the coffin of the police state," said the PFL's convoy leader, Andrew Spence.

With regional police forces closely monitoring the convoy yesterday it stopped for the night at Ferrybridge on the A1 near Leeds.

A 50mph minimum speed limit has been imposed on lorries driving to London. Those that make it will be stopped at checkpoints set up on the main arteries into the city, some as far out as the M25, and drivers will be asked to leave their vehicles in special parking bays and demonstrate on foot if they wish.

Lorry drivers will be asked for ID and proof of where they are going and why. If that cannot be provided, the driver will be asked to leave his vehicle in a lorry park close by and continue on public transport.

Those that refuse could be arrested under the provisions of the Public Order Act, which gives the police power to intervene when public safety might be at risk, and which was passed in the wake of police interference with striking miners' protests in 1984-85. Officers with HGV licences will be available to drive vehicles to police compounds if necessary.

The Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, has further powers available in the 1839 directives of the Metropolitan Police Act. This allows him to keep the area of Westminster, particularly around the houses of parliament, free of obstruction while the Commons and Lords are sitting. All leave for Met traffic officers has been cancelled.

Mr Stevens said that the threat posed by dissident republican terrorists opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process also justified barring large numbers of lorries from the capital on Tuesday. Car or lorry bombs could be driven into London by terrorists posing as protesters, he said.

"We are on a high state of alert at the moment. We have to be absolutely sure that we do not allow certain people in [to] the centre of London. We are not prepared for London to be brought to a standstill."

Police were in constant communication with the protesters and they have established a cordial working relationship, Sir John claimed. Talk of 500,000 marchers from Hyde Park to Battersea Park - a mile west of the Commons - on Tuesday is regarded as wildly exaggerated because the Treasury's concessions have helped defuse public support, as has the wider disruption of road and rail by floods and repairs.

Tony Burden, who sits on the government's civil contingencies committee as president of Association of Chief Police Officers, said: "Fifty miles an hour is a reasonable speed to maintain on a motorway. Any vehicle attempting to drive too slowly will be removed from the road by the police. We looked at the impact caused by the slow convoys in September and the danger they caused to other motorists rubber necking to see what was going on. Anyone who snubs the police and snubs the law will face action."

Speaking at a nursing conference in Brighton yesterday, Mr Blair said: "We did what we responsibly could to help motorists and hauliers on Wednesday [Mr Brown's statement] but we did it in a way that did not put at risk either economic stability - which helps businesses and our mortgages - or our programme of investment.

"We have chosen the path of investment. And I say to the fuel protesters and others: we understand your concerns, we are happy to carry on in dialogue with you, but we have done as much as we responsibly can."

fields.headline: Motorists benefit as Brown goes green
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: the Budget
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The Chancellor has tried to curry favour with disgruntled motorists with a package of fuel and excise duty cuts, but car owners will have to wait for the benefits to kick in.
fields.body:
The Chancellor has tried to curry favour with disgruntled motorists with a package of fuel and excise duty cuts, but car owners will have to wait for the benefits to kick in.

Mr Brown announced 3p a litre off the duty on the little-known ultra low sulphur petrol (ULSP), comprising 2p in the next budget, on top of a 1p per litre cut introduced last month. The AA calculates that the tax cut should see a Mondeo driver, doing an average 10,000 miles a year, paying £22.51 less a year on fuel, while a Fiesta driver will save £24.44.

But so far only a third of the country's filling stations sell ULSP and there are concerns that oil companies may be slow to make it more widely available or to pass on the tax cut .

ULSP can be used in any car that already uses standard unleaded petrol and produces less sulphur dioxide. Supporters claim it improves fuel efficiency too.

The Chancellor says ULSP will be available everywhere by the time of his spring Budget, when the full duty cut becomes effective. In fact, you may already have been filling up your tank with ULSP unwittingly. Esso, for example, says it is already selling ULSP in three-quarters of its filling stations, but pumps are labelled as unleaded. BP says ULSP is on sale at 60% of its 1,500 filling stations but is promoted as "cleaner unleaded" fuel. At Sainsbury's, where ULSP is available in 117 of its 220 stations, the fuel is branded "city petrol".

The Treasury says it expects oil companies to pass on the 3p cut to consumers but it cannot guarantee they will do so.

The Petrol Retailers' Association is warning that the oil companies could pocket the tax cut. The oil companies are concerned at the processing costs involved and at many filling stations ULSP has been selling at a 2p per litre premium over regular petrol.

In another concession, a further 5.4m car owners will pay £55 a year less for their vehicle excise duty as the Chancellor said he would extend the £100 rate to small cars with engines of 1200cc to 1500cc. The move will benefit drivers of mid-range cars such as the Ford Focus, VW Golf, Vauxhall Astra and Rover 214.

The reduction takes effect from next year's budget, but the chancellor said he wants to backdate the savings to November 1. In previous occasions, the DVLA has sent out refunds or credit notes to eligible car-owners to be used against the purchase of the next tax disc. However, it is unlikely that motorists will receive any refunds before next July's finance bill.

webTitle: TV ads 'have little effect' on children

fields.headline: TV ads 'have little effect' on children
fields.standfirst:
Study claims peer pressure and irresponsible parenting are more likely to influence children's patterns of consumption

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Study claims peer pressure and irresponsible parenting are more likely to influence children's patterns of consumption.
fields.body:
Television advertising has little influence on children's real desire for consumer products and cannot provoke irresistible pester power against parents, according to new research.

After analysing 20 international studies on children as consumers, Adrian Furnham, professor of psychology at University College, London, said there was no evidence to support calls for stricter controls on the advertising of sweets, toys, music and other goods aimed at children.

"It is not advertising that harms children, but irresponsible parenting," he said in a pamphlet for the Social Affairs Unit, a free market thinktank.

"Parents have nothing to fear from advertising. Children are far more sophisticated consumers than popularly imagined. There is no respectable intellectual argument for the view that advertising alone creates false wants and parental conflicts."

The findings may surprise parents who have been persistently badgered by children to buy products which they have seen promoted in multi-million-pound advertising campaigns.

Mary MacLeod, chief executive of the National Family and Parenting Institute, said many European countries had controls on advertising directed at children under 12.

"Peer pressure is enormous on children. We hear from parents telling us of the pressure they feel that their children might be made to feel left out if they don't have something. More research is needed on this," she said.

Professor Furnham's analysis is likely to be used by the advertising industry to resist pressure for Europe-wide controls over campaigns directed at children after Sweden takes over the EU presidency in January. The Independent Television Commission is also reviewing its code of advertising standards after acknowledging that "minors do not always have the knowledge or experience to make reasoned decisions for themselves".

Professor Furnham said such intervention was based on a myth that advertisers could create unnatural wants in children, leading to pester power and conflict with parents.

"There is no esoteric knowledge which advertisers can somehow employ to create, out of nowhere, demands in children.

"When children are as young as three they can tell ads from programmes and by the time they are seven they realise that advertisements can mislead," he said.

"Television advertisements are far less intrusive upon children's lives than is imagined. German data shows children between three and 13 spend only 1.4% of their waking time watching television advertisements.

"Peer influences and parenting styles are massively more influential in determining children's wants and patterns of consumption than advertising," he said.

The evidence showed authoritative parenting styles - laying down rules and expectations, but explaining decisions and valuing the child's point of view - were more likely to nurture responsibility in children. This was better than authoritarian or permissive parenting styles.

"Agreeing rules about pocket money and what it should and should not pay for helps turn children into responsible consumers. Banning advertising delays a child's understanding and decision making," Professor Furnham said.

Helen Seaford, head of planning and development at the Children's Society, said the professor's earlier work showed that children's behaviour was influenced by various factors, including peer pressure, parenting and TV advertising.

"Disentangling the impact of each is difficult. It is not until children are 12 that their understanding of advertising is on a par with that of adults," she said.

"Children in the UK are subject to more advertising than those in other European countries. They watch 18,000 ads a year."

webTitle: An ABC guide to making up the right excuses

fields.headline: An ABC guide to making up the right excuses
fields.trailText: Moving on up
fields.body:
A. Loop hole

The word "excuse" associates more naturally with adjectives such as flimsy and pathetic rather than good. Trying to justify something you did or didn't do

has an "it wasn't my fault" subtext which casts a shadow over the rest of what you are saying. In busy work environments there's little room for the habitually unreliable. However creative and amusing your explanations are, they put you at risk of being left out of the loop.

B. Say sorry

So, what should you do when faced with accounting for something that really was beyond your control without appearing weak and snivelly? De-personalise the situation by just stating facts, not apportioning blame. Keep it short: the less you say and more likely others are to believe you. Apology puts you in a stronger position than denial, particularly if coupled with the offer to help put things right. webTitle: How to... position yourself for promotion

fields.headline: How to... position yourself for promotion
fields.standfirst: Are you a a cut above the usual suspects?
fields.trailText: Are you a a cut above the usual suspects?
fields.body:
In the old days of office life, the route to promotion was simple. You worked long hours, agreed to any and all management suggestions, laughed at the boss's jokes and talked in loud tones about "being with the company for life". But nowadays, with the workplace becoming increasingly idiosyncratic and fractured, the factors that contribute to being promoted can differ hugely between industries, offices and individual managers.

"For me, it's enthusiasm for the job that really counts," says Bill Vestey, general manager of corporate affairs at Sony. "If there were two candidates up for a promotion and they were both equally competent and experienced, I would give the job to the one who was most enthusiastic about the company and their position in it."

Jo Johnson, director of BGB & Associates, a travel and leisure PR company, also believes in the importance of enthusiasm, particularly if it translates into a willingness to make every effort. "In our business we obviously do everything we can for our clients, who are basically customers," she says, "but I tend to be impressed by people who make that much effort for everyone - clients, colleagues or other business partners that we work with."

Obviously there are some common factors across all industries when it comes to promoting someone - relevant experience, qualifications, positive attitude and dedication to the job. But even these are changing. "The idea that working long hours will increase your chances of promotion isn't necessarily true any more," says Richard Wilson, business policy executive at the Institute of Directors. "In some industries it will - in many finance houses and law firms, long hours are expected if you want to get on. But in other industries - IT, some areas of the media, manufacturing - there is the feeling that it's not good to always be the office and that someone who balances a dedication to their job with a full home life is probably the best bet."

John Bailey, a development adviser at KPMG, agrees. "What is important is that the job is done, and done well - and we would probably be more impressed with someone that was doing that and working normal hours, than someone who was in the office evenings and weekends."

John also dismisses the idea that if you want to get promoted, you should never say no to anything. "We expect flexibility from our staff and we do ask people to move around, to work in different areas. But if someone said no, or said they really didn't want to move we certainly wouldn't hold it against them; we'd try to effect a compromise.

"I think companies are increasingly respectful of people's private lives - and we certainly don't expect employees to put their job first, whatever the cost."

In order to stand the best chance of being promoted, it is vital to understand your boss and the way your office works. If he or she is constantly looking to you for ideas and asking you for your opinions, then it's important to work on your own initiative and be creative. This is especially relevant in e-commerce businesses. "Dotcom companies are very new and far less hierarchical than conventional companies," says Nick Robertson, MD of AsSeenOnScreen.com, a site which sells products seen in films and TV programmes. "It's hard to employ people with experience, because it's such a new industry, so you rely on people to be self-starters and to come up with ideas which they will then go and research."

According to Nick, the key factors if succeeding in a dotcom company are confidence and creativity. "I am impressed by people who come to me - whether it's the receptionist or the marketing manager - with ways to develop the company and with interesting thoughts about new strategies. Someone who waits to be told what to do, even if they do the job well, is not going to be on my promotion list."

Increasingly, employers seem to value honesty in their staff; as time becomes an ever more valuable commodity, managers think more highly of those who admit to problems than those who stay quiet and allow them to get out of hand. "I am impressed by openness," says Jo Johnson. "If someone is having difficulties with an area of the job and they come to me and talk about it, I totally respect that and it allows me to deal with the situation before it becomes serious.

Honesty, creativity, confidence, enthusiasm - they may not be what is traditionally thought of as the qualities most likely to get you up the career ladder. But in the 21st century these are what managers are looking for in the people they want to promote.

If you don't remember anything else...

To position yourself for promotion, you have to understand your company and your boss. Take time to observe how he or she works, what impresses them and what doesn't, and what the attitudes, objective and ideals of the company are.

webTitle: Heard the one about office gossip?

fields.headline: Heard the one about office gossip?
fields.standfirst: Indulge in the 'free exchange of ideas'
fields.trailText: Indulge in the 'free exchange of ideas'
fields.body:
Thinking of applying for a new job? Can't stand your boss? Caught the managing director in a compromising position at the office Christmas party? Don't tell anyone. If you do, the chances are the story will spread as quickly as the "news" about what Leonardo di Caprio got up to with both Appleton sisters in the bathroom at The Beach premiere party. (If you don't know what I'm talking about, far be it from me to perpetuate gossip).

Britain's employees, it seems, are not to be trusted. A recent survey by recruitment consultant Office Angels discovered that office

workers are incapable of keeping a secret. More than 90% of employees admitted they'd shared secrets after being specifically asked not to. And, if you need proof of the old adage that "gossip spreads like wildfire", 77% had passed the gossip on to at least two other people within the same working day.

The survey of 1,500 office workers found that two thirds of us can't keep our traps shut about our colleagues' office frustrations, promotions and pay rises or new job applications. And we're almost certain to gossip about personal information, such as relationships, health or money.

So, why can't we keep our lips sealed when we're asked to? Because, says psychologist Sandi Mann of the University of Central Lancashire, "Knowledge is power. But, unlike children who can get away with saying: 'I've got a secret and I'm not going to tell you what it is', adults are impotent unless they pass the knowledge on."

There's no thrill in being the first to know something if no-one else knows what it is. Indeed, in the survey 36% of people admitted they craved the attention associated with revealing information and a devious one in five used their new found knowledge as a means to demonstrate power.

A foolish 1 in 10 just couldn't help themselves - the secret slipped out "by accident".

Most of us, with the exception of newspaper gossip columnists, follow a misguided "moral" code. When we pass on a secret we think it doesn't count if we say: "You mustn't tell anyone else this." As Sandi Mann explains: "People feel

they're justified because they perceive that the information is still confidential,"

Kissing and telling has brought down many an MP, the odd government and - very nearly - the president of the United States. It can also be detrimental to your career. Two out of three bosses questioned in the survey say they'll never again trust an employee who discloses company secrets. And 4% have sacked staff with verbal diarrhoea.

Of course, bosses can use the gossip grapevine to their advantage too. John (not his real name) used to work as creative director at a large publishing company. He says that he was able to manipulate his slippery-tongued staff by starting rumours which he knew would leak out: "If I wanted my team to work harder, I might tell a particularly big-mouthed member that someone wasn't pulling their weight and could be taken off a project. Within hours, I could be certain that everybody would become more conscientious. It was sneaky, but far more productive than calling a meeting and directly telling people to knuckle down.

"And if I had suspicions that someone in my team wasn't to be trusted, I'd confide some untrue information to them - and make them swear not to tell. If it got out, I'd know that my instincts were correct."

No-one is immune to gossip. What's important is how you play the game. "You have to be very careful," warns Angela Baron, an adviser at the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development. "Spiteful or sexual remarks can border on bullying or harassment. If something is offensive, you'd be wise not to pass it on or you might risk being disciplined. Likewise, you should never ever discuss trade secrets or team developments, especially with clients. If you gossip about confidential data, you might be contravening the data protection legislation or rights to privacy under the new Human Rights Act."

Sandi Mann says there's no doubt we find out more from the grapevine than through formal means: "Everybody knows this, which is why we listen to gossip. My advice is: don't spread gossip, but don't ignore it either. If you refuse to listen to it, you might miss out on useful information."

If, for example, you've found out your boss is a huge Barry Manilow fan, it won't do your promotional prospects any harm if you start humming Cococabana as you pass her (well it must be, mustn't it?) desk. Heard about an impending merger? It might be true, so you can start looking around for another job in plenty of time.

What if you've let an entire pride of lions out of the bag? Can you salvage your reputation and redeem yourself? It depends on the seriousness of the secret you let slip - and on the forgiving nature of the person whose confidence you betrayed. "You could go to them and apologise," suggests Sandi Mann. "They might be grateful for your honesty and forgive you. Then again, they might fire you.

"Alternatively - and this is more risky - you could send out a contrary rumour to diffuse your original rumour." Told everyone your boss is having an affair? Actually, the woman you saw him with is his wife; she's just lost lots of weight and was wearing a blonde wig.

According to Angela Baron, gossip shouldn't be banned because it plays such an important role in organisations: "Employers are well aware that allowing employees to chat to each other breeds new ideas. The free exchange of ideas should be encouraged, but gossip can be damaging. It's important that organisations put frameworks in place so people understand what the limits are and what is confidential, but creativity is given free reign."

fields.headline: Help: My enthusiasm has vanished!
fields.standfirst: Two years ago I was thrilled to get this great job with a good employer. But now if I'm honest I'm bored with it. All the excitement has gone. It's just become routine.  PF, researcher, Cardiff
fields.trailText: Two years ago I was thrilled to get this great job with a good employer. But now if I'm honest I'm bored with it. All the excitement has gone. It's just become routine. PF, researcher, Cardiff
fields.body:
One of the reasons we survive at all is our ability to adapt. It doesn't take long to get used to both the horrible and the wonderful and accept either as the norm. Once a situation loses its power to excite, it's tempting to look elsewhere.

The danger with that is that you give up something extraordinarily good and only realise its value in retrospect.

But once a job goes stale there is little point in staying just because it once represented the pinnacle of your ambitions. For a quick reality check imagine a scenario where you've left and are watching someone else doing your work. Do you feel relieved or devastated?

You've obviously moved on in the last two years and are now more confident and capable. Has the job moved with you? What was challenging when you first started is unlikely to stretch you now. Talk it over with your boss.

Good employers should not to be abandoned lightly.

Don't use the word "bored" or even hint at it. Be positive about how you see your career developing and the benefits that could bring to all.

Have lots of suggestions for projects you could devise and new skills you'd like to master. You know what would make you feel enthusiastic again, so go and get it.

fields.headline: Bombing in Iraq an 'undeclared war'
fields.standfirst:
Lib Dems accuse MoD of misusing no-fly zones

Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The government was accused yesterday of conducting an undeclared war against Iraq as new figures showed that RAF planes have been dropping an average of four tonnes of bombs a month on the country.
fields.body:
The government was accused yesterday of conducting an undeclared war against Iraq as new figures showed that RAF planes have been dropping an average of four tonnes of bombs a month on the country.

Well over 100 bombs - 84 tonnes of weapons - have been dropped on southern Iraq by British aircraft since operation Desert Fox in December 1998. This compares with 2.4 tonnes over the previous six years.

The figures were provided by the Ministry of Defence to Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman. "The continuing operations seem to be more designed to degrade Saddam Hussein's air defence systems than to fulfil the role of humanitarian protection," he said last night.

He described the legal justification for the no-fly zone policing campaign, which has cost the MoD over £800m, as "doubtful to say the least". Mr Campbell also called for the lifting of all non-military sanctions against Iraq.

His remarks, coming at a time when sanctions against Iraq are crumbling fast, are particularly significant since Mr Campbell is close to the Foreign Office establishment. There are many in the FO who believe that the government's policy towards Iraq is unsustainable.

The vast majority of bombs - 450 tonnes since December 1998 - have been dropped by US aircraft which police no fly zones over northern and southern Iraq.

On all the occasions RAF and US planes have dropped bombs on southern Iraq in recent months they have targeted Iraqi air defence systems. Yet Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, continues to insist that the purpose of the no-fly zones is entirely humanitarian.

The zones are not backed up by any UN security council resolution and do not include flights by Iraqi helicopters. Iraq is now flying civilian aircraft over the zones.

France and Russia, who are on the security council, recently participated in the Baghdad trade fair.

"The sanctions regime is being steadily eroded, aided by certain members of the security council," Mr Campbell said. "If this persists, the authority of the security council and the United Nations will be irretrievably damaged."

He said that sanctions "contribute nothing to the policy of containment. They make no difference to Saddam Hussein or his brutality. They damage the lives of the ordinary people of Iraq. They hand Saddam Hussein a gratuitous propaganda advantage. It is time they went."

He added: "Ten years of sanctions have driven the Iraqi people into poverty, malnutrition and ignominy and have done nothing to bring Saddam Hussein to heel. Saddam Hussein exploits the existence of sanctions, and he uses them as an excuse. They are his justification for brutality and privations he has imposed on his own people."

In Arab capitals, Mr Campbell said, "there is much anxiety and a belief that the Iraqi people have suffered as much as they need to. The Iraqi people are the oppressed not the oppressors. The elite whose survival depends on Saddam are left untouched".

 A group of British politicians has flown to Iraq in a defiant gesture aimed at ending the sanctions.

They include the Labour MP for Glasgow Kelvin, George Galloway, the Labour peer Lord Rea, and Father Noel Barry, a former press secretary to Cardinal Thomas Winning, head of the Catholic church in Scotland.

webTitle: Restaurants: Gresslins, Angel Inn, YMing, Gifto's Lahore Karah and Gidleigh Park

fields.headline: Gresslins, Angel Inn, YMing, Gifto's Lahore Karah and Gidleigh Park
fields.standfirst: Food editor Matthew Fort revisits some of his past conquests
fields.trailText: Food editor Matthew Fort revisits some of his past conquests.
fields.body:
GRESSLINS 15.5/20
Tel: 020-7794 8386.
Address: 13 Heath Street, London NW3.
Food Modern European.
Price: £14.95-£28 a head without wine.

On its way to becoming a veteran of the Hampstead restaurant scene, which doesn't have many veterans of quality. Revamped decoration has given the place more personality. The food always has it - pretty much finger-on-the-pulse stuff, but with a serious knack behind it. Modern European includes nods to the east (raw fish), south (couscous), west (salsa) and north (strudel). But assured handling of ingredients and sound technique means that the flavours come out singing in unison rather than a gustatory cacophony.

ANGEL INN 15/20
Tel: 01756 730263.
Address: Hetton, North Yorkshire.
Food: British European.
Price: £11-£29.50 a head without wine.

There you are, pedalling (or striding) up hill and down dale, particularly up hill, and at the top of a particularly tiresome hill you happen across the Angel Inn; that's when you know what happiness is. Happiness comes in the shape of a fine old building with lots of snug rooms with beams and fires in season; of cheerful and kindly service; of spot-on Black Sheep bitter and a prodigious wine list, some of the classier numbers being sold by the glass; and food which usually combines top-class local ingredients, a ray or two of Mediterranean sunshine with a Yorkshireman's sense of proportion.

YMING 15/20
Tel 020-7734 2721.
Address: 35-36 Greek Street, London W1.
Food: Northern Chinese.
Price: £10-£25 a head without wine.

A bit of an unsung hero of the Chinese restaurant world. Heroine to be exact, for the proprietor and guiding spirit of the coolly elegant Yming is the charmingly elegant Christine Yau, the moving force behind the school of Chinese cookery recently set up at Westminster College. Yming under her hand (there was a short and unhappy interregnum) has devoted itself to some of the less well-known corners of Chinese cooking with exemplary consistency, and consistently exemplary results. Some of the dishes show the high seasoning characteristic of Northern Chinese cooking, and there are some unusual dishes involving long, slow cooking (belly pork; lamb). The service is distinctly not of the bang-it-down-in-front-of-you school we know and love, and the wine list makes for some interesting food/wine matching games.

GIFTO'S LAHORE KARAHI 13/20
Tel: 020-8813 8669.
Address: 162-164 The Broadway, Southall, Middlesex. Food: Indian.
Price: £7-£14 a head without wine.

Tasteful it ain't. Tasty, certainly, but the frontage of Gifto's is an assault on the eyeballs, and things don't get any easier when you walk in. Lighting seems specifically designed to show up every wrinkle, bag, nip and tuck in brilliant detail. But never mind that. We're here for the food not the fantasy, as are hundreds of others. Karahi is a method of cooking that involves impaling seasoned meats on flat skewers like broad swords and grilling them. These masterpieces of the barbecuer's art are served with equally spectacularly good breads. And that's it. Well, that's karahi for you, but it is not the limit of Gifto's range by any means. They also do ace puris, a splendid sag gosht (lamb curry) and karela gosht (lamb with bitter melon). Disarmingly cheerful service. Always busy.

GIDLEIGH PARK 18.5/20
Tel: 01647 432367.
Address: Chagford, Devon.
Food: Modern French haute cuisine.
Price: £24-£67.50 per head without wine.

Luxury incarnate. Cosseting on an Olympian scale. A place to remove all the care from your shoulders (except for the bill, of course). The whole place runs with smooth, or highly tuned, power which is delicately geared to individual sensitivities - more Bentley Mulsanne than Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow. And Michael Caines's cooking is of a piece. His years at Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons and Jamin show in the fabulous technical skill with which he holds a multitude of ingredients in precise relationships with lightness, intensity and clarity. Paradoxically, perhaps, the results are rich in sensation, but infinitely rewarding. Wine list of legendary proportions. Not cheap, but neither is a trip to watch Manchester United these days, and meals last longer than a game of two halves.

On its way to becoming a veteran of the Hampstead restaurant scene, which doesn't have many veterans of quality. Revamped decoration has given the place more personality. Address: Hetton, North Yorkshire. Food: British European. Price: £11-£29.50 a head without wine. fields.headline: Frog leap
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I couldn't find out from any amphibian handbook if frogs went through a form of divorce, or if in fact they stayed faithful to the same partner
fields.body:
Tuesday, October 31, 2000. Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Pandora's weekend home, Lock Keepers Cottage, on the banks of the river Severn has been flooded out. She had to be rescued by a fireman in a Canadian canoe. The rescue was filmed by Midlands Today. Apparently, she and a 19-year-old youth called "Scottish Sandy" had been marooned for a day and a night in Pandora's bedroom. According to her, Sandy had been stacking sandbags against her doorstep when the torrent overtook them and they were forced to flee upstairs. When asked by Julia Snoddy, Midlands Today's weather correspondent, why Pandora had not alerted the emergency services earlier, the controversial MP replied, "I knew how busy they were and did not want to add to their workload."

Asked to describe her ordeal she said, "It was hell, I ran out of Marlboro Lights and I'd left my Prada bag on the sitting-room floor. It has been totally ruined by the floodwater. She told Ms Snoddy that she would be pressing Mr Prescott, the flood supremo, for financial assistance towards flood defences in the Severn-Trent area. "It is time our rivers were lined with concrete," she said. "It would be terribly sad to lose the bullrushes and the wildlifey things, but we are living in a new era and cannot afford to be sentimental about nature."

She pointed out that various retail outlets could be built on the concrete banks of the Severn: "Starbucks coffee shops would bring cappuccino to our neglected countryside areas," she said. Pandora has always hated the countryside: on our nature rambles with the school, she would wear dark glasses saying, "All this green makes me utterly, utterly sick." Lock Keepers Cottage was furnished in New York style. The blinds were kept permanently down. In fact, they were nailed to the sills.

I sincerely hope that Pandora does not achieve her ambition and become the first female Labour prime minister. During many private conversations with her, she has confided in me that she would be quite happy to see the fens covered in decking, Dartmoor replaced with Astroturf and the Lake District equipped with escalators to make it easier for the disabled. My mother claims that Pandora was only joking, but I'm convinced that her contempt for the English language is genuine.

Wednesday, November 1, 2000

My literary agent, Brick Eagleburger (who has failed to sell any of my novels, television series, radio plays or epic poems), got in touch with me today after a period of two years. Somebody in Wolverhampton - a certain Jim Smith - is keen to publish The Restless Tadpole, my 592-page prose poem about a tadpole's journey from the early days of frogspawnhood to the dying moments of old frogdom. It charts the events of the creature's life and draws parallels with events in my own, though I did not include my divorce, as I couldn't find out from any amphibian handbook if frogs went through a form of divorce, or if in fact they stayed faithful to the same partner.

Glenn has just informed me that "frogs are at it day an' night, Dad, with anythink that turns up". Brick Eagleburger said that Jim Smith had sent a fax saying, "The Restless Tadpole is a lyrical lament for the past glory that was the English countryside. I was moved to tears by the frog's violent death under the wheels of a German juggernaut." Brick said, "The guy's payin' zilcho spondoolicks but the exposure's godda be good for ya." I asked for the name of Jim Smith's publication and was told it was Frog Weekly. It touches me greatly that so many people care so deeply about frogs that they can be bothered to fill in the subscription form and fork out nine quid a year. Personally, I can't bear the loathsome slimy creatures.
