fields.headline: From sages  to celebrities
fields.standfirst: What does it mean when we stop listening to intellectuals and pay heed to pop stars? Stefan Collini concludes his series on the changing state of British culture
fields.trailText: What does it mean when we stop listening to intellectuals and pay heed to pop stars? Stefan Collini concludes his series on the changing state of British culture
fields.body:
The death of the intellectual has left a void in public life". This obituary was posted in October 1997, when Michael Ignatieff lamented that public debate in Britain had been handed over to the "worthy professors, cultural bureaucrats, carnival barkers and entertainers". It has become a familiar refrain. Not so long ago, it is claimed, there were intellectual figures of real eminence who acted as guides to the perplexing business of living, sages who would be listened to with respect. But now it has become impossible to command that kind of cultural authority: not only will people no longer listen, but intellectual specialisation means that no single figure can possess the necessary range to address a broad audience. There may be experts, but there are no longer any sages.

It is always difficult to sift out what is genuinely new about the historical moment through which we are living from the various illusory novelties generated by combining a highly selective view of the present with a thin and foreshortened view of the past. But as soon as we start to take a longer perspective we realise that laments about the intellectual's lack or loss of cultural authority are as old as the concept itself. After all, the occasion which is usually credited with giving birth to the modern concept of "the intellectual", the Dreyfus Affair in France in 1898, also generated the first in a long line of objections to the very idea of such an exercise of cultural authority when the conservative littérateur Ferdinand Brunetière asked rhetorically "what right has a professor of Tibetan to instruct his fellow citizens about politics?"

This singling out of a hypothetical "professor" as a peculiarly unpersuasive claimant of authority did not merely reflect the circumstances of the Dreyfus Affair, for the enormous growth of higher education since the late 19th century has been in itself one of the major forces of cultural change. The statistics are striking: in 1939 there were about 50,000 university students in Britain; by 1960 this had doubled to about 100,000. By 1988 the figure had reached 580,000, and by the end of the century almost one million. There was a corresponding increase in academics, and what goes on in universities - including their alleged scandals - now bulks much larger in the public culture than 50 years ago.

Of course, it is by no means true that all intellectuals have been academics, and even less that all academics have been intellectuals: but at the heart of the notion of "the intellectual" has been a movement between two poles, going beyond an initial source of standing or respect in order to "speak out" to a broader public, and the university has come more and more to be seen as a major, perhaps the major, home of that initial standing. It is precisely this movement "out", we are told, that has become impossible or ineffectual today. But is it true that intellectuals in general, and academics in particular, used to possess this authority and have now lost it? There is no question that part of what we, in Britain as in other comparable societies, are living through is a further, and considerably speeded-up, instalment of a long process of cultural democratisation. A crucial aspect of this process has been the way in which intellectual standing has more and more been stripped of merely historical or contingent association with social standing. Where the "crisis of authority" theorists go wrong is in confusing the decline in deference towards social superiority with the disappearance of cultural authority as such, and hence as entailing "the death of the intellectual".

As in most scenarios of "decline", considerable historical foreshortening is involved. The fact is that alarmists in each generation have confidently announced that, as a result of changes in the social structure or the rise of new media or the expansion of higher education, the age of the general intellectual has come to an end and the era of the mere specialist or expert is upon us. Yet history has each time confounded the pessimists.

In the 20s, for example, highly educated commentators predicted that the arrival of such populist media as radio would leave no room for serious attention to art and ideas. But any listener to The Third Programme a generation later would have had to admit that the medium had in fact furnished intellectuals with a new and highly congenial platform. Again, in the 60s it was no less confidently predicted that the era of the serious periodical was drawing to a close: old titles were folding, there would be no call for new ones. But again, a generation later, new titles such as the London Review of Books or Prospect seem in rude health, and are providing the intellectuals of our time with some of the same opportunities that their predecessors found in Encounter, or the Nation, or the Fortnightly, and so on all the way back to the original Edinburgh and Quarterly reviews in the early 19th century.

One thing that has changed is the assumption that members of the traditional upper classes were automatically authorities on "culture" and vice versa. From its foundation in 1946, the Third Programme did indeed carry an impressive range of serious artistic and intellectual programmes, but it displayed some highly conventional assumptions about where "serious" ideas were to be found: debates from the Oxford Union were broadcast live, and anyone now listening to recordings of talks and discussions from that time might infer that regional balance was provided by having speakers from Winchester as well as from Eton.

Something similar could be said for other media of that period. As late as the 60s, the great cardinals of the Sunday review pages - the Cyril Connollys, Philip Toynbees, and Raymond Mortimers - clearly represented the old alliance of high culture, and high social class (with a dash of high Modernism, too, in several cases, which tended to add a "European" spice to the authority). Not only could they tell a sonnet from a villanelle, but also a Chateauneuf from a Chambertin, and these were accepted as related forms of cultivation. Readers of the "quality" Sundays still by and large expected their cultural tastes to be arbitrated by members of "the quality".

And more generally, a delicate balance may be said to have obtained in the middle decades of the 20th century, when certain leading dons began for the first time to become frequent contributors to popular media (for example, AJP Taylor or Bertrand Russell). For a while, they were still able to trade on old snobberies and that taken-for-granted association of the ancient universities with the country's cultural elite, but in subsequent decades these sources of deference diminished considerably as newly prosperous strata increasingly determined the nature of media that owed no allegiance to the tastes of that cultivated milieu. Today, any academic who appears regularly in such settings risks being regarded as merely one "personality" among others, much less famous than pop stars and footballers, and some way below astrologers, TV chefs, and gardening experts.

The social changes which have undermined much of the deference from which earlier generations of academic intellectuals profited were touched upon in the first of these articles. They include increased prosperity and hence much greater market power for the bulk of the population, as well as the impact of technological innovation such as the rise of visual and electronic media. Increasingly egalitarian attitudes (notwithstanding the evidence of stark inequalities) have deprived many of the old markers of social standing of their power. More specifically, there has been a loss of status for academics as a result of the huge expansion of higher education and what has been termed the "proletarianisation" of the profession of university teacher: a "professor", whether of Tibetan or (more likely) of Tourism, is no longer a substantial figure in the local or national community.

But perhaps at this point we should pause and question the very idea of there being a single "national community" as far as cultural and intellectual life is concerned. Perhaps it was only ever an habitual complacency about their and their friends' importance which allowed leading public figures of earlier ages to think that they addressed, or even spoke "for", such a community in the first place. Certainly, the increased recognition of the competing claims of various "subcultures", whether defined in terms of ethnicity and gender or of musical taste and body piercing, has made such complacency harder to sustain. This does not mean that the ambition to address some kind of broad, non-specialist public has disappeared, just that it has to acknowledge its own social location and the legitimate interests of other, sometimes very different, locations. And this is surely a gain.

These longterm social changes have been compounded by three more recent cultural developments. The first is the way in which, partly as a consequence of the cultural democratization mentioned earlier, the public discourses of our society reflect an unease about the exercise of informed judgment. A broadly diffused but inconsistently held value relativism is at work here. People fear that judgment, the discrimination of better from worse in almost any sphere, is "elitist", even snobbish, masking mere prejudice and in concrete cases sheer favouritism. By contrast, measurement appears more palatable: it retains the aura of being impersonal, objective, open, even democratic. Measurement is thought of as a technical skill and therefore (it is falsely assumed) as value-neutral. Rational argument about one thing being more valuable or more worthwhile than another constantly threatens to be displaced by mere head-counting: when "what people want" is sovereign, the pollster speaks with more authority than the philosopher.

The second change which has accelerated recently is the rate of intellectual specialisation and professionalisation. Disciplines spawn subdisciplines; technical vocabularies become more arcane; the pressures on academics to stick to specialised research become more intense. The transnational research community becomes the "public" that counts - and the Research Assessment Exercise is the mechanism for counting it. In most scientific and scholarly fields, addressing a non-specialist audience is regarded as the equivalent of voluntary work in the community.

The third development concerns the way in which populist media promote the dynamics of celebrity even in the intellectual field: we have Spice Dons as well as Spice Girls. Celebrity, of course, depends entirely on the attention of the relevant media, and is therefore to some extent self-sustaining: notoriously, celebrities are in the end nothing more than people who are "famous for being famous". The shift from "Big Brother is watching you" to "You are watching Big Brother" is not just about depoliticisation or the development of more interactive forms of "mass" culture: it is fundamentally driven by the mechanism of the celebrity economy. The important thing is to be known and recognised, even if it is only for how you take a shower in front of six million people.

The extended power of the celebrity mill is particularly consequential for the role of the intellectual. Expertise, reputation, and celebrity may all be elements in cultural authority, but they each operate in different ways, and in recent years celebrity has increasingly threatened to out-trump the other two. Here the danger for media-friendly academics, is that by constantly seeking exposure and agreeing to make such pronouncements they risk forfeiting much of the authority upon which their public role was initially founded, and so to maintain their "visibility" they are forced into the vicious circle of pursuing celebrity itself through factitious controversy and sheer opinionatedness.

These developments are certainly important, but again we have to remember that ours is not the first generation to have to grapple with some variant of such forces. There is a long line of social critics who have challenged the assumptions about "consumer sovereignty", "popular taste", and other forms of "the evacuation of value" built into the public vocabulary dominant in their time. Attempts to counter the narrowing effects of scholarly specialisation can be traced back at least to the mid-19th century; Arnold's idea of "culture" was intended to do precisely that, after all. It is true that the insidious pressures constantly working to convert reputation into celebrity and reasoned arguments into mere soundbites do tend to catch academics, in particular, off-balance, as they find themselves unversed in the ways of imposing their perspective on the media rather than the reverse. But here, too, there are encouraging exemplars from the past (think of Jacob Bronowski on television) and in such cases today (Simon Schama, or Germaine Greer) skillful exploitation of the medium can amplify rather than diminish the reputation.

Intellectuals, in Britain as elsewhere, can rely less and less upon the deference formerly accorded to irrelevant or merely contingent social attributes and connections, but the obituary notices may none the less be premature. The very processes which appear to make it more difficult for reasoned argument, informed judgment, and a broad perspective to get a hearing in the public domain simultaneously generate a corresponding hunger for those qualities. A diet of media-degradable soundbites can also stimulate an appetite for something more substantial. It is a good bet that a future historian surveying cultural change in Britain in the first half of the 21st century will find, amid developments which may at present be scarcely imaginable, that this appetite will have continued to find serious fare to chew.

 Stefan Collini is Reader in Intellectual History and English Literature at Cambridge University

Increasingly egalitarian attitudes (notwithstanding the evidence of stark inequalities) have deprived many of the old markers of social standing of their power. More specifically, there has been a loss of status for academics as a result of the huge expansion of higher education and what has been termed the "proletarianisation" of the profession of university teacher: a "professor", whether of Tibetan or (more likely) of Tourism, is no longer a substantial figure in the local or national community. But perhaps at this point we should pause and question the very idea of there being a single "national community" as far as cultural and intellectual life is concerned. Perhaps it was only ever an habitual complacency about their and their friends' importance which allowed leading public figures of earlier ages to think that they addressed, or even spoke "for", such a community in the first place. Certainly, the increased recognition of the competing claims of various "subcultures", whether defined in terms of ethnicity and gender or of musical taste and body piercing, has made such complacency harder to sustain. This does not mean that the ambition to address some kind of broad, non-specialist public has disappeared, just that it has to acknowledge its own social location and the legitimate interests of other, sometimes very different, locations. And this is surely a gain. These longterm social changes have been compounded by three more recent cultural developments. The first is the way in which, partly as a consequence of the cultural democratization mentioned earlier, the public discourses of our society reflect an unease about the exercise of informed judgment. A broadly diffused but inconsistently held value relativism is at work here. People fear that judgment, the discrimination of better from worse in almost any sphere, is "elitist", even snobbish, masking mere prejudice and in concrete cases sheer favouritism. By contrast, measurement appears more palatable: it retains the aura of being impersonal, objective, open, even democratic. Measurement is thought of as a technical skill and therefore (it is falsely assumed) as value-neutral. Rational argument about one thing being more valuable or more worthwhile than another constantly threatens to be displaced by mere head-counting: when "what people want" is sovereign, the pollster speaks with more authority than the philosopher. The second change which has accelerated recently is the rate of intellectual specialisation and professionalisation. Disciplines spawn subdisciplines; technical vocabularies become more arcane; the pressures on academics to stick to specialised research become more intense. The transnational research community becomes the "public" that counts - and the Research Assessment Exercise is the mechanism for counting it. In most scientific and scholarly fields, addressing a non-specialist audience is regarded as the equivalent of voluntary work in the community. The third development concerns the way in which populist media promote the dynamics of celebrity even in the intellectual field: we have Spice Dons as well as Spice Girls. Celebrity, of course, depends entirely on the attention of the relevant media, and is therefore to some extent self-sustaining: notoriously, celebrities are in the end nothing more than people who are "famous for being famous". The shift from "Big Brother is watching you" to "You are watching Big Brother" is not just about depoliticisation or the development of more interactive forms of "mass" culture: it is fundamentally driven by the mechanism of the celebrity economy. The important thing is to be known and recognised, even if it is only for how you take a shower in front of six million people. The extended power of the celebrity mill is particularly consequential for the role of the intellectual. Expertise, reputation, and celebrity may all be elements in cultural authority, but they each operate in different ways, and in recent years celebrity has increasingly threatened to out-trump the other two. Here the danger for media-friendly academics, is that by constantly seeking exposure and agreeing to make such pronouncements they risk forfeiting much of the authority upon which their public role was initially founded, and so to maintain their "visibility" they are forced into the vicious circle of pursuing celebrity itself through factitious controversy and sheer opinionatedness. These developments are certainly important, but again we have to remember that ours is not the first generation to have to grapple with some variant of such forces. There is a long line of social critics who have challenged the assumptions about "consumer sovereignty", "popular taste", and other forms of "the evacuation of value" built into the public vocabulary dominant in their time. Attempts to counter the narrowing effects of scholarly specialisation can be traced back at least to the mid-19th century; Arnold's idea of "culture" was intended to do precisely that, after all. It is true that the insidious pressures constantly working to convert reputation into celebrity and reasoned arguments into mere soundbites do tend to catch academics, in particular, off-balance, as they find themselves unversed in the ways of imposing their perspective on the media rather than the reverse. But here, too, there are encouraging exemplars from the past (think of Jacob Bronowski on television) and in such cases today (Simon Schama, or Germaine Greer) skillful exploitation of the medium can amplify rather than diminish the reputation. Intellectuals, in Britain as elsewhere, can rely less and less upon the deference formerly accorded to irrelevant or merely contingent social attributes and connections, but the obituary notices may none the less be premature. The very processes which appear to make it more difficult for reasoned argument, informed judgment, and a broad perspective to get a hearing in the public domain simultaneously generate a corresponding hunger for those qualities. A diet of media-degradable soundbites can also stimulate an appetite for something more substantial. It is a good bet that a future historian surveying cultural change in Britain in the first half of the 21st century will find, amid developments which may at present be scarcely imaginable, that this appetite will have continued to find serious fare to chew.  Stefan Collini is Reader in Intellectual History and English Literature at Cambridge University

fields.headline: Dubious divisions
fields.standfirst: What does the dumb debate mean for groups that  are often excluded from "high art" yet dominate the landscape of popular culture? By Maya Jaggi
fields.trailText: What does the dumb debate mean for groups that  are often excluded from "high art" yet dominate the landscape of popular culture? By Maya Jaggi
fields.body:
Black people, Stuart Hall has said, are the "dominant defining force in street-oriented British youth culture. Without them, white youth culture would not exist in the form it does today."

Popular culture in post-Windrush Britain has unquestionably been transformed by the black and Asian presence, from the proliferating musical forms of ragga and scratch, jungle and drum 'n' bass, to sporting heroes, comedians and styles of dance, fashion and cuisine.

Yet what of the so-called traditional arts? Are there more or fewer black artists assailing these pinnacles, and to what extent are they being spurred or deterred? To begin with, black artists of all disciplines may be forgiven for refusing the terms of this "dumbing down" debate - the battle, as Melvyn Bragg identified it in this paper, between "the traditional arts and popular culture  high and low art". Some of these artists' survival may well depend on the outcome of funding arguments waged in these terms. But when the goalposts of western aesthetics have so often been angled to bar black art forms and belittle black creativity, they may find such hierarchies of value, if not irrelevant, then deeply suspect.

The "purely aesthetic" criteria vaunted in judgments between "high" and "low" culture, or within arts, have seldom, if ever, been pure. According to Hegel, the very capacity to make art was a European prerogative. Non-European civilisations were routinely rubbished to shore up the colonial project. Thomas Macaulay opined in parliament in 1835 that a single tome in the British library was worth more than the sum of Indian and Arabic literature - though it has taken others to point out what the modern European novel owes (via Cervantes) to the Thousand and One Nights.

More than 150 years later, Harold Bloom could write that "the 'expansion of the [western] Canon' has meant the destruction of the Canon", since it now includes those "women, African, Hispanic or Asian [writers] who offer little but the resentment they have developed as part of their sense of identity".

The point is that the very definition of western high art, with its gate-keeping canons and academies, has historically placed other cultures in the "dumb" camp, regardless of the sophistication of their art forms. Oral narrative was naturally inferior to written literature, as Creole was to the master's tongue. Ballet is high art; the complex choreography of carnival is not.

These dubious hierarchies persist. The spurious divide between poets of the page and the stage that sparked Linton Kwesi Johnson's ironic composition, "If I woz a Tap Natch Poet", underestimates forms such as dub poetry and misses the huge contribution made by the spoken word in reinvigorating British poetry for a new generation.

The "dumb" dichotomy crumbles yet further when one appreciates that black artists historically sought out forms that were simply more open to them - film and photography, say, rather than the more institutionalised arts - and less susceptible to others' control. The art of the steel drum developed from the banning of traditional African instruments in the British West Indies. Ska and reggae were blasted out on sound systems, at blues parties and on pirate radio in the 70s and 80s, when they found no place on the air waves.

The fact of artists' blackness has often bizarrely skewed critical response to their work. Early jazz was praised for its "natural", "untutored" spontaneity, black visual artists were endlessly labelled "primitive" and "naive". Though famously raided for "primal" inspiration by Picasso and the modernists, their art was judged outside the scope of what Paul Gilroy has called the "aesthetic citadels of modernism and postmodernism".

Valorisation of art takes place not in a vacuum but in relation to the national culture - the cement of national identity in our "imagined community". Artists given no place in that story are subject to national amnesia. Hall cites diasporic artists such as Ronald Moody, Aubrey Williams, Francis Souza, Anwar Schezma, David Medalla, Li-Wan Chia, Avtarjeet Dhanjal, who have been "quietly written out of the record. Not British enough for the Tate, not international enough for Bankside".

Courtney Pine spearheaded the creation of a black British jazz in the mid-80s in the teeth of what he sees as the myth that "black people don't play jazz because it's superintelligent music". But how many recall the pivotal role of the West Indian jazz musicians Joe Harriott and Shake Keane in originating European freeform jazz here in the 50s? More than 150 novels were written here by writers from the Caribbean in the 50s and 60s, but where are Sam Selvon or George Lamming in the notion of British literature of the period?

Black British artists have increasingly made an undeniable and explosive impact, not least on the citadels of literature - from the Booker winners Salman Rushdie and Ben Okri to 21st-century talents such as Zadie Smith - and fine art; Chris Ofili and Steve McQueen scooped the Turner prize in two successive years. Yet skewed value judgments can still create a straitjacket of expectations. Heir to notions of the "primitive" has perhaps been the policing of black artists' "authenticity", that would reduce "ethnic arts" to an exotic, backward-looking adjunct on the fringes of British art. The requirement that their work be distinguished from their white peers' by its "Africanness" or "Asianness" was a fiat wittily sent up by Ofili's daubs of elephant dung.

Perhaps the most pervasive of today's pathologies is the blanket identification of black culture as street culture - whether Americanised or, increasingly, homegrown. This view produces its own pressure, not least in literature, to chart a narrow and monolithic "black British experience". It results not only in the spurious "street cred" of the title of the Penguin Book of New Black Writing in Britain: IC3 - the police category for black - but the palpable absurdities of conflating black authors with their characters. Those expecting Vanessa Walters to share the lives of her jobless teenage characters in Rude Girls found instead a private school student bound for Oxford.

As Victor Headley said in frustration when his novel Yardie came out, the assumption is that black authors writing about gangsters have lived the life, while white writers have done some research.

Whatever the pressures, black doyens of "high art" have been here all along and are going strong. But is their place guaranteed in the "unfolding national story", and if not, what greater disincentive could there be to the next generation? As Gilroy has claimed in relation to a transatlantic "brain drain" of black artists and thinkers from Britain, for many people, the term "black intellectual" is still an oxymoron. The notion of a commodified black street culture, of "food-and-frocks multiculturalism", may still be more digestible in some quarters than due recognition of an artistic flowering and exchange going back centuries.

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: MPs were once revered, says David McKie. Now they are disparaged or ignored
fields.trailText: MPs were once revered, says David McKie. Now they are disparaged or ignored
fields.body:
At present," wrote Lord Macaulay in 1843, "the best way of giving rapid and wide publicity to a fact or argument is to introduce [it] into a speech made in Parliament  A speech made in the House of Commons at four in the morning is on 30,000 tables before 10. A speech made on the Monday is read on the Wednesday by multitudes in Antrim and Aberdeenshire."

A century later, the MPs who gathered for the first postwar parliament could tell themselves that Macaulay's verdict was still largely true. They had been called at a deeply serious moment to a deeply serious and hugely influential place: one which governed the destinies not just of one of the world's great nations - the one whose steadfastness in the early days of the war had saved civilisation from Hitler - but one of the world's greatest empires. Many of these MPs had fought in the war (some took their seats in uniform) and even those who had not, had known its tragedies and privations. Struggle, to them, meant rather more than trying to persuade the Ivy to book you a table. They were heirs to a solemn tradition.

Labour's great election landslide had purged the House of many of its traditional aristocrats. The hold of the great public schools was not what it was. Yet a sturdy contingent in Attlee's 1945-51 cabinets came from privileged schools. The easy erudition of the turn of the century, where a minister could quote Livy in the original and still be understood, has gone. Yet the place in the first postwar years had a formidable intellectual and cultural firepower, on the Labour benches especially: Richard Crossman, Michael Foot, Roy Jenkins, Tony Crosland, Harold Wilson. And alongside them, a mighty phalanx of horny-handed sons (there were very few daughters) of toil: some like Ernest Bevin and Aneurin Bevan, denied much conventional education but more than a match for their erudite comrades. When they spoke, they could feel the world listened.

It wouldn't be quite true to say that MPs today no longer expect to be treated with reverence: no one who has heard Sir Peter Tapsell in action could make that mistake. In fact they are hugely disparaged and - even more woundingly - largely ignored. The old tradition of daily blow-by-blow reporting of Commons debates in the broadsheets is almost extinct. Why? Because, in the judgment of the newspapers, what goes on in the Commons is rarely news. If you want to get your facts and arguments on to the tables of Antrim and Aberdeen you would do better to go on Newsnight, Today, and the World at One. And it is hardly open to MPs to complain that the media neglects their debates when increasingly they do so themselves. Like the broader public, they tend to be there for the weekly battle of sound-bites that is prime minister's questions. Elsewhere their attention is fitful.

Modern politicians have not grown up in their own traditions of reverence for the chamber and have other calls on their time: constituency business in a consumer age accounts for much more of their day than it would have done 50 years ago. Select committees, too, have become a more effective way of curbing the executive than speaking in a near-empty chamber. Landowners, military men and men sprung from provincial business have given way to lawyers, journalists, and, above all, to career politicians, fresh from party organisations and MPs' offices. For them, what happens on the floor of the Commons is only a small and increasingly insignificant part of what they define as politics.

In Attlee's time, prime minister's questions were a feast of decency. Questions for the most part were courteously put, and clearly designed to elicit information: it wasn't the bearpit it is today. Whatever the other excitements, this was a serious time with a serious purpose. It doesn't feel like that now: another thing which will will no doubt be blamed on our unloved politicians. But the true explanation for all these changes goes much wider than that. It is a different world at Westminster, but that is because it is a different world outside, full of other preoccupations, with the shackles of deference and reverence long ago thrown away. Dumber? Undoubtedly. But as much a reflection of our own time as the 1950 parliament was of that our forebears.

fields.headline: Fashion
fields.standfirst: From haute couture to street culture, Veronica Horwell finds that fashion has been usurped by fashionability
fields.trailText: From haute couture to street culture, Veronica Horwell finds that fashion has been usurped by fashionability
fields.body:
Vogue, 1951: a picture of a debutante-type in twinset and pearls in a country pub staring at the camera, as is the flat-capped local chap next her. The caption: "The theme: poise, dignity, the respect of person for person and class for class. The girl, quiet in dress and manners, waits while her husband gets drinks. The man  has unselfconsciously pinned a rose in his coat." These snobbish words reafirm what fashion had long been, an amusing visual aspect of the life of those born to privilege. But the picture by Norman Parkinson, a postwar photographer with a fresh eye for real ambience, already suggests a changed world. It doesn't record an outfit created for any regular engagement on a social calendar: the presence of that girl (she looks a mature 25), in those clothes, in that place, is a story.

The most significant garment in the picture, the girl's skirt, is obscured under a shove ha'penny board, but it is a fair bet that its length and shape had been determined by the season's shows at Paris couture houses, especially that of Christian Dior. His house had been launched in 1947, substantially backed by textile magnate Marcel Boussac in the justified hope that Dior's creations would help re-establish French pre-eminence in luxury trades. That launch marked not just a change in fashion (with Dior's outrageously lavish New Look, followed by annual resculpturings of the female form by Dior and other Paris couturiers through the 50s), but a change in the basis of the business of selling apparel: as Valerie Steele, chief curator at New York's Fashion Institute of Technology, says, it inaugurated the modern era when "fashion was restructured and reconceived as big business and high art".

Boussac, among others, accurately foresaw the boom of the next half-century, in which newly prosperous classes first reached up for status through enhanced personal appearance - what John Berger once described as the Cinderella transformation. New consumers viewed proliferating fashion images not as confirmations of the enviability of the lives they already led, but as the pattern of what their lives might be if they wore the look (by purchasing a copy, or a copy of a copy). They were inspired by what Steele calls "a handful of designers who could be promoted as stars"; and, allured by media reaction to couture's extremes, they bought at least perfumes and small luxuries bearing Parisian names. Most importantly, they were sensitised to spending a higher proportion of income on bigger wardrobes with shorter wearing-spans.

But their interest and expenditure was minor compared with that of the next generation - those who had their own disposable incomes by the 60s. Couture's lead was augmented, and then supplanted, by younger designers way outside Paris, directly selling informal clothes to their contemporaries through minimally capitalised shops, where retailing was a social event - the boutique trip as party. Vogue, its message amplified by new magazines targetting 16-24-year-olds, proposed to the boomers that fashion had become a complete, desirable way of life, in synthesis with the expanding music business. A 1966 David Bailey photograph of the wife of a Beatle poses her in a studio in the latest London ready-to-wear, cosmetics and haircut (she looks a faux-naive 18): the caption mentions only names, prices and stockists. Simply the presence of the fashionable young is the story.

Fashion 2000 has gone far beyond being an optional passion for young adults: it saturates all aspects of all lives, with every object, environment and belief subject to accelerated marketing cycles of modishness and disposability. Western women (and men) own more clothes than did rich prewar style-setters, and reject them ever faster, even though the raw materials and workmanship of mass-produced clothes have been upgraded. Never in history have so many been able to purchase such quality fabrics assembled by skilled workers, albeit often in global sweatshops. Vogue, reinforced by kiosks crammed with magazines (soon to stock Vogue Teen aimed at 12-15-year-olds), insists that fashionable appearance is the primary purpose of every woman: the 1951 requirement for investment in clothes, and the 1966 bills for cosmetics and hair, have been supplemented by demands for faces and bodies reshaped and resurfaced at huge outlay of time, money and effort.

The current Vogue cover, shot by Mario Testino against white paper, shows a model about to shed her bikini, sequinned with the Union flag, in response to a naked Robbie Williams (both look teenaged, but used). The words say "Eat fat, get thin" and "The new sexy chic"; there is a credit for the "grooming" of Williams (oil on his tattoos?).

The presence of fashion is now the only story. That's dumb. And ignore the defence that fashion is now ironic: nobody ever got rich from selling irony.

The most significant garment in the picture, the girl's skirt, is obscured under a shove ha'penny board, but it is a fair bet that its length and shape had been determined by the season's shows at Paris couture houses, especially that of Christian Dior. His house had been launched in 1947, substantially backed by textile magnate Marcel Boussac in the justified hope that Dior's creations would help re-establish French pre-eminence in luxury trades. That launch marked not just a change in fashion (with Dior's outrageously lavish New Look, followed by annual resculpturings of the female form by Dior and other Paris couturiers through the 50s), but a change in the basis of the business of selling apparel: as Valerie Steele, chief curator at New York's Fashion Institute of Technology, says, it inaugurated the modern era when "fashion was restructured and reconceived as big business and high art". Boussac, among others, accurately foresaw the boom of the next half-century, in which newly prosperous classes first reached up for status through enhanced personal appearance - what John Berger once described as the Cinderella transformation. New consumers viewed proliferating fashion images not as confirmations of the enviability of the lives they already led, but as the pattern of what their lives might be if they wore the look (by purchasing a copy, or a copy of a copy). They were inspired by what Steele calls "a handful of designers who could be promoted as stars"; and, allured by media reaction to couture's extremes, they bought at least perfumes and small luxuries bearing Parisian names. Most importantly, they were sensitised to spending a higher proportion of income on bigger wardrobes with shorter wearing-spans. But their interest and expenditure was minor compared with that of the next generation - those who had their own disposable incomes by the 60s. Couture's lead was augmented, and then supplanted, by younger designers way outside Paris, directly selling informal clothes to their contemporaries through minimally capitalised shops, where retailing was a social event - the boutique trip as party. Vogue, its message amplified by new magazines targetting 16-24-year-olds, proposed to the boomers that fashion had become a complete, desirable way of life, in synthesis with the expanding music business. A 1966 David Bailey photograph of the wife of a Beatle poses her in a studio in the latest London ready-to-wear, cosmetics and haircut (she looks a faux-naive 18): the caption mentions only names, prices and stockists. Simply the presence of the fashionable young is the story. Fashion 2000 has gone far beyond being an optional passion for young adults: it saturates all aspects of all lives, with every object, environment and belief subject to accelerated marketing cycles of modishness and disposability. Western women (and men) own more clothes than did rich prewar style-setters, and reject them ever faster, even though the raw materials and workmanship of mass-produced clothes have been upgraded. Never in history have so many been able to purchase such quality fabrics assembled by skilled workers, albeit often in global sweatshops. Vogue, reinforced by kiosks crammed with magazines (soon to stock Vogue Teen aimed at 12-15-year-olds), insists that fashionable appearance is the primary purpose of every woman: the 1951 requirement for investment in clothes, and the 1966 bills for cosmetics and hair, have been supplemented by demands for faces and bodies reshaped and resurfaced at huge outlay of time, money and effort. The current Vogue cover, shot by Mario Testino against white paper, shows a model about to shed her bikini, sequinned with the Union flag, in response to a naked Robbie Williams (both look teenaged, but used). The words say "Eat fat, get thin" and "The new sexy chic"; there is a credit for the "grooming" of Williams (oil on his tattoos?). The presence of fashion is now the only story. That's dumb. And ignore the defence that fashion is now ironic: nobody ever got rich from selling irony.

fields.headline: In another country
fields.standfirst: Billy Elliot screenwriter Lee Hall explains how the north-south divide and the experience of Thatcherism conditioned his view of art
fields.trailText: Billy Elliot screenwriter Lee Hall explains how the north-south divide and the experience of Thatcherism conditioned his view of art
fields.body:
Anyone growing up in north-east England in the 70s and 80s and interested in "the arts" couldn't help but be aware of a huge and seemingly unbridgeable divide between what was characterised as high and low Art. "High art" was perceived by the majority working class as dessicated, pretentious and irrelevant - a symbol of the worst traits of the posher classes. On the other hand, the popular art that spoke to the majority was dismissed as formally simplistic or sentimentally inclined. There were snobs on both sides and both views spoke eloquently of prejudice. However, it seemed to me, there was always something to recommend the plebeian point of view. High art spoke a patrician language which brooked little real conversation with anything of relevance to ordinary people and the snobbery that dismissed popular forms seemed to be a tautology: popular art was bad simply because it was plebian. But whenever I looked at high art it seemed to be brimming with all the excesses of sentiment and manipulation that made the low stuff so great. So very early on I had an inkling that in fact there was no difference between the two at all.

What characterised British culture in the 20th century was a radical, democratic impulse to free the glories of "art" from the privileged preserve. The Proms, the BBC and the WEA made mildly preposterous the crass assumption that the great unwashed were also unread. In fact, the great unwashed were constantly renewing the High Arts and some of the finest practitioners were in fact ordinary lads from similar backgrounds to mine. It was the cultural commentators who were predominantly posh and, therefore, unable to do anything but patronise - however well intentioned they may have been.

Until my twenties, I had no idea such a thing as European cinema existed. Suddenly here was the class divide played out in film. It may as well have been called High Art House. Strangely, the best of the British work in this vein, venerated by critics and institutions such as the BFI, was firmly about class and aspiration yet it was marginalised, inaccessible. While the films themselves adopted the loose narrative techniques of the nouvelle vague, their subject matter emerged from British popular culture.

In the mid-90s I spent several years in America and was amazed at how film-literate everyone was. The arty circles in which I mixed were not just informed about Hollywood or American independent film-making, but had a huge grasp of world cinema in general. People who aspired to make horror movies would quote Tarkovsky as their favourite film-maker. I came to realise that what is deemed as the Hollywood narrative tradition was largely developed by European "high art" emigrés. There seemed to be an acceptance that film-making was just film-making, defined more by economics than something inherently "high" or "low" about the art itself. It became obvious to me that it was unnecessary to emulate the ascetic forms of my heroes to address the subject-matter that inspired me.

I was working on an idea about a ballet dancer in a pit village, which seemed to allow for all kinds of artiness, but if it was about the kid reaching for high art, why couldn't I strive to find a popular ("low") form for the story? If you can be "full on" in the ballet or the opera or in soaps or in a pop song, why can't you deal with emotion in a film?

Growing up in the north east under Thatcher left the injustices that were perpetrated on hundreds of thousands of people indelibly stamped on my consciousness, and so the film is about growing up in that environment.

What seems so strange is that moment in history is almost forgotten. The film for me became an act of remembering. What shocked me most was that many of the young people who watched the early cuts of the film didn't even know what a strike was, let alone the details of this particular struggle that did so much to define our current age. Ironically, the fissures in British life are as deep as ever, despite the supposed levelling of the Blairite project. This has nothing to do with culture but everything to do with real inequality. Lives continue to be blighted by being denied their full expression.

During my research for the film I came across the following quote: "I know that we can produce a society where man will cease to simply go to work and have a little leisure, but will release his latent talent and ability and begin to produce in the cultural sense all the things I know he is capable of: music, poetry, writing, sculpture, whole works of art that, at the moment, lie dormant simply because we, as a society, are not able to tap it." From a speech given by Arthur Scargill in 1984, it encapsulates everything I was writing about.

 This is an edited extract from the introduction to the screenplay of Billy Elliot, published by Faber and Faber

fields.headline: Pop
fields.standfirst: Being dumb may be the essence of pop music, argues Tom Cox, but there are many varieties of dumb. Still, things are pretty bad
fields.trailText: Being dumb may be the essence of pop music, argues Tom Cox, but there are many varieties of dumb. Still, things are pretty bad
fields.body:
It would be too easy to measure pop by words alone. If we did, Warren Zevon would be the world's greatest songwriter. It would also be rather tricky to justify the argument for five decades of dumbing down between "Awopbopaloobop alopbamboom!" and "Wooh! We're going to Ibiza".

The key to a great pop song is more than words and melody combined, more even than words and melody and emotion combined. And it is this, the mysterious, accidental quality of great music, which allows the lover of pop to sustain their faith in today's uniquely uninspiring era. The brilliant American songwriter Dwight Twilley called it "looking for the magic". You can't lock it up and define it. If you could, Slade wouldn't have made Merry Christmas Everybody and Morrissey would never have besmirched Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now with National Front Disco.

Although it is impossible to tell what makes a timeless, telling pop song, It is somewhat easier to see what doesn't. To anyone even vaguely in love with the past, it is clear that the corporate stranglehold of today's music business is siphoning the lifeblood of pop's heart and soul. The other argument, of course, is that pop has always been dumb, from Fats Domino to Fatboy Slim - it just attains substance with age, as the patina of nostalgia settles on it. A scary vision of the future, that: young record collectors digging up dusty copies of S Club 7's Natural, marvelling at the level of real, unbridled human emotion on display.

The difference between the charts of then and now is not just a mission to please. Who doesn't want to write a hit single? The difference is the gap between writing what you think the public will perceive as a hit single, and writing what you think someone in a suit will think the public will perceive as a hit single. This is part of a more general entertainment industry problem. Everything is a pitch. Unless you have attained the (frankly unique) autonomy of Radiohead, you are summing up your life's work in soundbites in order to sell it.

Imagine reducing the masterpieces of the past to a soundbite, when they didn't even have a precedent. The Rolling Stones' Exile On Main Street. ("Mangles blues debauchery in the basement of a French mansion!"). Chic's Risque ("A non-stop party soundtrack played on a giant elastic band!"). Love's Forever Changes ("A loved-up, deranged hippy ethic about death with punk attitude!"). Folks would have thought you were mad.

The best pop doesn't lend itself to soundbite because somewhere at its core is a sense of the unexplored. But it is not easy to explore new frontiers when there's a record company just waiting to pitch you to the media as "Jeff Buckley meets Radiohead at Coldplay's house". Just as the days seemed longer when you were a kid, pop's first three decades seem, in retrospect, to have lasted almost for ever. Not only were there more boundaries to break, there was more time to think about breaking them. Who has got time to be a dreamer now, when there is email to check, photo shoots to attend, copy to approve, questions to field? Musicians are no longer part-time drop-outs; they are corporate cogs, getting their soul made over and their sole stimulation from other corporate cogs. Retaining artistic control is no longer merely a question of proving yourself, it is a matter of proving yourself before anyone has given you any money. Southport lads Gomez seem to have it written into their contract that they reserve the right to continue being Southport lads, but their celebrated debut album was done and - in a very real sense - dusted in the garage long before the bidding wars began.

There are three varieties of dumb in pop. The first is fun, knowing dumb, as in "We're An American Band, by Grand Funk Railroad is a big, dumb anthem" - dumb, but not shallow. The second is not dumb in essence, but assumes a dumb mantle - for example, Free's All Right Now in the aftermath of the chewing gum advert. The third arrives hopelessly, irrevocably dumb - vacuous from birth. This last type of song is the one we hear more and more. The environment which formed it was supremely empty and robotic, the machines that produced it were set to "enhance" (ie "devitalise") it and the person singing it either didn't believe in the lyrics or had their vision tampered with. The song doesn't really know any better. The difference between the modern irrevocably dumb song and the classic irrevocably dumb song is that somewhere beneath the manufactured image, the Monkees believed in the romantic pop star myth and made you hear that they believed in it, whereas the only thing that Steps sound like they believe in is their costumer designer.

Perhaps we expect too much and too little. Analysed by a million paid thinkers, not to mention Salman Rushdie, pop has now attained the status of art, as opposed to trash, but doesn't seem too comfortable with it. Its most profound moments happen when they are least expected, but pop currently finds itself weighed down by the high expectations of the people who know its history and the low expectations of the people who don't care about it. What pop is missing is what Thomas Beecham, the classical conductor, described as the sound of surprise, trailed by satisfaction. A believable voice, in other words.

webTitle: Dumb: The land that forgot time

fields.headline: The land that forgot time
fields.standfirst: Alan Rusbridger spent a horrid evening at the opening of the Dome. If only he had been at the other Dome, centrepiece of the 1951 Festival of Britain. In those days, before national amnesia set in, history mattered
fields.trailText: Alan Rusbridger spent a horrid evening at the opening of the Dome. If only he had been at the other Dome, centrepiece of the 1951 Festival of Britain. In those days, before national amnesia set in, history mattered
fields.body:
The terrible pasting Fleet Street handed out to the Dome in the first week of January was popularly ascribed to the indignity grand editors had suffered waiting three hours at Stratford station on Millennium Eve. If only we'd been allowed to swish in by chauffeur-driven Merc, as per usual, how different things might have been! Actually, the queue at Stratford had a kind of Dunkirk jollity about it. What really dampened the spirits was the dismal show that greeted us once we'd arrived.

A thousand years of British culture! Imagine what the millennial celebration could have been in the hands of Richard Eyre, Sam Mendes, Stephen Daldry or Peter Hall. We could have feasted on Shakespeare, Milton, Dickens, Paine, Auden, Austen, Burns and Keats. Birtwistle, Benjamin and the Beatles could have followed on from Purcell and Elgar. Turner, Constable, Whiteread, Ofili, Darwin, Kelvin, Fleming, Crick, Brunel, Newton. Or another dozen names equally great, equally enriching. And what did we get? An overture to the Dome by Jools Holland. A new piece by a theatre composer called Jonathan Dove. A new royal fanfare by - wait for it - Richard Morris, who is apparently a commissioner of English Heritage. A piece by John Tavener was squeezed in before Auld Lang Syne, but Mick Hucknall topped the bill.

The evening was narcissistic in its deliberate amnesia about our past. You could not imagine the French, the Italians or even the Americans putting on such a show. On the biggest night of all it seemed we had, as a nation, nothing to say to ourselves about anything. Someone had decided that what was needed instead was an ITV variety show.

I suspect it was the tone of that "One Amazing Night" rather than the wait at Stratford that turned editors against the Dome. The majority of the most brutal pieces that followed fastened on to the emptiness of the experience. You emerged from a visit with a blanded-down, logo-plastered vision of corporate-sponsored UK plc. But as a reflection of the textures of our lives in 2000 it said nothing new or challenging. It left you cold.

The contrast with the South Bank Exhibition of 1951 could hardly have been greater. Some of it, of course, echoes down from a generation still coming to terms with a rapidly disappearing Imperial heritage. But Laurie Lee's essay on the British character unashamedly glories in the "instinct for liberty" that threaded from Magna Carta through Cromwell, Milton, Daniel O'Connell, the Tolpuddle farm-hands and Mrs Pankhurst.

The argument about the ICM poll that started this Dumb? series off sometimes raged about whether a knowledge of the past was relevant to the present or the future. The left, in particular, sometimes has an ambivalence about historical precedents - especially those involving kings, barons and generals. See the Mayor of London's distaste for General Havelock.

So I showed our poll results to Paul Foot. His comment on them is as eloquent a rebuttal of the Dome's Millennial amnesia as one could hope for: "I cite just one example. I sit here in bankrupted Hackney at a time of unprecedented economic growth and unspeakable riches in high places. The air is thick with the clamour of head teachers in state schools informing parents that 'statemented' children with learning difficulties will have to be sent home because there is no more money to teach them; of nursery teachers and parents whose nurseries (hailed as indispensable by education ministers) are being arbitrarily closed down without warning; of refuse collectors threatened with union-bashing and mass sackings. And I think of Poplar and George Lansbury and the first Labour council there.

"Those councillors reacted to the most awful wretchedness among the working people who elected them by deliberately breaking the rules about the collection of rates which forced them in Lansbury's words to 'tax the poor to help the poor'."

They were sent to prison for their defiance and to some extent won the principle of rates equalisation in London, a principle that lasted at least until the Greater London Council and the Inner London Education Authority were abolished by Thatcher 65 years later. If people today even knew about Poplarism in the 1920s, if they had ever heard of George, Edgar and Minnie Lansbury, the councillors might not concede so easily to political vandalism in Hackney; and the battered working class would be more confident to resist. As it is, we will have to teach and learn those lessons all over again.

 Alan Rusbridger is editor of the Guardian

fields.standfirst: The decline of modesty. With a little bit of help from his family, Alan Jenkins gives a personal view of changing attitudes to desire
fields.trailText: The decline of modesty. With a little bit of help from his family, Alan Jenkins gives a personal view of changing attitudes to desire
fields.body:
It is 1958, or thereabouts. My mother, clutching a yellow duster, attacks the sideboards. She is singing. "Bali Ha'i, I hear you calling /From the depths of the sea/Bali Ha'i, you are calling/Come to me, come to me " or "Some enchanted evening  ". The exact import of these mysterious words is lost on me - aged three - but they seem to make my mother happy. Why?

Much later, I learn that those songs and all the others in South Pacific were first sung in 1947, the year my father and mother were married. And I recall another thing: the stranger - dark-haired, dressed in a trenchcoat, speaking American - who called one afternoon. He and my mother sat for hours over the tea-things, both of them talking softly while I, unsure what to make of this new rival for my mother's undivided weekday-afternoon attention or the slightly abashed, conspiratorial tone of grown-up conversation, pretended to be absorbed in some game.

I'm unsure what to make, now, of her entranced fondness for palm-fringed musical dreamworlds in which all-conquering Americans are themselves conquered, by exotic beauty and customs, and indulge "cross-cultural" desires. Did everything pass between her and a homesick GI in 1943 or 44, or nothing? It doesn't matter. Those songs spoke to her of everything she had once felt for my father and perhaps other men too, everything she had hoped for and dreamed of.

And what did it all have to do with the copy of Lady Chatterley's Lover she kept in her bedside cabinet, along with the paperback Married Love in Later Years? Lady Chatterley: not her cup of tea at all, but briefly notorious, briefly, even, a part of "popular culture" after a prosecuting counsel asked if it was a book one would want one's wife or servants to read.

That was then. But my father, although a natural SuperMac voter, would have seen the point of Christine Keeler  and anyway, "everyone did the honourable thing". Then the Beatles' first LP was upon him and with it a future of suggestion-laden pop lyrics - "Please please me, whoa yeah, like I please you". This sounded pretty limp once Mick Jagger had thrust his way into my teenage sister's affections, and she began the uphill work of pulling us into the 60s.

It was a struggle that only ended with the decade. The easily embarrassed pre-war middle class couldn't red-bloodedly rejoice in robust music-hall "sauciness" - "After a while I began to perspire / It wasn't the ride, I was pumping her tyre" and so on. The war itself is supposed to have licensed a universal loosening of stays, belts and braces, but there had been nearly 20 years of tightening them up again by the time that "boys" started to appear in our home, with the purpose - varying only in the degree to which they failed to disguise it - of getting my sister away from us, on her own.

Often to the pictures. In much the same way, I'm sure, as our parents had done, and as I in my own good time would do, they bought their tickets, sat in the back row and snogged - and more. But there was this difference: for my mother, at least, the pictures themselves were not supposed to reflect her life but to take her out of it. They were glamour too, and romance, and sex - she didn't like to admit to having "favourites" but she did, Tyrone Power, Gregory Peck and, a bit later, Elvis. Watching any of these could make her blush or flush. My father teased her about it, gently. He had other things on his mind - like making sure my sister was still drawing the line between a bit of slap-and-tickle, and the unthinkable. It is a tribute to his flexibility, to my sister's perseverance, and to the distance they both travelled together that when one Sunday breakfast-time she broke into a bit of music-hall of her own - "To have a poke with a bloke may be quite accidental / Durex is a girl's best friend" - my mother only spluttered with pretend outrage and my father just smiled awkwardly and smoothed his moustache with the back of his hand, first one side then the other.

A modest man, it was his good-natured way of acknowledging something immodest. He and most of his generation have gone; so has my mother and so has modesty, in London at least. Sex, long used to sell the products of the leisure industries, is now itself a leisure industry, the latest, lucrative opiate of the masses - those of them who don't want actual opiates, anyway. Busy getting an eyeful of Pan's Peoples' knickers on Top of the Pops or the bikinis on Benny Hill, I didn't see Page 3 coming.

When my girlfriend started to stay the night in my bedroom, nothing was said. Was this unusual? I can't think so. By then the work had been done - the family work and the social work. In my own case, the record-player played a bigger part in these than the Pill, a car or drugs. You could spend as long as you wanted on your own with your girlfriend in the comfort of your room, doing more or less what you wanted, as long as the record player was on - it was called "Listening to records". And I did listen to them, as well. Certain songs - bits of The White Album and Disraeli Gears, Smokey Robinson, Marvin Gaye, quite a lot of the Stones, the Doors, and Leonard Cohen - still mean, for me, the crossing of boundaries that were first crossed to the accompaniment of their voices. In other words: they mean everything.

 Alan Jenkins latest book of poems is The Drift, published by Chatto and Windus

fields.headline: The death of custom
fields.standfirst: "The remnants of what was at least in part an urban culture 'of the people' are being destroyed." Richard Hoggart, 1957. That was then. DJ Taylor sees how things stand now, in the era of Kentucky Fried Chicken and Rupert Murdoch
fields.trailText: "The remnants of what was at least in part an urban culture 'of the people' are being destroyed." Richard Hoggart, 1957. That was then. DJ Taylor sees how things stand now, in the era of Kentucky Fried Chicken and Rupert Murdoch
fields.body:
On the shelves of the second-hand bookshops, the "classics" of the 1950s lie drawn up in rows: Lucky Jim, The Future of Socialism, Room at the Top, Saturday Night and Sunday Morning. And yet, if one wanted to settle on the most "influential" book of the immediately postwar era - certainly one that provided a context in which Amis and Crosland could be discussed - there is a strong case for Richard Hoggart's The Uses of Literacy, first published in 1957 and, like its author, still very much alive.

The work of a then obscure tutor at Hull University's Department of Adult Education, The Uses of Literacy had an impact out of all proportion to its modest sales. Even today no textbook account of postwar social developments can get by without its four- or five-page recension, and the book's influence hangs over fiction written in and about the time.

The Hoggart thesis has suffered so often at the hands of sympathetic commentators anxious to prove the negative effects of mass culture on "ordinary life" that it is worth restating it in the author's own terms. His argument was not, as he put it, "that there was, in England one generation ago, an urban culture still very much 'of the people' and that now there is only a mass urban culture." Rather, it was that the appeals made by what he called "the mass publicists" were made "more insistently, effectively and in a more comprehensive and centralised form today than they were earlier; that we are moving towards the creation of a mass culture, that the remnants of what was at least in part an urban culture "of the people" are being destroyed".

In his studies of cheap novels and magazines, popular newspapers and postwar cinema, Hoggart detected drift on almost every side. The old, close, tightly-knit working-class culture of stuffy front rooms, allotments, back-to-back housing and charabanc trips was breaking up. In its place was emerging a mass culture composed of tabloid newspapers, advertising and Hollywood. Forty years later, it is important to realise that what Hoggart is complaining about is not popular culture - defined as the ordinary routines of working-class life - but mass culture. This is a serious distinction. After all, when an early 21st century critic laments the victory of "popular culture", the chances are that he or she means McDonald's, Rupert Murdoch and the Daily Mirror - in other words something that is imposed on the populace from above.

The value that Hoggart found in "popular" culture, whether lived out in working men's clubs or around the family hearth, lay in what he saw as its fundamental integrity, but also in the fact that it was self-created, broadly sui generis, evolving according to its own laws and dictates rather than at the promptings of the mass media. Using this as a yardstick, it is tempting to wonder whether such a thing as "popular culture" still exists, whether TV, the VCR and the Kentucky Fried Chicken bar on every corner haven't simply ironed out genuine manifestations of popular will and choice into a uniform consumerist whole.

At the same time, the cultural landscape of the past five decades is littered with the bones of more or less unforced manifestations of popular taste. Practically any musical movement of the last 40 years, for example, can be traced back to a crucible far beneath the mass-cultural assembly line. The early 60s beat boom, and by extension the Beatles, began with merchant seamen bringing back obscure American rhythm 'n' blues records back to Merseyside. "Mod" started life in a handful of west London pubs, just as a dozen years later punk rock crawled off the streets of London and Manchester, and a dozen years after that the popularity of a new kind of dance music and the availability of a new kind of recreational drug combined to produce Acid House. The essential element of these movements was that no one - no music press journalist or marketing baron - had foreseen them. They had simply taken root somewhere in the subculture before growing to the point where the media was prepared to take an interest.

It hardly needs saying, of course, that "media interest" nearly always means an immediate expropriation and assimilation by the mass culture. But very occasionally, a genuinely "popular" phenomenon manages to survive and prosper beyond the constricting net of the mass culture and the mass audience. A good example from the world of music might be the "Northern Soul" movement of the 60s and 70s. Centred on the famous Wigan Casino and various other up-country venues, based on rosters of little-known records imported from the States, it inspired a fanatical following of weekending dancers and its own patterns and rituals, without ever finding the wider commercial interest to extend it beyond its original base.

Elsewhere, if any of the threads of the genuine "popular culture" whose disappearance Hoggart was regretting 40 years ago still exist, they do so far out of sight, deep down on the factory floor or the street corner - in hobbies and small-scale activities that the tabloid newspapers and television have never approached. Oddly enough, out beyond the cultural horse collar of the M25, there are still substantial numbers of people taking part in Cumberland wrestling, pigeon racing, caged-bird fancying and whippet-rearing.

Such things go unreported and unexploited by the mass media merely because there is no money in them, but they are there. Even a car boot sale, that odd 80s version of the street market, represents "popular culture" at work at the most basic level: something self-creating and with its own private ordinances. Richard Hoggart would probably be appalled to think that the, undoubtedly limited, but also warm and comfortable working-class world he described in The Uses of Literacy should come to rest in a semi-circle of hucksters selling counterfeit videos from the backs of cars. But given the ravages that mass culture has wrought on our national life in the past half-century, even this is a survival of a sort.
