webTitle: Dumb: Is America bad for us?

fields.headline: Is America bad for us?
fields.standfirst: How is it possible to maintain cultural difference in a world run by US corporations? With difficulty, argues Phillip Horne. But it's not all America's fault, says Nicholas Lezard
fields.trailText: How is it possible to maintain cultural difference in a world run by US corporations? With difficulty, argues Phillip Horne. But it's not all America's fault, says Nicholas Lezard
fields.body:
Phillip Horne: Yes

What is "global culture"? Three quarters of a century ago "global" was a mathematical term meaning spherical. The terms "globalisation", "globality" or "global culture" would have conveyed little more than "oblong culture" or "trapezoid culture".

Not that "globe" itself lacked metaphorical bite. Shakespeare had shown the potential for poetical spin on the word in The Tempest, where Prospero says the masque-vision he has magically conjured must fade away, just as "the great globe itself, Yea, all which it inherit, shall dissolve". And in A Midsummer Night's Dream, the fairy king Oberon, reconciled to Titania, promises her that "We the globe can compass soon/ Swifter than the wand'ring moon." In fact, Shakespeare's Hamlet had also used the word, promising to remember his dead father "While memory holds a seat/ In this distracted globe" - making his head a world, as troubled heroes have done right down to The Matrix.

When we think of a globe it is usually a miniature model of the earth, which one finger can send into violent revolution. If we dwell on that aspect, the tag "global culture" ominously hints at a terrible, dizzying shrinkage, at the mercy of some external hand (eg Disney, Murdoch, Coca-Cola). The more obvious implication, of course, is that "global culture" is something vast, a giant structure existing beyond any of us no matter how cosmopolitan our personal horizons. Neither way does "global culture" seem to belong to medium-sized human beings with a local habitation and a name. But then are we really supposed to feel good about it? Perhaps it is often meant sarcastically - as an oxymoron indeed - as if to say, "What kind of roots could a culture like that grow?"

Or, if we follow the modern tendency to use the word "culture" as a neutral term of anthropological description rather than positive endorsement, "global culture" might simply name the artistic and other non-essential phenomena (like fashion) commonly consumed in most of the countries of the world. If this means shopping in an airport mall for a hard copy of Stephen King, Independence Day on DVD and Nike footwear, we are a long way indeed from Matthew Arnold's definition of culture in 1876 as "the acquainting ourselves with the best that has been known and said in the world". We might be tempted to offer some sourly updated formula to fit the global culture of the 21st century, like "the acquiring for ourselves the best-advertised that is being made and sold in the world".

The emerging order certainly offers some opportunities for the Arnoldians among us: Internet shopping, for example, and the practice of multi-language subtitling on DVD, promises that we will be able to follow the oeuvres of foreign film-makers without being dependent on the whims of UK distributors. The Internet also allows British readers to explore a world of books in English (and, if we're equipped, "in foreign") not published in this country. New broader markets create newly profitable constituencies for minority interests. But such openings for a personal culture - for self-improvement - are side-roads off the information highway, permitted accidents of a system commercially geared to maximise corporate profit by maximising transactions.

A decade or two ago, one used to think an "entertainment empire" was an incidental, if highly profitable, aspect of serious political power and control. Now big corporations wield more power than national governments, and it is in their interest to make the world safe for shopping by promoting a pseudo-democratic "culture" where obedient workers obtain their rewards by consuming movies, TV, music, fashions, cigarettes and foods, and by making other "lifestyle" expenditures. "Rebellion" is part of the package of associated values offered with every purchase, but mostly within what would in the 70s have been called "the system", in the form of the rock star's circumscribed individual bravado rather than political or social protest.

Yet it is likely that sooner or later there will be some form of more organised resistance to these new kinds of imperialism. In fact some of the most conspicuous recent mainstream Hollywood movies themselves seem to smuggle in a measure of ironic criticism of the processes by which they are made and purveyed. The Richard Gere thriller Red Corner (1998) was about Western media corporations moving into the huge, corrupt new market of Communist China, and its lawyer-hero ends by rejecting his work for a US corporation and telling the US embassy to "Go to hell". The Bond movie Tomorrow Never Dies (1997) had Jonathan Pryce as its villain, a Murdoch-like conspirator for world media domination. The Truman Show (1998) and The Matrix (1999), like Paul Verhoeven's Total Recall a few years back, are allegories of false consciousness, whose heroes are called to wake up to the illusoriness of the constructed world they only seem to inhabit, and, somehow, to dissolve it and break out.

Furthermore, it does not seem that the main reason for Hollywood's return to the Roman Empire as a subject in Ridley Scott's Gladiator is that CGI technology now allows one to fill in the missing bits of the Coliseum and crowd it with cheap digitally rendered extras. The sprawling, ethnically diverse Roman world the film presents holds many parallels with the US empire of today. In particular, its genuine traditions of representative government have given way to crazed despotism and the bloody mass-entertainment displays of the gladiatorial ring.

It is surely no coincidence that one of Gladiator's writers, John Logan, also wrote Oliver Stone's thuggish football movie Any Given Sunday. Both films, themselves crowd-pleasing spectacles of violence, offer a consciously wishful fantasy-ending in which the battered hero remembers the authentic values which have become degraded. He then heroically re-establishes them in the very arena where the corrupt regime - for Stone, it is television - most potently displays its power. The edge of desperation in all these films suggests the traumatic, trapped condition of the citizen of today's world, who has nowhere else to go and for whom the globe is like the bubble that repeatedly and inescapably swallows up Patrick McGoohan in The Prisoner (a source, surely, for The Truman Show). And it is all too plausible to see the films themselves as swallowed up by the system they may be trying to criticise, reinserted into the industry of human interest and indiscriminate sensation (the "culture") that helps to distract the people of the globe from realising how they stand.

 Phillip Horne is Professor of English Literature at University College London. His Henry James: A Life in Letters is published in paperback early next year

Nicholas Lezard: No

Two observations. First: Anthony Burgess begins You've Had Your Time, the second volume of his autobiography, with an anecdote about being convinced he was going to die during a trip to America; "I was revived", he says, "with quarts of chill Coca-Cola, against which let no man say a word."

Second observation: an American film based on a true story, about the capture of a German U-Boat during the second world war, is released in this country. To our great consternation, the nationality of the capturers has been changed from British to American. This, we feel, is a tampering with the historical record which cannot be condoned. The common ground for disdain here is America. It is the source of all that vulgarly affronts and afflicts the high, doomed culture of Europe. And "vulgar" is the word: America is for the crowd in the movie house, and not the scholar in the garret. Who are these idiotic Trimalchios, these moneyed yahoos to whom we are so powerfully drawn?

In The Loved One, Evelyn Waugh described the contents of the averagely educated American's mind as the kind of sparse furniture one barked one's shins against in an otherwise empty room. His hero, the English expatriate poet Dennis Barlow, woos Aimée Thanatogenos, the funeral parlour beautician, by quoting the most famously anthologised English poems and allowing her to think that he has written them himself. When she went to university she studied "Beauticraft".

Saul Bellow coined the term "the moronic inferno" to describe his country; the less highbrow American film critic Joe Queenan pointed out in his book America that "this society was dominated by the likes of William Shatner, not William Shakespeare". But there is something unconvincing about this view, something about it that doesn't quite hold up to close scrutiny. American culture is built on quantities: on mass reproduction and consumption, on filling a vast space with a homogenous unity. To compare European and American is not to compare like with like. McDonald's boasts that its burgers taste identical all over the globe; Andy Warhol pointed out that the President's Coke tasted the same as the bum on the street's Coke, and no amount of power or wealth would buy the President a better Coke than the bum. Similarly, the great gift of America to the cultural universe, the Hollywood movie, has, by and large, been the product of rigidly-determined principles, guidelines and codes since its very inception.

Yet Hollywood has taken over the world. And when the world is overrun without a shot having had to be fired, then you can be sure that the world wanted to be conquered. For the great point about American culture is that it forces one to take a side, pro- or anti-, on the issue of democracy. If you don't like American culture you had better ask yourself what it is you are precisely objecting to, and an honest answer to that is often an uncomfortable one. To compare European Keats with American Dylan is a category error; and why not, while we are at it, compare American Henry James with European Donovan? The idea of us as the cultivated Greeks, to the Americans' barbaric but powerful Romans, can no longer be meaningfully sustained, and, to be fair, no one really tries any more, or hedges the argument about so carefully as to be more apology than argument. One may mock the American university, but that is the one which will buy your correspondence when you die.

But the U-Boat film remains a problem for many. The Americans' very cavalier treatment of the historical record is the issue. But I put it that we are not focusing on it in the right way. For the historical victor, history is malleable. And the question is not so much why the Americans rewrote history, as this: why we did not have the money, the energy, or the inspiration to make our own film about the event ourselves. If that is how we guard our heritage, ie "bleating about it long after the event", then we deserve to be written out of it.

 Nicholas Lezard is writing a book about the history and practice of fun, to be published by Faber and Faber
fields.bodyText: Phillip Horne: Yes What is "global culture"? Three quarters of a century ago "global" was a mathematical term meaning spherical. The terms "globalisation", "globality" or "global culture" would have conveyed little more than "oblong culture" or "trapezoid culture". Not that "globe" itself lacked metaphorical bite. Shakespeare had shown the potential for poetical spin on the word in The Tempest, where Prospero says the masque-vision he has magically conjured must fade away, just as "the great globe itself, Yea, all which it inherit, shall dissolve". And in A Midsummer Night's Dream, the fairy king Oberon, reconciled to Titania, promises her that "We the globe can compass soon/ Swifter than the wand'ring moon." In fact, Shakespeare's Hamlet had also used the word, promising to remember his dead father "While memory holds a seat/ In this distracted globe" - making his head a world, as troubled heroes have done right down to The Matrix. When we think of a globe it is usually a miniature model of the earth, which one finger can send into violent revolution. If we dwell on that aspect, the tag "global culture" ominously hints at a terrible, dizzying shrinkage, at the mercy of some external hand (eg Disney, Murdoch, Coca-Cola). The more obvious implication, of course, is that "global culture" is something vast, a giant structure existing beyond any of us no matter how cosmopolitan our personal horizons. Neither way does "global culture" seem to belong to medium-sized human beings with a local habitation and a name. But then are we really supposed to feel good about it? Perhaps it is often meant sarcastically - as an oxymoron indeed - as if to say, "What kind of roots could a culture like that grow?" Or, if we follow the modern tendency to use the word "culture" as a neutral term of anthropological description rather than positive endorsement, "global culture" might simply name the artistic and other non-essential phenomena (like fashion) commonly consumed in most of the countries of the world. If this means shopping in an airport mall for a hard copy of Stephen King, Independence Day on DVD and Nike footwear, we are a long way indeed from Matthew Arnold's definition of culture in 1876 as "the acquainting ourselves with the best that has been known and said in the world". We might be tempted to offer some sourly updated formula to fit the global culture of the 21st century, like "the acquiring for ourselves the best-advertised that is being made and sold in the world". The emerging order certainly offers some opportunities for the Arnoldians among us: Internet shopping, for example, and the practice of multi-language subtitling on DVD, promises that we will be able to follow the oeuvres of foreign film-makers without being dependent on the whims of UK distributors. The Internet also allows British readers to explore a world of books in English (and, if we're equipped, "in foreign") not published in this country. New broader markets create newly profitable constituencies for minority interests. But such openings for a personal culture - for self-improvement - are side-roads off the information highway, permitted accidents of a system commercially geared to maximise corporate profit by maximising transactions. A decade or two ago, one used to think an "entertainment empire" was an incidental, if highly profitable, aspect of serious political power and control. Now big corporations wield more power than national governments, and it is in their interest to make the world safe for shopping by promoting a pseudo-democratic "culture" where obedient workers obtain their rewards by consuming movies, TV, music, fashions, cigarettes and foods, and by making other "lifestyle" expenditures. "Rebellion" is part of the package of associated values offered with every purchase, but mostly within what would in the 70s have been called "the system", in the form of the rock star's circumscribed individual bravado rather than political or social protest. Yet it is likely that sooner or later there will be some form of more organised resistance to these new kinds of imperialism. In fact some of the most conspicuous recent mainstream Hollywood movies themselves seem to smuggle in a measure of ironic criticism of the processes by which they are made and purveyed. The Richard Gere thriller Red Corner (1998) was about Western media corporations moving into the huge, corrupt new market of Communist China, and its lawyer-hero ends by rejecting his work for a US corporation and telling the US embassy to "Go to hell". The Bond movie Tomorrow Never Dies (1997) had Jonathan Pryce as its villain, a Murdoch-like conspirator for world media domination. The Truman Show (1998) and The Matrix (1999), like Paul Verhoeven's Total Recall a few years back, are allegories of false consciousness, whose heroes are called to wake up to the illusoriness of the constructed world they only seem to inhabit, and, somehow, to dissolve it and break out. Furthermore, it does not seem that the main reason for Hollywood's return to the Roman Empire as a subject in Ridley Scott's Gladiator is that CGI technology now allows one to fill in the missing bits of the Coliseum and crowd it with cheap digitally rendered extras. The sprawling, ethnically diverse Roman world the film presents holds many parallels with the US empire of today. In particular, its genuine traditions of representative government have given way to crazed despotism and the bloody mass-entertainment displays of the gladiatorial ring. It is surely no coincidence that one of Gladiator's writers, John Logan, also wrote Oliver Stone's thuggish football movie Any Given Sunday. Both films, themselves crowd-pleasing spectacles of violence, offer a consciously wishful fantasy-ending in which the battered hero remembers the authentic values which have become degraded. He then heroically re-establishes them in the very arena where the corrupt regime - for Stone, it is television - most potently displays its power. The edge of desperation in all these films suggests the traumatic, trapped condition of the citizen of today's world, who has nowhere else to go and for whom the globe is like the bubble that repeatedly and inescapably swallows up Patrick McGoohan in The Prisoner (a source, surely, for The Truman Show). And it is all too plausible to see the films themselves as swallowed up by the system they may be trying to criticise, reinserted into the industry of human interest and indiscriminate sensation (the "culture") that helps to distract the people of the globe from realising how they stand.  Phillip Horne is Professor of English Literature at University College London. His Henry James: A Life in Letters is published in paperback early next year Nicholas Lezard: No Two observations. First: Anthony Burgess begins You've Had Your Time, the second volume of his autobiography, with an anecdote about being convinced he was going to die during a trip to America; "I was revived", he says, "with quarts of chill Coca-Cola, against which let no man say a word." Second observation: an American film based on a true story, about the capture of a German U-Boat during the second world war, is released in this country. To our great consternation, the nationality of the capturers has been changed from British to American. This, we feel, is a tampering with the historical record which cannot be condoned. The common ground for disdain here is America. It is the source of all that vulgarly affronts and afflicts the high, doomed culture of Europe. And "vulgar" is the word: America is for the crowd in the movie house, and not the scholar in the garret. Who are these idiotic Trimalchios, these moneyed yahoos to whom we are so powerfully drawn? In The Loved One, Evelyn Waugh described the contents of the averagely educated American's mind as the kind of sparse furniture one barked one's shins against in an otherwise empty room. His hero, the English expatriate poet Dennis Barlow, woos Aimée Thanatogenos, the funeral parlour beautician, by quoting the most famously anthologised English poems and allowing her to think that he has written them himself. When she went to university she studied "Beauticraft". Saul Bellow coined the term "the moronic inferno" to describe his country; the less highbrow American film critic Joe Queenan pointed out in his book America that "this society was dominated by the likes of William Shatner, not William Shakespeare". But there is something unconvincing about this view, something about it that doesn't quite hold up to close scrutiny. American culture is built on quantities: on mass reproduction and consumption, on filling a vast space with a homogenous unity. To compare European and American is not to compare like with like. McDonald's boasts that its burgers taste identical all over the globe; Andy Warhol pointed out that the President's Coke tasted the same as the bum on the street's Coke, and no amount of power or wealth would buy the President a better Coke than the bum. Similarly, the great gift of America to the cultural universe, the Hollywood movie, has, by and large, been the product of rigidly-determined principles, guidelines and codes since its very inception. Yet Hollywood has taken over the world. And when the world is overrun without a shot having had to be fired, then you can be sure that the world wanted to be conquered. For the great point about American culture is that it forces one to take a side, pro- or anti-, on the issue of democracy. If you don't like American culture you had better ask yourself what it is you are precisely objecting to, and an honest answer to that is often an uncomfortable one. To compare European Keats with American Dylan is a category error; and why not, while we are at it, compare American Henry James with European Donovan? The idea of us as the cultivated Greeks, to the Americans' barbaric but powerful Romans, can no longer be meaningfully sustained, and, to be fair, no one really tries any more, or hedges the argument about so carefully as to be more apology than argument. One may mock the American university, but that is the one which will buy your correspondence when you die. But the U-Boat film remains a problem for many. The Americans' very cavalier treatment of the historical record is the issue. But I put it that we are not focusing on it in the right way. For the historical victor, history is malleable. And the question is not so much why the Americans rewrote history, as this: why we did not have the money, the energy, or the inspiration to make our own film about the event ourselves. If that is how we guard our heritage, ie "bleating about it long after the event", then we deserve to be written out of it.  Nicholas Lezard is writing a book about the history and practice of fun, to be published by Faber and Faber

fields.headline: A tale of two tulips
fields.standfirst: Harriet Porter on how the boom in narrative non-fiction is leading to a decline in standards of scholarship
fields.trailText: Harriet Porter on how the boom in narrative non-fiction is leading to a decline in standards of scholarship
fields.body:
The process of dumbing down is nowhere more apparent than in the world of non-fiction. Compare Tulipomania, a 1950 King Penguin, written by Wilfred Blunt, art master at Eton, with The Tulip, a 1999 Bloomsbury glossy hardback written by Anna Pavord, journalist. King Penguins, introduced during the war, were miniature monographs the length of a modern magazine article, plus 20 colour plates. Exceptional care was taken over KPs, with text and pictures by different British printers; they were Allen Lane's determined attempt, at 3s each, to make quality hardbacks more widely accessible. He had responded to the real hunger generated during the war for non-fiction, further intensified after the 1944 Butler Act led to the partial reformation of the education system and a new popular audience for factual information. The pictures in Pavord's book, by contrast, feel lavish, ripe for a public satiated by slick magazines.

Other publishing houses besides Penguin also thickened their non-fiction catalogues during the 50s and 60s. Familiar categories existed - biography, history, travel, food and science, although not cultural studies - but individual works were not commissioned with any intent to market the books so as to achieve sales comparable with bestselling fiction. There was less pressure on academic writers to publish - if they did, the results were not titled and marketed to the general reading public; there were a limited number of non-academic, professional writers - non-fiction was most often the byproduct of an authorial passion necessarily subsidised by the day job.

Now non-fiction, in particular narrative non-fiction (books like Longitude, or Cod, which dramatise historical incident, invention or some narrow cultural byway) is the heart of what is laughably called the business of publishing. The books above aren't the real culprits; as usual, it is the legion of low-grade imitators which are dumbing down non-fiction. Editors, scrabbling around for the latest arcane topic, seem be taking more and more books produced by those who, with no real knowledge of the subject, are simply looking to make a quick buck. The notion of peer review, as used to happen with traditional academic monographs, has gone out of the window. These books are commissioned and promoted in the hope of the same marketable appeal, and often the same personal creative identity, as fiction. There's nothing wrong with that in itself, it's when the books themselves become farragos of untruth, and the marketing undermines genuine scholarship, that the trouble starts.

fields.headline: Violence
fields.standfirst: Thug culture is becoming the norm for the mass of young British men. Greg Williams finds its roots in films and classroom failure
fields.trailText: Thug culture is becoming the norm for the mass of young British men. Greg Williams finds its roots in films and classroom failure
fields.body:
If one is to believe gloomy news reports regarding exam results, literacy, absentee teenage fathers and (most of all) casual violence then there exists a generation of young men who wilfully fail every educational and behavioural standard set for them.

Whether you believe that schools are failing our boys or that our boys are failing the schools, one thing is as clear as the serial Fs on their report cards: boys are becoming increasingly marginalised from the education system. Denied or rejecting traditional roles of parenthood or breadwinning, young men are increasingly looking to the street and to what can only be described as "attitude" to define themselves.

The influences that wash over them are many and varied - ranging from acquisitive trainer culture and combative video games, to the corporate sponsored financial free-for-all that masquerades as the Premiership. But one thing is increasingly clear, these days, being perceived as a geezer, or its more alarming cousin, a thug, is a more commonly travelled avenue for young white working-class men in search of identity and purpose than we would like to think.

Even the posh boys, the providers of culture, want a slice of the action. The movies Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and Snatch - the makers of which were, unsurprisingly, not educated at the state's expense - have had huge success amongst the key cinema-going demographic of young men in their late teens and early 20s.

Lock, Stock  and Snatch, of course, offer no real insight into thug culture, preferring to reference superior American movies, dress them up in Arfur Daley's camel Crombie and package them in skilfully edited chunks accompanied by an MTV-friendly sound track. What they do well is to trade on the stereotypical bish, bash, bosh culture of wideboys and the various hilarious racial archetypes that they encounter on their crazy adventures in the land of mockney. So acute was the nerve that the Lock, Stock  movie tapped into, that the Channel Four TV series was rewarded with a marketing tie-in to its very antithesis, The Sun.

These movies are the Robbie Williams of film-making: cheeky, ironic, knowing, crass and central to a culture that the writers Steven Daly and Mark Jordan have dubbed Thick Plus. "Thick Plus is the sum of the moronically ironic, the cluelessly camp, the oafishly sexy, the methodically soulful and the gamely ersatz," they wrote recently. Thick Plus consciously pilfers black and gay culture and reappropriates it within the mainstream. It is possible that white youth, robbed of meaningful ways of representation, is finding itself further marginalised by the upper-middle-class programme makers/editors/film-makers who co opt the lives of traditional outsiders for mass consumption.

The brutish and reductive nature of cultural totems such as Lock, Stock  and Robbie Williams goes some way to explaining why there is a "crisis" of sorts amongst young British men. It wasn't always so. Young men, from teds to punks to skinheads have always rebelled, and always actively and wilfully used clothes, music and attitude to distance themselves from the mainstream, to declare themselves outsiders. And in Britain, perhaps more than anywhere else in the world, reacting against the mainstream can take the form of dressing smartly and conservatively - from the mod to casual to today's Polo geezer - in order to prove that you are worthy, that you've arrived.

The semiotics of apparel are such that dressing up has also been the mode of choice for gangsters from Capone onwards. One of the most memorable images of recent times was that of the young white men accused of murdering black teenager Stephen Lawrence leaving a public inquiry into police handling of the case. Dressed in natty suits and shirts, eyes masked by sunglasses, they behaved with a brazenly studied bullishness that marked them out as more like a football firm than witnesses summoned by the official fiat.

The look was derivative, culled from one of the opening sequences of Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs, which itself came from classic iconography of that most masculine and exclusive of male clubs, the Rat Pack.

The attitude, of course, was calculatedly disrespectful. They also wanted to demonstrate something else: they wanted to show us that they were game, that they could look after themselves. In contemporary Britain it seems that the culture amongst many young men is exactly that - they're a bit tasty, can take care of themselves when it comes to the pavement. Sadly, few would wish to doubt them.  Greg Williams is the author of the novel Diamond Geezer, and a former editor of Arena magazine

fields.headline: Think pink: soon  you will have to
fields.standfirst: Mark Simpson on why dumbing down is really gaying up
fields.trailText: Mark Simpson on why dumbing down is really gaying up
fields.body:
It is true: there really is a "gay conspiracy". It stretches its pink tentacles into every aspect of our contemporary culture, from TV to music, publishing to politics. It is a conspiracy aimed at exploiting and extending the hegemony of mass culture. In fact, so successful is it that everybody talks about "dumbing down", instead of what is obviously "gaying up". Habits previously associated with gays, such as nightclubs, promiscuity and diva worship, are all the rage with straight people. Pop music is dominated by silly boy bands and bossy girl groups - usually with gay puppetmasters pulling the strings. Even politics is under the gay sway: New Labour's populist "image-led" makeover was masterminded by a gay Svengali prince of pinkness, while New Toryism's William Hague sports a buzz-cut makeover that makes him looks like a gay man's interpretation of Grant Mitchell.

It wasn't always this way. Not so long ago homos were involved in a very different kind of conspiracy - a conspiracy of high culture against the hoi polloi. Homos were aesthetes par excellence - colonising and often monopolising the arts and disdaining the mob. Oscar Wilde was the very symbol of the homo as aesthete: in fact it was his arrest and very public trial which made aestheticism "homosexual".

When high culture was "hot", this is where gays - who, being largely rootless, tend to align themselves like iron filings with the poles of magnetic influence - ended up. In the postwar period, the rise of consumerism and "pop culture" reorientated British society's attention away from the "highbrow" to the "lowbrow", from elitism to populism.

The comic tragedy of Kenneth Williams' life was bound up with the way that he was caught between these two poles, forever oscillating backwards and forwards between "high" and "low" - rather like his voice; which went from "dead common" to "dead posh", often in the same sentence. Of course, even the grandest of the homo aesthetes had an interest in low culture, or at least the lower orders. What Wilde described as "feasting with panthers" was what Williams would have called simply "rough trade". Edmund White and Alan Hollinghurst are examples of contemporary literary gay writers who straddle "high" and "low" in their work - a night at the opera might in their books be followed by a visit to the leather club and an exciting encounter with a despatch rider.

And there were some homosexuals who rejected both high and low culture and instead were drawn to a "bohemian" or "alternative" culture. The last gasp of any kind of alternative culture in Britain was punk, which was incubated in gay pubs and clubs because punks, bless 'em, thought that gays were outsiders like themselves.

Queer proved to be more shortlived than Madonna's "lesbian" period, and failed to reverse the main post-Stonewall gay political strategy - "we're just the same as you". Or, for that matter, the consequent homogenisation of gay culture. This is why gays are perfectly situated by the beginning of the New Millennium to exploit and extend the reign of mass culture. Having gone spectacularly mainstream themselves, gays set about mainstreaming everything else and advancing themselves by gaying up. A cultural elite - with their history of camp, irony, mastery of surfaces and haircuts - they disguised themselves and their influence by pretending to be naffer than the naffs.

 Mark Simpson's The Queen is Dead (Arcadia, £11.99) has just been published

fields.headline: Art
fields.standfirst: Almost by stealth, the public has discovered that it likes modern art after all, says Adrian Searle. And they don't think that it's dumb
fields.trailText: Almost by stealth, the public has discovered that it likes modern art after all, says Adrian Searle. And they don't think that it's dumb
fields.body:
Have artists lost their art historical sense? Did the heroics of abstract expressionism in 1950 lead inexorably to acres of sloppy, fumbling mannerism and too much heavy breathing? Did pop art lead to pap, so you can't tell the difference between art and advertising, the artist and the product controller in the R&D department? Well, advertising has got a lot more clever and a lot more fun since the ad-men started taking a look at contemporary art. Did conceptual art, with its texts on the wall, long walks and a-glass-of-water-as-an-oak-tree point to everyone being an artist and everything being art, which is the same as no one being an artist, nothing being valued as art?

If we have trouble sorting out what is art and what is not, we still somehow manage to say that some things are better than others, for often quite different reasons. You hear it so often, that all those modern artists are only pulling the wool over the public's eyes, with their stupid piles of bricks, their concrete sheds and their dung-covered canvases. It is easy to laugh, in a superior kind of way, both at the more extreme examples of contemporary art and at the apparent philistinism of its detractors. But, almost by stealth, the British public has discovered it perhaps does like modern art after all.

Has the public wised up, or has the art dumbed down? If - and I think it is an if - people find that contemporary art is not so difficult or complicated or highbrow and impenetrable as they once thought, it could also mean that the art is somehow becoming less intelligent, less sophisticated than it was. The current enthusiasm for modern art - there are more people visiting Tate Modern every week than there were people in Florence at the height of the Renaissance - appears to be more than a fad. If people got nothing from what they see there, they would vote with their feet.

At the end of the 19th century a lot of people had problems with Impressionism, and, later, when confronted with Picasso and Braque's cubist paintings, the gallery-going public had problems with those too. The surrealists were often deemed mad, but liking surrealism is perfectly sane and acceptable, and it appears everywhere, from posters to advertising campaigns. We are all more visually literate than before, more immune to shocks, innured to surprises. Little wonder artists often feel the need to take things to ever greater extremes, to make things bigger, or more abject, more high-flown, or more dumb.

It isn't such a great leap from the cubism of the early century to post-second world war pop art, in which the everyday - from Warhol's Brillo Boxes to Roy Lichtenstein's comic-book paintings - both celebrated and cast a jaundiced eye over the pickings of the consumer society. And from there, we can arrive at Sarah Lucas's montaged behemoths taken from the pages of the Sunday Sport, and her rude still lives. In fact, the resonances and references make her work better, rather than diminishing it. In a way, shorn of a shared religious value system and old certainties, art had to turn its gaze on the world about it - a world that contains both Chardin and shopping, the museum and the massage parlour, advertising, the movies, TV, the proliferating electronic media.

Where have all the allegories gone, whither the theories, where's the beef? Technically, the resources available today for artists are astonishing. Even as far back as the 20s the Hungarian born experimenter Moholy-Nagy lamented the gulf between the painter's technology and the amazing resources of film. Yet painting persists, not killed by the camera after all. You can have Bill Viola's videos and Lucien Freud's portraits, Chris Ofili's paintings and Douglas Gordon's Hitchcock appropriations.

Painting and sculpture have histories almost as old as mankind. But video and film have histories too, albeit shorter ones. The emergence of these two media as art forms has been arguably the biggest change in art practice in the last half-century. The ready-made - the appropriation of real objects as artworks - has a history which leads from Picasso's use of a real absinthe spoon in a 1912 sculpture, through Duchamp's 1919 shop-bought urinal to Damien Hirst's shark, Tracey Emin's beach hut and bed and Jeff Koons's spanking new vacuum cleaners in perspex cabinets. Some of these works are better, more telling, funnier, more apposite than others. Lineage and history don't go away, and sheer newness or novelty probably counts for less in art than it did even 20 years ago.

fields.headline: The whole whack
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom on how, for better or worse, we have unzipped the very idea of what culture actually is
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom on how, for better or worse, we have unzipped the very idea of what culture actually is
fields.body:
Culture used to be so simple. Culture used to mean art, literature, and ideas. And not just any old art, literature, and ideas. Culture was High Art, Great Literature, and Big Ideas. And more particularly, our High Art, Great Literature, and Big Ideas.

But these days culture means cultures, plural. It also means Things as well as Ideas, and the Everyday as well as the Exceptional.

When people talk about contemporary culture they are therefore just as likely to be talking about biros, fast cars and Mars Bars, trainers or high heels as they are to be talking about about Shostakovich, Shakespeare or Nabokov. Goods have become as significant a measure and marker of culture as the Great and the Good.

The meaning of culture has been extended to cover just about any thing. Culture is no longer merely the beautiful and sublime, the refined. Culture is life in the raw, the whole whack, head to toe, up to and including the Pokemon phenomenon, kettles and the kitchen sink. This turn to things is really quite recent. It wasn't until the late 20th century that a scholarly interest in items began to displace the traditional interest in -isms, with historians, literary critics and philosophers all suddenly becoming fascinated by the meaning of objects, large and small.

It may be that this interest in material culture represents a return to an interest in the nature of matter, traditionally one of the great subjects of philosophy. It may represent a renewed search for the Aristotelian materia prima - the primary matter, an attempt at divining the very stuff of life. Or it may just be a sign of a society cracking under the strain of too many things.Our current obsession with material culture, one might argue, is simply a response to the Western crisis of abundance. We are addicted to stuff. We live in terror of being swamped by what we own and possess, but we can't do without it.

In a relatively short period - just over 70 years - our lives have become so freighted and loaded with things that we no longer know what to think about them. So we theorise. Of course, people have always sensed a massiveness, a meaning, looming up from within objects and artifacts, within even the smallest of things. Take Christian relics: pieces of petrified bone, hems of garments  these things have always been understood to carry meaning. The difference is now, so too do stilettos and trainers.

There are obvious problems with this materialist conception of culture. If our experience of everyday life is unsatisfactory, then how much more unsatisfactory is the spectacle of everyday things under scrutiny. The thrill of the everyday as art object soon palls. And writing about material culture is no better. Books about the trivial always tend towards the pompous: stuff soon becomes stuffy. As the poet DJ Enright once remarked, "The more sophisticated among us are unused to the obvious and, when duty obliges us to take note, we incline to belabour it as a signficant discovery."

Then again, some obvious things are significant discoveries: fragranced plastic nappy sacks for example, or mobile phones. There are those who believe that talking or writing about such things is a technique of evasion, a way of avoiding talking about more important things: human relationships, say, or in-depth psychology, history and politics.

But talking about things is a way of talking about people. Things are deeds: they are made by people, for people. The making and possessing of things calls into play our human capacity for imagination, reflection, and invention. Things embody and express conflict, desire, and fear. The narration of stuff, in other words, is the narration of lives. "I do not believe in things," said Georges Braque, "I believe in relationships." The two are not mutually exclusive.

Trainers
The increasingly relentless bombardment of ridiculously styled and overpriced trainers is the acme of dumb. Everyone thinks of Michael Jordan. But the trend for fancy athletic shoes cannot be attributed solely to him. When James Dean met his premature end in his Porsche in 1955 he did so shod in a pair of classic Converse Jack Purcell's, themselves named after a legendary badminton star of the 30s. Mr Dean's passion for shuttlecocks was not noted, but he liked the shoes. To be fair he didn't have much choice, it was either those or the similarly endorsed Chuck Taylor All Stars, another Converse product. In the 50s, besides brothel creepers, that was your lot 

By 1990, post Michael Jordan and the Nike explosion, it was a completely different story. Now, with brand ubiquity at saturation point, the sports shoe market has begun to turn full circle. The most popular trainer today is a bland tennis-cum-running shoe, the Reebok Classic. It is the definitive non-trainer. It does not hold inert gas bubbles or promise to help you run like a cheetah. Nor does it does it give you affiliation with long-retired tennis stars.
Matt Brookes

High heels

High heels have always walked a precarious path, epitomising both elegance and vulgarity, smartness and dumbness. Their ne plus ultra is the stiletto. Roger Vivier, Dior designer from 1953, is credited with its creation, although Italian shoemakers had already perfected the technology of inserting a metal pin to keep the heel from snapping. The shoe was named after the narrow-bladed knife favoured by Renaissance assassins.

It is their blatant sexuality that gives high heels their frisson of vulgarity. The accentuated phallic shape of the heel itself is nothing compared to the sexualising effect a pair of high heels has on a woman's body. The silhouette changes completely, giving the effect of 'push-up bras for the feet', as one fashion journalist put it.

The iconography of heels has inevitably become caught up in gender politics: odalisques in the harem of the Turkish sultan were once made to wear high, precarious sandals to prevent them from fleeing. Then there is the helplessness of a woman in heels: part real, part perceived. But the sexual politics of the heel are complex. The classic height for a pair of proper high heels is four or five inches: it is surely no coincidence that this cancels out the average height difference between the sexes.
Jess Cartner-Morley

fields.headline: Why today's protesters have to be smarter
fields.standfirst: The wising-up of dissent. Making yourself heard is harder than ever, argues Andy Beckett
fields.trailText: The wising-up of dissent. Making yourself heard is harder than ever, argues Andy Beckett
fields.body:
In 1968, as the rebellions of that decade felt like they were succeeding, the writer and activist Jeff Nuttall described the feeling. "Young people are not correcting society," he wrote. "They are regurgitating it." In 1996, as a counterculture of road protests and raves again appeared to be changing Britain, another excited writer, George McKay, could confidently write, "Britain's changing. Great, isn't it?"

Nowadays, McKay may be less optimistic. The goals of the postwar British counterculture - radical political change, protection for the environment, liberalisation of the drugs laws - seem as far away as ever. Meanwhile its methods - informal organisation, word-of-mouth communication, ingenious direct action - have been most successfully employed of late, in Britain at least, by conservative interest groups such as truck drivers and farmers. At the same time, for a majority of the population, this country is increasingly prosperous; consumer and career choices have probably never been so wide; what used to be scorned by hippies as "straight" society has seldom looked so enticing.

And as damp squats have become developers' opportunities, and drug chat has become standard syntax in advertisements, so it has begun to seem that the counterculture, far from undermining capitalism and the old hierarchies of class and wealth, has in fact reinvigorated them. Richard Branson, who once lived in a houseboat and sold records by longhaired Germans, is now Britain's best-known businessman. The organisers of illegal raves in the late 80s now run record labels for large corporations. As early as 1993, the Henley Centre estimated that the British dance music industry was as lucrative as book or newspaper publishing.

The ability to improvise and think irreverently are valuable commodities, now, in the restless global market. Britain's status in the world is increasingly tied to the frequency with which it throws up, packages, and exports rebellions such as punk. And if the mainstream has grown so inclusive and anarchic, then how can the counterculture define itself? When today's graffiti artist is tomorrow's sponsored muralist, the very notion of a counterculture can seem almost quaint.

It was much easier to spot dissent in the early postwar years. The "wild public festival spirit" Nuttall sensed on the first Aldermaston CND protests, the absurd costumes and raucous music, was not completely new; it echoed British revolts since the Civil War and earlier, with their vivid glee in mocking and overturning the dominant order. What made British rebelliousness different from the late 50s on was that a national media now existed: converts could be won, and opponents could be alerted.

By the mid-60s, complete dissenting lifestyles were available. The American journalist Tom Wolfe found one by following a London office boy on his lunch hour: "Larry Lynch cuts in the doorway at 79 Oxford Street  there is a vast black room heaving with music  a lot of boys and girls in this kinetic trance, dancing by themselves  The point is simply immersing yourself for one hour in The Life, every lunch hour." Wolfe noted the customised clothes, the swallowing of specific pills, the desire to create a separate world in a forgotten place in the city. This pattern would be repeated by punks in the 70s, ravers in the 80s and 90s, even today's nightclub purists.

Amid Wolfe's giddy detail, however, there were also hints that the counterculture could be tamed. The lunchtime disc jockeys had career plans. There were a few slightly older dancers, with an entrepreneurial eye on the fashions. And at the end, everyone went back to the office. Challenging the established order full time and sober has proved a harder occupation.

Communal living experiments had been tried in Britain, again, since at least the Civil War, yet by the early 70s the staples of this existence - the wet encampments, the wheezing travellers' vehicles, the squatted terraces - had become widely familiar. In the 80s, the right to live like this at all was questioned and roughly eroded by the Conservative government. Anyone who doubted that a counterculture still existed during Mrs Thatcher's boom years had only to see the pictures of policemen smashing up the Peace Convoy at Stonehenge.

When the Conservatives weakened in the mid-90s, the counterculture enjoyed perhaps its period of greatest British influence. Ideas about animal rights, opposition to bypasses, and anxiety about the free-market society Thatcher had created, all spread far beyond the inky bulletins of professional protesters and into the everyday conversation of more conventional Britons. For a time, it seemed that dreadlocked activists might be seen as principled rather than perplexing.

No longer. Anti-capitalist gatherings, like the recent May Day demonstrations, are once more mostly scorned by the press. To be taken seriously, it seems, protests have to happen in Prague or Seattle. The counterculture's hedonistic impulses, meanwhile, seem to have evolved into little more than a new set of dumb leisure appetites.

Yet when the next recession comes, or the mainstream culture stagnates, and these narrow islands seem stifling again, the old rebelliousness will re-emerge. The British counterculture anyway, is part of a worldwide network these days. And plenty of Britons still share its suspicion of today's ever-expanding corporations. The doorway of 79 Oxford Street is still there, too; maybe someone will stash their tools for uprooting GM corn in the basement.

fields.headline: Books
fields.standfirst: Pulp fiction. Alex Clark on why commercial realities are reducing the chances of truly innovative novels seeing the light of day
fields.trailText: Pulp fiction. Alex Clark on why commercial realities are reducing the chances of truly innovative novels seeing the light of day
fields.body:
In Rosamond Lehmann's The Weather in the Streets (1936), an aristocratic affair is begun on a train journey, amid a welter of grumbles about the passing landscape, desecrated by bungalows. "England gets squalider and squalider. So disgraced, so ignoble, so smug and pretentious and nobody minds enough to stop it," complains the heroine. We have just heard her puzzling over her inability to make any sense of Tristram Shandy.

In fictional terms, the spread of bungalows - with their connotations of cheapness and lack of taste - was to continue apace after the war. With the advent in the 50s of writers such as John Braine and Alan Sillitoe, whose novels were characterised by their provincial settings, downplayed realism and, above all, defiantly ordinary protagonists, the landscape of the novel was changed permanently.

The literary critic Cyril Connolly, whose Enemies of Promise was also published towards the end of the 30s, had proposed a theory of literary boom and bust, inflation and deflation to describe the succession of modernism by realism before the war. He was, however, confident that the pendulum was ready to swing back; the new realism, he claimed, was dead, its vocabulary "never rich, worn away by the attrition of success", its exponents "wearied by the enormity of their imitators". In the coming years, he believed, "experiment and adventure are indicated".

Connolly was not entirely wrong, for although the combination of accessible prose style and engaging subject matter was a key factor in the success of the "angry young men" - and in the comic novels of Kingsley Amis and John Wain - the experimental and the difficult still persisted. The 50s, for example, saw the publication of Beckett's Molloy trilogy, and Iris Murdoch's Under the Net (1954). Murdoch's debut, which briefly bestowed on her honorary "angry young man" status, can also be seen as realistic and comic; in fact, however, it is a densely philosophic work, heavily influenced by the author's interest in French thought, and by Beckett himself. A decade or two later, and BS Johnson had embarked on his career as an avant-garde writer, producing The Unfortunates (1969) - a novel written in 27 unbound sections and presented in a box.

Fast forward to 2000, and such abandoned and eccentric experimentalism no longer seems possible, not necessarily because it wouldn't find readers, but because it would be unlikely to attract a publisher. The last 10 years in particular have seen a swingeing rationalisation of the British publishing industry, with the larger, long-established houses incorporated into multinational conglomerates, editors placed under increasing pressure to maintain a healthy bottom line, and the unprecedented rise of the marketing campaign. Were Kafka's Metamorphosis to arrive on a literary editor's desk today, it would probably be accompanied by details of its author's readings at Waterstone's and a promotional gimmick in the shape of a can of Vapona fly spray; the publicity-shy author has become publishers' biggest headache.

Cultural pessimists could certainly argue for a decline in the quality and scope of the British novel, its limited aims and achievements dwarfed by the scale and diversity of its counterparts from America and the rest of the world. Such a damning judgment would be false, as brilliantly original and inventive novels continue to be written. It's not just about the collapsing of any dubious distinction between mass and literary fiction (as the jackets on this page show - that began long ago); the problem is that the difficult and the innovative are finding it harder than ever to fight their corner.
fields.bodyText: In Rosamond Lehmann's The Weather in the Streets (1936), an aristocratic affair is begun on a train journey, amid a welter of grumbles about the passing landscape, desecrated by bungalows. "England gets squalider and squalider. So disgraced, so ignoble, so smug and pretentious and nobody minds enough to stop it," complains the heroine. We have just heard her puzzling over her inability to make any sense of Tristram Shandy. With the advent in the 50s of writers such as John Braine and Alan Sillitoe, whose novels were characterised by their provincial settings, downplayed realism and, above all, defiantly ordinary protagonists, the landscape of the novel was changed permanently. The literary critic Cyril Connolly, whose Enemies of Promise was also published towards the end of the 30s, had proposed a theory of literary boom and bust, inflation and deflation to describe the succession of modernism by realism before the war. He was, however, confident that the pendulum was ready to swing back; the new realism, he claimed, was dead, its vocabulary "never rich, worn away by the attrition of success", its exponents "wearied by the enormity of their imitators". In the coming years, he believed, "experiment and adventure are indicated". Connolly was not entirely wrong, for although the combination of accessible prose style and engaging subject matter was a key factor in the success of the "angry young men" - and in the comic novels of Kingsley Amis and John Wain - the experimental and the difficult still persisted. The 50s, for example, saw the publication of Beckett's Molloy trilogy, and Iris Murdoch's Under the Net (1954). The last 10 years in particular have seen a swingeing rationalisation of the British publishing industry, with the larger, long-established houses incorporated into multinational conglomerates, editors placed under increasing pressure to maintain a healthy bottom line, and the unprecedented rise of the marketing campaign. webTitle: Dumb: The changing culture of the political interview

fields.headline: Boring old blokes on TV - an A to Z
fields.standfirst: The changing culture of the political interview
fields.trailText: The changing culture of the political interview
fields.body:
Aversion

Had things been left to Labour Prime Minister, Clement Attlee, in 1951, we would still all be tuning into our radios rather than switching on the TV. Deeply suspicious of the medium, Attlee, together with Opposition leader Winston Churchill and BBC's director general Sir William Haley, agreed that television should take no part in politics. Attlee viewed TV as nothing more than an idiot's lantern: Churchill, convinced that the BBC was 'honeycombed with Communists', agreed.

Autocue

Canny Harold Wilson recognised the power of TV and used it as the essential vehicle to take him to Number 10. Presenting the image of a down-to-earth practical family man, Wilson mended his son's bicycle for the cameras in his living room. His technique of scarcely moving his eyeballs as he read the autocue made him highly effective at speaking directly to the camera. "I felt the camera was my friend and not my enemy."

Bias
Early BBC political interviews were little more than party political broadcasts, stage- managed and rehearsed. Allegations of bias - which were to become commonplace - had fuelled calls for the establishment of independent TV. Aidan Crawley introduced Independent Television News in 1955, pledging to bring American television news techniques to Britain and to transform television's attitudes to politicians. "The obsequiousness of BBC staffers no doubt stemmed from the fact that they were in a sense civil servants, paid for out of public funds and on a lower grade than Cabinet ministers," said Reginald Bosanquet who would soon to take the lead in combative interviewing techniques.

Bow-tie
Robin Day's forthright style of questioning contrasted sharply with the deference still prevalent among BBC news reporters: One early critic wrote, "In the studio, Mr Day puts his blunt, loaded questions with the air of a prosecuting counsel at a murder trial. As he swings back to face the cameras, metaphorically blowing on his knuckles, one detects the muffled disturbance as his shaken victim is led away."

Grilling
Is Jeremy Paxman responsible for dumb TV? In comparison with some never-attained ideal of thoroughgoing political analysis, perhaps. But not when contrasted with the sycophantic deference that had come before. Paxman won the interview of the year category in the Television Sports and Journalism Awards 1997 for his savaging of Michael Howard on Newsnight. This historic exchange crystallised the disagreement over the state of interviewing. Paxman asked the former Home Secretary 14 times whether he had pressurised Derek Lewis, then head of the prisons service, to sack the governor of Parkhurst prison following the escape of three dangerous prisoners.

Hair
Arguably an essential component of working the cameras. Over the years Heseltine's impressive sweep has become a suave slick, Dennis Healey's eyebrows have intimidated millions, and Robin Day was defeated by Margaret Thatcher, as one newspaper reported, "with the effortlessness of a beautifully coiffeured steamroller flattening a blancmange." Also see Cecil Parkinson, Kenneth Baker, under oleaginous.

Interruption
The first truly aggressive interruption came from Reginald Bosanquet while addressing Harold Macmillan on the Tories' byelection defeat in 1957. "Sir, as time is short," Bosanquet began, "could we question you on a domestic matter which I think is uppermost in our minds at the moment?" "If you must," Macmillan replied.

Lounging
The tactic which has perhaps done more than anything else to maintain dumbness levels in interviewing is politicians' headlong rush to the lifestyle programme sofas and easy chairs when the polls look bad. The technique was pioneered by Thatcher in 1984 when she became the first Prime Minister to appear on a TV chatshow, a tactic Tony Blair would seek to perfect on This Morning with Richard and Judy.

Spin
First invented by Anthony Eden in 1951. He chose to be questioned, rather than speak direct to camera, and picked as his questioner Leslie Mitchell, presenter of the anodyne Picture Page and TV's best-known face. "Well now, Mr Eden," Mitchell began, "with your very considerable experience of foreign affairs, it's quite obvious that I should start by asking you something about the international situation today - or perhaps you would prefer to talk about home? Which is it to be?" Eden opted for home affairs.

Title Fight
Robin Day's aggressive style met its match in the Iron Lady, Margaret Thatcher. Their 1983 encounter marked a milestone in the power balance between interviewer and interviewed. "You are going further than I wish to go," Thatcher chided Day. "Well, naturally, that's part of my job, Prime Minister," Day responded.

Zzz
Perhaps we should be grateful for aggressive interviewing techniques. One of the first, and perhaps the most boring political interviews, took place in 1954. Clement Attlee, now presumably resigned to the medium, was interviewed by Hugh Cudlipp. The performance was, the Guardian's correspondent wrote, "a bit tedious"; Mr Cudlipp put the $64,000 question: "Of the two great parties, which one is going to work most effectively for peace?" Instead of answering "Labour, of course," Mr Attlee: "There are certain factors common to any party," and fumbled on diffusely.

 Compiled by Oliver Burkeman, with acknowledgment for interview transcripts to Michael Cockerell's book Live From Number 10 (Faber, 1988)

fields.headline: Dance
fields.standfirst: Ballet and other dance forms are still reinventing themselves, says Judith Mackrell, while preserving the purity of the classics
fields.trailText: Ballet and other dance forms are still reinventing themselves, says Judith Mackrell, while preserving the purity of the classics
fields.body:
Dance may still appear as a minority art form in Britain, lacking the historic confidence and critical audience mass enjoyed by literature or the theatre. Yet its use of men and women - rather than pens, pigments or technology - as its raw material, assures it a unique place in the popular zeitgeist. The way people look, the way they dress, the rhythms their bodies move to, the images they have of themselves inevitably colour the ways in which danceworks are performed and made.

On stage, dance becomes a hybrid art, incorporating music, costume and design into its final product, thus making the art form especially receptive to shifts in the general culture. Evidence of dumbing down in the external world would probably therefore become immediately obvious on the dance stage. Certainly a checklist made of changes in the art form over the last 50 years would reveal a widening embrace of popular music and street fashion. It would show the effect of video and advertising techniques on the look and editing of choreographic material. Even within the arena of pure movement it would chart an increasingly casual flipping between different traditions, with choreographers quoting from ballet, bharata natyam or break dance within a single work.

So thoroughly has dance absorbed the contemporary cultural mix that academic distinctions between classical and modern, street and serious are often impossible to apply. Dance has always been dextrous in its thefts and borrowings, and is doing this more obviously as the culture speeds up.

There are, though, distinctions to be made between ballet and modern dance. The latter (initially developed in opposition to the academic discipline of ballet) came late to Britain and it wasn't until the late 60s that British dancers and choreographers started to follow the lead of American pioneers such as Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham - throwing off their ballet shoes, freeing up their bodies and embracing big ideas.

The UK is now recognised as one of the world's most volatile arenas of new dance, and its audiences have become incredibly sophisticated, and incredibly hardworking. Over the last 20 years, this audience has learned to absorb a dense weave of ideas, images, emotions and cultural reference points without relying on verbal narrative or clues. It is an audience with stamina, curiosity and alertness. Yet, signicantly, it is mainly composed of 20-40-year-olds - a group allegedly with the attention span of a gnat.

When new modern dance is bad it is not usually because it is dumb but because it is impenetrable - but with ballet the issues are very different. In the 19th century, ballet, like opera, flourished on the strength of its own vigorous dumbing down, with choreographers mixing the pure aesthetics of classical dance with pretty chorus girls, flying wires and grandiose spectacle. For ballet companies today, one of the big challenges is to preserve both the purity and the vigour of its classics. Because there is a perceived canon at stake, the ballet world is often viciously at odds over how this should be done. One of the most vexed issues is training and performance, for while everyone agrees that superballerinas like Darcey Bussell and Sylvie Guillem move with a power that eclipses the technique of Margot Fonteyn and her peers, some critics argue that their athleticism has been acquired at the expense of subtler qualities such as musicality and dramatic nuance.

In the creation of new ballets, the most depressing tendency is less a move to dumbing down, than damping down. Ballet audiences are historically more conservative than the public for modern dance, and because ballet productions are expensive to create there is a tendency for companies to court the box office with works which either timidly recycle old models or else peg their choreography to familiar scores or titles. There have been distinguished and subversive exceptions however - the harrowing dance dramas of Kenneth MacMillan and the witty formal experiments of William Forsythe and Ashley Page have all prevented ballet dancers and their audience from sinking into cosy inertia. Purists may squeal that ballet has gone whoring after youth culture but it is actually doing what it has always done to survive - taking what it needs from the world outside the ballet studio and, through the alchemy of its own disciplines and traditions, creating something new.

fields.headline: Lastminute plunges
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Shares in Lastminute.com, Britain's highest profile dotcom stock, yesterday fell to a record low.
fields.body:
Shares in Lastminute.com, Britain's highest profile dotcom stock, yesterday fell to a record low.

The beleaguered online travel agent and retailer watched its share price dip 4.76% to 80p at the close last night. It had fallen as far as 75.5p earlier in the day.

The price has dropped around 40% over four weeks since Allan Leighton, former chairman of Asda, invested £100,000 and took more than 1m in options as the online company's new chairman. He now has a paper loss of around £675,000.

Internet research firm MMXI Europe said a study of more than 4,500 British web users on travel-related sites showed that Lastminute had lost almost 25%of its domestic users for September.

fields.headline: Moneyextra sold for £26m
fields.standfirst:
Ignominious fate for a £400m float

Net news
fields.trailText: Moneyextra.com, the personal finance website that was the crucial part of a £400m flotation last year was yesterday sold for £26m as its holding company quit the business to consumer marketplace.
fields.body:
Moneyextra.com, the personal finance website that was the crucial part of a £400m flotation last year was yesterday sold for £26m as its holding company quit the business to consumer marketplace.

When Moneyextra's parent group, Exchange Holdings, floated in August last year it was 17 times oversubscribed, and subsequently embarked on an acquisitions spree to build a Europe-wide personal finance transactions portal.

It renamed itself Moneyextra.com and at one point its shares hit 425p, valuing the firm at more than £900m.

But yesterday, with its shares trading at just 33.5p, it admitted that transaction activity was lower than anticipated and said the future for standalone business to consumer finance websites was bleak.

The site is being sold to Bristol & West, a subsidiary of Bank of Ireland, which says it intends to invest £14m in developing the business as a "bricks and clicks" rather than "clicks only" website.

The sale of Moneyextra.com means the group will return to its former name, Exchange, and focus on business to business activities. It said yesterday it is to pay £29.4m for Crisp Computing, a business software group.

As recently as September this year, Moneyextra chief executive Paul Lindsey said: "We are well positioned to exploit the continued growth in the market for online personal financial services," and that heavy investment in the first half of the year would be rewarded in the second half.

But yesterday he said competition from financial institutions combining telephone and branch-based advice with web delivery had made the market for independent websites difficult.

"'Clicks only' has not worked. We are beginning to see that for more complex financial products people need advice, which means integrating a site such as Moneyextra.com into call centres and so on," said Mr Lindsey.

He said the amount of investment required to meet such demands "has reduced the attractiveness of the business to consumer opportunity." Moneyextra raised £90m in cash from the float last year, but more than £50m has been swallowed up in investments in the site, advertising and acquisitions.

In October 1999 it paid £6m in cash for Moneyworld.com, followed by largely share-financed takeovers in Europe.

In February it reported an operating loss of £18m on turnover of £14m, but said it would press ahead with increased investment in the consumer market, including an £18m advertising campaign.

But five months later it gave the first warnings that transaction-based revenues were falling short of expectations.

www.moneyextra.com

webTitle: Blair admits leaving NHS short of cash

fields.headline: Blair admits leaving NHS short of cash
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night appealed to nursing leaders not to play into the hands of those who want to scrap the health service and to "show solidarity" during any winter crisis, as he admitted underinvesting in the NHS for his first three years in power.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night appealed to nursing leaders not to play into the hands of those who want to scrap the health service and to "show solidarity" during any winter crisis, as he admitted underinvesting in the NHS for his first three years in power.

Speaking at an NHS conference in Brighton, the prime minister said he would "stand or fall" by his decision to stick to Tory spending measures in the early years of the Labour government, which, he confessed, meant nurses were working "flat out" and the NHS had been underfunded.

But he urged senior nurses not to turn on him if hospitals succumbed to a bed crisis this winter. Claiming hospitals were better prepared for winter than last year, he said: "There are tremendous pressures in the winter ... but I don't think we should be in any doubt there are those who would use the state of the national health service this winter to say it's hopeless.

"People within the health service, we should have some sense of solidarity against those who say because these problems exist the national health service isn't worth saving."

The prime minister's appeal for support came as, with the onset of winter, the government prepares for an onslaught of criticism both from the opposition benches and the media, whom the health secretary, Alan Milburn, last week accused of being "determined to have their crisis". The prime minister's spokesman has already accused BBC Radio 4's Today programme of scaremongering.

Yesterday Mr Blair tried to explain why he had failed to channel sufficient money into the NHS until this year.

Likening his "two, nearly three, tough years on public spending" with the "responsible" stance he had shown towards the fuel protesters, he said he had made the "tough decision" to keep interest rates low and to encourage investment. But Mr Blair admitted: "It all came at a price ... It meant we didn't start really to invest in the NHS in the way we wanted until this year. So you were working flat out and often still are in an NHS that was underfunded."

He added: "I would like to have got more money more quickly into the health service but I am sure the way I am doing it now will get the money that lasts."

During his speech at the chief nursing officers' conference, the prime minister also announced a bonus of up to £1,000 for nurses priced out of living near their hospitals, with senior nurses in London receiving the top amount, juniors £600, and those living in parts of the south where property prices are highest an average of £500.

In a move aimed at luring more nurses back to the NHS, he revealed that a "nursing bank" would be set up to allow nurses to work whenever they wanted.

Working in a similar way to private agencies, the scheme - called NHS Professionals - would give nurses holiday pay and enable them to stay in the NHS pension scheme. But it would prove cheaper for the taxpayer, since private agencies currently cost the NHS more than £350m.

Mr Blair's admission that the NHS had been underfunded was described as "better late than never" by the Liberal Democrat health spokesman Nick Harvey, who said: "One accepts that some stern financial management was needed, but to do that at the expense of starving the NHS of crucial and much needed resources meant taking that dose of medicine more quickly than was needed in retrospect."

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said the Tories could not be blamed for inadequate levels of investment. "Tony Blair is the 'not me guv' prime minister and problems with underfunding are entirely his government's fault.

"He's only admitting to underinvestment now because everyone who works in the service realises the NHS is worse than it was three years ago."

webTitle: Managers vow to find answer to rail cracking

fields.headline: Chastened managers vow to find technical answer to rail cracking
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: The safety reputation of the railways has been dealt further damage in an independent report into broken rails suggesting that the industry's managers had fostered a culture of complacency on the issue.
fields.body:
The safety reputation of the railways has been dealt further damage in an independent report into broken rails suggesting that the industry's managers had fostered a culture of complacency on the issue.

Commissioned by the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, and the health and safety executive, the report said there had been "a traditional acceptance in Britain of relatively high numbers of broken rails compared with other countries, and that Railtrack has until recently continued this practice".

Railtrack is the track-owning firm that supervises maintenance done by its contractors. The report was commissioned in August and prepared by a US firm of transport consultants before the Hatfield crash, which was caused primarily by a defective rail. But it may give a wake-up call to an industry that must prevent public disillusionment becoming permanent.

Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, and his colleagues were instructed to introduce "a robust and thorough system for inspecting, identifying, reporting, monitoring and auditing actions being taken by Railtrack and its contractors".

Given the very high number of rail defects in the network, the report said Railtrack must re-examine its assumptions about rail life, since rails installed in the past 10 years appeared to suffer a higher rate of degradation.

The highly critical report confirms some of the admissions made by Mr Corbett at the Ladbroke Grove inquiry yesterday. It may focus minds on Railtrack's own inquiry task force. This inquiry, chaired by Rod Smith, an engineering professor at Imperial College London, will investigate gauge corner cracking, found at the Hatfield crash. Railtrack says such cracking probably exists on 3,000 sites around Britain, and it has had to impose 500 speed restrictions to prevent a possible further accident.

The task force has its first meeting on Monday. One member, Brian Clementson, chairman of the train operators' rolling stock committee and a senior rail engineer, frankly admitted yesterday his embarrassment at "the whole damn situation". He had been "totally unaware" of the extent of the problem, and roundly blamed the industry for failing to carry out sufficient research.

Mr Corbett described it as a recent phenomenon that had grown rapidly, and pointed out it was cropping up in France, the US and Germany, which accounts for the presence of a representative of the latter's successful state-run railway on the task force.

Mr Clementson thought the most likely reason for the increase in cracking was the interaction between wheel and rail; other possibilities might be the quality of steel, and the ultrasonic testing for faults.

Corus, a firm with factories in Workington in Cumbria and Hayange in France, supplies 60% of Railtrack's rails. It continues to give "technical advice", and has offered to assist the task force - though it said there was no question of the Hatfield rail being faulty steel. It is working on a European standard rail for the UK, slightly higher than its British-designed equivalent.
