webTitle: Tactless Corbett says sorry to crash families

fields.headline: Tactless Corbett says sorry to crash families
fields.standfirst:
Rail network 'like pressure cooker waiting to explode'
Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, yesterday described the network as "like a pressure cooker about to explode".
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, yesterday described the network as "like a pressure cooker about to explode".

Giving evidence to Lord Cullen's inquiry into the Paddington rail disaster, in which 31 people died, he also compared the pursuit of safety to a journey in which "you never arrive at your destination".

That comment drew bitter laughter and some tears from the relatives of the dead in the public gallery.

Mr Corbett was later asked by John Hendy QC, acting on behalf of the injured and bereaved at Paddington: "Do you appreciate the offence that gave?" Mr Corbett replied: "I apologise."

Outside the inquiry, relatives of the dead condemned Mr Corbett's remarks as "insensitive".

Linda Dilieto, from Cambridge, whose 24-year-old son died in the crash, said: "Fancy saying something like that. It was totally insensitive because our loved ones did not complete their journeys."

When asked by Robert Owen QC, counsel for the inquiry, who was responsible for the Hatfield crash, Mr Corbett said: "I think it's me. It's clear in the public's mind that they think it is me.

"The record of the privatised railway is not as bad as perceived. In some cases it's quite good."

During the inquiry hearing Mr Corbett said that one senior rail executive had told him after the Hatfield crash that balancing safety and performance was "like trying to fit a quart into a pint pot".

He refused to accept that the rail industry's safety problems were due to management failure.

He said: "It's more of a system rather than a management failure. The organisation has been under huge pressure and it has delivered a lot. But it has not been able to deliver everything."

Mr Corbett, who has headed Railtrack for three years, expressed his opposition to the government's plans to introduce a new charge of corporate killing. He said: "I think it would encourage a culture of secrecy and blame which is not necessarily an appropriate safety culture."

He also rejected the suggestion that Railtrack should have its responsibility for safety removed.

He said: "Power, control and accountability should be set in the same place. Moving them to an outside body, although politically it may sound good, would not make things any better."

Mr Corbett told the inquiry that it had not been clear who was responsible for safety on Britain's railways and blamed the regulatory bodies - by inference the rail regulator and the shadow strategic rail authority - for not providing proper leadership.

Mr Corbett said that the industry had three regulators when there was only the need for one.

"There needs to be an overall vision on what the railway is trying to achieve. If the regulators can get it all joined up then it will make things a lot easier to manage."

Railtrack faced an extremely difficult task on safety, Mr Corbett said, because of the fragmentation of the network into 100 different parts after privatisation.

The company was "left batting in a vacuum because nobody was giving the lead on safety".

webTitle: Court tells Mugabe to end occupations

fields.headline: Court tells Mugabe to end occupations
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The supreme court in Zimbabwe ruled yesterday that the country's "fast-track" land resettlement programme is unconstitutional and ordered police to remove government supporters from more than 1,600 white-owned farms.
fields.body:
The supreme court in Zimbabwe ruled yesterday that the country's "fast-track" land resettlement programme is unconstitutional and ordered police to remove government supporters from more than 1,600 white-owned farms.

The decision is a blow to President Robert Mugabe and his land redistribution scheme, which has seen Zimbabwe's most productive farms engulfed by violence and prevented from growing crops.

The ruling states that if the government wishes to seize land, it must follow the procedures of the country's Land Acquisition Act, which gives owners the chance to contest farm seizures in court and at least 90 days to vacate their land.

The court accused the government of promoting illegality and violence under the guise of land redistribution and called for police to stop the occupation of farms by war veterans and other Mugabe supporters. Until now the police have refused to remove the occupiers and have not protected owners from violence.

The government had not responded to the ruling by last night.

webTitle: Dome raid: great film, says BBC

fields.headline: The great dome raid: great film, says BBC
fields.standfirst:
Factual drama department starts work on foiled robbery, with backing from Dyke
Special report: the future of the BBC
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: In what appears to be a case of art imitating life imitating art, the BBC is planning a fictional account of the audacious Millennium Dome diamond snatch.
fields.body:
In what appears to be a case of art imitating life imitating art, the BBC is planning a fictional account of the audacious Millennium Dome diamond snatch.

The BBC's factual drama department has started work on a film of the foiled attempt to steal the Millennium Star, one of the world's most valuable stones. The crime itself drew comparisons with a sequence in a James Bond film, The World Is Not Enough.

Researchers have already contacted journalists, police and others involved in the story. While the project is in its earliest stages of development - any programme could not be shown until after a trial, and eight men have just been charged - the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, is said to be keen. A spokeswoman said: "Discussions are at a very early stage - it is just a gleam in the eye at the moment."

Nevertheless, the tale is ripe for dramatisation, and other broadcasters are also thought to be chasing it. Central to the film would be the role of the Flying Squad, which foiled the operation. The team was led by detective superintendent Jon Shatford, and some observers say some dramatic licence might have to be taken with his part. "He's more Inspector Morse than Denis Waterman," one said.

However, John Thaw, who starred in the Sweeney as well as the later detective series, is on an exclusive contract with ITV. The obvious alternative would be Pete Postlethwaite, a current BBC favourite.

The film could also provide work for Nick Berry, the former Heartbeat actor who is on a £3m exclusive deal with the BBC, but whose latest vehicle, Harbour Lights, was a disaster. Young and suave, he would be an ideal Mr Big. Ricky Tomlinson would be the crime gang's obligatory Scouser, perhaps commandeering the mechanical digger that smashed through the dome's exterior.

PY Gerbeau, the Frenchman who runs the dome, must also have a prominent part - Gérard Depardieu could be in line.

Questions remain over a role for Pierce Brosnan, who slid down the dome's roof in the dramatic opening sequence for the latest Bond movie. But while the BBC drama budget has received a huge boost under Mr Dyke, it is unlikely to extend to the fees of Hollywood stars.

The final thing to be decided, of course, would be a title. There is surely only one option: The Domebusters.

fields.headline: Mechanical politics
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It's slightly unfair, all this gloating, but inevitable: a superpower which cannot organise an election without waiting days (or weeks) for a result deserves to be teased.
fields.body:
You can hardly blame them. The Cubans and Russians, Italians and Africans have listened for so long to Americans lecturing them on democracy, it's no wonder they are revelling in the chance to get their own back. Imagine the pleasure of the headline writer at Granma, Havana's national daily, as he branded the US "a banana republic". Think of the delicious shudder of schadenfreude that ran down the spine of Robert Mugabe's official spokesman, as he helpfully suggested Zimbabwe dispatch a team of observers to help Americans manage their democracy. At long last they, along with the Chinese and Iraqis, can have a good laugh at the great American know-it-all, slipping up so spectacularly.

It's slightly unfair, all this gloating, but inevitable: a superpower which cannot organise an election without waiting days (or weeks) for a result deserves to be teased. But America is suffering from an outcome that could, theoretically, happen to any democracy: a tie. Britain has had hung parliaments before; we've also had seats won by margins of just one or two votes (the 1997 majority in Winchester was two). What the US is enduring now is both possibilities - at the same time. As one Florida election official put it this week, "Democracy is not always neat and simple. If you want simple, head 70 miles south of here to Cuba - their elections are always very simple and very clear."

So America has not been exposed as a banana republic this week. If that were true, Jeb Bush would have done a better job of rigging the Florida contest for his brother - or Bill Clinton would have declared a state of emergency and made himself president-for-life (I bet the thought has crossed his mind). Instead the country has a functioning government, with Clinton in place for three more months and a procedure to follow. It will take time, but the system is not about to collapse.

That said, the surreal twists and turns from Palm Beach county and beyond have exposed a deep flaw in the US. Not that the country is fundamentally corrupt - cock-up rather than conspiracy seems to explain most of the voting irregularities - but that America is crippled by a nostalgic, unjustified attachment to mechanisms which are long past their sell-by date.

The most screamingly obvious example is the electoral college, the phantom body which stands between voters and the final outcome. If it was just a matter of winning the most votes in the country, Al Gore would be president-elect by now, albeit by the narrowest of edges. Instead, the candidates have to put together a jigsaw puzzle of states, bagging their votes in the electoral college.

That idea is not all bad in itself: indeed, it prevents candidates lavishing all their attention on heavily populated areas like New York and California, forcing them instead to listen to the smaller states. In a federal country, that's essential. No, the problem is not with the electoral college itself so much as the way it operates.

The reason why Gore and George W Bush are locked in a death match in Florida is that only one of them can win the state's 25 electoral college votes: it's winner-takes-all. What's to stop Florida giving 12 votes to one candidate, 13 to the other? Nothing. Florida could do it, just as Maine and Nebraska already do. If the other 47 states went the same way, allocating their votes proportionally, the electoral college vote would reflect the popular one - and still give clout to the smaller states. Yet Americans would tremble before taking that simple step.

Or consider the now notorious ballot paper in Florida's Palm Beach County, the one that required laser-beam eyesight and a knack for logic puzzles. Why did that county have that weird ballot paper? How come they're not all the same, if not across America then at least in Florida? The answer is that same, conservative attachment to the old way of doing things.

Americans are militant about preserving the rights of individual states to resist the standardising instincts of the centre - just as they were when they built the country 224 years ago and fought a civil war a century later. They are still radical devolutionists, who believe each area should always be able to go its own way: even if that means Palm Beach county having its very own ballot paper.

There is a pattern here. Rules devised for a very different era - the late 18th century - are obeyed to this day as if they were religious edicts. The electoral college grew out of an 18th-century fear of the undiluted popular will, preferring the deliberations of wise men to the instincts of the masses - yet today's 21st-century Americans fear altering it even by one jot. The principle of states' rights was a reaction against the centralising rule of George III - yet modern America clings to that principle two centuries after the British have gone, even when it leads to a patchwork of wildly different voting systems and electoral chaos.

It's an odd trait for Americans, who we usually imagine as a people unshackled by history, the creators of a new world. Yet this nostalgic fear of change is very real. While Britain redesigns its bank notes every few years, the US dollar bill looks the same now as it always has. The same goes for the layout of America's leading newspapers: short of centuries of history, they cling to what they have.

Politically this habit makes a big difference. For it chains Americans to a system that can be patently anachronistic. Writer Daniel Lazare has argued that America is "the frozen republic", paralysed by a constitution that is absurdly out of date. But one does not have to go that far. For the beauty of the constitution is that it contains within it the possibility of its own reform. It can be amended. Not on a whim, admittedly, but amended all the same. So when Americans wanted to ban alcohol, as they did in 1919, they could pass the 18th amendment. And when they wanted to unban it, as they did in 1933, they could pass the 21st. Americans are not paralysed by the constitution - only by their own fear of changing it.

So they could modernise the electoral college or standardise voting (perhaps using computer software) if they wanted to. While they're at it, they could learn a few things from Britain - demanding, for example, that all postal ballots are in by election day and all votes counted before a result is declared. A simple idea that, but it does seem to work. They might also look at free TV advertising, like our party election broadcasts, removing the pressure to raise so much campaign cash.

There is much America can learn from democracies around the world. But first it has to realise that, though the founding principles of the republic remain inspiring, not every cog and wheel of that 18th-century machinery is sacred. America needs to recall its revolutionary origins, to remember that it was built on change - and that it can change now.

So they could modernise the electoral college or standardise voting (perhaps using computer software) if they wanted to. While they're at it, they could learn a few things from Britain - demanding, for example, that all postal ballots are in by election day and all votes counted before a result is declared. A simple idea that, but it does seem to work. They might also look at free TV advertising, like our party election broadcasts, removing the pressure to raise so much campaign cash. There is much America can learn from democracies around the world. But first it has to realise that, though the founding principles of the republic remain inspiring, not every cog and wheel of that 18th-century machinery is sacred. America needs to recall its revolutionary origins, to remember that it was built on change - and that it can change now. jonathan.freedland@theguardian.com

webTitle: Mark Lawson: Bewildered into voting for Blair

fields.headline: How very unlike our own affairs
fields.standfirst:
No Sussex retirees claim they were bewildered into voting for Blair

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: No Sussex retirees claim they were bewildered into voting for Blair.
fields.body:
Many have drawn from George W Bush's strong, if now ambiguous, showing in the US poll an electoral warning for our own Clinton-clone, Tony Blair. They point out that politics tends to echo across the Atlantic: from the ideological twinning of Reagan/Thatcher and Clinton/Blair to the odd historical footnote that both nations were run during 1976 by unelected leaders: Ford and Callaghan.

But there is another, disturbing, parallel between Britain and the US. During the final quarter of the year 2000, both have experienced democratic gridlock. The fuel dispute created by the farmers and truckers briefly threatened the UK with standstill and anarchy. A few Floridian incompetents or revolutionaries have now achieved the same effect in America. In both cases, there is a presumption that electoral decisions can be adjusted to suit a perception of a greater good.

The practical circumstances are different. Although many have questioned the direction of the Blair administration, its democratic legitimacy is beyond challenge. No Sussex retirees claimed to have been bewildered into voting for him by a Picasso-like ballot paper, nor did Brixton electors report being turned away from the polling station.

And yet the growing complaint that the electoral system leaves large groups of voters disenfranchised threatens the seats of power in both Washington and London. In truth, divisiveness has always been a fault of democracy - in rewarding the majority, a disgruntled residue must be left. The difference is that what William Hague called "fine upstanding citizens" are now prepared to do something about it. British rural communities take to the motorways; US pensioners challenge the ballot through the courts.

The threat of a standstill Britain seems to have been averted at least for the moment by Gordon Brown's subtle buy-off of enough of the disgruntled in Wednesday's pre-budget statement. America's power stasis - and the question of which president will be shaking hands with Brown and Blair from next January - cannot be so easily settled. There is now no procedure in Florida - recount, restaging, supreme court intervention - which could deliver a president acceptable to even half the country. Gore, though, might be the marginally less compromised, if only because none of his family was involved in the count.

As politicians often point out, perception is more important than reality. And, though Governor Jeb Bush of Florida doubtless treated both candidates as brothers in his supervision of the poll, history might at the very least squint at the idea that a candidate had been given a cigarette-paper victory by the results from a state run by his sibling.

There is something of Greek drama in the way that the Bush family has its apparent political triumphs undermined. In late 1991, Big George was a war-winning president with huge approval ratings, seemingly certain of a second term. But the people replaced him one year later with a draft-dodger. Now Little George may be allowed only 84 minutes of unchallenged presidential victory on election night before settling for being a lame-duck from day one. The egalitarian US is unkind to its political dynasties. Kennedys get killed; Bushes are humiliated.

A Gore restoration in America would set a terrifying precedent: lawyers would replace spin doctors as a losing candidate's best friend. There's a rule in football that, while television replay evidence can lead to the after-match disciplining of players, it can never be used to over-turn a result. Even if the cameras prove that the ball bounced down behind the goal-line, the unlucky team's score will never be increased. Without this, no cup would ever be awarded because of impending court actions.

How much more might this rule apply to elections. The last three US presidents - Reagan, Bush senior, Clinton - have faced legal attempts to remove them from office. It's merely an acceleration of the trend that lawyers should now be involved in intercepting one on the way to the Oval Office door.

But there's an old saying that we get the leaders we deserve. If so, it would be appropriate for America to be run by a president without a mandate: either Gore forced in by the courts or Bush chosen by the electoral college despite losing the popular vote. An electorate in which at least half of the enfranchised decline to vote (and many who do participate no longer believe in the system) deserves to be represented by an illegitimate president.

Throughout the 90s, a constant theme of pundits was the growing contempt of the electorate towards politicians. We were right about this but wrong about the form it would take. Rather than the anticipated apathy, the rejection of democratic tradition has been manifested by activism and practical or legal attempts to change the nature of the leadership.

Even without the row over the Florida poll, the dead heat elsewhere in America is a perfect reflection of what most voters think about politics. We'd tended to assume that the popular moan that "they're just as bad as each other" would result in non-voting and low turnouts. But, in this poll, the American people have managed to make the point by voting.

Contact: comment@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Storms batter Hilton's gambling and hotel trade

fields.headline: Storms batter Hilton's gambling and hotel trade
fields.trailText: This autumn's fierce storms have taken their toll on Hilton, the hotels and gambling group, which has suffered from hundreds of late room cancellations and a series of wash-outs at race meetings.
fields.body:
This autumn's fierce storms have taken their toll on Hilton, the hotels and gambling group, which has suffered from hundreds of late room cancellations and a series of wash-outs at race meetings.

In a trading update yesterday, the company said its trading was strong in the three months to September, with revenue per hotel room in Britain rising 13.6%.

However, Hilton hotels and Ladbroke bookmakers were both "adversely affected" by the weather in October.

A spokesman said Scottish hotels had suffered particularly as chaos on the railways helped deter English holidaymakers. "Many people go up there for weekend breaks but it's been virtually impossible to get past Doncaster on the trains for a weekend."

A total of 27 race meetings had been cancelled since the beginning of last month and punters have proved reluctant to stake their money on alternative events.

"If UK races are cancelled, we bring up the programme some races from other countries, such as South African and Ireland.

"But some people don't like betting on horses and courses they don't know so well."

The spokesman said the effect so far was "not material" for Hilton's annual profits but added: "If these weather patterns go on until the end of the year, they will continue to affect both our businesses."

One analyst, who declined to be named, said he was cutting his forecast for the company's profits by £5m to around £300m.

Andy Duncan, a leisure analyst at the business consultancy Pannell Kerr Forster, said: "Businesses have been really quite phased by all these events. What has applied to Hilton will have applied to many other hotel operators."

There was better news elsewhere for Hilton - revenue per available room in hotels outside Europe rose 11.7% in the third quarter, with booming occupancy in Australia during the Olympics.

In continental Europe, revenue rose 15.7%, although profits were affected by the weak euro.

Negotiations over the sale of Hilton's 27 casinos are progressing rapidly. The company has agreed to grant exclusivity to the bingo operator Gala, which has offered £250m. The chain includes sites such as Maxim's in London.

Hilton's shares reacted positively to this, rising 1.5p to 203.5p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Welsh Water bid approved
fields.body:
Welsh Water bid approved

Water industry regulator Ofwat gave qualified approval to the £1.8bn Welsh utility merger, which has been billed as a model for reshaping the industry.

Ofwat said the agreed bid for Welsh Water by Glas Cymru, a not-for-profit company owned by the utility's customers, did not present any insurmountable issues.

Last week Glas Cymru agreed to buy Welsh Water from Western Power Distribution.

Ofwat's director general of water services, Philip Fletcher, said the deal had yet to be cleared. But he added: "My preliminary view is that the Glas ownership model does not, on balance, give rise to any insurmountable issues, provided that the licence modifications can be fully implemented and the appropriate investment-grade rating secured.

"However, the views of stakeholders will be critical to my final assessment."

HMV books and music sales up

Books and music retailer HMV Media reported improved trading in the 13 weeks to October 28, with total sales up 9.5% against the same period last year.

HMV's retail sales were up 12.9% and book chain Waterstone's grew 2.4%.

The company said like-for-like sales from comparable stores grew by 3% during the period.

Freeserve bars more surfers

Internet service provider Freeserve said yesterday it had cut more heavy users off its unmetered access plan, which would remain shut to new users for the foreseeable future.

A spokesman said the company had stopped accepting new users three weeks ago for its "unlimited Freeserve time", which cost £10 a month.

The suspension was to ensure the rapidly expanding network was strong enough to cope with huge demand, he said. Surfers have flocked to Freeserve since other operators abandoned flat-fee access plans on cost grounds.

Fourth T-Online director quits

Deutsche Telekom said a fourth member of the board of its internet unit T-Online had departed, but gave no further details.

Berndt Reichert-Berg, was responsible for distribution and service, DT said in a statement. It added that Veronika Altmeyer had joined the board as member for personnel and legal matters.

Two rail firms join forces

Arriva and Connex Transport UK said yesterday they were bidding jointly for two new rail franchises created by the redrawing of the railway map.

The two will bid for the Wales and Borders franchise, for which they had both pre-qualified. Connex pre-qualified for the Thameslink franchise but Arriva would now join that bid, the two firms said.

BT to open up 600 exchanges

British Telecom has told its rivals it would make at least 600 of its 6,000 exchanges available to them between January and June next year for access to its local network.

But it said at 410 of those exchanges firms would have to install ADSL equipment in nearby buildings, adding to their costs.

fields.headline: German overture to EMI
fields.standfirst: Blocked deal with Warner Music opens up opportunity for ambitious Bertelsmann
fields.trailText: Blocked deal with Warner Music opens up opportunity for ambitious Bertelsmann
fields.body:
EMI, the music group behind the Spice Girls and Robbie Williams, yesterday confirmed that German rival Bertelsmann had made an approach which could led to a "combination" of their recording businesses.

The overture was made after EMI's planned £14bn merger with Warner Music faltered last month. The pair withdrew their plans as it became clear the European commission was preparing to block the deal.

Bertelsmann under Thomas Middelhoff, its ambitious chief executive, has long been seen as a possible suitor for EMI.

Mr Middelhoff said at the beginning of the year he expected his music business, BMG, to become the world's largest by the end of 2000.

There was some speculation that Bertelsmann was aiming to inject BMG into EMI in return for a stake in the enlarged group which would remain listed in London.

The theory seemed to be supported by a brief statement from EMI which said the approach did not constitute an offer for the company, although it cautioned that detailed talks had not yet taken place. The approach is not believed to be hostile.

Bertelsmann insiders said they were confident that a deal could get past Brussels and hinted that an informal approach had already been made to the competition authorities.

A combined EMI-BMG would have a similar market share to EMI-Warner but is less dominant in music publishing, and would not raise the same concerns over Time Warner's merger with AOL.

BMG's artists include Britney Spears, the Backstreet Boys and Whitney Houston.

EMI - which was the Beatles' record label - and Warner are hoping to return to Brussels with a redrawn plan but the intervention of a third party was widely anticipated.

Some reports, however, have have cast doubt on whether EMI and Warner Music, owned by Time Warner in the US, would continue to try to hammer out a deal the regulators would accept.

Shares in EMI initially flew upwards on the announcement but settled back 27.5p higher at 571.5p at the prospect of a nil-premium deal.

Warner Music and EMI have an agreed period of exclusivity which prevents either seeking alternative buyers before the end of January 2001.

But that does not stop EMI discussing a deal with Bertelsmann, as the German company made the approach.

Management changes at BMG which earlier this week which saw the departure of Michael Dornemann, the chairman, and Strauss Zelnick, president and chief executive of BMG Entertainment, could make a merger of the two less problematic.

Mr Middelhoff recently broke ranks with the other large recording businesses by agreeing a deal to legitimise the controversial online music site Napster - which would include Bertelsmann taking a stake in the operation.

Some analysts suggested the Bertelsmann approach could also work in EMI's favour by ensuring that Warner Music does not try to screw better terms out of the company.

EMI and Warner Music came close to agreeing a compromise with the EC by offering to divest substantial parts of their businesses - including Virgin Records and Chapell Music.

The EC said the last-minute informal offers had substantially improved the chances of approval but added that it still had doubts and did not have time for a proper evaluation of the new concessions.

EMI and Warner Music withdrew their bid from the table at the start of last month to avoid an official veto from Brussels that would have prevented them returning with a reworked bid.

fields.headline: Recess called in spectrum auction
fields.trailText: The government auction of fixed wireless spectrum started with a whimper yesterday when a recess was called after the completion of only one round of bidding.
fields.body:
The government auction of fixed wireless spectrum started with a whimper yesterday when a recess was called after the completion of only one round of bidding.

The auction was stalled with £27.1m on the table and will resume on Monday morning at 10.10am. Each bidder is allowed to call for one recess day.

Several bidders have also significantly reduced the number of licences they intend to go for.

Broadnet, which is owned by US cable company Comcast, made only two bids which, according to the auction's complex rules, means it can now only bid for a maximum of four licences. It had initially indicated that it would go for national reach with 14 licences.

A UK company, Unica, withdrew from the auction entirely leaving nine bidders for the broadband services.

Analysts had expected the auction of 42 regional licences to raise around £1bn for government coffers. The three London licences have proven most popular so far. Energis, US group Winstar and Faultbasic, owned by Nextlink in the US, each met the £4m reserve price.

fields.headline: Dolly's begetters turn to pigs
fields.trailText: PPL Therapeutics, the animal cloning company which created Dolly the Sheep, is turning its attention to diabetes with a plan to develop insulin-producing cells in genetically modified pigs.
fields.body:
PPL Therapeutics, the animal cloning company which created Dolly the Sheep, is turning its attention to diabetes with a plan to develop insulin-producing cells in genetically modified pigs.

The Scottish biotech firm said it was setting up a subsidiary focused on diabetes, which could eventually be floated off in a separate stockmarket listing. Chief executive Ron James said PPL had two "lines of attack". The first was to produce human stem cells that can turn into pancreatic islet cells, which govern the output of insulin. PPL claims to have a unique, but undisclosed, method of producing stem cells without the need to use human embryos.

The company's second approach is to grow islet cells in "knockout pigs" - swine which have had key genes "switched off" to make their organs compatible with the human immune system. These pig cells will then be simply injected into diabetics, as an alternative to more regular doses of pure insulin.

Mr James said: "It's hard to see which approach will be more effective - we'll have to see which gets there first."

The company has already carried out considerable research into pigs - it broke new ground in March by announcing the birth of five cloned pigs - named Millie, Christa, Alexis, Carrel and Dotcom. The animals are intended for research into xenotransplantation - the growth of entire human organs, such as hearts and livers, in animals.

PPL's shares rose 2.5p to 171.5p on yesterday's news.

The Scottish biotech firm said it was setting up a subsidiary focused on diabetes, which could eventually be floated off in a separate stockmarket listing. Chief executive Ron James said PPL had two "lines of attack". The first was to produce human stem cells that can turn into pancreatic islet cells, which govern the output of insulin. PPL claims to have a unique, but undisclosed, method of producing stem cells without the need to use human embryos. webTitle: Wall Street in retreat as candidates bicker

fields.headline: Poll mayhem hits markets
fields.standfirst: Wall Street in retreat as candidates bicker
fields.trailText: US stock markets fell sharply yesterday as fears of an economic slowdown combined with continued uncertainty over the result of the presidential election to depress investor confidence.
fields.body:
US stock markets fell sharply yesterday as fears of an economic slowdown combined with continued uncertainty over the result of the presidential election to depress investor confidence.

The Nasdaq Composite fell 134.57, or just over 4%, at one point to 3,065 after Dell, the computer manufacturer, predicted that sales would increase by a lower-than-expected 20% next year. The forecast, from a company that won plaudits on Wall Street in the 1990s for repeated sales increases of more than 50%, prompted several analyst downgrades. Shares in several other computer manufacturers also fell.

Fears of weaker demand as the economy slows down came as the campaign teams of George W Bush and Al Gore continued to bicker over the results of the closest presidential election in over a century. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 150 points, to 10,683 yesterday as the Gore campaign joined calls for further legal inquiries. Several market strategists said that continued uncertainty would be worse for the markets than either of the two candidates winning.

The markets have fallen sharply since Tuesday's election failed to provide an outright winner.

Analysts warned investors to expect continued uncertainty in the stock, bond and currency markets until the result is announced. Fears over inflation increased the price of short-term US government bonds yesterday.

Shares in Dell were among the worst hit on the Nasdaq with an 18% decline at midday to $23.44. In a note to investors, Andrew Neff, analyst at Bear Stearns, wrote: "The 20% target is a legitimate cause of concern as it fell short of most expectations and signals yet continued slowing growth."

webTitle: Leaderless is how Americans like things

fields.headline: Leaderless is how they like things
fields.standfirst: Americans abhor the smack of firm government. At home, firm governance would do the stock exchange much good
fields.trailText: A Tale of Two Cities. Part One. New York, Wednesday. Nothing on the surface had changed. The Van Wyck Expressway was at a standstill. The cabbie feigned never to have heard of my hotel. The Times Square ticker told of a falling tech market. Oh, and there was no President to speak of.
fields.body:
A Tale of Two Cities. Part One. New York, Wednesday. Nothing on the surface had changed. The Van Wyck Expressway was at a standstill. The cabbie feigned never to have heard of my hotel. The Times Square ticker told of a falling tech market. Oh, and there was no President to speak of.

America has thrived on a lack of government for the past two years. A lame duck Democratic President and a Republican Congress have neutralised each other. The economy has prospered from the fine-tuning of the Federal Reserve. A growth dowry has been created which, if the Republicans are successful in fighting off legal appeals, now falls to a clean-sweep administration to disburse.

Neither Congress nor White House may have planned the laissez faire environment of the past two years, but Americans have reaped its reward nonetheless. Strong growth has brought plenty of jobs, rising asset prices and an unprecedented level of perceived well-being. Against this backdrop, this week's elections were fought on issues down in the detail of society, the two sides disputing refinements to a socio-economic system broadly accepted as a success.

Investors, unsurprisingly, have made hay from the stalemate in Washington over the Clinton years. Even at a time of crisis, when emerging markets imploded in autumn 1998, the Federal Reserve proved admirably capable of safeguarding the American financial system. The shift in the political sands brings a new uncertainty to markets, then, that it would be foolhardy to ignore.

Wall Streeters are impossible to pigeonhole. The "greed is good" creed is a caricature. Do not assume that a Republican administration will be welcomed with self-interested enthusiasm by America's bankers and brokers in the same way that Conservative triumphs always used to be in the UK. Wall Street society is diverse, liberal and finds it easy to reconcile the pursuit of riches with a well exercised conscience. With the rest of America it also shares a suspicion of big government.

George W Bush is unfortunate in an economic inheritance that is so rich. Things can only get worse. Perhaps it runs in the family. George Snr emerged blinking from the considerable shadow of Ronald Reagan to preside over an economic stumble that cost him office. George Jnr succeeds a President with - for all their differences - much of Reagan's sure touch and towering popularity. A lightly poisoned chalice, perhaps.

If the Republicans rush to spend their dowry, the economy will overheat, bringing closer the end to its extraordinary run. Too much unity in Washington could prove a dangerous thing. Four years of recounts would do just fine instead.

A Tale of Two Cities. Part Two. London, Friday. Back home, then, in time for the close of the second lurid chapter in the third millennial history of the London Stock Exchange. Chapter one set the scene with the sudden arrival and even swifter departure of the Germans in the form of the proposed iX merger. Chapter two was the tale of a hostile bid for London from Sweden's OM Gruppen.

It was no surprise that the Swedes did not receive the "rush of acceptances" they forecast at the start of the week, instead winning acceptances of only 6.7%.

While on the surface, then, nothing has changed for an independent LSE, in reality nothing will ever be the same again. Emboldened by an army of small private client broking firms anxious to protect their leverage, the LSE chose to confront OM head on and the bid battle was conducted in colourful language reminiscent of the great struggles of the 1980s. The LSE has been granted time to change. It has a respite not a ring-fence.

The task befalling the LSE management team is threefold: facilitation, brand management and strategic development. The exchange exists to bring together buyers and sellers of equities and enable them to conduct their business in an atmosphere of trust. In the modern world this is about technology and regulation. There is no reason why the LSE should not compete with the best in the world.

The London market's heritage and scale are important contributors to the LSE's brand image, as is a regulatory culture that bears comparison with all other markets outside the US. This brand deserves to be trumpeted widely so as to make London the market of choice for share listings and fund raisings by companies worldwide.

This will only be achievable if the LSE ensures that its standards and technologies are within the mainstream of global practice. There will be no prize for becoming the Betamax of stock exchanges to the world's VHS.

Technology alliances are, therefore, inescapable, and from them will follow co-operation across the spectrum of exchange functions.

Now is the time for the London Stock Exchange's shareholders (of whom my firm is one) to encourage its management to press home the advantage of its brand in discussions with other exchanges at home and abroad. Too much more of the reactionary attitudes evident in recent weeks will force the LSE to pursue an isolationist strategy that would jeopardise its future and that of the City. This book, I hope, has barely begun.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: The science of living gracefully
fields.standfirst: Memo to the chancellor: British researchers are alive and well and building California's biotech industry
fields.trailText: If Gordon Brown wants to know why under the white coat of every nerdy scientist in America beats the heart of an adventure capitalist, the chancellor should spend some time in the Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of California San Francisco.
fields.body:
If Gordon Brown wants to know why under the white coat of every nerdy scientist in America beats the heart of an adventure capitalist, the chancellor should spend some time in the Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of California San Francisco.

At the $75m glass and beige brick facility teams of scientists work in large laboratories with the latest equipment and generous budgets on reducing the incidence of cancer.

The surrounding Bay Area is home to three of the world's leading bio-science research universities, 645 biotech companies and their 80,200 workers.

UCSF's most notable spin-off is Genentech, the $44bn New York-listed biotech firm. It was established in 1976 when Professor Herbert Boyer, a geneticist, teamed up with Robert Swanson, a partner at venture capitalists Kleiner Perkins, to commercialise his research.

Yet for all the pride about "local excellence," the coffee machine chatter is as much about Celtic or Chelsea as the Giants and the 49ers, and the accents are British as often as they are Californian.

A quarter of the 24 labs are run by British professors and many of the brightest post-doctoral researchers who staff them trained in Cambridge, London or Glasgow.

The presence of so many Brits has led to fevered debate in the UK science establishment about a "brain drain".

Professor Gerard Evan, 48, moved out here with his wife and their two daughters in August last year. As principal scientist at the Cancer Research Fund in London and the Royal Society Napier research professor of cancer biology, his defection was high profile.

"We moved here for scientific opportunity, not simply material gain," he says. "When you make the jump from Britain to the US you make a pact with the devil. I desperately didn't want to leave - and at times you ache to go home - but then very quickly you adopt a lifestyle where the standard of living is much higher, your job is regarded much higher and it becomes very difficult to leave."

Prof Evan says an increasing number of senior British scientists have tired of driving second-hand cars, holidaying at Lake District campsites and consoling themselves that, while they may struggle to pay the mortgage, what they do is important and respected.

"The notion that a scientist can or should make money from their discovery is seen by many British institutions as something you simply don't do, yet it's taken as read here. To try and pretend that people are not motivated by personal gain is pie in the sky. Here you are positively encouraged to build links with the commercial sector."

The need to collaborate with the private sector is becoming more acute now that advances in information technology allow biologists to analyse vast quantities of unstructured data in great detail and at speed.

"The cutting edge of science is now not in academia, it's at the interface of academia and industry where work is being done that will change the life of the man in the street," Prof Evan says. "Academia is good at discovery but dreadful at the research and development that leads to a product. If you need to mix the notion of academic excellence with a fat bonus then so be it."

Instead of a 90 minute journey from Stevenage to central London, Prof Evan now drives half an hour from his home in exclusive Marin County, over the Golden Gate Bridge and into San Francisco.

His lab is well funded. Five of his 12 staff are British. He keeps in touch with developments in the commercial sector by sitting on advisory boards of three US biotech firms.

It is a similar story for the centre's other Britsh born and educated professors who have been attracted by better wages, lifestyles and working cultures. A professor at the peak of his or her profession in the UK can expect to earn around £50,000. At UCSF a leading professor is paid more than $200,000 (£140,000) a year.

Andy Finch, 29, left a post-doctoral research position in Cambridge to work for Prof Evan 14 months ago. "I wanted to work with people of his reputation," Mr Finch says. "Now I'm out here I love it. I'm not sure when I'll go back."

The challenge for British science is to ensure that young researchers like Mr Finch no longer feel the need to emigrate and to lure home those that already have, says Professor Martin McMahon.

A 40-year-old Glaswegian, he moved to the Bay Area 15 years ago. It was supposed to be a short visit.

"The new coal in Britain is the brains of the individuals being produced by the university system and the revenues generated from their intellectual exploits," Prof McMahon says. "You cannot afford to lose that human capital."

The foundations of California's biotech sector were built at universities like UCSF, Berkeley and Stanford. Venture capital put it among the world leaders.

British scientists depend largely upon the research institutes to top up government budgets. Many become frustrated and join drugs companies, emigrate or quit science.

The Government denies there is a brain drain, pointing to the inflow of scientists from Europe and the former Soviet Union. Yet, ex-pats in San Francisco believe, unless attitudes change, even this migration could turn into an Atlantic crossing.

webTitle: Junk bond king is biotech prophet

fields.headline: Backing the Bay
fields.standfirst: Now junk bond king is biotech prophet
fields.trailText: Michael Milken carried an air of invincibility as the "junk bond" king of Wall Street in the 1980s. When prostate cancer tested his mortality he became one of biggest supporters of scientific research and the biotech sector.
fields.body:
Michael Milken carried an air of invincibility as the "junk bond" king of Wall Street in the 1980s. When prostate cancer tested his mortality he became one of biggest supporters of scientific research and the biotech sector.

He joined other high net worth individuals who have funded the battle against disease, including Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen , Howard Hughes and the Van Andel family, owners of the Amway corporation.

Many of their investments have been in California, now a hub for the US biotech industry and boasting 50 firms worth $1bn or more. The San Francisco Bay area alone has 645 biotech firms employing 80,200 people, according to Mr Milken's eponymous research institute in Santa Monica.

Los Angeles, San Diego and Orange County add a further 1,500 firms and 95,000 workers. Universities like Stanford, Berkley, UCSF and Pasadena's California Institute of Technology have created a nucleus for growth by commercialising research.

Mr Milken says more backing is needed because biotech ventures tend to be high risk. "As a whole the industry lost $5bn in 1999. Here we have real negative cash flow," he told a recent conference on biotech funding.

He quoted University of Chicago research which found the economic value of reducing cancer deaths in the US is $46.5trillion.

The costs of developing cancer drugs are prohibitive. The average American company spends $1,600 per employee on research and development; at biotech firms that figure is $120,000. Internet and software firms remain more popular with venture capitalists as a consequence. Those industries attracted $18.6bn in venture money last year compared with $3.6bn for biotech.

Ernst & Young says the gap is closing. In the 12 months to June 30, US biotech firms raised $2.7bn through initial public offerings , more than 10 times the previous year's level. This year the industry is on course to raise $30bn.

John Cassy

fields.headline: Ellis & Everard accepts Dutch takeover
fields.trailText: Dutch transport and storage group Royal Vopak yesterday made an agreed £310m bid for Ellis & Everard, the Bradford-based company, which is the world's fourth largest chemical distributor.
fields.body:
Dutch transport and storage group Royal Vopak yesterday made an agreed £310m bid for Ellis & Everard, the Bradford-based company, which is the world's fourth largest chemical distributor.

The low rating of the company's shares has prevented it from continuing as a leading player in the industry. Ellis & Everard chief executive Peter Wood said: "We saw consolidation in our industry and realised that it would be increasingly difficult to be a top tier player because of the difficulty in raising equity as a low rated company."

The offer reflected fair value for the company, and was in the best interests of shareholders and employees, he added.

Vopak yesterday bought 29.9% of the British company's shares and has letters of intent to accept the offer in respect of a further 25.5%.

The 310p a share offer is a 130% premium over the price in late October when Ellis & Everard was forced to admit that bid talks were taking place.

The offer is part of the Dutch group's aim of creating leading market positions for its three main activities - oil and gas logistics, chemical logistics and chemical distribution.

It plans to merge Ellis & Everard with its own chemicals distribution company. The company's aim is to double sales through organic growth and acquisitions within five years.

Tom Spoor, Vopak's chief executive, said that jobs would be lost but it was too early to say how many would go. Under the deal reached with Vopak, the Ellis & Everard board will resign, and most of the directors will leave the company with compensation payments for loss of office.

Mr Spoor said: "This acquisition is an important step in the development of Vopak's position as a leading logistics and distribution service provider to the oil and chemical industries."

webTitle: Doorstepping Express Dairies expands home delivery service

fields.headline: Doorstepping Express Dairies expands home delivery service
fields.trailText: Express Dairies announced yesterday it is to deliver Littlewoods catalogues and dry cleaning to doorsteps as well as milk. The move comes as the company's milk delivery business continue to decline in volume.
fields.body:
Express Dairies announced yesterday it is to deliver Littlewoods catalogues and dry cleaning to doorsteps as well as milk. The move comes as the company's milk delivery business continue to decline in volume.

"What is becoming increasingly apparent to us is that there is inherent value in our doorstep networks," Neil Davidson, the chief executive, said.

The company has decided to extend its product range after delivering "home shopping essential" products such as breakfast cereal, nappies and toilet rolls, on a trial basis in Yorkshire and west London. It will deliver Little woods catalogues in the north-west and collect and deliver dry cleaning in Nottingham on a trial basis. Express is also looking into parcel delivery as well as delivering prescription drugs if regulations allow.

Delivering interim results yesterday, the company said difficult trading conditions would continue at least for the next six months. It said the problems were due to too much processing capacity and a lack of consolidation in the sector. Short term performance would be affected by the higher costs of raw milk, packaging and fuel.

webTitle: Do we really want to shop at Wal-Mart?

fields.headline: Do we really want to shop at Wal-Mart?
fields.standfirst: Little appetite evident in UK
fields.trailText: What has happened to Wal-Mart's messianic vision of building ugly metal sheds to sell bargain bucket products throughout Britain's green and pleasant land?
fields.body:
What has happened to Wal-Mart's messianic vision of building ugly metal sheds to sell bargain bucket products throughout Britain's green and pleasant land?

The hugely successful American retailing chain had big plans to overwhelm Tesco and Sainsbury when it bought Asda for £6.7bn last year. But a trickle of high profile departures seems to suggest the dream is proving difficult to realise.

Asda's long serving chief executive, Allan Leighton, left two months ago and his deputy, 51-year-old Tony Campbell, announced plans to retire shortly afterwards. They were followed this week by George Davies - founder of the chain's widely acclaimed George clothes brand, which was the first serious attempt at genuine fashion in supermarkets.

With former chairman Archie Norman now applying his talents to the Conservative front bench, few of the architects of Asda's 1990s success remain. That success was based on flair - innovative products, "happy to help" badges and quirky advertising. Industry sources suggest Asda's senior ranks are becoming disillusioned with their American parent company's starry-eyed focus on price.

Retail research firm Verdict points out that the British consumer is more sophisticated than most, ranking range and convenience as higher priorities than value. Many say that quality and ambience are crucial in their choice of where to shop.

Wal-Mart is already struggling to impose its retailing philosophy on Germany, where staff are said to hide in the toilet each morning to escape the compulsory Wal-Mart chant - give us a W... give us an A... The company is beginning to appear frustrated over here - trading this year has been disappointing and there is so far only one Asda Wal-Mart superstore. The aim of 10 to 12 hypermarkets seems a long way off, particularly since the government is proving reluctant to approve the construction of any more monuments to consumerism in the countryside.

Net hubris

Keen observers of net hubris will welcome the humbling of Moneyextra.com, sold off yesterday for less than a tenth of the value ascribed to it during the dot.com madness of March. More evidence, it appears, that e-commerce is failing to deliver its promises.

But it is easy to draw the wrong conclusion. Earlier this week Ryanair reported that 60% of its flight bookings are now online, a massive increase on last year, and the reason for a continuing fall in costs. Financial products were widely believed to be ideally suited to internet delivery. So why have sites like Moneyextra.com failed to deliver?

It is now emerging that only certain types of financial products will work on the net. Car insurance works - it is a simple, annual policy where comparative quotes were the norm even before the advent of the net. But it will be a very long time before mortgage and pension buying reaches the level of car insurance. There is a clear, and very understandable, resistance to buying complex financial products online.

Independent financial websites face the Herculean task of trying to match the face to face advice banks offer in branches or over the phone.

Yesterday some sites were scoffing at Moneyextra's embarrassment, but it is hard to see where their future, and other independents such as iii.com, hemscott.net and motleyfool.com, lies if they follow a "clicks only" strategy. Moneyextra's sale to Bristol & West is evidence that the clicks badly need the big bricks to survive.

Vertical tuning

When EMI announced its merger with Warner Music, investors gave the deal a lukewarm reception. As time went on, however, shareholders begun to grudgingly accept the cold logic of the nil-premium deal which would produce the world's largest music company and achieve savings of some £250m a year. A combination of EMI with Bertelsmann's BMG would give the pair market share in Europe of 25-27% - a similar level to that of EMI and Warner. Concerns raised by Brussels over the EMI-Warner tie-up do not appear to pose a problem.

The first was its prominence in music publishing - music for advertising or soundtracks. The second was centred on "vertical issues", such as Warner's relationship with AOL, which could see it having too much influence over the emerging online music market.

A combination of BMG and EMI would escape those vertical issues, and Bertelsmann's music publishing business is far smaller than Warner's.

Even the normally thorny issue of who would take the lead in a merged business has also been conveniently dealt with. BMG lost two top executives earlier this week.

webTitle: Sandwich maker braced for job cuts after Irish bid

fields.headline: Sandwich maker braced for job cuts after Irish bid
fields.trailText: Job losses in the convenience food industry seem inevitable if the agreed takeover offer by Irish Greencore Group for Hazlewood Foods, Britain's biggest sandwich maker, is backed by shareholders.
fields.body:
Job losses in the convenience food industry seem inevitable if the agreed takeover offer by Irish Greencore Group for Hazlewood Foods, Britain's biggest sandwich maker, is backed by shareholders.

Greencore yesterday said the £258m deal could bring savings of £7m a year in two years' time, after an extensive rationalisation programme.

The two companies have overlapping product ranges in chilled pizzas as well as in speciality bread products and sauces, and these product areas are likely to see cuts or sell-offs.

David Dilger, the chief executive of Greencore, said he planned to raise more than £120m - 47% of the offer price - from disposals within the first 15 months. He would not be drawn on potential job losses. Kevin Higginson, the chief executive of Hazlewood, said: "Being realistic and honest I have no idea about future job losses. I have got the best price for shareholders." Hazlewood has 11,500 workers, mainly in Britain - while Greencore employs 4,500.

Greencore's agreed cash offer was set at 113p a share, giving Hazlewood investors a 17% premium on the company's share price before Hazlewood announced it was in bid talks.

The Irish firm has received acceptances from shareholders owning 29% of its target.

Analysts had expected the offer - acknowledged by Greencore to be a bold "step change" - to be part-financed by shares, but Mr Dilger said he was "comfortable" to finance it entirely by debt.

The group has secured loans worth £645m from Citibank, the Royal Bank of Scotland and Bank of Ireland. But one analyst said plans to shed large swaths of Hazlewood could prove difficult. He said there were deep-seated problems with Hazlewood's operational structure which was affecting profitability.

Greencore said that the takeover would lead to an exceptional charge on the group's results in the next financial year.

Hazlewood's half-year results to the end of September yesterday revealed pre-tax profits of £13.1m, down from £21.0m last year, on sales from continuing operations of £389.8m, compared with £388.7m in 1999.

The group accompanied the figures with another profit warning. In September it had said it expected profits to be below the previous year's level, and yesterday it said they would be even lower.

webTitle: NSB clinches delayed deal to buy STS for £272m

fields.headline: NSB clinches delayed deal to buy STS for £272m
fields.trailText: NSB, which supplies software systems to retailers, yesterday announced it is to acquire the North American company STS Systems for £272m.
fields.body:
NSB, which supplies software systems to retailers, yesterday announced it is to acquire the North American company STS Systems for £272m.

The Reading-based company, which has been working to acquire STS for more than a year and had to delay the deal a few months ago because of volatile market conditions, will fund the acquisition by issuing new shares and paying £109m in cash.

Nikki Beckett, chief executive of NSB, said: "NSB has found a perfect transatlantic partner in STS. The two businesses complement each other in terms of products, geography and culture."

STS would add to the progress NSB had begun to make in North America. According to NSB, the combined group will become the largest independent global supplier of software solutions to retailers.

NSB and STS provide products such as programs recording retail sales and those tracking stock levels.

Following the completion of the deal North America is ex pected to provide about half of the group's business and analysts predict it will more than double NSB's sales.

The City welcomed the deal. One analyst said: "This is a transforming deal for NSB and should be viewed positively."

He added that NSB had to go global to match the reach of clients. Customers include Gap and Nike, while STS numbers among its clients Chanel, DKNY, House of Fraser and Tommy Hilfiger.

The acquisition is expected to enhance earnings immediately and, because STS's headquarters are in Montreal, there will be tax relief on research and development costs.

The share price received a 13.3% boost yesterday, rising 22p to 187p.

fields.headline: At this price?  AstraZeneca
fields.trailText: Executives at AstraZeneca have been nervously scrutinising prescription data in search of clues about the take-up of Nexium, the company's new treatment for stomach ulcers.
fields.body:
Executives at AstraZeneca have been nervously scrutinising prescription data in search of clues about the take-up of Nexium, the company's new treatment for stomach ulcers.

It went on sale in Britain on September 11 and, according to the company, enjoyed the fastest take-up of any new prescription drug in its first few weeks.

However, a research note just out from Deutsche Bank drugs analyst Alex Evans casts doubt on whether even this performance will be good enough for Nexium to fill the gap left by Losec, its predecessor treatment which is about to go off-patent.

Deutsche interviewed 109 pharmacies, of which 29% have dispensed a prescription for the new drug, suggesting it has captured 0.5% of the market for its class of gastro-intestinal medicine. This is good but not good enough if, as expected, AstraZeneca has a window of just nine months in the US between the launch of Nexium and arrival of generic competition for Losec.

Deutsche also points out the vast majority of Nexium prescriptions are for 20mg doses, which are priced 35% lower than Losec, making it difficult to see how the company will sustain revenue.

Losec is the world's best-selling prescription drug, accounting for around a third of AstraZeneca's $15.8bn (£11bn) annual sales. Some experts question whether Nexium is a significant improvement.

AstraZeneca responded by saying its own "more substantial" databases showed Nexium achieved a better first month than other "highly successful" ulcer drugs.

Because sufferers of regular gastro-intestinal disorders are often on regular repeat prescriptions, it would not expect them to visit their doctors and be switched to Nexium within seven weeks of the drug's launch.

Down 14p to £33.85, AstraZeneca's shares trade at a 20% discount to Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham. The Nexium doubts make the shares too risky for prudent investors.

webTitle: Matalan up with the big boys

fields.headline: Matalan up with the big boys
fields.trailText: Matalan , wunderkind of the retailing scene, could soon claim the corporate accolade - membership of the FTSE 100.
fields.body:
Matalan , wunderkind of the retailing scene, could soon claim the corporate accolade - membership of the FTSE 100.

With less than a month to go until the next reshuffle of the FTSE indexes, the discount clothing retailer is Britain's 98th-largest company. While this does not guarantee automatic promotion to the big time, odds are Matalan will still make it.

Based on Friday's closing prices, four blue chips - Baltimore, Bookham, Emap and P&O Princess Cruises - will automatically drop out of the index at the review. Their places will have to be taken by the biggest companies in the FTSE 250, of which Matalan, by a quite some distance, is one.

According to dealers the sharp rise in Matalan's share price this week - it opened on at 747p on Monday and closed last night at 774p - owes a lot to the speculation about its inclusion; despite yesterday's 26p fall the gains look set to continue.

Dealers reckon the large stake controlled by the family of chairman John Hargreaves is going to make it hard for index trackers to get hold of enough stock to build an appropriate weighting. At least one broker - said to be Salomon Smith Barney - reckons the shares could run well beyond 800p in the next few weeks.

Retailers as a whole had a good day with investors moving out of "new economy" stocks into more defensive areas of the market as the uncertainty over the US presidential election continued. High street chemist Boots rose 45p to 575p, electrical retailer Dixons added 17p to 229p and home shopping outfit GUS gained 23.5p to 520.5p.

Other defensive issues to find favour included BG, up 13p to 276p, Tesco, 9.5p better at 277.75p, and Unilever, up 15p to 551p. Even Marks & Spencer, 10.5p higher at 202.5p, was in demand although this probably had more to do with a late rumour of a possible bid for the group from French retailer Pinault Printemps Redoute - last mentioned as a bidder for Kingfisher, also higher, up 9p to 441p.

After falling nearly 100 points shortly after Wall Street opened for business, leading shares managed to recover their poise late in the day and the FTSE 100 closed down only 42 points at 6,400.2. The FTSE 250 fell 51.8 to 6,736.2 and the Techmark 100 ended 124 adrift at 3,222.48.

Most of the downside came courtesy of a weakness in the technology and telecoms sectors, something not entirely surprising given that computer maker Dell issued what amounted to a profits warning.

According to dealers there was not a buyer to be found for the likes of Bookham Technology. Even though the optical components maker issued a statement which effectively said everything was fine, its shares still fell 266p to £15.60 - their lowest since flotation in April.

Elsewhere in the tech world, Logica fell 145p to £17.25p and Sema lost 63p to 770p. Things were no better for telecom stocks. Colt Telecom fell 121p to £17.19p and BT lost 49p to 700p with investors still unimpressed by its radical restructuring plan.

Yet for those prepared to trade there were a few stories knocking about. Building materials group Heywood Williams , up 5.5p at 164.5p, was again attracting some educated buying. Earlier this year Heywood was on the receiving end of a 300p-a-share bid from a venture capital consortium and, so the story goes, its current problems have rekindled the group's interest. Last week the company issued its second profits warning in three months and the feeling is that large shareholders no longer think it has a future as an independent company.

Elsewhere, William Baird , the clothing supplier best know for trying to sue Marks & Spencer, rose 2.5p to 59.5p on word that the company will soon go private.

webTitle: Campaign to turn tide of sexist ads

fields.headline: Campaign to turn tide of sexist ads
fields.trailText: Fed up with the unreconstructed chauvinism of a country that considers bare breasts an appropriate way to advertise anything from lawnmowers to low-fat margarine, a group of feminists plans to call for a national boycott of all products sold using sexist slogans.
fields.body:
Fed up with the unreconstructed chauvinism of a country that considers bare breasts an appropriate way to advertise anything from lawnmowers to low-fat margarine, a group of feminists plans to call for a national boycott of all products sold using sexist slogans.

"We've been campaigning against sexist French advertising for 20 years, spraying graffiti on posters, writing to advertisers and even starting a prize for the least sexist ad campaign," said Florence Montreynaud, a writer and historian who is organising the initiative.

"None of it has worked. It's time to confront ordinary people with the violence that these adverts perpetrate against women, to ask them to examine what they say about them and about French society, and simply to stop buying goods advertised in a sexist manner."

Ms Montreynaud, who last year founded the Guard Bitches, dedicated to stamping out sexist insults in public life, has launched a petition that has garnered the signatures of such well-known figures as the former women's affairs minister, Yvette Roudy, MP Roselyne Bachelot, and the best-selling author Amélie Nothomb.

French manufacturers have long favoured the use of the naked female form to publicise their products. The very first commercial, projected before the featured film in a turn-of-the-century French cinema, extolled the virtues of a pasta brand with the help of a scantily-clad demoiselle.

Among today's more offensive examples are advertisements from the confectioner Suchard, which advertises its mouthwatering chocolates with a nude model and the words "You say No; We hear Yes"; and a brand of cream ("Even whipped or beaten, Babette stays creamy").

The Nomade mobile phone campaign is illustrated with a picture of an obscene-looking inflatable doll and the words "Your girlfriend will be open-mouthed"; a financial information database uses a pair of naked female buttocks and the slogan "Has she got decent foundations? Check out the solidity of your company!"; and the latest ad for the haute couture Ungaro shows a werewolf licking a woman's bare body.

The petition, which is to be published next month, will also call on advertisers and manufacturers to develop a code of non-sexist conduct in conjunction with its signatories, and will urge the French government to adopt legislation outlawing blatant sexism in advertising.

"Advertisers use, out of all context, pictures of women's bodies and scenes of sexuality," it reads. "They apply them to all kinds of products, like yoghurts and cars. Under a veil of so-called creativity, they impose their norms and their fantasies. We say No! to degrading, devaluing and dehumanising images, and Yes! to human respect."

But the campaign faces an uphill struggle. It was not long ago that the French president, Jacques Chirac, described his ideal woman as one who "served the men at table, never sat down with them, and never spoke", and the singer and artist Sacha Guitry famously said: "If women were any good, God would have had one."
fields.bodyText: Fed up with the unreconstructed chauvinism of a country that considers bare breasts an appropriate way to advertise anything from lawnmowers to low-fat margarine, a group of feminists plans to call for a national boycott of all products sold using sexist slogans. "We've been campaigning against sexist French advertising for 20 years, spraying graffiti on posters, writing to advertisers and even starting a prize for the least sexist ad campaign," said Florence Montreynaud, a writer and historian who is organising the initiative. "None of it has worked. It's time to confront ordinary people with the violence that these adverts perpetrate against women, to ask them to examine what they say about them and about French society, and simply to stop buying goods advertised in a sexist manner." Ms Montreynaud, who last year founded the Guard Bitches, dedicated to stamping out sexist insults in public life, has launched a petition that has garnered the signatures of such well-known figures as the former women's affairs minister, Yvette Roudy, MP Roselyne Bachelot, and the best-selling author Amélie Nothomb. French manufacturers have long favoured the use of the naked female form to publicise their products. The very first commercial, projected before the featured film in a turn-of-the-century French cinema, extolled the virtues of a pasta brand with the help of a scantily-clad demoiselle. Among today's more offensive examples are advertisements from the confectioner Suchard, which advertises its mouthwatering chocolates with a nude model and the words "You say No; We hear Yes"; and a brand of cream ("Even whipped or beaten, Babette stays creamy"). The Nomade mobile phone campaign is illustrated with a picture of an obscene-looking inflatable doll and the words "Your girlfriend will be open-mouthed"; a financial information database uses a pair of naked female buttocks and the slogan "Has she got decent foundations? Check out the solidity of your company!"; and the latest ad for the haute couture Ungaro shows a werewolf licking a woman's bare body. The petition, which is to be published next month, will also call on advertisers and manufacturers to develop a code of non-sexist conduct in conjunction with its signatories, and will urge the French government to adopt legislation outlawing blatant sexism in advertising. "Advertisers use, out of all context, pictures of women's bodies and scenes of sexuality," it reads. "They apply them to all kinds of products, like yoghurts and cars. Under a veil of so-called creativity, they impose their norms and their fantasies. We say No! to degrading, devaluing and dehumanising images, and Yes! to human respect." fields.headline: Minister hit by sleaze claim
fields.trailText: A senior German minister came under pressure to resign yesterday after being caught up in an unlikely scandal involving a Roman Catholic charity and a football club.
fields.body:
A senior German minister came under pressure to resign yesterday after being caught up in an unlikely scandal involving a Roman Catholic charity and a football club.

Reinhard Klimmt, the transport minister and a member of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's Social Democratic party(SPD), has been charged with three counts of aiding and abetting fraud in his native Saarland. A court in Trier will decide within the next few days whether to accept a prosecutor's recommendation that he be fined DM27,000 (£8,400)

Mr Klimmt's lawyer has said his client will make no comment until after the ruling.

There is no suggestion that Mr Klimmt benefited personally from the fraud. But opposition Christian Democrats say the same defence could be used for their leading lights implicated in a funding scandal.

At the heart of the latest scandal is a charity, Caritas Trägergesellschaft Trier (CTT), which racked up losses of more than £6m under a former director, Hans-Joachim Doerfert. Prosecutors have charged Mr Doerfert with fraud and breach of trust.

During an investigation into the charity's affairs, they discovered that CTT had been subsidising a local football club, FC Saarbrücken. Under a contract signed in 1997, when Mr Klimmt was the club's chairman, CTT handed over almost £200,000 in breach of its charitable status.

Claims have been made that the charity won favours from the regional administration in return and, in particular, that hospitals run by CTT were shielded from budget cuts.

The prosecutors said they could find no evidence that Mr Klimmt, a former head of the regional administration, had misused his influence.

An FC Saarbrücken official has already been fined after pleading guilty to a role in the deal. If, as expected, Mr Klimmt himself opts not to put up a defence, he will be under no obligation under German law to give up his cabinet post.

Calls by Christian Democrats for him to resign have been weakened by the fact that a senior member in their own party in Saarland has also been caught up in the affair.
