webTitle: Inquiries put Brazilian football on the spot

fields.headline: Inquiries put Brazilian football on the spot
fields.trailText: Football is on trial in Brazil as a high-profile inquiry threatens to expose subjects ranging from the Brazil squad's relationship with Nike to match-fixing and corruption in player transfers.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in  Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Football is on trial in Brazil as a high-profile inquiry threatens to expose the murky world behind the proudest symbol of the country's national identity. Two congressional investigations into football heard testimony this week about subjects ranging from the Brazil squad's contract with the clothing manufacturer Nike to match-fixing and corruption in player transfers.

Pele and Ronaldo - World Cup stars past and present - are the best known names on a list that includes players, coaches, agents, club bosses and journalists who will be called to give evidence to the cross-party investigating committees.

The hearings have caught the imagination of a public disillusioned with national football after a run of corruption scandals and embarrassing defeats. "I think the [inquiries] are a good thing. They are of great public interest and [football] needs some morality," said the Brazilian president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso.

Renata Alves, the former secretary of the recently sacked Brazil coach, Wanderley Luxemburgo, testified on Thursday that between 1993 and 1994 (before he was appointed Brazil coach in 1998) he used to leave weekly business meetings with a briefcase stuffed full of dollars from commissions from selling players.

Ms Alves added that she saw well known club directors at these meetings and that their discussions included match-fixing.

"Football is one of the few sectors of our society where there is a black box waiting to be opened," said Senator Alvaro Dias, author of the inquiry in the upper house. The senate will look at issues including fake passports used by players sold to Europe, tax evasion by clubs and the role of players' agents.

Nike deal

Congressmen - who have stronger powers of investigation than the police - have been allowed access to the banking and telephone records of Brazil's 19 Fifa-registered football agents and the go-between for Nike and the Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF).

The 10-year £300m Nike deal, which will be the focus of the inquiry in the house's lower chamber, is seen by many as an affront to Brazilian sovereignty since it gives the US company power to arrange a fixed number of friendly games.

Supporters of the CBF say the deal should be applauded because it brought money to Brazilian football, although the precise destination of the funds has never been clear.

Congressmen will also attempt to investigate one of the greatest conspiracy theories of modern football - whether Nike pressurised Brazil to field Ronaldo in the World Cup final in 1998 because he was part of its advertising campaign.

This week the inquiry heard from Joao Havelange, who was president of world football's governing body, Fifa, for 24 years, and before that was head of the Brazilian federation.

His questioners appeared surprised and irritated when Mr Havelange, who remains a highly influential figure in Brazilian football and whose former son-in-law is the current chairman of the CBF, said he had never read the Nike contract.

Eurico Miranda, vice-chairman of Rio club Vasco da Gama, is also expected to be asked to give evidence. He has been linked to suspicions of irregularities in his club's business dealings, especially the sale of the World Cup star Bebeto to a Spanish club in 1992.

Mr Miranda won a seat in congress, thanks mainly to the votes of Vasco fans. Elected officials are immune from prosecution.

Self-respect

Aldo Rebelo, presiding over the hearing, said that football "integrates all the races that make up our country".

"It is like a religion, and our players are like its apostles. It is our patrimony. But it has been treated just as a commodity. It cannot be reduced to this. This is the death of football. For the public interest it needs investigation."

Mr Rebelo, of the Brazilian Communist party, said he hoped the effect of both hearings would go beyond the prosecution of individuals. "The main purpose is to fight against the mentality of the market. We want to preserve football as a culture of entertainment and preserve the nation's self respect."

Criticisms of the way football is run tend to be brushed under the carpet when the squad is doing well. But the last few months have seen humiliating defeats against Paraguay and Chile in qualifying games for the 2002 World Cup - only the second and third time Brazil has ever lost a game at the preliminary stages - and against South Africa and Cameroon at the Sydney Olympics.

The poor results claimed the scalp of the coach, Luxemburgo, and caused a national outcry that created the political impetus to start the hearings.

The hearings: team sheet

Ronaldo

The striker is due to explain what went on at the 1998 World Cup final in France. The inquiry wants to know whether he was picked because of pressure from the team sponsor, Nike, despite having suffered convulsions before the game.

Edu

Arsenal signed Edu, one of Brazil's best defenders, from Sao Paulo club Corinthians in June. But he showed UK immigration officers a fake Portuguese passport and was turned back.

Wanderley Luxemburgo

Sacked as Brazil's coach after his team lost to Cameroon in the Olympic quarter-finals. Accused of earning commissions for choosing substandard players and raising their transfer values.

Eurico Miranda

The vice-president of Rio club Vasco da Gama was elected to congress on the strength of votes from Vasco's fans on a platform of defending the interests of his club. Widely considered the most powerful man in the sport in Brazil.

fields.headline: Japan's coalition turns on leader
fields.trailText: Japan's ruling party was plunged into open revolt yesterday when one of its most powerful members threatened to topple the administration of the unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.
fields.body:
Japan's ruling party was plunged into open revolt yesterday when one of its most powerful members threatened to topple the administration of the unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.

Koichi Kato, a former secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party and the head of one of its biggest factions, said he was ready to abstain during a no-confidence motion that the opposition is expected to submit by the end of the month.

If he is followed by all 62 members of his faction, the ruling coalition would lose its majority in the 480-seat lower chamber of parliament and the government would be forced to call a general election.

Little love is lost between Harvard-educated Mr Kato, who has a reputation for fiscal rectitude and social reform, and Mr Mori, an old-fashioned conservative who has pursued a free-spending economic policy.

In recent months, Mr Kato has distanced himself increasingly from the premier, whose tendency to put his foot in his mouth has made him a laughing stock among the electorate

He has refused to join the cabinet and has used his outsider status to snipe at the government's failure to address the ballooning public debt, which stands at about 130% of Japan's annual output.

Until now, he has toed the party line in expressing his support for Mr Mori even while his cadres have been scheming behind the scenes.

Yesterday, however, he appeared to make his move. In a leaked conversation with one of Mr Mori's aides, he said he might not show up for a no-confidence motion. "We have to think very hard about whether it is right to back a prime minister who has lost the support of more than 70% of the electorate," he later told reporters.

The challenge caps a bad period for Mr Mori. Last month, he was criticised for telling Tony Blair that relations with North Korea could be improved by diplomatic sleight-of-hand. Last week, his chief cabinet secretary, Hidenao Nakagawa, resigned amid allegations of drug use and links with rightwing extremists.

An opinion poll in the newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun on Monday showed that only 6% of voters thought Mr Mori was the best person to be prime minister. A magazine, Uwasa no Shino, sued Mr Mori yesterday, demanding that he pay 10m yen (£65,000) for suing it over a story alleging that he was arrested in a brothel in his youth.

With an upper-house election due next summer, many in the LDP - especially young politicians with vulnerable seats - have been plotting to remove Mr Mori before his unpopularity rubs off on them.

Yesterday, however, LDP elders rallied around their leader and criticised Mr Kato for his disloyalty and his timing - on the day that the government submitted a 4.78 trillion yen (£29bn) supplementary budget bill to stave off recession.

"Given Japan's difficult economic situation, everyone should be pulling together," said Junichiro Koizumi, the head of Mr Mori's faction.

webTitle: Fatah chief waits for sign from Israel

fields.headline: Fatah chief waits for sign from Israel
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Kamal Ahmed had been in mourning for months before joining yesterday's funeral procession for his lieutenant slain by Israeli rockets.
fields.body:
Kamal Ahmed had been in mourning for months before joining yesterday's funeral procession for his lieutenant slain by Israeli rockets.

"We failed to bring peace," said the man who commands Yasser Arafat's Fatah organisation in Bethlehem.

Like many of the men now guiding the protests by day and planning attacks on Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlements at night, Mr Ahmed won his spurs during the last intifada when he was jailed 11 times. Like the majority of Fatah leaders, he later converted to peace.

"We promised our people, as Fatah leaders, we will bring peace for you, and a good economic situation, and an independent state with Jerusalem as its capital. But in reality, we failed," he said.

For seven years, Fatah had preached a negotiated peace with Israel, urging Palestinians to scale back dreams of independence.

Meanwhile, Mr Ahmed admitted, the coterie who followed Mr Arafat back from exile accumulated power.

"We lost our people's confidence because we could not do anything for them. We did not stop the settlements. We could not improve their economic situation, and we could not make Israel respect agreements."

Amid the bloodshed of the last six weeks, he has seen a changing of the guard in Fatah. This crisis is producing a younger generation of field commanders - like the militant Hussein Abayat.

Now there is an additional danger to Israel from Islamist militant groups such as Islamic Jihad and Hamas who have threatened bombing attacks within the borders of the Jewish state. Amid the present chaos Fatah may not have the power to stop them.

"Even though we failed to bring peace, we still believe in it," he said. "We know this intifada cannot bring us to the finish. We need talks and negotiation. But first we need a clear announcement from Israel."

After two decades of sheltering refugees from war and famine, Pakistan said yesterday it would close its borders to Afghanistan.

webTitle: Arabs united in rage at killings

fields.headline: Arabs united in rage at killings
fields.standfirst:
Assassination of militia leader ignites new mood of revenge

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A day before leaving for Washington and President Clinton's final salute to the peace process, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, was unrepentant yesterday over the assassination of a Palestinian militant, laid to rest amid the peal of church bells and the rattle of gunfire.
fields.body:
A day before leaving for Washington and President Clinton's final salute to the peace process, Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, was unrepentant yesterday over the assassination of a Palestinian militant, laid to rest amid the peal of church bells and the rattle of gunfire.

Nuns and gunmen, middle aged businessmen - with starched pocket handkerchiefs - and Islamists in flowing robes turned out in their thousands to bury a leader of Yasser Arafat's Fatah party and two elderly women cut down by Israeli helicopters in a wealthy suburb of Bethlehem.

Thursday's attack galvanised Palestinians, erasing divisions of religion, class and political affiliation, and uniting a population in grief and anger. But Mr Barak, undaunted by a growing Palestinian resolve to continue their intifada, said Israel was committed to an aggressive new policy of pre-emptive attacks.

"We will continue with such operations," the prime minister said during a visit to his army's West Bank headquarters. "We will hit those who hit us."

Mr Barak's tough posture is certain to cause further dismay in Washington, where President Clinton met Mr Arafat on Thursday in yet another attempt to pull Israel and the Palestinians back from war to negotiations.

The Palestinian leader said he had reaffirmed his commitment to peace, and even to direct talks with Mr Barak - provided such a meeting had greater chances of success than the collapsed Camp David summit of last July. He was to visit the United Nations tonight to press his campaign for an international protection force for the West Bank and Gaza.

The renewed diplomacy brought few concrete signs for hope. "We continue to be frustrated," the White House spokesman, PJ Crowley, said.

That situation is unlikely to change tomorrow when Mr Barak takes his turn at meeting President Clinton. Yesterday, he said it would be "a little too far-fetched" to expect a resumption of negotiations. Instead, Mr Barak said, as he has so many times during these last six weeks, that the violence must end first.

But in Beit Sahour, where thousands gathered at a local schoolyard over the flag-draped coffins of the two elderly women who were among the first victims of his new "initiated" military policy, Palestinians were clear that it was Israel that was the source of the violence.

"This is a real crime... they are doing to our people," said a nun from St Joseph's school in Bethlehem.

Behind her was a lorryload of teenagers, in black T-shirts printed overnight with the image of the newest martyr: Hussein Abayat, a local leader of Mr Arafat's Fatah militia, clad in fatigues and holding an assault rifle. "Down with the olive branch, up with the gun," they chanted.

Israel said Abayat was responsible for killing three of its soldiers, and for the nightly gunfire on the Jewish settlement of Gilo, built on land confiscated from a Palestinian village on the southern edges of Jerusalem.

The Palestinians see his assassination - and the killing of the two women - as a clear sign that Israel has turned its guns on Mr Arafat's Fatah movement, which had been preaching peace for seven years.

Yesterday, the sense of betrayal ran deep. "Revenge, revenge for the three the Israelis slaughtered with their missiles," said the imam presiding over the women's funeral.

"We are more united, Muslim and Christian. This is the land of Jesus and the prophet Mohammed so both Christians and Muslims have the right to struggle against the occupation."

The Palestinians got their revenge minutes later when an Israeli soldier was shot in the neck outside Rachel's tomb, a biblical pilgrimage site that is a constant battleground between Israelis and Palestinians.

Another Israeli soldier was injured outside Ramallah as a declared "day of rage" saw clashes the length of the West Bank and in Gaza.

At least three Palestinians were killed, and 168 injured yesterday, the Red Crescent Society said.

Nuns and gunmen, middle aged businessmen - with starched pocket handkerchiefs - and Islamists in flowing robes turned out in their thousands to bury a leader of Yasser Arafat's Fatah party and two elderly women cut down by Israeli helicopters in a wealthy suburb of Bethlehem. Thursday's attack galvanised Palestinians, erasing divisions of religion, class and political affiliation, and uniting a population in grief and anger. But Mr Barak, undaunted by a growing Palestinian resolve to continue their intifada, said Israel was committed to an aggressive new policy of pre-emptive attacks. "We will continue with such operations," the prime minister said during a visit to his army's West Bank headquarters. "We will hit those who hit us." Mr Barak's tough posture is certain to cause further dismay in Washington, where President Clinton met Mr Arafat on Thursday in yet another attempt to pull Israel and the Palestinians back from war to negotiations. The Palestinian leader said he had reaffirmed his commitment to peace, and even to direct talks with Mr Barak - provided such a meeting had greater chances of success than the collapsed Camp David summit of last July. He was to visit the United Nations tonight to press his campaign for an international protection force for the West Bank and Gaza. The renewed diplomacy brought few concrete signs for hope. "We continue to be frustrated," the White House spokesman, PJ Crowley, said. That situation is unlikely to change tomorrow when Mr Barak takes his turn at meeting President Clinton. Yesterday, he said it would be "a little too far-fetched" to expect a resumption of negotiations. Instead, Mr Barak said, as he has so many times during these last six weeks, that the violence must end first. But in Beit Sahour, where thousands gathered at a local schoolyard over the flag-draped coffins of the two elderly women who were among the first victims of his new "initiated" military policy, Palestinians were clear that it was Israel that was the source of the violence. "This is a real crime... they are doing to our people," said a nun from St Joseph's school in Bethlehem. Behind her was a lorryload of teenagers, in black T-shirts printed overnight with the image of the newest martyr: Hussein Abayat, a local leader of Mr Arafat's Fatah militia, clad in fatigues and holding an assault rifle. "Down with the olive branch, up with the gun," they chanted. Israel said Abayat was responsible for killing three of its soldiers, and for the nightly gunfire on the Jewish settlement of Gilo, built on land confiscated from a Palestinian village on the southern edges of Jerusalem. The Palestinians see his assassination - and the killing of the two women - as a clear sign that Israel has turned its guns on Mr Arafat's Fatah movement, which had been preaching peace for seven years. Yesterday, the sense of betrayal ran deep. "Revenge, revenge for the three the Israelis slaughtered with their missiles," said the imam presiding over the women's funeral. "We are more united, Muslim and Christian. This is the land of Jesus and the prophet Mohammed so both Christians and Muslims have the right to struggle against the occupation." The Palestinians got their revenge minutes later when an Israeli soldier was shot in the neck outside Rachel's tomb, a biblical pilgrimage site that is a constant battleground between Israelis and Palestinians. Another Israeli soldier was injured outside Ramallah as a declared "day of rage" saw clashes the length of the West Bank and in Gaza. At least three Palestinians were killed, and 168 injured yesterday, the Red Crescent Society said.

webTitle: The Roman baboon that speaks its mind

fields.headline: The Roman baboon that speaks its mind
fields.trailText: There are many things weird about the baboon. He is furry rather than hairy. He sits on the street all day. He spurts water. He makes political   statements. He is ignored.
fields.body:
There are many things weird about the baboon. He is furry rather than hairy. He sits on the street all day. He spurts water. He makes political statements. He is ignored.

Romans say he has been there for 2,000 years and they have heard it all before, but they can't have. He is an up-to-the minute baboon with a ryhming couplet to comment on the latest headlines.

True, he can be repetitive. Ehud Barak's courtship of Ariel Sharon induced a stream of circular invective. He cannot get over Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia. Mr Bush he does not like.

But most days he is a baboon with a fresh take on a fresh subject. So why don't people listen?

At the very least it's rude. This is a creature their ancestors dragged - stole - from Greece. Cast in marble, he is sprawled above a gurgling bath tub, propped up on an elbow.

A man's bearded face grins above the neck, but below is a different story. A green mossy substance shrouds the muscular body in fuzz. More ape than human, he has given the street its name, Via del Babuino.

His career started in imperial times when offending the rich and powerful could lead to death, or at least exile, as befell the poet Ovid. The villa he pined for but never saw again was unearthed by builders only last week.

The baboon made his debut at dawn: a sign around his neck, placed by unknown hands during the night, proclaiming the idiocy of a certain noble. Crowds gathered as word spread.

The emperor, so it is said, was tickled, and a star was born. Dissenters, complainers, grumps, eccentrics, radicals, all came to deposit messages.

Today the street gleams with fashion boutiques but the baboon is as loud as ever, yelling not from signs but graffitti on the wall behind.

It is cleaned every fortnight but the writing returns.

Yesterday: "Israel will pay", "So will Jeb", "But not Berlusconi". Three different hands, in descending order, attacking Israel's violence, George Bush's brother's failure to deliver Florida and a media magnate's alleged tax evasion.

Some comments are cruel. After a helicopter crash killed seven Carabinieri police officers: "Yee ha! Stick to horses, boys."

Opposition to authority blooms in Campo dei Fiori, a beautiful square on the other side of town. They have usually cleared up and melted away by the time tourists arrive for dinner but this is where the anarchists congregate.

They come because Giordano Bruno, an outspoken philosopher-priest, was burned at the stake here in 1600 for challenging the Vatican. Rallies, vigils and fresh flowers sprout around the statue which marks the spot.

It is one of the few visible manifestations of widespread, thriving anti-clericalism. What was said about the Pope at a recent gathering would have been too strong for Ian Paisley.

It was the baboon's misfortune to be marooned in a shopping district for those who can afford Gucci, Armani and Ferre.

Not once have I seen a Roman pausing to read his thoughts. The only attention comes from tourists, wondering if he is too grotesque to photograph.

webTitle: Corner of a foreign field that is forever dangerous

fields.headline: Corner of a foreign field that is forever dangerous
fields.standfirst: More than 80 years on, a deadly harvest of unexploded artillery shells is still being found in Flanders' fields
fields.trailText: It is mid-morning in Flanders and Chief Petty Officer Marc Baelde and Master Corporal Dirk Swertvaegher of the Belgian army are out on a routine mission - collecting artillery shells used by the British army more than 80 years ago.
fields.body:
It is mid-morning in Flanders and Chief Petty Officer Marc Baelde and Master Corporal Dirk Swertvaegher of the Belgian army are out on a routine mission - collecting artillery shells used by the British army more than 80 years ago.

CPO Baelde, a team leader with explosives ordnance disposal (EOD), is crouching by the side of a cornfield in Zandvoorde, near Ypres, tapping gently with a small hammer at the end of a rust-streaked tube encrusted with dry earth.

"Don't worry," he says, pointing with gloved hands to the metal band encircling the end of a six-inch calibre shell - measured to identify the precise type. "The copper strip is still there, so that means it has never been fired."

Half a dozen other shells are wire-brushed clean, checked and then laid carefully in a wooden tray, filled with sand, in the back of an EOD white and dayglo Mercedes truck, a stylised bomb emblem emblazoned on its bonnet.

"Always sideways," explains Cpl Swertvaegher, a strapping, slow-talking 6ft-something who does the heavy lifting.

"To prevent detonation if there's an accident." Crystallised explosives become unstable and can easily go off.

Today is the 82nd anniversary of the end of the first world war, and as poppies are buttoned into lapels and remembrance services held, these Belgian servicemen will be out as usual gathering the deadly harvest of an unending conflict.

Most of it was sown in the spring of 1917, during the third battle of Ypres - known as "Wipers" to British troops - when a staggering 4.7m shells were fired into a narrow salient protruding into the German front line.

Of those, as many as one third failed to explode in the wet clay, notorious to the men who served and died there.

"Good God," Field Marshal Haig's chief of staff gaped later, weeping as his car floundered through the mud at Passchendaele. "Did we really send men to fight in that?"

Today Passchendaele is just a sleepy village and the neat tombstones of the Tyne Cot cemetery (the name is a legacy of the Geordies of the Northumberland Fusiliers) are the only reminder of the terrible human cost of the fighting.

But six ordnance teams, operating from the nearby Steenstraat barracks, still receive 3,000 calls a year and remove hundreds of tonnes of shells, trench mortars, grenades and other weapons left over from the world's first industrial-scale war.

Known as Dovos after their Flemish acronym, the teams operate a daily, nine-to-five collection service, and are booked weeks in advance through police stations.

In Zandvoorde, the farmer, a Mr Verhoest, has even helpfully sketched directions on the back of an envelope on how to find the shells in his field.

The detritus of battle is part of this bleak landscape, routinely unearthed when people plough their land, plant vegetables, build extensions - or dig graves for newly found human remains in Flanders' many war cemeteries. Occasionally it is still deadly: the latest victim was Luk Evinck, a farmer from Diksmuide, just up the road, who died in his barn last month when he tried to defuse a shell.

"We are used to these things and we are not afraid," said Els Mabesoone, who grows beets and keeps pigs at Boezinge, and has a neat pile of two dozen or so shells - mostly British, with a few French and German ones - ready for collection.

"Every time we plough we find a few more so we leave them here by the cowshed and wait for the Dovos to come."

Except in winter, when the ground is waterlogged, the shells are blown up twice a day in special pits in a field next to the Steenstraat base. Toxic ammunition containing poisons like phosgene are x-rayed and treated separately.

CPO Baelde is a local lad from Messines, and remembers happy boyhood hours collecting shell fuses. He joined the Dovos, an all-volunteer unit, after 22 years as a navy diver.

The Dovos have a strong sense of camaraderie forged by exposure to danger, black humour - and a special allowance called "bibbergeld" (literally "shaking-money") that helps buy a few beers in the camp bar after a day's work.

But protective gear is almost non-existent. "Body armour is just to keep the pieces together so they can give you a decent funeral," laughs Baede. "Shit happens. If one of those six-inchers goes bang, now ... sorry boys."

Belgian bomb disposal and mine clearance experts operate as far afield as Cambodia, Kuwait and Kosovo. But it is on these first world war battlefields at home that the bulk of their work is done. And it could take 70 more years to finish.

webTitle: 6m Iraqis sign up to join Jihad

fields.headline: 6m Iraqis sign up to join Jihad
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: More than 6m Iraqis, including 2m women, have volunteered to fight Israel, President Saddam Hussein said yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 6m Iraqis, including 2m women, have volunteered to fight Israel, President Saddam Hussein said yesterday.

His announcement came as leaders of 54 Muslim countries began gathering in Qatar for a summit which will discuss the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

In a message read on state television, President Saddam said that in just one month 6,607,306 people had signed up for training "to launch Jihad to liberate Palestine", and he was closing the register. He said the campaign was intended to show "enemies and some of the good people" the stand and determination of the Iraqi people.

"When we opened doors for volunteering we knew ... that the Iraqi people was psychologically and ideologically ready and practically prepared together with its armed forces to fight for liberating Palestine from the river [Jordan] to the [Mediterranean] sea," he said.

Meanwhile, Qatar has decided to close the Israeli trade mission in the capital, Doha, after threats by Iran and Saudi Arabia to boycott the Islamic summit. Iran welcomed the move, but Saudi Arabia demanded assurances that the closure would be permanent.

Oman, the only other Gulf state which had ties with Israel, severed relations last month. Morocco and Tunisia have taken similar steps. Egypt, Jordan and Mauritania continue to have full diplomatic relations with Israel.

Qatar had been reluctant to close the office, which opened in 1995, but realised that the issue could wreck the summit, which opens tomorrow.

At a preparatory meeting on Thursday the Iranian foreign minister, Kamal Kharrazi, indirectly criticised Qatar by calling on the Islamic nation to "unify and solidify our positions in support of Palestine".

"People in the Islamic world pin their hopes on this conference to take immediate, effective and lasting measures to determine ways and means to counter the ongoing brutal and inhumane aggression and alleviate the suffering of the Palestinian people," he said.

In a few weeks, the intifada has undone many years' work by Israel to develop signs of normalisation with the Arab world. Although much of this has centred on trade, its significance is mainly political.

Even so, the Arab boycott is making a financial impact. Moshe Nachum, of the Israeli Manufacturers' Association, was quoted in Ha'aretz newspaper this week as saying "Egypt is starting to cause problems for Israeli industrialists."

The article said Israeli businesses have had difficulty landing goods at Egyptian ports. Mr Nachum said joint ventures with Jordan are also being jeopardised because Israeli company representatives are afraid to travel there.

More seriously for Israel's relations with Europe, Syria and Lebanon are seeking to cancel a meeting set up under the Barcelona Declaration. This could undermine moves to establish a free trade zone between European states and countries on the Mediterranean coast, which include Israel, Syria and Lebanon.

webTitle: Aggrieved voters pin hopes on reluctant courts

fields.headline: Aggrieved voters pin hopes on reluctant courts
fields.standfirst:
Legal battle Ballot could be overturned, but will the judges dare?

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: American legal experts believe that aggrieved voters in Florida's Palm Beach county have a basis on which to go to court to have Tuesday's voting in their area overturned. The key question, though, is whether the courts will dare to uphold the Palm Beach voters' claim.
fields.body:
American legal experts believe that aggrieved voters in Florida's Palm Beach county have a basis on which to go to court to have Tuesday's voting in their area overturned. The key question, though, is whether the courts will dare to uphold the Palm Beach voters' claim.

It is one thing to overturn an election for the local school board. It is quite another to order a re-run which could have the most dramatic nationwide consequences possible.

Courts in the US, like those in most democracies, are very reluctant to get involved in elections. The pressures in a case brought in Palm Beach would be the most intense imaginable. Not only would the presidency itself be at stake, but there is also a tight constitutional timetable to be met, and courts do not like to be rushed.

There are, however, precedents to give encouragement to those who are trying to bring a case. As recently as 1998, Florida's supreme court said disputed elections could be declared void even where there was no allegation of fraud or intentional wrongdoing - which is the case in the Palm Beach dispute.

In almost all circumstances, the right of action seems to lie in the Florida courts and with the voters of Florida rather than with Al Gore and the Democratic party. The party can fund the voters' case, however, and Mr Gore is expected to try to raise up to $5m (£3.3m) for the purpose if necessary.

Aggrieved voters in Palm Beach say their intention to vote for the candidate of their choice was frustrated by the now celebrated two-page "butterfly" ballot paper issued in their county.

That paper listed George W Bush on the top line on the left hand side and Al Gore beneath him. But the second hole down in the line of holes which the voters had to punch to record their vote was the one which registered a vote for the Reform candidate Pat Buchanan, whose name appeared on the right hand side. Mr Gore's hole was the third one.

Lawyers say the ballot paper provides two grounds for legal action. First it did not conform to Florida election law, which states that voters must make their mark to the right of the name of the candidate.

Second, the lawyers argue, the ballot caused voters to be confused and thus to be effectively disenfranchised. Many voters claim to have voted in error for Mr Buchanan, while 19,000 ballot papers in Palm Beach county were invalidated because voters voted twice.

The Florida precedent which seems to allow the aggrieved voters to make their case came in a disputed sheriff's election in 1998, when the state supreme court ruled that courts can invalidate an election when "reasonable doubt exists as to whether an election expressed the will of the voters".

In such circumstances, the courts must declare the election void, "even in the absence of fraud or intentional wrongdoing". Challenges could be based on fraud, bribery and the ineligibility of candidates - none of which apply in the present case - as well as "any other cause or allegation" that would show voters' intentions had been frustrated.

Election supervisors will be able to argue that 400,000 other voters in the county successfully mastered the butterfly ballot. And they can point to a 1974 Florida case which held that "mere confusion does not amount to an impediment to the voters' free choice if reasonable time and study will sort it out". Moreover, butterfly ballots have been used before in Palm Beach and have not caused objections.

Even if the plaintiffs have a right of action, the courts have always been very reluctant to order election re-runs, even in the 1998 case. But they certainly would have the power to do so. The most probable re-run order - if one is made at all - would confine the right to vote in the second election to those who voted in the first.

A key objection to a re-run is that it would take place in such different circumstances to the original contest. The second time around, voters would know they held the future of the presidency in their hands.

By and large, the US federal courts leave such disputes to local courts and most lawyers think the federal courts will not want to become involved. Judges at every level in Florida are appointed by the state governor, currently the Republican Jeb Bush, on the recommendation of a commission of legal experts. All seven of the Florida high court judges who might hear a Palm Beach case were appointed by earlier Democratic governors.

However, Florida judges are also subject to periodic elections. Judges who sat in the case would do so in the knowledge that they could become marked men or women by whichever party felt aggrieved by their ruling.

If separate allegations that black voters were unable to vote on Tuesday were to be substantiated, the federal courts would become involved.

The stakes are so high that some experts have begun to envisage a different scenario, in which Florida's election remains unresolved in legal terms by the time the electoral college meets to award the presidency next month.

If Florida is unable to certify a team of 25 electors to take part in the December 18 meeting, neither candidate could muster the 270 electoral college votes needed for victory.

Then the issue would go to the House of Representatives, with each of the 50 state delegations having one vote. In that case, Mr Bush would become president.

And they can point to a 1974 Florida case which held that "mere confusion does not amount to an impediment to the voters' free choice if reasonable time and study will sort it out". Moreover, butterfly ballots have been used before in Palm Beach and have not caused objections. Even if the plaintiffs have a right of action, the courts have always been very reluctant to order election re-runs, even in the 1998 case. But they certainly would have the power to do so. The most probable re-run order - if one is made at all - would confine the right to vote in the second election to those who voted in the first. A key objection to a re-run is that it would take place in such different circumstances to the original contest. The second time around, voters would know they held the future of the presidency in their hands. By and large, the US federal courts leave such disputes to local courts and most lawyers think the federal courts will not want to become involved. Judges at every level in Florida are appointed by the state governor, currently the Republican Jeb Bush, on the recommendation of a commission of legal experts. All seven of the Florida high court judges who might hear a Palm Beach case were appointed by earlier Democratic governors. However, Florida judges are also subject to periodic elections. Judges who sat in the case would do so in the knowledge that they could become marked men or women by whichever party felt aggrieved by their ruling. If separate allegations that black voters were unable to vote on Tuesday were to be substantiated, the federal courts would become involved. The stakes are so high that some experts have begun to envisage a different scenario, in which Florida's election remains unresolved in legal terms by the time the electoral college meets to award the presidency next month. If Florida is unable to certify a team of 25 electors to take part in the December 18 meeting, neither candidate could muster the 270 electoral college votes needed for victory. Then the issue would go to the House of Representatives, with each of the 50 state delegations having one vote. In that case, Mr Bush would become president.

webTitle: Lawyers are back: US is on trial

fields.headline: Lawyers are back: US is on trial
fields.standfirst:
The only assured winners in Florida are the legal eagles

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: One thing was clear in the Florida state capital yesterday. The confusion over the election results has paved the way for a stealthy and rapid seizure of power in the US. The lawyers have truly taken over.
fields.body:
One thing was clear in the Florida state capital yesterday. The confusion over the election results has paved the way for a stealthy and rapid seizure of power in the US. The lawyers have truly taken over.

They were everywhere in Tallahassee, patrolling the normally sleepy streets in uniform charcoal suits and colourful ties for the men, the women in earth tones. They huddled in hotel lobbies or on street corners, and marched in and out of the courthouse with the heady sense of purpose of people who had been waiting all their careers for just such a moment.

Following them everywhere, into restaurants and toilets, was a spiky huddle of journalists, bristling with cameras and tripods, the television networks' star legal correspondents to the fore. Meanwhile, on the sidelines and emitting constant background noise, were the protesters from both camps.

Lawyers, press and demonstrators, mingling under Florida's palms while the rest of the world looked on in horror - no wonder it all seemed familiar. It was Elian Gonzalez: the Sequel. Except this time the fate of US democracy was at stake, not just the future of a cute six-year-old boy.

The two opposing camps of suits are led by two grizzled generals, Jim Baker on the Republican side and Warren Christopher for the Democrats. These two veterans used to fly into the trouble spots like the Middle East to soothe tensions and bridge differences. This time they have been dropped into Florida, principally to stir things up on behalf of their parties.

Mr Christopher, President Bill Clinton's first secretary of state, muttered about "disturbing irregularities". Mr Baker, secretary of state for his current boss's father, former president George Bush, summoned a press conference yesterday to urge the country back from the abyss.

Last chance

"This may be the last chance to do that. There is no reasonable end to this process if it slips away," he said.

Outside the rotunda of the old state capital, the two doyens have vied to gain the upper hand in gravitas, approaching the press hordes with deliberately slow and well-considered steps. Nearby, souvenir copies of Wednesday special editions of the Tallahassee Democrat declaring a Bush victory were on sale for $5 each.

The two sides had set up opposing camps from which to deploy their legal battalions. The Republicans could mostly be found in the luxurious Governor's Inn hotel in the centre of town. The Democrats were a couple of miles away, in a hastily improvised command-post sandwiched between a manicurist's salon and a cheap Greek restaurant. Political volunteers manned the phones in the front office while the room in the back was filled with a special operations team of lawyers, analysing news of irregularities flowing in from the counties.

It was clear it would be a long battle. The automatic recount in Florida's 67 counties cut the margin between George W Bush and Al Gore to 327 out of the nearly 6m votes cast in the state. As the Democrats' lawyers pointed out, the accuracy of the mechanised voting machines was only 99.95%, which meant a possible error of 3,000 either way.

That is normally thought trivial. By yesterday, it looked like a landslide. Manual recounts have been ordered in four big counties: Palm Beach, Volusia, Broward and Miami-Dade, with well over 1m votes. Then there are the absentee ballots - navy and airforce personnel abroad and US Jews living in Israel who have maintained an official residence in Florida.

By the day of the election, about 170,000 of the absentee ballots requested had still not been returned. Those which arrive by next Friday and are postmarked before election day, November 7, will count.

Then there is the next wild card - the legal challenges about the controversial ballot paper in Palm Beach, the behaviour of the police towards black voters around Tampa, which allegedly put some off voting. And rumours are flying of more exotic shenanigans. In Miami-Dade county, which includes much of Miami, the dead have been known to vote in mayoral elections. Many Floridians refer to their state as "the banana republic", and a popular protest is to throw bananas on the steps of government buildings.

Miami's Dade county was at the centre of a storm in an earlier election nail-biter. In 1876, a recount was ordered in the county, to help resolve the disputed presidential contest between Rutherford Hayes, a Republican, and his Democratic opponent, Samuel Tilden. Even though the county, a malarial swamp at that time, had only 85 residents, it was so slow in delivering its votes that the US erupted in fury. A New York newspaper printed an editorial asking: "Where the hell is Dade county?" The question this time is what the hell is happening in Florida?

Rotten thing

Already the backwash from the Elian controversy is becoming entangled with the electoral debacle. Yesterday Elian Gonzalez's Florida relatives, who blame the Clinton administration for sending the shipwrecked boy back to Cuba, cancelled a ceremony to honour Kendall Coffey, a prominent Miami lawyer who was in the legal team which fought to keep Elian in the US. Mr Coffey has now joined lawyers helping Mr Gore and the Democrats in their Florida challenge.

"After his public statements questioning the integrity of this administration, I cannot understand how he could work for it," a spokesman for the Gonzalez family, Armando Gutierrez, said of Mr Coffey. Elian's great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, added: "I find this action incomprehensible. It was a rotten thing to do."

Only five months after their court fight failed and Elian returned to his father in Cuba, the lawyers are back in charge. And this time the US is in the dock.

webTitle: Uneasy tale of two Americas badly in need of unity

fields.headline: Uneasy tale of two Americas badly in need of unity
fields.standfirst:
Daunting task remains in healing nation's splits

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Every morning, millions of Americans recite a pledge about themselves as "One nation, under God, indivisible". But the question today, after Tuesday's split-down-the-middle presidential election, is just how true any of this is any longer?
fields.body:
Every morning, millions of Americans recite a pledge about themselves as "One nation, under God, indivisible". But the question today, after Tuesday's split-down-the-middle presidential election, is just how true any of this is any longer?

"This nation has rarely appeared more divided than it does right now," the doyen of American political commentators David Broder commented yesterday in his Washington Post column.

Mr Broder was one of many Americans peering over the brink this weekend, wondering just how much post-election recrimination and legal challenge the United States constitution can take.

"We say yes to counting a little more, but the legal action about which Mr Daley [the Al Gore campaign chairman] spoke elliptically should be approached with enormous caution" warned an editorial in the Washington Post.

Typically, the mood was much more brusque in New York. Enough Already! ran the headline on the tabloid New York Post's front page. "Stop whining, finish counting and move on."

Over on the west coast, the response was just as characteristically mellow. "There's time to sort this out without resorting to hysterics," counselled the Los Angeles Times in an editorial.

The hysteria level was as strong on the right as it was on the left. The Wall Street Journal's editorial page, conservative America's favourite playground, came out yesterday with a vintage collection of obsessive think pieces. The three headlines tell it all: A Gore Coup d'Etat? The People Have Spoken; Will Gore Listen? and Blame Bush For Hillary's Win.

"There are two Americas, and when you look at the electoral map the division has never been clearer," observed the Rutgers university professor, Ben Barber, yesterday.

"One is an old-fashioned America of traditional values. The other wants a much more open, diverse society, less judgmental of people. One America wanted to impeach and remove Clinton. The other wanted to exonerate him".

Not much was spoken about the Clinton factor in the election campaign that everyone thought had ended on Tuesday. But the issue was very much there, just below the surface. Tuesday's exit polls showed that 44% of voters said the Clinton scandals were important in deciding which way they would vote.

The sense of division in modern America came through very clearly in the November 7 election. Americans divided 50-50 in the presidential election, 50-50 in the senate election, and 50-50 in the House of Representatives election. More than one commentator this week has quoted Abraham Lincoln's solemn words: "A house divided against itself cannot stand."

The divisions have sparked creative thinking in some quarters. "Let's face it. This election was basically a tie," says Gail Collins, of the New York Times, calling on Bush and Gore to respond accordingly by moderating their calls for absolute victory.

In the same paper, Thomas Friedman went even further yesterday. "This unprecedented ending to a US election calls for an unprecedented response - some kind of national unity cabinet," he suggested. If Bush wins, he should appoint Bill Clinton as his secretary of state and give Al Gore a seat in the cabinet. If Gore wins, Colin Powell should go to state and Bush should get the education secretaryship. I'm serious - sort of," Mr Friedman wrote.

Others have not been. The satirical magazine Onion carried a front page celebrating the election of "President Bush or Gore" amid crowds of "delirious Republicans or Democrats" in a report datelined "Austin or Nashville."

Radio commentator Peter Loge took up the idea, suggesting "a tag-team presidency". If charm and schmooze were needed, Bush could do the presidential duties. If a bit of knowledge was required, Gore could take over.

But the real mood in America is uneasy, and the huge interest which the election has generated is beginning to harden into something more apprehensive.

"Beware what you wish for," the columnist Charles Krauthammer cautioned yesterday. "It is deeply troubling that the future course of a country of 275m should be determined by a handful of voters."

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Dallas Morning News Cooler heads must recognise that this nation cannot be kept indefintely in limbo while every vagary in the voting process is put under the legal microscope in a highly-charged political atmosphere. If the Florida clarification process is expanded to include a count by hand in four counties, as the Democratic campaign wants, then in fairness other close results in other counties would have to be canvassed as well - and then where and when would it end?
fields.body:
Dallas Morning News Cooler heads must recognise that this nation cannot be kept indefintely in limbo while every vagary in the voting process is put under the legal microscope in a highly-charged political atmosphere. If the Florida clarification process is expanded to include a count by hand in four counties, as the Democratic campaign wants, then in fairness other close results in other counties would have to be canvassed as well - and then where and when would it end?

Toledo Blade It is galling to hear Republican party officials complain that Mr Gore is a sore loser who can't bear to accept that he may have lost this election. The vice-president has no choice but to pursue this matter as long as it takes. He won the popular vote nationwide and we have to believe that he also won the popular vote in Florida. Florida governor Jeb Bush's job was to carry his state for his brother. Whether he did or didn't, he is forever tainted by this fiasco.

Plain Dealer, Cleveland Take a long look at a map showing the states won by George Bush and Al Gore. Notice the similarity. Both reflect our divisions. What an ugly sight. While nearly half of those who voted supported Bush and nearly half cast their lot for Gore, neither man was a clear-cut winner. The resulting confusion and bitterness only serves to drive Americans further into separate camps. This mess is the logical outcome when campaigns are built on endurance and destruction, not leadership and inspiration.

Arkansas Democrat-Gazette Whether the future holds a President Bush or a President Gore, this election will have conferred all the power of the presidency, not necessarily the authority. But that is the way it has always been. It is not the margin of electoral victory that in the end confers legitimacy on a president, but what he does in office.

webTitle: America should copy us, says Russian poll chief

fields.headline: America should copy us, says Russian poll chief
fields.standfirst:
Many countries are enjoying the US shambles

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In Serbia it was a case of  déjà vu yesterday. "I could never have predicted that what happened in elections in Yugoslavia would be repeated in the United States," the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, quipped at a press conference.
fields.body:
In Serbia it was a case of déjà vu yesterday. "I could never have predicted that what happened in elections in Yugoslavia would be repeated in the United States," the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, quipped at a press conference.

It may take the Americans until December to find out who won their presidential election, but the Serbians managed to get a result within two weeks: not on a recount but by storming the parliament building after Slobodan Milosevic tried to fiddle the votes in the September 24 poll.

"It seems our virus of election manipulation has now found its way to America," said Velimir Ilic, mayor of Cacak, who, early in October, led armed men and a bulldozer through police blockades from his town to storm the parliament in Belgrade.

Russians, for decades on the receiving end of US lectures about democracy, also allowed themselves a touch of smugness yesterday.

Alexander Veshnyakov, head of the central elections commission, who was criticised earlier this year for irregularities in Russia's presidential contest, said the US system was "undemocratic and confusing", and advised Americans to learn from Russia.

Boris Nemtsov, a leading liberal, former deputy prime minister and a frequent recipient of US advice on democracy-building, said he expected the US to get rid of its electoral college and move toward direct elections.

"They would then catch up with Russia," he said.

But in a snipe at both voting systems, the satirical website, www.anekdote.ru, fantasised that the US had sought technical help from the Russian central election commission to get it out of its difficulties.

"Veshnyakov has flown to the US. Latest reports show Vladimir Putin in the lead," it quipped.

In Zimbabwe, where Robert Mugabe has been in power since 1980, and his most recent electoral campaign was marred by by intimidation and violence, the government's spokesman, Jonathan Moyo, said it made no sense that Al Gore could win the popular vote without winning the presidency. "We could not get away with something like that in Zimbabwe without the threat of sanctions," he said.

America's electoral muddle has given the "emerging democracies" an opportunity to mock their mentor. They are usually expected to welcome international observers at election time to ensure fair play, and if they do not, aid from the US and other western countries may be at risk.

"Maybe Africans and others should send observers to help Americans deal with their democracy," Mr Moyo told BBC radio 4.

"Call it American democracy at work, but for most people outside the US watching the presidential ballot in Florida, it looked like a third world election fiasco," columnist Thanong Khanthong wrote in Thailand's Nation newspaper.

International relations expert M Shahiduzzman in Bangladesh called the all-or-nothing US system "pathetically flawed".

India, which boasts that it is the world's largest democracy, was also quick to adopt a "it couldn't happen here" line.

Chief election commissioner M Gill said: "The US may be the most technologically-advanced country, but our electoral system is any day better... Their delegate system is archaic." He conceded that fraud was widespread in India, but said if irregularities were found, there was a new poll.

In the Middle East, where presidents regularly get over 90% of the vote, the Lebanese paper al-Safir apologised for its premature announcement of Mr Gore's victory. It said in Arab countries the results are usually known before polling.

webTitle: Allies tell Gore to back down

fields.headline: Allies tell Gore to back down
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore was last night coming under intense pressure from both allies and foes to step back from legal action and accept the final count of the US 2000 presidential election in Florida when it is completed in a week's time.
fields.body:
Al Gore was last night coming under intense pressure from both allies and foes to step back from legal action and accept the final count of the US 2000 presidential election in Florida when it is completed in a week's time.

Senior Democrats have warned Mr Gore in a series of mainly private but sometimes public messages that the US political system may not be able to take the strain if he presses ahead regardless with plans to challenge Tuesday's elections in the Florida courts.

Party leaders are worried that public support for Mr Gore's challenge to George W Bush's claims to the presidency, currently running at well above 50% in the opinion polls, may begin to drain away if Mr Bush is once more declared the winner in Florida when all the votes are counted.

The key deadline in America's post-election uncertainty seems increasingly to be next Friday, the final date by which the state's overseas postal votes can be accepted by election officials.

Republicans redoubled the pressure on Mr Gore to throw in the towel even sooner than that. Mr Bush's official observer in Florida, James Baker, said Mr Gore should concede the election after news agencies reported that the officially ordered recount there had produced a tiny majority of 327 votes for Mr Bush.

"It is frustrating to lose an election by a narrow margin, but it happens," the former US secretary of state said in a statement in Tallahassee, the Florida state capital.

"For the good of the country and for the sake of our standing in the world, the campaigning should end and the business of an orderly transition should begin."

The Gore campaign hit back that such calls were inappropriate. "The outcome here in Florida remains in doubt, as it will for several more days," Mr Gore's chief observer William Daley said in Tallahassee. "Calls for the declaration of a victor before all the votes are accurately tabulated are inappropriate."

There was nevertheless a change of tone and emphasis in Mr Daley's remarks yesterday, with the stress on the need to await the full count of votes, including overseas postal votes, rather than on challenging the fairness of the election in the courts. That shift reflects the high delicacy of the continuing post-election stand-off, in which both sides are acutely aware that they are fighting a battle for public sympathy as much as for judicial approval.

Among the senior Democrats who are understood to have counselled caution to Mr Gore are the party leader in the House of Representatives Dick Gephardt, as well as two outspoken Democrats in the Senate, John Breaux of Louisiana and Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, who went public with his views last night.

"I want Al Gore to win this election but, more than that, I want somebody to win this election," Mr Torricelli said yesterday. "I would urge both Al Gore and George W Bush to think of the country - the continuity of its government, its stability - and avoid any collateral attacks on the process."

Mr Gore kept out of the limelight again yesterday - he has only made one brief public comment on the election since early Wednesday morning. The vice-president ordered his campaign team to leave its Nashville headquarters and regroup in Washington. Mr Gore spent the day at his official residence in the capital.

The Gore campaign was reported yesterday to be preparing to raise $4-5m in order to help finance any legal challenges.

Mr Daley made clear that Gore campaign lawyers now believed that the ballot in Florida's Palm Beach county was unlawful because of the form of the ballot paper used there. He said their conclusion had been "implicitly acknowledged by the election supervisor who put out a flyer on election day warning about the problems."

The county election supervisor at the centre of the storm, Theresa LePore, a Democrat, was said to have spent most of the day in tears.

A recount by hand will begin today in three precincts in Palm Beach County as Democrats seek further evidence to prevent the award of Florida's 25 electoral college votes to Mr Bush. Officials in Volusia county near Daytona Beach have also agreed to conduct a sample hand count.

Both parties are upbeat about their chances of capturing the postal votes, with Republicans relying on the armed services and some Latino support and Democrats claiming that absentees in Israel and black American service voters will swing the result their way.

Bigger political calculations are increasingly making themselves felt as the tension drags on in Florida. A recount may have to be triggered in Oregon, officials hinted yesterday. Republicans are also poised to call for second counts in Iowa, New Mexico and Wisconsin, all of which Mr Gore won by narrow margins, if Mr Bush tells them to do so.

Latest calculations from Tuesday's election published yesterday continued to show Mr Gore ahead in the overall popular vote across the US. At the latest count, Mr Gore had 49.11m votes as against 48.89m for Mr Bush.

Mr Gore has 260 electoral college votes compared with Mr Bush's 246, with 270 required for victory. Florida's 25 votes and Oregon's seven votes remain outstanding.

Election countdown

Today: Second recount, this time by hand, begins in parts of Palm Beach and Volusia counties

November 14: Deadline for completion of all recounts in Florida

November 17: Eligible Florida postal votes must be received

December 18: Electoral college meets in each state

January 6: Congress meets to receive the electoral college vote

January 20: Inauguration of new president

fields.headline: Yorkshire
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Five years ago the media descended upon Yorkshire in droves, despatched to report on empty reservoirs and dried up streams. The media is back in droves again, only now the story is about too much water. Now, the reporters are looking for the latest village to be swamped with floods, the next settlement along the Rivers Derwent and Ouse where sandbags are being shipped in by the thousand.

In the south of the county, the River Rother has burst its banks, the earthern floodbanks visible only as a thin ribbon of snaking green on a cloth of mud-brown water. The controlled washlands, deliberately inundated as part of the flood management plan, are full to capacity. At Whiston Meadows, the water spreads across the road, the brook, usually home to a good sized colony of water voles, identifiable only by the stone bridge under which it flows.

Wildlife is adapting to the new landscape. Along the temporary shoreline, new water vole runs can be found. Sadly, their old tunnels by the brook side, stocked with winter food supplies, will be lost. A tiny field vole leaps in the water by our feet, swimming out furiously like a clockwork toy, to the branches of a half-submerged hazel bush. Once there, it clambers up into the cleft of a branch Joint and grooms itself, before jumping in the water again and setting off into the new jungle of twigs and sticks.

An old broken fence post, just a few inches protruding above the water, is smothered with woodlice, clambering over each other in a seething mass as those closest to the lapping waters seek to scramble higher, pushing those beneath still lower as they do. For a flock of long-tailed tits it is business as usual, looping along the hedgerow, constantly cheeping to each other to maintain contact, checking each nook and cranny for food.

It has stopped raining now, although more is forecast. The media is looking to the next story, checking out of the hotels in York and off to wherever the editor sends them. Meanwhile, the wildlife, with no sandbags supplied, no insurance and no media spotlight, will cope with the aftermath on its own.
