webTitle: 'No remedy presents itself so soon to my heart as mine own sword'

fields.headline: 'No remedy presents itself so soon to my heart as mine own sword'
fields.standfirst: What drives people to commit suicide? Psychiatrist  Kay Redfield Jamison  knows better than most
fields.trailText: What drives people to commit suicide? Psychiatrist Kay Redfield Jamison knows better than most
fields.body:
Summer evenings at the Bistro Gardens in Beverly Hills tended toward the languorous. My friend Jack and I went there often when I lived in Los Angeles. From time to time, Jack would use the occasion to suggest we get married. It was an idea with such potential for catastrophe that neither of us had much of an inclination to take it with much gravity. But our friendship we took seriously.

This particular evening, I found myself edgily knocking the ice cubes around in my whisky glass. We were making a blood oath: if either of us again became deeply suicidal, we agreed, we would meet at Jack's home on Cape Cod. Once there, the nonsuicidal one would have a week to persuade the other not to commit suicide; a week to present all the reasons we could come up with for why the other should go back on lithium (we both had manic-depressive illness and had a tendency to stop taking our lithium); a week to cajole the other into a hospital; to invoke conscience; to impress upon the other the pain and damage to our families that suicide would bring.

We would, we said, walk along the beach and remind the other of all of the times we had felt at the end of hope and, somehow, had come back. Who, if not someone who had actually been there, could better bring the other back from the edge?

We decided that a week was long enough to argue for life. If it didn't work, at least we would have tried. And, because we had years of experience with impetuousness and knew how quick and final a suicidal impulse could be, we further agreed that neither of us would ever buy a gun.

"Cheers," we said in synchrony, ice and glass clinking, sealing our foray into the rational world. Still, I had my doubts. I listened to the details, helped clarify a few, finished my scotch, and stared at the tiny white lights in the gardens around us. Who were we kidding? Never once, during any of my bouts of depression, had I been inclined or able to pick up a telephone and ask a friend for help. It wasn't in me. How could I seriously imagine that I would call Jack, book a flight, get to an airport, rent a car, and find my way out to his house on the Cape? It seemed only slightly less absurd that Jack would go along with the plan, although he, at least, was rich and could get others to handle the practicalities.

It is a tribute to the persuasiveness and infinite capacity for self-deception of two manic temperaments that by the time the desserts arrived we were utterly convinced that our pact would hold. He would call me; I would call him; we would outmanoeuvre the black knight and force him from the board.

The black knight, however, has a tendency to remain in play. And so it did. Many years later - Jack had long since married and I had moved to Washington - I received a phone call from California: Jack had put a gun to his head, said a relative. He had killed himself.

No week in Cape Cod, no chance to dissuade. A man who had been inventive enough to earn a thousand patents for such diverse creations as the Hawk and Sparrow missile systems used by the US Defense Department, toys played with by millions of children, and household devices used in millions of homes; a Yale graduate and lover of life; a successful businessman - this remarkably imaginative man had not been inventive enough to find an alternative solution to a violent, self-inflicted death.

Although shaken by Jack's suicide, I was not surprised by it. Nor was I surprised that he had not called me. I, after all, had been dangerously suicidal myself on several occasions since our Bistro Gardens compact and had not called him. Suicide does not always hearken to plans drawn up in lucid moments and banked in good intentions.

I know this for an unfortunate fact. Suicide has been a professional interest of mine for more than 20 years, and a personal one for far longer. I have a hard-earned respect for suicide's ability to undermine, overwhelm, devastate and destroy. As a clinician, researcher, and professor of psychiatry, I have known patients who hanged, shot, or asphyxiated themselves; jumped to their deaths from stairwells, buildings or overpasses; died from poisons, fumes, prescription drugs; slashed their wrists or cut their throats. Friends, fellow students from graduate school and children of colleagues have done the same. Most were young and suffered from mental illness; all left behind a wake of unimaginable pain and guilt.

Like many who have manic-depressive illness, I have also known suicide in a more private, awful way, and I trace the loss of a fundamental innocence to the day that I first considered suicide as the solution to an unendurable level of mental pain. Until that time I had taken for granted, and loved more than I knew, a temperamental lightness of mood and a fabulous expectation of life. I was 17 when, in the midst of my first depression, I became knowledgeable about suicide in something other than an existential, adolescent way.

I thought about when, whether, where, and how to kill myself. I learned to present to others a face at variance with my mind; ferreted out the location of two or three nearby tall buildings with unprotected stairwells; discovered the fastest flows of morning traffic; and learned how to load my father's gun.

The rest of my life - sports, classes, writing, friends, planning for college - fell fast into a black night. Everything seemed a ridiculous charade; a hollow existence to fake one's way through as best one could. But gradually the depression lifted, and by the time my senior prom came around, I had been well for months. Suicide had withdrawn to the back squares of the board and become, once again, unthinkable.

Over the years, my manic-depressive illness became worse, and the reality of dying young from suicide became a dangerous undertow in my dealings with life. Then, when I was 28, after a damaging and psychotic mania followed by a prolonged siege of depression, I took a massive overdose of lithium. I unambivalently wanted to die and nearly did. Under the circumstances - I was a young faculty member in a department of academic psychiatry - it was not a very long walk from personal experience to clinical investigation. I studied everything I could about my disease and read all I could find about the psychological and biological determinants of suicide, as a tiger tamer learns about the minds and moves of his cats.

No one knows who was the first to slash his throat with a piece of flint, or take a handful of poison berries, or intentionally drop his spear to the ground in battle. Death, as Seneca states, has always lain close at hand; yet it is a mystery why the first to kill himself did. Was it a sudden impulse, or prolonged disease? An inner voice, commanding death? Perhaps shame or the threat of capture by an enemy? Despair? Exhaustion?

We do, however, have what psychiatrist Chris Thomas believes to be the first extant suicide note. Four thousand years ago, an Egyptian wrote his despair on to papyrus in the form of a narrative and four short-versed poems. This document, now in the Berlin Museum, reflects the ruminations of a deeply depressed, probably psychotic mind:

Lo, my name is abhorred,

Lo, more than than the odour of carrion

On summer days when the sky is hot.

Death is before me today

As a man longs to see his house

When he has spent years in captivity.

Cultures have varied in their notions of self-inflicted death. Several - for example, the Eskimos, Norse, Samoan, and Crow Indian - accepted, and even encouraged, "altruistic" self-sacrifice among the elderly and sick. Among the Yuit Eskimos of St Lawrence Island, if an individual requested suicide three times, relatives were obligated to assist in the killing. The person seeking suicide dressed in ritual death garb and then was killed in a "destroying place" set aside for the purpose.

The Catholic church, during the sixth and seventh centuries, codified its opposition to suicide by excommunicating and denying funeral rites to those who died by their own hand. Jewish custom forbade funeral orations for anyone who committed suicide; mourners' clothes were not encouraged, and burial was limited to an isolated section of the cemetery, so as "not to bury the wicked next to the righteous". In Islamic law, suicide is a crime at least as grave as homicide. In many countries, the bodies of those who killed themselves were buried at night and at a crossroads. The greater traffic was thought to "keep the corpses down", and the intersection, it was believed, would make it more difficult for the spirit to find its way home.

Robert Burton's influential The Anatomy of Melancholy, which argued for mercy for those who were in such despair and agitation as to kill themselves, was published in 1621. Twenty-five years later, Biathanatos, a landmark treatise on suicide, was published. Its author, John Donne, was also the dean of St Paul's Cathedral. In Biathanatos, Donne declared that suicide was, on occasion, justified; certainly it was understandable. It was, for him, personal. "Whensoever any affliction assails me," he confessed in the preface, "methinks I have the keys of my prison in mine own hand, and no remedy presents itself so soon to my heart as mine own sword."

Suicide in the young has at least tripled over the past 45 years and is, without argument, one of our most serious public health problems. It is the second major killer of women between the ages of 15 and 44 worldwide (after TB) and the fourth of men in the same age group (after road accidents, TB and violence). For every completed suicide there are estimated to be 10 to 25 attempts.

In his memoir A Sort of Life, Graham Greene described his early encounters with suicidal depression. While still at school, "I tried out other forms of escape after I failed to cut my leg. Once at home I went into the dark room by the linen-cupboard, and in that red Mephistophelean glare drank a quantity of hypo under the false impression it was poisonous. On another occasion I drained my blue glass bottle of hay-fever drops, which, as they contained a small quantity of cocaine, were probably good for my despair. A bunch of deadly nightshade picked and eaten on the common had only a slightly narcotic effect and I once swallowed 20 aspirins before swimming in the school baths."

When Greene was 19, he took his brother's revolver from the cupboard in their bedroom -"I felt nothing. I was fixed, like a negative in a chemical bath" - and walked into the woods: "I slipped a bullet into a chamber and, holding the revolver behind my back, spun the chamber_ [put] the muzzle into my right ear and pulled the trigger. There was a minute click, and looking down at the chamber I could see that the charge had moved into the firing position. I was out by one. The experience I repeated a number of times..."

Greene did not, in the end, kill himself. But the possibility of suicide was a recurring presence in his life and, as for many with depression, the seeming best response to bale and weariness. He continued to wage war against his black depressions, "the hopeless misery of the years", as he put it, using alcohol, the perverse exhilaration of Russian roulette, and travels into war zones and other areas of high political and social volatility, as antidotes to his bled-out state.

The 18th-century poet Thomas Chatterton wrote Suicide a few months before he swallowed a fatal dose of arsenic.

Since we can die but once, what matters it,

If rope or garter, poison, pistol, sword,

Slow-wasting sickness, or the sudden burst

Of valve arterial in the noble parts

Curtail the miseries of human life?

Though varied is the cause, the effect's the same:

All to one common dissolution tends.

Not long before he died in 1770, he wrote, "Cease my anguish'd soul_ and this last act of wretchedness forgive." He was 17.

Symbolism and suggestion have played their part in the circumstances of self-inflicted deaths. Some places become "suicide magnets", drawing to them not only the impulsive but the more chronically suicidal as well. At Beachy Head on the South Downs of the English coast, suicides have been reported since the sixth century.

Jumping from public monuments has also had a contagious allure - the Eiffel Tower in Paris, St Peter's Basilica in Rome, the Empire State Building in New York. Mount Mihara, an active volcano on the Japanese island of Oshima, was almost entirely unknown until January 1933, when two classmates from a Tokyo college climbed to the top of the crater. There Meiko Ukei, 24, announced to her friend Masako Tomita that she intended to throw herself into the volcano. She would, she explained, be cremated instantly and sent heavenward in smoke and beauty. After extracting a vow of secrecy from her friend, she jumped.

Masako, 21, was understandably unable to keep her promise. She confided in another friend, who then insisted that Masako take her to Mihara so that she could "follow Meiko to paradise". Masako was unable to persuade her friend otherwise, and in early February the two women climbed to the top of the volcano. The friend jumped in, Masako returned alone, and soon the story was a major force in the cultural life of Japan.

People swarmed to Mihara, first by steamer and then by a larger boat that was required to handle the curious. On an April Sunday not long after the deaths of the two young women, six people leaped into the volcano; 25 others had to be restrained from doing so. Tourists lined up to watch the suicides, which were now occurring several times a week. By year's end, at least 140 people had committed suicide.

The following year, more than 160 plunged to their deaths and another 1,200 had to be restrained from following suit. In January 1935, three young men jumped to their deaths within 10 minutes of one another. The police set up a 24-hour watch at the crater, and a barbed-wire fence was erected; yet in 1936, at least 600 people killed themselves. Access to the mountain was eventually closed, but not before at least 1,000 people had thrown themselves into Mihara.

Today, as suicide rates increase, the World Health Organisation has outlined six basic steps for the prevention of suicide, most of which centre on reducing the availability of methods; gun possession control, detoxification of domestic gas, detoxification of car emissions, control of toxic substance availability, more effective treatment of mental disorders, and toning down suicide reports in the media.

Psychologists are deciphering the motivations for suicide and piecing together the circumstances that so dangerously ignite the brain's vulnerabilities. But I have become more impatient as a result of writing this book. I cannot rid my mind of the desolation, confusion and guilt I have seen in the relatives and friends of those who kill themselves. For every moment of exuberance in the science, or in the success of governments, there is a matching and terrible reality of the deaths themselves; the young deaths, the violent deaths, the unnecessary deaths.

While writing this book, I kept on my desk a fragment of a poem . It is the last line from Douglas Dunn's Disenchantments:

Look to the living, love them, and hold on...

 This is an edited extract from Kay Redfield Jamison's Night Falls Fast: Understanding Suicide, published by Picador (£16.99). Over the years, my manic-depressive illness became worse, and the reality of dying young from suicide became a dangerous undertow in my dealings with life. Then, when I was 28, after a damaging and psychotic mania followed by a prolonged siege of depression, I took a massive overdose of lithium. I unambivalently wanted to die and nearly did. Under the circumstances - I was a young faculty member in a department of academic psychiatry - it was not a very long walk from personal experience to clinical investigation. I studied everything I could about my disease and read all I could find about the psychological and biological determinants of suicide, as a tiger tamer learns about the minds and moves of his cats. No one knows who was the first to slash his throat with a piece of flint, or take a handful of poison berries, or intentionally drop his spear to the ground in battle. Death, as Seneca states, has always lain close at hand; yet it is a mystery why the first to kill himself did. Was it a sudden impulse, or prolonged disease? An inner voice, commanding death? Perhaps shame or the threat of capture by an enemy? Despair? Exhaustion? We do, however, have what psychiatrist Chris Thomas believes to be the first extant suicide note. Four thousand years ago, an Egyptian wrote his despair on to papyrus in the form of a narrative and four short-versed poems. This document, now in the Berlin Museum, reflects the ruminations of a deeply depressed, probably psychotic mind: Lo, my name is abhorred, Lo, more than than the odour of carrion On summer days when the sky is hot. Death is before me today As a man longs to see his house When he has spent years in captivity. Cultures have varied in their notions of self-inflicted death. Several - for example, the Eskimos, Norse, Samoan, and Crow Indian - accepted, and even encouraged, "altruistic" self-sacrifice among the elderly and sick. Among the Yuit Eskimos of St Lawrence Island, if an individual requested suicide three times, relatives were obligated to assist in the killing. The person seeking suicide dressed in ritual death garb and then was killed in a "destroying place" set aside for the purpose. The Catholic church, during the sixth and seventh centuries, codified its opposition to suicide by excommunicating and denying funeral rites to those who died by their own hand. Jewish custom forbade funeral orations for anyone who committed suicide; mourners' clothes were not encouraged, and burial was limited to an isolated section of the cemetery, so as "not to bury the wicked next to the righteous". In Islamic law, suicide is a crime at least as grave as homicide. In many countries, the bodies of those who killed themselves were buried at night and at a crossroads. The greater traffic was thought to "keep the corpses down", and the intersection, it was believed, would make it more difficult for the spirit to find its way home. Robert Burton's influential The Anatomy of Melancholy, which argued for mercy for those who were in such despair and agitation as to kill themselves, was published in 1621. Twenty-five years later, Biathanatos, a landmark treatise on suicide, was published. Its author, John Donne, was also the dean of St Paul's Cathedral. In Biathanatos, Donne declared that suicide was, on occasion, justified; certainly it was understandable. It was, for him, personal. "Whensoever any affliction assails me," he confessed in the preface, "methinks I have the keys of my prison in mine own hand, and no remedy presents itself so soon to my heart as mine own sword." Suicide in the young has at least tripled over the past 45 years and is, without argument, one of our most serious public health problems. It is the second major killer of women between the ages of 15 and 44 worldwide (after TB) and the fourth of men in the same age group (after road accidents, TB and violence). For every completed suicide there are estimated to be 10 to 25 attempts. In his memoir A Sort of Life, Graham Greene described his early encounters with suicidal depression. While still at school, "I tried out other forms of escape after I failed to cut my leg. Once at home I went into the dark room by the linen-cupboard, and in that red Mephistophelean glare drank a quantity of hypo under the false impression it was poisonous. On another occasion I drained my blue glass bottle of hay-fever drops, which, as they contained a small quantity of cocaine, were probably good for my despair. A bunch of deadly nightshade picked and eaten on the common had only a slightly narcotic effect and I once swallowed 20 aspirins before swimming in the school baths." When Greene was 19, he took his brother's revolver from the cupboard in their bedroom -"I felt nothing. I was fixed, like a negative in a chemical bath" - and walked into the woods: "I slipped a bullet into a chamber and, holding the revolver behind my back, spun the chamber_ [put] the muzzle into my right ear and pulled the trigger. There was a minute click, and looking down at the chamber I could see that the charge had moved into the firing position. I was out by one. The experience I repeated a number of times..." Greene did not, in the end, kill himself. But the possibility of suicide was a recurring presence in his life and, as for many with depression, the seeming best response to bale and weariness. He continued to wage war against his black depressions, "the hopeless misery of the years", as he put it, using alcohol, the perverse exhilaration of Russian roulette, and travels into war zones and other areas of high political and social volatility, as antidotes to his bled-out state. The 18th-century poet Thomas Chatterton wrote Suicide a few months before he swallowed a fatal dose of arsenic. Since we can die but once, what matters it, If rope or garter, poison, pistol, sword, Slow-wasting sickness, or the sudden burst Of valve arterial in the noble parts Curtail the miseries of human life? Though varied is the cause, the effect's the same: All to one common dissolution tends. Not long before he died in 1770, he wrote, "Cease my anguish'd soul_ and this last act of wretchedness forgive." He was 17. Symbolism and suggestion have played their part in the circumstances of self-inflicted deaths. Some places become "suicide magnets", drawing to them not only the impulsive but the more chronically suicidal as well. At Beachy Head on the South Downs of the English coast, suicides have been reported since the sixth century. Jumping from public monuments has also had a contagious allure - the Eiffel Tower in Paris, St Peter's Basilica in Rome, the Empire State Building in New York. Mount Mihara, an active volcano on the Japanese island of Oshima, was almost entirely unknown until January 1933, when two classmates from a Tokyo college climbed to the top of the crater. There Meiko Ukei, 24, announced to her friend Masako Tomita that she intended to throw herself into the volcano. She would, she explained, be cremated instantly and sent heavenward in smoke and beauty. After extracting a vow of secrecy from her friend, she jumped. Masako, 21, was understandably unable to keep her promise. She confided in another friend, who then insisted that Masako take her to Mihara so that she could "follow Meiko to paradise". Masako was unable to persuade her friend otherwise, and in early February the two women climbed to the top of the volcano. The friend jumped in, Masako returned alone, and soon the story was a major force in the cultural life of Japan. People swarmed to Mihara, first by steamer and then by a larger boat that was required to handle the curious. On an April Sunday not long after the deaths of the two young women, six people leaped into the volcano; 25 others had to be restrained from doing so. Tourists lined up to watch the suicides, which were now occurring several times a week. By year's end, at least 140 people had committed suicide. The following year, more than 160 plunged to their deaths and another 1,200 had to be restrained from following suit. In January 1935, three young men jumped to their deaths within 10 minutes of one another. The police set up a 24-hour watch at the crater, and a barbed-wire fence was erected; yet in 1936, at least 600 people killed themselves. Access to the mountain was eventually closed, but not before at least 1,000 people had thrown themselves into Mihara. Today, as suicide rates increase, the World Health Organisation has outlined six basic steps for the prevention of suicide, most of which centre on reducing the availability of methods; gun possession control, detoxification of domestic gas, detoxification of car emissions, control of toxic substance availability, more effective treatment of mental disorders, and toning down suicide reports in the media. Psychologists are deciphering the motivations for suicide and piecing together the circumstances that so dangerously ignite the brain's vulnerabilities. But I have become more impatient as a result of writing this book. I cannot rid my mind of the desolation, confusion and guilt I have seen in the relatives and friends of those who kill themselves. For every moment of exuberance in the science, or in the success of governments, there is a matching and terrible reality of the deaths themselves; the young deaths, the violent deaths, the unnecessary deaths. While writing this book, I kept on my desk a fragment of a poem . It is the last line from Douglas Dunn's Disenchantments: Look to the living, love them, and hold on...  This is an edited extract from Kay Redfield Jamison's Night Falls Fast: Understanding Suicide, published by Picador (£16.99). fields.headline: Still adrift on Noah's Ark
fields.standfirst: Global warming, believed to be the cause of the present deluge, is an allegory for our time, echoing ancient legends of great floods.  John Vidal  on man's unslakeable thirst for myth
fields.trailText: Global warming, believed to be the cause of the present deluge, is an allegory for our time, echoing ancient legends of great floods. John Vidal on man's unslakeable thirst for myth
fields.body:
If is still raining tomorrow night, the Met Office says, we will have had 40 days and 40 nights of rain. Remind you of anything? Exactly. The biblical flood lasted the same length of time. The myth of how God made the sky fall on the earth but allowed Noah to escape with the animals has passed down the generations.

Little changes. In the old days, God was the administration. He alone ruled and he alone decided that man was corrupt, greedy and in need of a lesson. Today, the scientists are godlike, Prince Charles is the Old Testament prophet and the government preaches caution. They all say that we have induced global warming by corrupting the balance of nature with our profligacy and must learn to adapt.

Noah got the Flood. We get the floods. The only difference is that we are told that if we don't change we'll get massive storms, temperature extremes, sea-level rise and pestilence, too. Everything in the zeitgeist gets worse, it seems, except for old complacents like Sir John Mortimer who still believe global warming will be rather pleasant because we'll be able to grow more grapes.

The parallels between the two deluges are notable. Noah used the highest technology of his day to save himself and his charges. He built a 140m long ark remarkably quickly. We, too, rely on our technology to come up with a quick fix. Scientists and governments say we should buy fuel efficient cars and turn to wind and wave power. If all else fails, we can pour iron filings on the sea, put mirrors in space to turn the sun's rays back or all head off from the sinking planet on an ark of a spaceship to do some terraforming on Mars.

And as there was hope then, so there is today. Noah sent a dove to see if there was dry land and it returned with an olive branch, signalling that the waters were receding. The modern flight of fancy is our investment of hope in the United Nations, under whose auspices world governments will meet on Monday in the Hague to thrash out measures to slow global warming. The logo of the UN? That same olive branch. It's apt, too, that Holland was created largely from the sea.

Mankind is drowning in flood myths. Mark Isaac, an American researcher, has documented almost 200 cultures on every continent with myths or legends involving variations on the theme of sea waters rising or non-stop rains leading to disaster. In the epic poem Gilgamesh, the Sumerian gods get fed up with humanity and give man no warning about the floods they are about to send. In Yoruba (west Africa) myth, they spread oceans across the land because we are uppity; in Aztec culture, the Ancient One is fearfully upset because we do not honour him. He sends in the rains and only allows one family to escape, but the old boy has a sense of humour and turns them into monkeys because they chatter too much - whereupon he brings in new human recruits, the equivalent of Spanish nurses for the NHS. In Bolivia, the Snow God thinks humankind is arrogant and so covers the world in snow and ice and spares no one.

More or less the same flood myth is found from the Philippines to the Pacific islands, taking in Australian Aboriginals, Inuits, Blackfeet and Cheyennes, Lithuanians, Celts, Assyrians , Zoroastrians, Egyptians and Chinese. Every culture, it seems, has a deep sense that it will be drowned if the dominant force of the times is ignored.

For Gods then, read Nature now. Man-induced global warming is a replay of the eternal flood myth, writ fresh for the Millennium. It's not mythical in the sense of being "wrong"- it may one day be "proved" to be caused by sunspots or natural cycles, just as it may be shown eventually that it really is all mankind's fault - but it is a great allegory, the ultimate cautionary tale which we and future generations will tell and retell. It is culturally significant because it is the first secular myth to embrace all humanity and not just one tribe, civilisation or culture.

It is the perfect myth for an increasingly globalising world. Its power to cross cultures is undoubted. In the past three years I have heard the new story of mankind's folly changing the climate and bringing destruction on everyone told in Timbuktu, the Colombian cloud forest, remote Indian villages and smog-bound Indonesia. Even the San, the bushmen of the Kalahari, have adapted man-induced global warming into their modern cosmology. The only places where it is not spoken of in some awe seems to be in George W Bush's Republican party in the US and the offices of the World Trade Organisation. But future generations may see them as the gods of this oil age.

So what is the function of this myth? Global warming seems to fulfil all the elements of true myth. It binds society together, it warns everyone against folly, teaches us to think of our neighbours, has innocent parties (the poor) and guilty (the Americans, especially). Profoundly moral and allegorical, it holds open the option of both Christian redemption and of passage to a better, fairer, saner world. But it also allows every faith, and even the agnostic, to grasp the notion of metamorphosis. It will inform our intellectual and belief systems for generations.

Its power is that, like all the myriad flood myths, it cannot be absolutely proved or disproved and so stays in the imagination. After several thousand years and generations of scientific advances and new understandings of plate tectonics, geology and archaeology, we still cannot say categorically that a catastrophic flood did not at some point in prehistory cover the whole earth - much to the delight of the Christian fundamentalists, who believe the Bible word for word.

But we must tilt at our myths. In September, the oceanographer Robert Ballard, who discovered the Titanic, telephoned Tim Radford, the Guardian's science editor, from a research ship in the Black Sea. He had factual evidence that there had been a mighty flood in the Black Sea.

Using remote-controlled underwater vessels with cameras, his team had located a former river valley. In the valley, 311ft below the present sea surface, was a collapsed but intact 39ft by 13ft structure with preserved wooden beams worked by hand. It was characteristic of Stone Age buildings 7,000 years ago in the interior of Turkey.

It contained a stone chisel and two other stone tools with holes drilled through them. This was recognised as the missing evidence that the Black Sea had suddenly risen in level when a land barrier with the Mediterranean had failed, allowing water to surge in.

The scientific fundamentalists reached for the hypothesis of two oceanographers, William Ryan and Walter Pitman, who had written a book postulating that the people of a flooded Black Sea civili sation had spread out across Africa, Asia and Europe, taking the story of the flood with them. This was the missing piece. Case shut?

Of course not. The creationists were not remotely shaken out of their core beliefs. Genesis Ministries International, a leading fundamentalist group in the US, at once accepted Ballard's evidence of the Black Sea flood, but said it was just a local affair, offering no proof against the biblical world-wide one which has left its mark on every continent.

The link with Noah's flood, they said, was arbitrary, and they hang on to their theory that Genesis's "fountains of the great deep" which mythically covered the mountains of the world in 40 days involved a series of volcanic eruptions with prodigious amounts of water bursting up through the ground.

The wiser scientists kept the door open. It was not the final word one way or another. It neither proved nor disproved Noah' s flood, they said. The scientific jury's still out on global warming too and they'll be arguing about it in 100 years' time, whether we're growing grapes in Scotland or Africa has become a desert. And so will the proponents and opponents of all our other modern myths like the Gaia hypothesis, the big bang, alien abductions, conspiracy theories, Marxism, the myth of progress, the existence of evil, crop circles, the notion that salvation can come from scientific rationalism, or that technology or religion can save the world.

Facts are not important in myths. Global warming caused by man's profligacy leading to catastrophic floods and rising seas is nothing to do with facts. It shows that we need the power of the imagination more than ever. Right or wrong. Come hell or high water.

fields.headline: Popping your clogs
fields.trailText: Quite early one morning, possibly in the context of the possible danger of eating lamb, and probably during the BBC's excellent news magazine Farming Today, I heard a robust lamb-eater assert her intention to go on eating the stuff till she popped her clogs. There are many, many euphemisms for dying, of which this is one, but it had never before occurred to me to wonder how it infiltrated the language.
fields.body:
Quite early one morning, possibly in the context of the possible danger of eating lamb, and probably during the BBC's excellent news magazine Farming Today, I heard a robust lamb-eater assert her intention to go on eating the stuff till she popped her clogs. There are many, many euphemisms for dying, of which this is one, but it had never before occurred to me to wonder how it infiltrated the language.

"Bite the dust", first recorded in 1697, seems clear enough - it means to fall down dead, face down. "Hop off" (18th century) equates death with a bird vacating a twig, and "turn up one's toes" relates to the western practice of placing a corpse on its back. "Peg out" has something to do with cribbage. "Kick the bucket", listed in Francis Grose's Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue (1785), is a mystery but may reflect the notion of a slaughtered animal twitching while suspended from a beam (for which "bucket" was once a synonym).

All these are clearly established in the Bloomsbury Dictionary of Euphemisms, along with "conk out", though they seem less clear about the derivation of "conk". But unhappily, the popping of clogs fails to be listed. The Oxford Dictionary of Idioms describes the term as "informal", but again gives no derivation. The only example it cites dates from 1998: "We cannot claim any credit for foreseeing that Enoch was about to pop his clogs" - in the Oldie. But it certainly goes back a long way further than that.

I wonder if clog in this usage might be clog as defined in my old Oxford English dictionary: "a block or heavy piece of wood, attached to the leg or neck of a man or beast, to impede motion and prevent escape". To pop one's clogs in this context would mean to escape the burdens of life, to shuffle off this mortal coil. "Like a spirit," as Southey helpfully writes, "which hath shaken off/The clog of dull mortality."

Which reminds me that I also discovered this week the origin of the term denim. Apparently it is a short form for de Nmes - from Nmes, in France - which is where the fabric initially known as Serge de Nmes sprang from. Had I been asked to guess, I would probably have identified Serge de Nmes as a French comedy actor of the 50s and 60s, rather like Louis de Funes, if anybody remembers him, though possibly fatter.

And who was it who said: "To govern is to choose?" - a lesson Tony Blair has had to learn, painfully and belatedly. It was, I discovered this week, the Duc de Lévis, described as "French soldier and moralist", born 1764, died 1830. It appears in his book Maximes et Réflexions. Could he perhaps have modelled himself on the French writer and soldier, born 1715, died 1747, whose best known work was entitled Réflexions et Maximes? His name, which I am often rebuked nowadays for failing to mention, was Jean Luc de Clapiers, Marquis de Vauvenargues.

"I haven't been so excited since Sue at Giorgio Armani's tracked down the company's last remaining pair of patent-leather black backless six-inch heeled party shoes and had them sent over from Florence" - Anne Robinson on her cruel TV quiz show being switched from BBC2 to BBC1, the Times.

No survey of dumbing down, such as the Guardian is concluding today, would be anywhere near complete without some shuddering contemplation of a wretched event on Monday at the very start of the BBC's flagship (as we nowadays say) 10 o'clock news. The theme was Gordon Brown's pre-budget statement, due two days later. The scene was a circus. Not a mock-up of a circus, but a real one, with performers cavorting and swinging about on trapezes while the BBC's economics editor, Peter Jay, delivered a script full of puns on such concepts as balancing acts, walking on tight- ropes, risking your neck, etc.

But even that was not the worst of it. The nadir arrived when, right at the end, the cameras closed in on Jay and revealed him to be entrapped in some piece of circus equipment: a cannon, perhaps, ready to fire him across the arena.The effect was so distracting and my rage - on his behalf, as well as my own, for he is a serious man - so great that I could not later remember one line of what he had said. I hope Greg Dyke was watching. I hope he was sick with embarrassment.

"A poultry 3,452 bothered to attend" - Match report, Swindon Town v Cambridge, Wiltshire Gazette and Herald.

A hen night, perhaps?

T hough music critics (see recent excerpts from Nicolas Slonimsky) have often written huge nonsense about great composers, composers themselves have uttered some rather strange observations, too. My attention has been drawn to the memoirs of Hector Berlioz, who could not abide Rossini, and disapproved even of Handel, whom he described as a "gros tonneau de porc et de bière". This was partly, perhaps, because Handel had claimed that his cook was a better composer than Gluck, one of Berlioz's great heroes, the others being Beethoven and Spontini.

Any disparagement of Spontini drove Berlioz into a rage. "The fierce opposition that Spontini aroused, which for long ranged the whole French school and the majority of Italian musicians against him, was certainly a fruit of that complex of motives whose meanness and absurdity La Fontaine has fixed once and for all in the fable of the fox and the grapes." And yet I have never knowingly heard a note of Spontini (Gasparo Luigi Pacifico Spontini, to give him his due). There is only one work of his in the Penguin Guide. What he faces now is possibly worse even than fierce opposition. It is fierce indifference.

Asked on the Today programme if the industry would whack up the cost of insurance after the floods, a spokeswoman sublimely replied: "Some premiums will have to be revisited." Isn't that "revisited" cute? I commend it for inclusion in the next edition of the Bloomsbury Dictionary of Euphemisms.

The only example it cites dates from 1998: "We cannot claim any credit for foreseeing that Enoch was about to pop his clogs" - in the Oldie. But it certainly goes back a long way further than that. I wonder if clog in this usage might be clog as defined in my old Oxford English dictionary: "a block or heavy piece of wood, attached to the leg or neck of a man or beast, to impede motion and prevent escape". To pop one's clogs in this context would mean to escape the burdens of life, to shuffle off this mortal coil. "Like a spirit," as Southey helpfully writes, "which hath shaken off/The clog of dull mortality." Which reminds me that I also discovered this week the origin of the term denim. Apparently it is a short form for de Nmes - from Nmes, in France - which is where the fabric initially known as Serge de Nmes sprang from. Had I been asked to guess, I would probably have identified Serge de Nmes as a French comedy actor of the 50s and 60s, rather like Louis de Funes, if anybody remembers him, though possibly fatter. And who was it who said: "To govern is to choose?" - a lesson Tony Blair has had to learn, painfully and belatedly. It was, I discovered this week, the Duc de Lévis, described as "French soldier and moralist", born 1764, died 1830. It appears in his book Maximes et Réflexions. Could he perhaps have modelled himself on the French writer and soldier, born 1715, died 1747, whose best known work was entitled Réflexions et Maximes? His name, which I am often rebuked nowadays for failing to mention, was Jean Luc de Clapiers, Marquis de Vauvenargues. "I haven't been so excited since Sue at Giorgio Armani's tracked down the company's last remaining pair of patent-leather black backless six-inch heeled party shoes and had them sent over from Florence" - Anne Robinson on her cruel TV quiz show being switched from BBC2 to BBC1, the Times. No survey of dumbing down, such as the Guardian is concluding today, would be anywhere near complete without some shuddering contemplation of a wretched event on Monday at the very start of the BBC's flagship (as we nowadays say) 10 o'clock news. The theme was Gordon Brown's pre-budget statement, due two days later. The scene was a circus. Not a mock-up of a circus, but a real one, with performers cavorting and swinging about on trapezes while the BBC's economics editor, Peter Jay, delivered a script full of puns on such concepts as balancing acts, walking on tight- ropes, risking your neck, etc. But even that was not the worst of it. The nadir arrived when, right at the end, the cameras closed in on Jay and revealed him to be entrapped in some piece of circus equipment: a cannon, perhaps, ready to fire him across the arena.The effect was so distracting and my rage - on his behalf, as well as my own, for he is a serious man - so great that I could not later remember one line of what he had said. I hope Greg Dyke was watching. I hope he was sick with embarrassment. "A poultry 3,452 bothered to attend" - Match report, Swindon Town v Cambridge, Wiltshire Gazette and Herald. A hen night, perhaps? T hough music critics (see recent excerpts from Nicolas Slonimsky) have often written huge nonsense about great composers, composers themselves have uttered some rather strange observations, too. My attention has been drawn to the memoirs of Hector Berlioz, who could not abide Rossini, and disapproved even of Handel, whom he described as a "gros tonneau de porc et de bière". This was partly, perhaps, because Handel had claimed that his cook was a better composer than Gluck, one of Berlioz's great heroes, the others being Beethoven and Spontini. Any disparagement of Spontini drove Berlioz into a rage. "The fierce opposition that Spontini aroused, which for long ranged the whole French school and the majority of Italian musicians against him, was certainly a fruit of that complex of motives whose meanness and absurdity La Fontaine has fixed once and for all in the fable of the fox and the grapes." And yet I have never knowingly heard a note of Spontini (Gasparo Luigi Pacifico Spontini, to give him his due). There is only one work of his in the Penguin Guide. What he faces now is possibly worse even than fierce opposition. It is fierce indifference. Asked on the Today programme if the industry would whack up the cost of insurance after the floods, a spokeswoman sublimely replied: "Some premiums will have to be revisited." Isn't that "revisited" cute? I commend it for inclusion in the next edition of the Bloomsbury Dictionary of Euphemisms.

fields.headline: Vandal with a saxophone
fields.standfirst: Ornette Coleman played some great tunes in Belfast, says  Mic Moroney  - and ruined a few others
fields.trailText: Ornette Coleman played some great tunes in Belfast, says Mic Moroney - and ruined a few others
fields.body:
Ornette Coleman began his run at the Belfast Festival without his lifelong collaborators, Charlie Haden and Billy Higgins, but was joined instead by his son Denardo on drums and Charnett Moffett on bass. The crowd at Whitla Hall gave him a wild welcome as he moseyed onstage in a shiny, sky-blue suit several sizes too big. After mumbling a few words, he led his trio into an extraordinary hour-long set.

At 70, Coleman still has a bright, muscular tone on the alto sax. He introduced each arcing melody, many sounding like melancholic 1950s love songs.But his focus varied. At best, once the tunes disintegrated into exhilarating improv, he pulled melodic scraps from the ether - altered bebop or bluesy tropes, crooning mood fragments, anthem phrases or high, flaring moans.

The trio produced an amazingly infectious groove. Denardo's percussion was crucial, with the pace-pushing metronome of his back beats. Moffett's musicianship was also jaw-dropping: he attacked the double bass by any means necessary, from extraordinary rapid thumb-slaps to elegant, lyrical bow-work, or used the spine of the bow to rattle out funk rhythms.

Eventually the funk took over, with Denardo producing big, rocky 4/4s, while Ornette took up a trumpet, sending out Miles Davis-like notes, and then a fiddle, frenetically sawing out nightmarish Stockhausian bluegrass. This seemed to be the overture to the Belfast Suite, an improv session with Irish musicians: flautist Michael McGoldrick, John McSherry on pipes, Dezi Donnelly on fiddle and Jonjo Kelly on bodhran.

Jazz and Irish trad share a common basis in triplets, but if one was expecting intriguing moirés, the result was an atrocity. The Irish musicians tore off into reels, a beautiful descriptive tune led by Donnelly, and a set of jigs. Moffett settled into octaves and fifths, while Denardo gave it a big-band rock-jazz slam. Coleman provided harmonies and jazz runs, then cut across with awful, dissonant squawks. It was like two CDs playing at once. Karan Casey sang an Irish lament, followed by an uplifting version of Aililiu na Gamhna - both of which Coleman soulfully vandalised. Incredibly, the audience howled for more - and, what's worse, got it. Then it was back to an encore with Coleman's trio, and a last, scrambled, rather bleak tune, warmed by Moffett's Beethovian bow. It was a blessed relief.

fields.headline: Spanks for the memory
fields.standfirst: Kenneth Tynan's life is the stuff of lurid myth - and the subject of a new play. But the real point about the great critic, says  Michael Billington, was his superb, razor-sharp writing
fields.trailText: Kenneth Tynan's life is the stuff of lurid myth - and the subject of a new play. But the real point about the great critic, says Michael Billington, was his superb, razor-sharp writing
fields.body:
It is not often you find a play with a drama critic as hero, least of all one as glamorous as Kenneth Tynan. But the West Yorkshire Playhouse has managed it with. Janet Munsil's Smoking With Lulu, a wistful three-hander about Tynan's encounter with Louise Brooks. If the lives and careers of most critics amount to a near-miss, this play shows Tynan's to have achieved the status of near-myth.

The play is based on a famous New Yorker profile Tynan wrote of the 1920s screen idol in 1979. He persuaded the reclusive Brooks to reveal her recollections of working on Pabst's Pandora's Box; the result is a love letter written by an ailing fan to an ageing star, both of whom were to die of emphysema - Tynan five years before Brooks.

Munsil's not very original thesis is that Tynan was erotically haunted by Brooks's youthful screen presence - hence the existence of a third character, with bobbed, enamelled hair and a variety of silk knickers, who embodies Tynan's fantasies and becomes the eternal Lulu.

The story has obvious echoes of Sunset Boulevard: a silent screen goddess finds her spirit re-awakened by an intrusive writer. But Munsil, to her credit, realises the crucial difference. Brooks, given a sprightly performance by Thelma Barlow, was a bedridden autodidact who loathed the Hollywood system and had no wish to confront a camera again. And Tynan, incarnated with uncanny accuracy by Peter Eyre, was no hapless hack but a well-primed admirer who appealed to a star who always fancied herself as a writer's moll. I intend no slur on them, or on Sophie Millett's delicately fetching Lulu, if I say that some of the best moments are those in which we see extracts from a pristine print of Pandora's Box: the reality is even better than the fiction.

What Munsil never captures, however, is the thing that makes Tynan really significant and that earns him a foothold in posterity: his combination of a voluptuous prose style with a crusading moral fervour. As a critic, he fought for a socially committed drama, a national theatre and an internationalist outlook with all the eloquence at his command. And he did this not in language of pseudo-academic earnestness, but in prose where each phrase clicks into place with the satisfying resonance of billiard balls struck by a perfectly aimed cue.

Of course, Tynan was a clutch of paradoxes, some of which Munsil conveys. He was a natural rule-breaker, appalled to think that his epitaph would be that of the first person to say "fuck" on television. He was a dedicated spanker who campaigned against all forms of institutionalised cruelty. He was a latterday egalitarian who adored stars. But although Munsil hints at his contradictions and uses smoking as an apt metaphor - "I spent my life taking people's breath away and now I pay the penalty," says the coughing Tynan - she sees him as a Wildean hero who put his genius into his life and his talent into his work. I would argue the exact opposite: what really matters, in the end, is not his prosaic spanking but his spanking prose.

In some ways, Tynan was fortunate in his timing. He took up his Observer post in 1954, when English drama was enfeebled by gentility, restraint and a head-under-the-bedclothes evasion of social issues; it desperately needed shaking into life. He was also lucky in that he grew up at a time when heroic individualism, exemplified by Olivier, Richardson and Wolfit, was prized in acting and cried out for a recording angel. And the essay tradition of Hazlitt and Shaw was still, albeit tenuously, alive in English criticism before the onset of a basically consumerist culture. But Tynan also made his own luck and showed, through his Augustan prose, how criticism could seem both sexy and important when informed by a responsible zeal.

Tynan influenced a whole generation. I made my own stuttering entry into the business by parodying him in an Observer competition in 1960, and it was typical of his generosity that, when I bearded him at the Oxford Playhouse shortly after, he instantly recommended that I write to the paper's literary editor. Behind the international hedonist lay a gracious, sometimes surprisingly old-fashioned man. I remember being invited to a Christmas Eve do at his house in the early 1970s largely, I suspect, because of my enthusiasm for Trevor Griffiths's The Party. I went vaguely expecting an evening of sybaritic decadence; in fact, we spent much of the time doing a pencil-and-paper quiz that he had assiduously devised.

Tynan's great achievement was to write passionately about a medium he assumed was central to our lives. Today theatre has to fight to be heard in an increasingly tacky celluloid culture. Having time to kill before the Leeds premiere, I took myself off to an outlying cinema to see What Lies Beneath, praised in some quarters as Hitchcockian. What I found was a movie complex that resembled a Technicolor version of Dante's Hell and a formulaic film built on the notion of a shock every seven minutes. To come back in the evening to Smoking With Lulu was to be reminded both of theatre's insidious potency and of an era when screen acting was allowed, in Louise Brooks's words, to express "movements of thought and soul". Tynan was fortunate to be writing in an age when art was more than a matter of visceral bombardment; and we, who stumble about in his shadow, can only recall that his true legacy does not lie in his sexual peculiarities. It is to be found in his belief that the job of the critic is to articulate crusading zeal in the most impassioned prose that he or she can muster.

 Smoking With Lulu is at the Courtyard Theatre, West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds, until December 2. Box office: 0113-213 7700.

fields.headline: End of the affair
fields.standfirst: Stuart Jeffries  on France's tearful adieu to Charles Aznavour
fields.trailText: Stuart Jeffries on France's tearful adieu to Charles Aznavour
fields.body:
The first song was a waste of time. "I'm glad to have got that out of the way," said Charles Aznavour. "Nobody ever listens to the first song. They're too busy checking their mobile phones are turned off, wondering if I've had a facelift or collagen injections." From the fourth row of the 3,723-seat grand amphitheatre of Paris's Palais des Congrès, Aznavour looked devoid of collagen, but had the proper and appealing lines of a 73-year-old. He may have had a nose job at Edith Piaf's request, but that was a long time ago.

Now Aznavour has the stature and stiffness of age: the sorrowful 45-degree eyebrows and the nervous eyes that made his study of weakness and shyness in Truffaut's Shoot the Pianist so moving are now rarely part of his facial repertoire. Instead, the loveable, pint-sized, Armenian-born Gallic crooner commanded the stage utterly before one of the many devoted audiences who will be paying homage in the next few months to an icon of French song. In a two-and-a-half-hour set sung with great power and precision, Aznavour didn't break sweat. Better still, he didn't sing She.

This is Aznavour's long goodbye, a concert series that concludes a career spanning six decades, 60 films and more than 1,000 songs. It didn't matter that no one listened to the first song. There were 30 or so others. Some were middle-of-the road jaunts, blameless and well-arranged. But when Aznavour got stuck into those truly French songs of self-disgust and loss - my God! It was powerful stuff.

Britain has no tradition of popular song that can handle these emotions, which made his performance, for me, especially cherishable. He snarled sarcastically through Bon Anniversaire. He spat "Non, je n'ai rien oublié" world wearily, as the spotlight brightened on his dark, drawn brows and trembling mouth.

The string section repeatedly cut through his fraught baritone with great sheets of emotional counterpoint. Hardened matrons and their brick outhouse sidekicks clasped their hands in front of their chins and let their eyes become wet. Almost unbearably, he sang songs of lost youth. De Vingt Ans was the most heartbreaking, followed by a shrugging remark: "That's what I write songs about now. The past." During La Bohème, he produced a hankie and used it as a painter's rag as he dabbed an invisible canvas with his other hand.

Suddenly, there were six or seven women at the foot of the stage. The song over, he tossed the hankie like a bridal bouquet. An otherwise respectable middle-aged woman pressed the thing to her bosom and trotted back to her seat, aglow. Like everybody in the auditorium, she was in love with Aznavour.

He will end his career in Nice on April 6. I would hate to be Aznavour when that curtain falls for the last time, all audience adulation spent, that long, last walk to the wings ahead of him - and nothing to dab his eyes with, since that night's hankie is destined to be pressed to a besotted stranger's breast.

 At the Palais des Congrs (00 33 1 40 68 00 05), Paris, until December 17, then on tour throughout France.

fields.headline: Twitchy neurotic
fields.standfirst: Tim Ashley  is puzzled by an over-the-top rendition of Brahms
fields.trailText: Tim Ashley is puzzled by an over-the-top rendition of Brahms
fields.body:
Was Brahms bonkers? Having always considered him among the most humane and wisest of composers, as well as the greatest, I would have thought not. Christoph Von Dohnanyi, however, would seem to believe otherwise, as much of this concert at London's Royal Festival Hall, which coupled the Second Piano Concerto with the First Symphony, gave us a portrait of Brahms as a twitchy neurotic whose vision teeters on the disturbed.

Classical structural tautness and romantic emotional depth co-exist in his music, and require equal emphasis. Dohnanyi sacrifices the emotion for the tautness, then turns it into unyielding rigidity. The First Symphony opens with one of music's great tragic statements, passing through hope, despair and tentative calm before the malign universe is transformed into a world of elation. Dohnanyi, however, hurls us into obsessional, driven territory, alienating us when we should be moved. The great transition in the finale goes for little, with no sense of redemption or release, while the final peroration seems to heave itself out of exhaustion.

Moments of genuine insight come in the inner sections: the way the calm strings are suddenly knocked off balance by baleful brass in the slow movement was tellingly done. The programme informed us Dohnanyi had agreed to conduct the Philharmonia despite an injured shoulder. This may have affected his performance, but I wish he'd handed the baton to someone else.

The Second Piano Concerto was equally disquieting, and marked the long-awaited return of Maurizio Pollini to the concerto repertory, his presence ensuring the hall was packed. Pollini was magnificent, breathtakingly alive to every flicker of emotion, but the necessary cohesion between soloist and orchestra was intermittent. Dohnanyi let rip when Pollini wasn't playing, producing a coarse majesty in places. Coherence only came with the Andante, when Dohnanyi simmered down and the purity of Pollini's playing became transcendent. The finale was full of elegance, thrills and sensual nostalgia. Even so, the usually excellent Philharmonia seemed to be having an off night, and the evening was a major disappointment. Brahms and Pollini deserved better.

fields.headline: The great potato escape
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
The most bizarre aspect of The War Behind the Wire (BBC2) was how closely the veterans of second world war German prison camps corresponded to the way they were portrayed in British movies such as The Wooden Horse or The Colditz Story. You could have substituted bulldog breed-ish actors such as John Mills or Bryan Forbes for real-life prisoners Walter Morison or Jimmy James and barely noticed the difference.

Although the debunking of wartime heroics has become fashionable, even down to questionable attempts to portray RAF officers as ruling-class tsars callously using the enlisted peasantry as Messerschmitt fodder, it appeared from the reminiscences of survivors of the notorious prison camp Stalag Luft 3 that almost everything you'd heard about the place was true. Assuming the ex-servicemen were not suffering from collective post-traumatic delusion, it was possible to marvel yet again at the ingenuity of a bunch of half-starved prisoners who managed to dig complicated tunnels, forge documents using home-made ink and lumps of mouldy potato, and concoct German uniforms.

The tunnels would have been extraordinary feats of engineering even if they hadn't been constructed under the noses of German sentries. "Harry", the tunnel through which 76 prisoners enacted the so-called Great Escape, was 30ft deep, 360ft long, and had a ventilation system made from kitbags, hockey sticks and ping-pong bats - and a railway track with its own "stations".

However, something neither The War Behind the Wire nor any of its interviewees attempted to do was examine the psychological pressures or consequences of their experiences. The programme focused on the prisoners with the balls to attempt insane escapades, such as trying to steal a Luftwaffe aeroplane to fly back to England. But what about those less enthusiastic about risking being shot in the back byGerman guards? Was there a stigma attached to being found wanting in the gung-ho stakes?

Maybe the truth is that this lot were from a generation that would have scorned all such sociological considerations as balderdash. Walter Morison recalled being summoned to see Roger Bushell, the terrifying "Big X" in charge of escapes, later shot by the Gestapo. Morison didn't know why Bushell wanted to see him but "you just didn't ask". Cue academic paper on the culture of deference and the rise of "desubordination" in society. But maybe that's best left to Cutting Edge.

In Clarissa and the Countryman (BBC2), the bellicose Ms Dickson Wright and the urbane Johnny Scott sallied forth to north-east England to race their greyhound in the Waterloo Cup. If the idea was to give an insight into the arcane appeal of hare-coursing, it didn't succeed. Johnny's attempt to explain that the point of hare- coursing isn't to kill hares failed miserably - as he didn't explain what the point actually is . Indeed, the film did neither pro- nor anti-bloodsports lobbies much good, as the protesters seemed an abusive mob who ostensibly deplored killing animals, but would have been prepared to rip dog-owners limb from limb. As the credits rolled, I was left with a queasy sensation.

fields.headline: A totally pelvic Sunday spoof
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
The week in radioland began with a strange little laugh. It was Germaine Greer, sitting in for Jeremy Paxman on Start the Week (Radio 4), letting out a small chuckle before the chat began. I've got it on tape and it holds a certain fascination; I'm hoping Fatboy Slim might indulge me by sampling it on his next hit. It is the only tip Paxo might want to take from his new understudy. Chortle aside, Greer was oddly wooden, sounding as if she was reading when she was (which is only slightly better than sounding as if you're reading when you're not).

More, many more, laughs were provided by the return of The Sunday Format (Radio 4), winner of last year's British Comedy Award for best radio comedy. A spoof weekend newspaper, it does for reading the ever-expanding broadsheets what The Day Today did for watching the news. I can no longer take Michael Buerk's sonorous sincerity thanks to that show; now I fear I shall have to stay off lifestyle features, too.

A queasy side-splitter, especially for those of us involved in producing frothy copy, it was savage on the ceaseless proliferation of fluffy drivel in magazines and papers. Features included Distant Cousins, in which a woman talked about the importance of her fourth cousin twice removed. "He was always there for me. Well, when I say 'there', I mean Northampton. He was always in Northampton for me."

There was a flurry of Big Brother derivatives (Big Mother, Big Brother Chefs), sensational quizzes (Are You An Alcoholic?), and a cut-out-and-keep guide to what's hip: Totally Pelvic, with details of this season's must-have shades of Burnt Priest, Charred Brie and Barry White. Best of all was the restaurant review - this actually made me squeal - dripping with self-regard and ludicrous purple prose, and details of an obligatory new section, "Our new section: The New Section. Everything new that you should know about but never knew." The really scary thing is that some irony-bypass editors in the land will steal ideas from this and commission them.

Less likely to appear in a glossy supplement is a feature on whether Britain's stone circles and burial chambers were "acoustic spaces" - unless Madonna mentions it in an interview first that is. But there are people who want to know. Aubrey Manning for one. With a name like a toff in an Ealing comedy, he has been roaming Britain researching Unearthing Mysteries (Radio 4), a new series on historical enigmas. Kicking off with the burning issue of whether Stonehenge and Maeshowe on Orkney were constructed with sound in mind, Manning stood and hummed a lot. "Somebody give us a tune," he pleaded.

He met up with Aaron Watson, a man who makes "pink noise" for a living; imagine that on the business card. You can't hear it on radio, sadly, so this was a less than splendid part of the programme. "I didn't like the feeling," said Manning, quite discombobulated after some silence. Not quite as discombobulated, though, as Stone Age people might have felt "surrounded by the decomposing remains of their dead and with mysterious sounds apparently emanating from nowhere".

And you thought listening to Simon Mayo was bad.

fields.headline: Sorry, I'm a bit busy
fields.standfirst: One hour to curtain-up and the orchestra's been kidnapped. But the show goes on.  Andrew Clements  is dazzled by the subversive genius of Mauricio Kagel
fields.trailText: One hour to curtain-up and the orchestra's been kidnapped. But the show goes on. Andrew Clements is dazzled by the subversive genius of Mauricio Kagel
fields.body:
Mauricio Kagel has spent the best part of 40 years questioning the conventions of concert-giving. Though in Britain some of his most ambitious works remain unperformed, this Argentinian-born composer, now 68, has been a vital force in European music ever since he emigrated to Germany in the late 1950s. When the European Concert Hall Organisation (Echo) wanted to commission a music-dramatic work that would belong in a concert hall rather than an opera house or theatre, Kagel was the obvious composer to approach.

The result, Die Entführung im Konzertsaal (Kidnapping in the Concert Hall), was premiered by the Schoenberg Ensemble and the Netherlands Chamber Choir, with Reinbert de Leeuw conducting, at the Amsterdam Concertgebouw on Monday - starting a tour that will take in seven of the Echo member halls, ending up at Birmingham's Symphony Hall next month.

The hour-long work is by turns mysterious, dismaying and full of wonderful music; not everything in it works dramatically but, as always with Kagel, there is so much to think about, so many musical and extra-musical issues involved, that the experience is totally absorbing.

The starting point was a long-standing project of Kagel's to compose a cantata based upon the aphorisms of the German Enlightenment writer Georg Christoph Lichtenberg. In the new work, the audience is asked to imagine that a performance of this fictional cantata has been scheduled to take place, but that an hour before the start nearly all the chorus and the orchestra involved are kidnapped and held in a room close to the concert hall.

Those who escape, together with the conductor and the tenor soloist, decide to go ahead with what can be salvaged of the performance, and that is how Kidnapping in the Concert Hall begins. It is an uphill struggle for all concerned: the tenor soloist (Christoph Homberger) appears looking dishevelled and distressed, relives the moments of the kidnapping, and tries to concentrate on what he is supposed to be performing, while the chorus are understandably much more concerned with what is happening to their colleagues than with the Lichtenberg cantata.

The conductor ploughs on regardless, but he has a telephone next to him with which he can communicate with the unnamed kidnapper. The course of the work is interrupted 11 times by the ring ing of the phone. At one point the kidnapper demands food ("Meatballs all round"); at another, a ransom ("A million, right?"); halfway through, the conductor and a recording engineer discuss how well the recording of the performance is going. Meanwhile, the security response to the outrage is heard from outside the hall: helicopters circle overheard, and the noise of the police and fire services surrounds the building.

The words, the composer's own except when fragments of the Lichtenberg music break through, are direct ("Librettos are not great literature," Kagel said at a press conference before the performance) and he insists that they be delivered in the language of the audience in each venue. "Fiction has to be real," he said, and so even the sounds of the police sirens are changed from country to country.

But the illusion is not quite complete enough: what is going on outside the hall is never sufficiently vivid, and the deliberate vagueness of the ending is unsatisfactory. If, as the last telephone call suggests, something terrible has happened out there - maybe the police have stormed the building and the hostages have been killed in the process, maybe the kidnapper has carried out his threats - we are never told what that is.

Kagel's score, though, is extra-ordinary. The music has to take on a multi-layered function, providing a backdrop to the events unfolding around the performance, reflecting the seismic shifts of emotion as events build towards their climax, and presenting the fragments of the Lichtenberg settings that survive. It is a rich tapestry, in which 200 years of music tradition, as well as echoes of popular styles, are stitched into ever-changing textures, which play all kinds of tricks with traditional harmony and tonality. Kagel's ear for sonority and for creating new sounds in unforeseen ways remains unique.

There is another treat in the first half of the concert, for the new work is prefaced in the touring programme by a performance of Kagel's 1986 Mitternachtstuk, which sets fragments of Robert Schumann's diaries for speakers and chorus in a way that turns them into enchanted fairy tales as if they had been rewritten by ETA Hoffmann.

This is Kagel subverting expectations once again, taking these isolated little confidences and producing something very rich and strange. He really is a composer of magical imagination and disconcerting power.

 At the Symphony Hall, Birmingham, on December 1. Box office: 0121-780 3333.

webTitle: Stars, stripes, rainbows and multicoloured leaves

fields.headline: Stars, stripes, rainbows and multicoloured leaves
fields.trailText: Director's diary
fields.body:
October 27 1999

Yesterday driving to Gloucestershire, today to Provincetown in Massachusetts, after flying to Boston. "Massachusetts is a glory in the Fall," says John Proctor in The Crucible. And it is - gold, red, pink, bronze, brown, pink, and yellow. I'm always pleasantly surprised by rural America; it's so unlike the urban clatter of New York, Los Angeles and Miami that passes for our TV- induced view of the country. There are so many stars and stripes - huge ones flapping like sheets, small ones waving like Tibetan prayer pennants. In our country, the union flag (apart from its official use) is only ever displayed ironically or as a sort defiant assertion of imperial status. Here the flags are like the shrines that spatter the Italian roadside, homely advertisements of faith.

When we reach Provincetown, there are as many rainbow coalition flags as stars and stripes, declaring a different sort of faith - a belief in sexual tolerance. Which is possibly why writers and painters were drawn here since the 1890s to escape the summer heat of New York. One of the writers was Eugene O'Neill: it was here that he first had a play of his produced.

October 28

The day is a clear, bright autumn day, sky of della Robbia blue. I've written something about O'Neill's story being an American folktale - unperformed playwright to Nobel prizewinner - and Chris, the director for the American episode, has translated this into film imagery: I'm on a horse posed like a frontiersman on a ridge of sand dunes talking about the small shacks where O'Neill and his pals stayed to write and paint. O'Neill lived here, off and on, for nine years - a stay punctuated by wild drinking bouts and capering on the beach half-naked in a fright wig, like Edgar in Lear. My horse is a handsome chestnut named Buddy; he has a western-style saddle which, after riding an English saddle, feels like a comfortable office chair. Buddy proves himself to be eponymously named, and galloping along the edge of the incoming tide, long having ceased to care whether this sequence is in any way gratuitous, I'm having about as much fun as one can have legally. Fred, the French cameraman, kneels by the seashore and asks me to gallop as close as I can to him; the hooves pass inches from the lens. Afterwards he confesses that he closed his eyes as I passed.

October 29
Early morning finds us under a pier squelching through the wet sand to the accompaniment of the chanting of sea- gulls. O'Neill's first play was staged in a converted shed on an old pier, which stank of fish and smoke from a recent fire. I doubt if any play had such a launching: there was a storm during the performance which rocked the pier and drove the sea up through the gaps in the floor, wetting the feet of the audience and actors. Afterwards we walk through the main street of the town, and feel like we've been inserted into The Truman Show. The town has the same genial, hospitable air of the movie - the same colonial- style clapboard houses, the same universal goodwill. But the extras have been re-programmed: instead of conventional couples with 2.5 children, the shops and the pavements are peopled with gay and lesbian couples and instead of groceries and hardware stores, there are gay clubs, art galleries and leather shops. Tennessee Williams spent a summer here - "a sort of crash course in growing up". I'll bet. He returned a few years later to finish writing The Glass Menagerie. It's an engaging paradox that the town's most famous resident now is the archbishop of macho: Norman Mailer.

October 30

Dawn. Hoping for a dour sea mist to match O'Neill's dolefulness, we have a lavender dawn by Caspar David Friedrich. Then on the road to New York. As we drive out of town we pass what at first I take to be evidence of a lynching. It might be a sexual bigot, but it's a dummy with a skull for a head, hanging from a tree for Halloween. O'Neill said Provincetown was "hard to get to and hard to get out of". The latter proves to be uncomfortably true: it takes us eight hours to drive to New York, after getting lost in New Rochelle, landing up in New Jersey and wondering whether there is something in the Constitution that forbids the provision of comprehensible road signs.

October 31
Interview with Arthur Miller. Arthur is, incredibly, 84, but he is very energetic, physically and mentally unbowed. A new production of The Price is about to open on Broadway, so he'll have two of his plays running - a total rehabilitation after years of being patronised by the New York critics but being much performed and respected in Britain.

This exchange was in the New York Times recently:

Critic one : Arthur Miller is celebrated there.

Critic two : He's so cynical about American culture and American politics. The English love that.

Of course these critics get it wrong on all scores - about the English, who are in thrall to American culture and about Arthur, in whom they mistake disappointment for cynicism. For two hours in his apartment, we film Arthur talking about the past, present and future of American theatre. He tells stories about the first performance of Salesman, of appearing before the House Un-American Activities Committee, of being in London with Marilyn, of copying out speeches of Shakespeare to see how he wrote - all told as if he was recalling them for the first time.

After the interview we go to Brooklyn, which is where he used to live (in Brooklyn Heights) and work (in the US navy yard). We walk down to the riverfront to be filmed in the shadow of the pillars of the Brooklyn Bridge looking out over the East river. "These are our cathedrals," says Arthur, looking up at the bridge. "I thought those were," I say, pointing across the river to the business district and the twin towers of the World Trade Centre. "Oh sure. 'The business of America is business', that's what Calvin Coolidge used to say. He was the first president I can remember." Then he stares at the buildings. "None of them were here when I lived here. Not one. And in all those windows there'll be somebody counting figures. Piling up money." Then he smiles ruefully. "And snorting cocaine, I guess."

November 1
Sunday. It's very sunny and I'm sitting in my room all day writing Episode five: Brecht and Beckett. "This is somehow not the right country for me. The people are too strange," said Beckett, the only time he visited New York. I know what he meant: I got into the hotel lift this morning with four not-so-young women: "I love your jacket," said one. "I love your hair," said another. "I love your eyebrows," said a third. "I love you," said the fourth.

November 2
We drive for an hour or so through a landscape quilted with autumn colours to Tony Kushner's house, a beautiful bottle-green clapboard house on the banks on the Hudson river in New York state, 100 yards from where Washington put a chain across the river to stop the British from getting to New York - now achieved by American Equity. Tony talks with marvellous lucidity and grace about Williams and O'Neill and Miller.

His mother, a talented amateur actress, played Linda in Death of a Salesman when Tony was four. He says the play had a powerful effect on him then, so perhaps I should be less sceptical of Freud's love of Shakespeare at the age of eight. "With Shakespeare's plays," says Tony, "you don't feel trapped while the parade moves in front of you. The parade is there and you're moving around in it and you have room to turn around and that's a great thing to strive for in the sense that a whole world is contained in a play."

If you run a theatre, you hope for the sort of luck Peter Hall had when Waiting for Godot dropped on his desk at the Arts theatre, or Brendan Behan's The Quare Fellow on Joan Littlewood's; for me it was Tony's play, Angels in America, which seemed Shakespearian in its ambition. It still seems a fearful indictment of New York producers that his play wasn't produced there until after its National Theatre opening.

 The second part of Richard Eyre's Changing Stages is on BBC2 on Sunday at 7.40pm.
