It's an engaging paradox that the town's most famous resident now is the archbishop of macho: Norman Mailer. October 30 Dawn. Hoping for a dour sea mist to match O'Neill's dolefulness, we have a lavender dawn by Caspar David Friedrich. Then on the road to New York. As we drive out of town we pass what at first I take to be evidence of a lynching. It might be a sexual bigot, but it's a dummy with a skull for a head, hanging from a tree for Halloween. O'Neill said Provincetown was "hard to get to and hard to get out of". The latter proves to be uncomfortably true: it takes us eight hours to drive to New York, after getting lost in New Rochelle, landing up in New Jersey and wondering whether there is something in the Constitution that forbids the provision of comprehensible road signs. October 31 Interview with Arthur Miller. Arthur is, incredibly, 84, but he is very energetic, physically and mentally unbowed. A new production of The Price is about to open on Broadway, so he'll have two of his plays running - a total rehabilitation after years of being patronised by the New York critics but being much performed and respected in Britain. This exchange was in the New York Times recently: Critic one : Arthur Miller is celebrated there. Critic two : He's so cynical about American culture and American politics. The English love that. Of course these critics get it wrong on all scores - about the English, who are in thrall to American culture and about Arthur, in whom they mistake disappointment for cynicism. For two hours in his apartment, we film Arthur talking about the past, present and future of American theatre. He tells stories about the first performance of Salesman, of appearing before the House Un-American Activities Committee, of being in London with Marilyn, of copying out speeches of Shakespeare to see how he wrote - all told as if he was recalling them for the first time. After the interview we go to Brooklyn, which is where he used to live (in Brooklyn Heights) and work (in the US navy yard). We walk down to the riverfront to be filmed in the shadow of the pillars of the Brooklyn Bridge looking out over the East river. "These are our cathedrals," says Arthur, looking up at the bridge. "I thought those were," I say, pointing across the river to the business district and the twin towers of the World Trade Centre. "Oh sure. 'The business of America is business', that's what Calvin Coolidge used to say. He was the first president I can remember." Then he stares at the buildings. "None of them were here when I lived here. Not one. And in all those windows there'll be somebody counting figures. Piling up money." Then he smiles ruefully. "And snorting cocaine, I guess." November 1 Sunday. It's very sunny and I'm sitting in my room all day writing Episode five: Brecht and Beckett. "This is somehow not the right country for me. The people are too strange," said Beckett, the only time he visited New York. I know what he meant: I got into the hotel lift this morning with four not-so-young women: "I love your jacket," said one. "I love your hair," said another. "I love your eyebrows," said a third. "I love you," said the fourth. November 2 We drive for an hour or so through a landscape quilted with autumn colours to Tony Kushner's house, a beautiful bottle-green clapboard house on the banks on the Hudson river in New York state, 100 yards from where Washington put a chain across the river to stop the British from getting to New York - now achieved by American Equity. Tony talks with marvellous lucidity and grace about Williams and O'Neill and Miller. His mother, a talented amateur actress, played Linda in Death of a Salesman when Tony was four. He says the play had a powerful effect on him then, so perhaps I should be less sceptical of Freud's love of Shakespeare at the age of eight. "With Shakespeare's plays," says Tony, "you don't feel trapped while the parade moves in front of you. The parade is there and you're moving around in it and you have room to turn around and that's a great thing to strive for in the sense that a whole world is contained in a play." If you run a theatre, you hope for the sort of luck Peter Hall had when Waiting for Godot dropped on his desk at the Arts theatre, or Brendan Behan's The Quare Fellow on Joan Littlewood's; for me it was Tony's play, Angels in America, which seemed Shakespearian in its ambition. It still seems a fearful indictment of New York producers that his play wasn't produced there until after its National Theatre opening.  The second part of Richard Eyre's Changing Stages is on BBC2 on Sunday at 7.40pm.

fields.headline: The last word on   Aliens
fields.standfirst: When you are all alienated together, you are not really lonely. - Anonymous graffito
fields.trailText: When you are all alienated together, you are not really lonely. - Anonymous graffito
fields.body:
One disgruntled voter in the American presidential election told a television interviewer that he felt alienated by both candidates, and when asked why, said with unimpeachable logic that it was because they both seemed to him like aliens - meaning creatures from outer space. The idea that space aliens are not just quintessentially Other but therefore disagreeable - or dangerous - is itself disagreeable to Nasa, which is trying to make contact with intelligent life elsewhere in the universe. As part of this endeavour it is planning to send information about earth and earthlings in a package aboard the Mars Lander expedition currently being prepared.

America's presidential candidates ought, it seems, to have canvassed the town of Bedlington in Northumbria, where they would have had a better reception than many places Stateside. Bedlington responded to Nasa's invitation to provide material for the Message to Mars; Malcolm Robinson, chairman of its Chamber of Commerce, seeing the possibilities for tourism from space, said: "We'll offer any alien visitors a range of discounts, with pensioner rates for haircuts, and discounts on food and clothing. They won't get a warmer welcome anywhere in England." But he added: "God knows if they'll understand our accents."

The last time Nasa did something similar was in 1973, when it fixed a plaque to its Pioneer 10 spacecraft, showing a human male and female, and a geometric representation of earth's position relative to the sun. The plaque provoked a storm of controversy, first because it gives away our location to possibly aggressive superior galactic civilisations, second because the two humans depicted are obviously white, third because, to the chagrin of some, they are naked, fourth because it is the man who raises his hand in greeting while the woman stands passively by (some described her as standing dreamily by; others saw her as just about to sidle up to distract the man from the important business of greeting aliens by tempting him to the consequences implied by nudity), fifth because whereas the man has geni tals - of the inoffensively tiny sort characteristic of Greek statues, supposed to signify self-control - the woman has none; sixth because . . . well, let the imagination supply the rest, because in our age of interest groups, in which we are all members of one or another minority, in which most of us are victims of something, and in which we are all entitled to have our say, nothing whatever is uncontentious.

Space tourism to Bedlington and such controversies aside, there is a serious and interesting purpose behind the Nasa endeavours. This is that there is a high probability not just that there is life elsewhere in the universe, but intelligent life at that; and not just elsewhere in the universe, but here in our own galaxy. If the statistics are right, there is a better than evens chance that there are hundreds of millions of places in our galaxy where life in some form exists, and even if only a small proportion is intelligent, that still makes millions of civilisations among our neighbouring stars.

The idea seems like science fiction, but the reasoning is impeccable, and it explains why time and money - though not enough of either - are allocated to space scientists to scan the heavens in search of such evidence as radio signals. The project is known as SETI, meaning Search for Extra-Terrestrial Intelligence.

The disgruntled American voter's logic was in other respects not so good. Because of the closeness of the presidential race, both candidates displayed themselves to as many people as they could, which disqualifies them from being true aliens, who seem only to like appearing to occasional New Agers. When asked whether he thought we had ever had visitors from space, Stephen Hawking said, "I don't believe we have. Any such visit would be obvious and probably unpleasant. What would be the point of aliens revealing themselves only to a few cranks?"

On this reasoning, Messrs Gore and Bush are clearly mere earthlings.

fields.headline: Fair comment
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... reaction to our Middle East coverage
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... reaction to our Middle East coverage
fields.body:
This week I have been reviewing the Guardian's coverage of the crisis in the Middle East since the end of September, when Ariel Sharon, the leader of the Likud party in Israel, made his visit to al-Haram al-Sharif, the Temple Mount, in Jerusalem.

In the weeks of violence and death since then, the paper's coverage has been extensive and wide-ranging, with reports from its own team of correspondents - among whom are Hebrew and Arabic speakers, with at least one who speaks both languages - augmented by opinion pieces from distinguished commentators, for example, the Palestinian American Edward Said and the former prime minister of Israel and Nobel Peace laureate, Shimon Peres.

Through this period the paper's editorials have stuck to the same basic position. I paraphrase the writer's summary of it: there is only one peace process, but it is imperfect and requires compromise of a nature that is unsavoury to both sides; if it succeeds, the settlement will be unsatisfactory for both sides but still better than a state of undeclared war.

The editor of the paper believes that an impartial comparison with other newspapers, were such a thing possible, might well conclude that the Guardian's coverage was among the best. If that sounds slightly immodest, it might help to know that he made the remark in the context of a conversation about complaints directed at the paper over the past weeks. It has been accused of bias in favour of the Palestinians, bias in favour of the Israelis, anti-semitism, Islamophobia, and lapsing from the paper's liberal traditions and commitment to fair play. Some of the criticism has gone further and questioned the ethnic and religious hinterland of the paper's journalists, a subject to which I shall return briefly - and only briefly - in a moment.

Most of this was what might be called background rumbling until the publication on one of the Guardian's comment pages on November 1 of a piece by Jemima Khan headed "Tell the truth about Israel". The following oblique identification appeared at the end of the piece: "Jemima and Imran Khan live in Islamabad." There were remarks in this article which were quite understandably construed as anti-semitic. They caused offence not only to a large number of readers but to people inside the paper who also complained.

Ms Khan's theme was broadly that pro-Israeli interests, particularly in the US, were disproportionately influential in the Middle East debate to a point that hampered the peace process. Particular offence was caused when she went on from this to say "The media [in the US] are largely controlled by the Jews, as is Hollywood..." and later to refer to "the overwhelming Jewish influence in US politics and the media".

The deputy editor, who saw the article before publication, gave an instruction for a passage which included these remarks to be taken out. Somehow it was left in. Within two days of publication, the letters editor had received about 50 letters condemning the views expressed in the piece. Three were published.

Typically, one of the published letters said that statements such as those I have quoted represented "precisely the kind of view that propagates anti-semitism". Ms Khan then wrote a letter for publication in which, I am told, she made it clear that her remarks were not intended to be anti-semitic. The letters editor says this was not published because she took the view that Ms Khan had already made her case and she saw no reason to depart from the general rule that the authors of comment pieces then make way for others to respond.

Apart from the letters I have mentioned, there were about a dozen more directed to the editor of the paper personally, criticising him for allowing the piece to appear at all. I have seen these letters and the replies sent by or on behalf of the editor. Here, in part, is what the editor said in one of them: "...I think you are right in saying we should have removed the sentences you quote from Jemima Khan's piece..."

A mistake was made and the editor has acknowledged that. It is with little more than a forlorn hope that I suggest this should be seen in the context of the paper's overall coverage of the Middle East.

The editor said, "Other than New Labour there is no area where we come under such scrutiny and pressure. To accuse the Guardian of anti-semitism for running a piece by Edward Said [which was part of one complaint] is insulting and an improper kind of pressure."

On the other matter, the editor said Guardian journalists were employed for their ability. "We have just appointed a Northern Ireland correspondent and nowhere in the interview process was she asked whether she was a Protestant or a Catholic. I still do not know." A respected colleague said, "Ask me about my work, not my religion or ethnic background." All the journalist is asked to do is to tell us about it, without prejudice.

 Readers may contact the office of the readers' editor by telephoning 020-7239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

webTitle: Lib Dems agree pact on information bill

fields.headline: Lib Dems agree pact on information bill
fields.trailText: The government's much criticised freedom of information bill looks set to become law next year after home office ministers agreed a deal yesterday with the Liberal Democrats to smooth its passage through the House of Lords next week.
fields.body:
The government's much criticised freedom of information bill looks set to become law next year after home office ministers agreed a deal yesterday with the Liberal Democrats to smooth its passage through the House of Lords next week.

The home office minister, Mike O'Brien, agreed to four more concessions to the bill, and in return the Lib Dems will withdraw two key amendments to the legislation and back the bill in the Lords.

The move means the government is virtually guaranteed to get the bill on the statute book by the end of the month and its provisions will be phased in from next April.

The Liberal Democrats have obtained two major concessions to the legislation and two minor amendments. The main changes alter the balance of the legislation to ensure that government departments will be under more pressure to release all facts connected with policy making decisions, and will find it more difficult to refuse to release information in areas where ministers have tried to impose "blanket bans". The latter change will mean that where the new information commissioner, Elizabeth France, rules that information must be released despite restrictions on disclosures in areas such as policy making, the onus will now be on the government to prove it is in the public interest to keep it secret. Ministers must also now release all background facts and reports and indicate which ones influenced their decisions.

The minor changes involve compelling officials to help people trying to apply for the release of information, and ensuring that people who do not get a reply within a month are told how long they will have to wait.

In return the Liberal Democrats have agreed to drop their demand to remove the right of cabinet ministers to ban the release of information, and will not seek to remove the overriding law that allows information to be banned from release if it prejudices the conduct of public affairs.

The Lib Dem peer Lord Goodhart said yesterday: "We know it is still not a perfect bill but thought it better to negotiate the changes. We were told we had no chance of removing the override given to cabinet ministers to ban the release of information and we did not believe that the Conservatives would support us when it came to the vote."

The Conservatives have tabled their own amendments to the bill, insisting that the government must show that the ban on the release of information would cause "serious harm" and that any ban by ministers has to be approved by both houses of parliament within 20 days, or the ban is revoked.

Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, yesterday welcomed the government's latest concessions. But he added: "The bill still has serious defects. We hope the House of Lords will limit the scope of bans on the release of information by cabinet ministers."

webTitle: Leader: It matters who chooses parliament's watchdogs

fields.headline: Reform à la carte
fields.standfirst: It matters who chooses the watchdogs
fields.trailText: It matters who chooses the watchdogs
fields.body:
Those who have been members of parliament for some time, one of them told the Commons on Thursday, "know that this place is dying on its feet". Not all within the precincts would agree, but there is certainly a sense in the world outside that the House grows ever more marginal and impotent.

This week the Commons has seen two attempts to reform its procedures. The first, on Tuesday, brought approval for a government motion which will rationalise the conduct of business, chiefly by deciding a prior timetable for the passage of legislation. At present, the earlier stages of debate on a bill are often dragged out for tactical reasons until the government brings in a "guillotine" motion, after which debate is dangerously telescoped. The change agreed on Tuesday should bring much more balanced debate and more sensible sitting hours for MPs. But it will also make life easier for government, giving it greater certainty about when it will get its legislation, and depriving the opposition of a potent weapon: the eating up of government time. That is why ministers wanted it.

Things were very different on Thursday when backbench reformers pressed for changes designed to enhance their ability to scrutinise and where possible check the imperious ways of the executive. The MPs who chair them want control of select committees transferred from the government to the House. In theory, their composition is decided by the Commons selection committee. In practice, decisions are shaped by the whips, who try to squeeze known troublemakers out of them. But here reform ran into a sturdy roadblock in the shape of the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, who warned it might lead to committees becoming a kind of rival government, second-guessing the real one.

The rule on which the government operates seems perilously close to this: where reform helps the government, splendid: where it threatens inconvenience, block it. That is an understandable principle, but hardly a healthy one for an ailing parliament. The test on which these questions ought to be settled was neatly summed up by the Labour backbencher Dr Tony Wright: "Who owns the scrutiny system we have created? Is it to be owned by the executive or by the House of Commons?" For those who want MPs to do the job they were sent there to do, there can be only one answer to that.

webTitle: Charles cited in prayer book revolt

fields.headline: Charles cited in prayer book revolt
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Church of England traditionalists have been accused of dirty tricks in trying to drag the Prince of Wales into a row about the introduction of a new prayer book and liturgy next week.
fields.body:
Church of England traditionalists have been accused of dirty tricks in trying to drag the Prince of Wales into a row about the introduction of a new prayer book and liturgy next week.

Church leaders have reacted with fury to the attempt to undermine the book, Common Worship, which will be formally presented to the Queen at the General Synod in Westminster on Tuesday. It will provide the standard texts for all Anglican worship from the end of this year.

In a move which bears all the marks of a piece of Trollopian skulduggery, on the eve of publication traditionalists, who want the church to revert to the 451-year-old Book of Common Prayer, claimed they had the backing of the prince on the basis of a speech he gave 11 years ago, attacking the banalities of the modern language in the previous alternative service book.

The row comes at a particularly sensitive time for the church, following reports about the prince's musings about eventually becoming a defender of faiths rather than defender of the faith of the established church.

His speech, made in December 1989, is reprinted in The Real Common Worship, a book largely criticising the new prayers, edited by the Rev Peter Mullen, chaplain to the stock exchange, who claims Common Worship is "coy, evasive and euphemistic".

"Instead of 'In the same night that he was betrayed, he took bread', Common Worship offers: 'He had supper with his friends.' What, at the Savoy Grill or Pizza Hut or was it a Chinese takeaway? To deface the holiest prayer in this way is unbelievably crass," Mr Mullen said to the Mail on Sunday this week.

Senior church figures are pressing for corrections and retractions from Conservative newspapers and threatening Mr Mullen with sanctions for misrepresenting the book. He appears not to have noticed that at least a third of its text is taken from the Book of Common Prayer and its equally hallowed revision of 1662.

The Right Rev David Stancliffe, Bishop of Salisbury, who chaired the working party carrying out the revisions, said: "I have spoken to the prince and he is not at all unsympathetic to what we have done. Our critics are entitled to their opinions, but not to misrepresent the book. This is actually a rather conservative revision attempting to represent both ancient and modern traditions."

fields.headline: Lord Greenhill of Harrow
fields.standfirst: Distinguished mandarin who served Britain under three prime ministers
fields.trailText: Lord Greenhill of Harrow, who has died aged 87, was an unusual man, who reached the top of the diplomatic service by an unusual route. In early 1969, as Denis Greenhill, he became permanent under-secretary (PUS) at the Foreign Office and head of the Diplomatic Service, and served under both Labour and Conservative governments until his retirement in 1973. fields.body:
Lord Greenhill of Harrow, who has died aged 87, was an unusual man, who reached the top of the diplomatic service by an unusual route. In early 1969, as Denis Greenhill, he became permanent under-secretary (PUS) at the Foreign Office and head of the Diplomatic Service, and served under both Labour and Conservative governments until his retirement in 1973. Many, like myself, who served under him in the early 1970s, regarded him as one of the best, if not the best, PUSs since the war.

The news of his appointment was broken to him by Harold Wilson, with somewhat exaggerated informality, in the gentlemen's lavatory at 10 Downing Street. Greenhill had been George Brown's candidate for the job, partly, it seems, because Brown, then foreign secretary, mistakenly thought that his father had been an engine driver. After Brown had left the scene, the appointment was endorsed - slightly to Greenhill's surprise, but much to his delight - by Brown's successor Michael Stewart.

Greenhill had not thought of the foreign service as a career until he was well into his 30s. His father was a bank manager, and he himself went to Bishop's Stortford College, from which he won a scholarship to Christ Church, Oxford. There, he had a respectable, though not brilliant, academic career. However, his years at Oxford opened up for him a wider world of friends and acquaintances, in which his personality might flower.

From 1935-39, Greenhill worked in the railways as an executive. He gives an amusing account of these early years in his memoir, More By Accident (1992). Wartime experience completed his growing up and, by the end of it, he was a colonel in the Royal Engineers, with the CBE (military) and two mentions in dispatches, having served in the Middle East, Far East, India and North Africa.

It was through a wartime acquaintance in the Middle East, Edwin Chapman-Andrews, that Greenhill came to join the foreign service. Chapman-Andrews, who was the head of the personnel department of the Foreign Office in 1946, encouraged him to submit himself to the various postwar examinations and tests, from which he eventually emerged with the rank of second secretary.

His first posting was Sofia, where his resourceful wife, Angela McCulloch, whom he had met in Cairo during the war, saved his life after he became seriously ill and was treated incompetently by local doctors. He survived, but was expelled by the Bulgarians in 1948 on a charge of spying.

With the cold war now well underway, the circumstances of Greenhill's expulsion went down well in Washington, where he was next posted. This was the most important British embassy in the world, then under a first-class ambassador, Oliver Franks. Service in Washington proved to be the foundation on which Greenhill's career was built; he returned there as a counsellor, and later as minister (number 2 in the embassy).

It was the early 1960s, the outset of the Kennedy era. The newly appointed ambassador, Sir David Ormsby-Gore, thought well of Greenhill and had asked to keep him on as minister. Thus, during those perilous years, which included the Cuban missile crisis and President Kennedy's assassination, Greenhill continued to work in a key position in the US capital.

In 1964, he returned to the Foreign Office in London as an assistant under-secretary. On promotion a year later to deputy under-secretary, he soon began to be tipped as a possible PUS to succeed Sir Paul Gore-Booth. Although he had never been an ambassador abroad, Greenhill had had the opportunity of visiting a wide variety of foreign and Commonwealth countries during a tour of duty in Singapore in the 1950s, and now, as the most senior Foreign Office official dealing with defence and intelligence questions.

What counted especially in his favour was that he was seen to be "good with ministers"; in other words, he could give sensible, and sometimes unwelcome, advice to his political masters without causing annoyance.

It was Greenhill's attractive personality that was the key to his success. In the office, he was brisk and businesslike. In company, and in lighter moments, he was a most entertaining companion. A lively host and an amusing guest, he had a quick wit, an observant eye, and the tongue of a practised raconteur. As PUS, he served under three prime ministers, Wilson, Sir Alec Douglas Home and Edward Heath. These very different men relied greatly on him, and he served them with sagacity and loyalty.

Greenhill was also a wise and generous head of the Diplomatic Service, being a good judge of people, while tolerant of human weakness. It was a disappointment to him that ending Rhodesia's unilateral declaration of independence, on which he spent much time and endeavour as Britain's special envoy in both 1972 and 1976, was not achievable in his time. His mission had been to investigate the intentions of Ian Smith's regime.

On the other hand, he assisted energetically in the early stages of Britain's membership of the European Community, having been PUS at the time of our successful negotiations for entry. He also found some satisfaction in expelling a large number of Soviet spies operating in London in 1971; the repercussions of the expulsions, he described as risking the Soviet Union's "general beastliness".

As PUS, it fell to Greenhill to attend the Queen when she received the letters of credence of foreign ambassadors accredited to her. This took a couple of hours out of his morning, often at inconvenient times. But he never resented the task, realising that, for a foreign ambassador in London, even the most grand and sophisticated, it was a important occasion, and one at which the PUS ought to be seen to be present at his monarch's side.

Retirement came in 1973, and he became one of the two government-appointed directors of British Petroleum, a post he held until 1978, when he was 65, by which time the government owned 51% of BP. This was a crucial time for the company, in the wake of the revelations about its involvement in breaking oil sanctions against Rhodesia.

It was also a time of family tragedy for Greenhill, with the untimely death of Robin, the younger of his two sons. He and Angela bore this blow with courage and fortitude, but it left a deep scar.

In retirement, Greenhill took on numerous paid and unpaid jobs (for example, he joined the board of British-American Tobacco in 1974), but what gave him most satisfaction, and latterly occupied him most constructively, was his work as a crossbench peer in the House of Lords, where he was a hardworking member of various committees. He was also an assiduous letter-writer to newspapers.

Towards the end of his life, Greenhill wrote More By Accident. If his writing did not quite match the flavour of his efforts as a raconteur, the book was nevertheless much liked by former colleagues, and contains some good stories, as well as interesting footnotes to the diplomatic history of his time. Angela, too, took to her pen in later life, and won some literary acclaim with her poems, All Things Relate.

She survives her husband, as does his elder son, Nigel.

fields.headline: Hortense Ellis
fields.standfirst: Taking the music of Jamaica to the world
fields.trailText: The vocalist Hortense Ellis, who has died of cancer aged 59, scored several big hits during the ska, rock-steady, and lovers' rock phases of Jamaican popular music.
fields.body:
The vocalist Hortense Ellis, who has died of cancer aged 59, scored several big hits during the ska, rock-steady, and lovers' rock phases of Jamaican popular music.

One of seven children, she was born in Kingston, the daughter of a railway worker and a housewife, who occasionally sold fruit at a street market. The family soon moved from their home on Spanish Town Road to Trench Town, a musical hotbed in the years preceding Jamaican independence.

In 1959, Hortense made her singing debut at a talent contest, winning the first of many prizes with her rendition of Frankie Lymon's I'm Not Saying No At All. The song was chosen by her elder brother Alton, who was then enjoying his first record successes as half of a duo with Eddie Perkins. In 1962, she began touring the Bahamas and Trinidad with Byron Lee and the Dragonaires. In 1964 she was awarded the title of Jamaica's best female vocalist.

Hortense started recording during the early-1960s ska era with popular versions of the folk song, Brown Girl In The Ring, and soul favourite, I Shall Sing, for producer Ken Lack. In that time, she also worked with producers Duke Reid, Coxsone Dodd - with whom she recorded the first of many duets with Alton Ellis - and Prince Buster.

In the rock-steady period, her greatest success came for Studio One on adapted versions of Alton Ellis's hits, I'm Just A Guy (as I'm Just A Girl) and Why Birds Follow Spring. Their sustained popularity prompted Coxsone to record an album's worth of material in duet style, with Hortense overdubbing answers to lines from Alton, but it was not released until 1993, on the Heartbeat label.

In 1970, Alton Ellis brought Hortense to Toronto for live performances, but she was unhappy with the lifestyle in Canada and returned to Jamaica. The following year, she married Mikey "Junior" Saunders, and, as Mahalia Saunders, had two big hits recorded for Lee "Scratch" Perry. Her version of Patti Labelle's Down The Aisle, recorded for producer Harry Mudie, was long a mainstay of her live shows.

She had five children with Mikey Saunders before their marriage broke down in 1976. Raising children conflicted with her singing career and her output was curtailed for much of the decade. But she subsequently recorded what was, perhaps, her biggest hit, for producer Gussie Clarke, a version of the love song, Unexpected Places.

In the 1980s, Hortense lived in Miami with a long-term partner, with whom she had two children, occasionally performing but spending much of her time raising her children, and working in haberdashery. She again returned to Jamaica at the end of the decade.

In the 1990s, health problems led to the cancellation of some engagements, and throat cancer was eventually diagnosed. Hortense is survived by her eight children and a large extended family.

fields.headline: It could be you!
fields.standfirst: The real treat for many of us is simply sitting down to a very well cooked dinner - made just for you
fields.trailText: The real treat for many of us is simply sitting down to a very well cooked dinner - made just for you.
fields.body:
Dinner for two? At home? It has that have to have agenda stamped all over it. The temptation to go from beast couchant to lion rampant can prove hard to resist.

On that basis, I conjured up images of a marvellously bacchanal dinner - a great tray of ice piled high with native oysters, their flesh wet and glistening, outlined on the white interior of the shell. A chicken cooked gold and crisp without and moist within, the merest brushstroke of pink at the bone. Potatoes, crisped and browned from goose fat, crystals of sea salt glittering in the candlelight. A dish of quails, several partridge and a few squabs pot roasted in butter with a little garlic, the whole lot liberally doused in Armagnac, ready to be rent apart by hands lacquered with juices and devoured in an utterly pagan manner. An ultra-ripe Vacherin Mont d'Or, unashamedly oozing, practically liquid in its box with a great bunch of grapes tumbling out of a basket.

The idea of arranging this little snack had me chuckling merrily until I heard the guvnor say, "Steady the buffs, old boy." There just isn't enough glamour, I complained, but surrendered all notions of pagan triumph and thought of autumn instead. It's a favourite season for produce, feathered game and mushrooms aplenty, the first pears, prunes, even rumours of truffles.

Although one should entertain wildest fancy now and again, the real treat for a great many people in our fast-paced lives is simply sitting down to a very well cooked dinner, made just for you. Now that is what I really call a luxury of great rarity. Rare, for sure, but not necessarily costly: £15 a head, which was what I was allowed to spend, gives you some latitude for indulgence.

To some, mussels appear common, but why they should be regarded so, just because they are reasonably priced and delicious, is a quirk of British taste. More associated with dining out than dining in, there is not so much a lack of respect but of recognition for mussels as a delicacy for home consumption. Considering they take minimal preparation but for a good swill in cold water, any grit being left at the bottom of the pot once the mussels have been opened and dished up, they should be making regular appearances on the domestic table.

Tucking into a great big pot of moules cooked in a little onion, a generous slug of white wine, a knob of butter and a wee strew of chopped parsley is simple, delicious and wholly hands on.

The native grey-legged partridge (as opposed to the red-legged French partridge) is the most delicious of game birds after the grouse and woodcock. Beyond doubt, one of the very best ways to eat these birds is to roast them for a while, and then to pop them in a pot of braised cabbage, a classic combination. They may be left there for however long you wish. All you have to do is to heat them up for 10 to 15 minutes before eating - not a very serious chore.

For pudding, a great fondness for pears leads me to suggest cooking them (if possible, that pearl among pears, the Passe Crassane; if not, a Williams will do) in vin santo. Needless to say there should be a residue of vin santo ready to be chilled and served in a glass along with the pears.

To cook at home should be a pleasure not a trial, and time at the table a priority over time in the kitchen. And if the consequences should resemble a scene from Tom Jones, well so much the better.

All recipes serve two.

Moules marnierres Made simply, with the best mussels, this is utterly sublime.

1kg mussels (40-60)

2 small onions

1 small handful flat-leaf parsley

60ml white wine

60g unsalted butter

Sea salt and some pepper

Remove the beards from each mussel, then rinse them under running cold water for 20-30 minutes - a little grit is infinitely preferable to no flavour - and place them in a pan. Peel and finely chop the onion and put in the pan along with the white wine. Place a lid on the pot and set over a high heat. Set a colander within a bowl beside the cooker. Shake the pan regularly. When all the shells have opened, tip the mussels into the colander. Return the pot to the stove and decant the cooking liquor from the strained mussels back into the pot. Bring the liquid to a boil, chop the parsley, then stir this in, along with the butter. Whisk together. Place the mussels into two bowls, pour over the sauce, and serve with crusty bread and an eminent bottle of white wine.

Roast grey-leg partridge

2 grey-leg partridge

50g unsalted butter

Sea salt and pepper

Redcurrant jelly

Two bunches watercress

Two thin slices white bread, cut into a disc big enough to comfortably accommodate the bird

Preheat the oven to 230C/450F/gas mark 8. Let the two birds sit for half an hour or so after leaving the fridge - this helps the breasts to cook far better. Cover the birds with butter, and season them. Set them in a suitable roasting pan and place in the hot oven. The birds will take around 18 minutes to roast; baste them every five minutes. They should be pale gold, with a faint rosy blush at the bone. Do not overcook.

Remove the birds from the oven and set to one side, though nowhere too warm, and fry the bread in the roasting pan in a little butter until they're crisp and golden, having soaked up the juices. Set the croutons on a plate, and place the birds on top. A little watercress on one side of each bird and some redcurrant jelly in a separate bowl are the sole accompaniments. Let a good Burgundy enhance a meal of sublime simplicity.

Braised cabbage Alastair Little refuses to serve partridge with anything but braised cabbage. And this is one combination that would be hard to improve on. This dish cooks better in bulk. If you have a nice meat stock handy, then use this instead of the water.

carrot

stick celery

onion

small savoy cabbage

1 rasher streaky bacon

1 tsp duck fat or unsalted butter

1 juniper berry

1 espresso cup water

Salt and pepper

Peel and finely chop the carrot, onion and celery. Cut the bacon into thin strips. In a suitable, heavy-based pot, melt the fat or butter and fry the vegetables and bacon until softened. Cut the cabbage into two or four large pieces, place this on top of the cooked vegetables, and press it down lightly. Put in the water (or, preferably, stock), and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and place a lid on the pot. Cook until the steam has softened the cabbage, then add the juniper, crushed, and a little salt and pepper. Raise the heat and reduce any liquid to a teaspoon's worth.

Pears in vin santo Should vin santo prove rare and expensive, then use a good Marsala. Dinner for two is better served with largesse.

2 Passe Crassanne pears

2 dssp caster sugar

4 tbsp vin santo

1 vanilla pod

1 very small bayleaf

250g tub mascarpone or, better still, Jersey cream

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Place a heavy-based pan on a moderate heat. Split the pears straight through the core - and the stalk, if possible, as this will make the presentation all the more impressive. With a melon baller, remove the core and any fibrous matter attached, taking care not to dislodge the stalk, if at all possible. Put the sugar into the pan and leave to colour to a caramel in a gentle manner, stirring occasionally, but only starting to do so once the sugar crystals have begun breaking up - this should take five to 10 minutes.

Swiftly place the pear halves, cut-side down, in the caramel and pour over the vin santo. Stand back as the sugar may sputter with a furious spit. Drop in the vanilla pod, whole, and bayleaf. Put the pan in the oven, and leave to cook for 15-20 minutes, depending on the size of the pears. They are done when they offer little resistance to the touch. Remove from the oven and spoon some of the resulting syrup over the pears. As they are best served only just warm, cook them slightly before dinner. Serve with a spoonful of mascarpone or Jersey cream, with the syrup poured over.

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

An ultra-ripe Vacherin Mont d'Or, unashamedly oozing, practically liquid in its box with a great bunch of grapes tumbling out of a basket. The idea of arranging this little snack had me chuckling merrily until I heard the guvnor say, "Steady the buffs, old boy." There just isn't enough glamour, I complained, but surrendered all notions of pagan triumph and thought of autumn instead. It's a favourite season for produce, feathered game and mushrooms aplenty, the first pears, prunes, even rumours of truffles. Although one should entertain wildest fancy now and again, the real treat for a great many people in our fast-paced lives is simply sitting down to a very well cooked dinner, made just for you. Now that is what I really call a luxury of great rarity. Rare, for sure, but not necessarily costly: £15 a head, which was what I was allowed to spend, gives you some latitude for indulgence. To some, mussels appear common, but why they should be regarded so, just because they are reasonably priced and delicious, is a quirk of British taste. More associated with dining out than dining in, there is not so much a lack of respect but of recognition for mussels as a delicacy for home consumption. Considering they take minimal preparation but for a good swill in cold water, any grit being left at the bottom of the pot once the mussels have been opened and dished up, they should be making regular appearances on the domestic table. Tucking into a great big pot of moules cooked in a little onion, a generous slug of white wine, a knob of butter and a wee strew of chopped parsley is simple, delicious and wholly hands on. The native grey-legged partridge (as opposed to the red-legged French partridge) is the most delicious of game birds after the grouse and woodcock. Beyond doubt, one of the very best ways to eat these birds is to roast them for a while, and then to pop them in a pot of braised cabbage, a classic combination. They may be left there for however long you wish. All you have to do is to heat them up for 10 to 15 minutes before eating - not a very serious chore. For pudding, a great fondness for pears leads me to suggest cooking them (if possible, that pearl among pears, the Passe Crassane; if not, a Williams will do) in vin santo. Needless to say there should be a residue of vin santo ready to be chilled and served in a glass along with the pears. To cook at home should be a pleasure not a trial, and time at the table a priority over time in the kitchen. And if the consequences should resemble a scene from Tom Jones, well so much the better. All recipes serve two. Moules marnierres Made simply, with the best mussels, this is utterly sublime. 1kg mussels (40-60) 2 small onions 1 small handful flat-leaf parsley 60ml white wine 60g unsalted butter Sea salt and some pepper Remove the beards from each mussel, then rinse them under running cold water for 20-30 minutes - a little grit is infinitely preferable to no flavour - and place them in a pan. Peel and finely chop the onion and put in the pan along with the white wine. Place a lid on the pot and set over a high heat. Set a colander within a bowl beside the cooker. Shake the pan regularly. When all the shells have opened, tip the mussels into the colander. Return the pot to the stove and decant the cooking liquor from the strained mussels back into the pot. Bring the liquid to a boil, chop the parsley, then stir this in, along with the butter. Whisk together. Place the mussels into two bowls, pour over the sauce, and serve with crusty bread and an eminent bottle of white wine. Roast grey-leg partridge 2 grey-leg partridge 50g unsalted butter Sea salt and pepper Redcurrant jelly Two bunches watercress Two thin slices white bread, cut into a disc big enough to comfortably accommodate the bird Preheat the oven to 230C/450F/gas mark 8. Let the two birds sit for half an hour or so after leaving the fridge - this helps the breasts to cook far better. Cover the birds with butter, and season them. Set them in a suitable roasting pan and place in the hot oven. The birds will take around 18 minutes to roast; baste them every five minutes. They should be pale gold, with a faint rosy blush at the bone. Do not overcook. Remove the birds from the oven and set to one side, though nowhere too warm, and fry the bread in the roasting pan in a little butter until they're crisp and golden, having soaked up the juices. Set the croutons on a plate, and place the birds on top. A little watercress on one side of each bird and some redcurrant jelly in a separate bowl are the sole accompaniments. Let a good Burgundy enhance a meal of sublime simplicity. Braised cabbage Alastair Little refuses to serve partridge with anything but braised cabbage. And this is one combination that would be hard to improve on. This dish cooks better in bulk. If you have a nice meat stock handy, then use this instead of the water. carrot stick celery onion small savoy cabbage 1 rasher streaky bacon 1 tsp duck fat or unsalted butter 1 juniper berry 1 espresso cup water Salt and pepper Peel and finely chop the carrot, onion and celery. Cut the bacon into thin strips. In a suitable, heavy-based pot, melt the fat or butter and fry the vegetables and bacon until softened. Cut the cabbage into two or four large pieces, place this on top of the cooked vegetables, and press it down lightly. Put in the water (or, preferably, stock), and bring to a boil. Lower the heat and place a lid on the pot. Cook until the steam has softened the cabbage, then add the juniper, crushed, and a little salt and pepper. Raise the heat and reduce any liquid to a teaspoon's worth. Pears in vin santo Should vin santo prove rare and expensive, then use a good Marsala. Dinner for two is better served with largesse. 2 Passe Crassanne pears 2 dssp caster sugar 4 tbsp vin santo 1 vanilla pod 1 very small bayleaf 250g tub mascarpone or, better still, Jersey cream Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Place a heavy-based pan on a moderate heat. Split the pears straight through the core - and the stalk, if possible, as this will make the presentation all the more impressive. With a melon baller, remove the core and any fibrous matter attached, taking care not to dislodge the stalk, if at all possible. Put the sugar into the pan and leave to colour to a caramel in a gentle manner, stirring occasionally, but only starting to do so once the sugar crystals have begun breaking up - this should take five to 10 minutes. Swiftly place the pear halves, cut-side down, in the caramel and pour over the vin santo. Stand back as the sugar may sputter with a furious spit. Drop in the vanilla pod, whole, and bayleaf. Put the pan in the oven, and leave to cook for 15-20 minutes, depending on the size of the pears. They are done when they offer little resistance to the touch. Remove from the oven and spoon some of the resulting syrup over the pears. As they are best served only just warm, cook them slightly before dinner. Serve with a spoonful of mascarpone or Jersey cream, with the syrup poured over.  Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: Dear weekend
fields.trailText: Sean O'Hagan (The Fall Guy, November 4) appears to take a restricted view of Marilyn Manson's audience. I don't feel especially alienated, nor am I an adolescent, my bedroom is painted cream, I wear black eyeliner in small quantities, as do many women, and my clothes are not 'layers of greying lace and velvet'. While I can certainly be grumpy, I'd hardly characterise this as terminal moroseness. I do, however, believe that Manson is probably the most outstanding artist to have emerged recently on the near-mainstream music scene. Regardless of his image, he is a talented maker of music and an impressive performer. If you spot someone looking happy and wearing a comfortable cardie at the front of the mosh-pit among all the teenyboppers at Manson's next UK gig, that will be me.
fields.body:
Sean O'Hagan (The Fall Guy, November 4) appears to take a restricted view of Marilyn Manson's audience. I don't feel especially alienated, nor am I an adolescent, my bedroom is painted cream, I wear black eyeliner in small quantities, as do many women, and my clothes are not 'layers of greying lace and velvet'. While I can certainly be grumpy, I'd hardly characterise this as terminal moroseness. I do, however, believe that Manson is probably the most outstanding artist to have emerged recently on the near-mainstream music scene. Regardless of his image, he is a talented maker of music and an impressive performer. If you spot someone looking happy and wearing a comfortable cardie at the front of the mosh-pit among all the teenyboppers at Manson's next UK gig, that will be me.

Camille Giffard

Address withheld

Marilyn Manson looks like a freak, sings like a cat, and thinks like a too-clever teenager, but speaks like the educated, aware, articulate adult that he is. I read Sean O'Hagan's article wanting to believe that Manson is yet another blameless, mindless celebrity seized upon by the US Christian Right to purge themselves of any culpability for the atrocious actions of teenagers. I now see him as a shrewd media masseur, innocent of any connection with the Columbine high-school killings, but certainly not exonerated for the manipulation and objectification of his female fans. He is not a monster, but neither is he a child, and he should face up to his responsibilities as an adult human being.

Katherine Longshore

Tonbridge, Kent

Glen Tavener's interpretation of 'In my Father's house are many mansions' (Dear Weekend, November 4) - that there are many ways to reach God - is rather scuppered by Jesus saying just afterwards 'No one comes to the Father except through me' (John 14).

Rev Steve Parish

Warrington

steve@bloovee.freeserve.co.uk

I am delighted to hear that Charlotte Abrahams does not do her own vacuuming, 'obviously' (Home, November 4), and that her cleaner finds using stylish equipment makes his job so much more enjoyable. Would that we all had such appreciative servants! Or am I missing some oh-so amusing 21st-century irony here?

Michael Rank

London N1

rank@mailbox.co.uk

Julie Burchill is missing the point (November 4). Man is an occupational being. We need a balance of assorted meaningful activities, which are difficult enough to be challenging but not defeating, in order to stay physically and mentally healthy. It is precisely because we work such long hours that we need to engage in cooking/gardening/decorating, etc, when we get home. What better, after a hard day at the office/hospital/factory, than to come home and get on with something creative, such as rag-rolling a wall, icing a cake or pruning the roses? It has nothing to do with sex (which is another creative activity).

Alison Blank

Haslemere, Surrey

It's been hard work, but I have finally managed to read your Slow Down special issue (September 9). It was very good, though it did perhaps go on a bit.

Dr Mike Pringle

Swindon, Wiltshire

fields.headline: How to catch a star
fields.standfirst: There was a time when the studio photographer was king and film stars would pose to order. How different from the life of today's newspaper snapper, laments Eamonn McCabe
fields.trailText: There was a time when the studio photographer was king and film stars would pose to order. How different from the life of today's newspaper snapper, laments Eamonn McCabe.
fields.body:
Jane Russell stood on the far side of her pool, the Arizona mountains making a cowboy-movie backdrop behind her. She pulled in the slack of her kaftan-like dress with one hand behind her back, suddenly showing off that famous Playtex-sponsored bust. Moistening and puckering up her lips, she threw her head back and shouted "Now!" I obeyed and released the shutter.

I had my picture, but I was a mere technician. She knew the power of the desert sun and at what time of day it would make her look great. She had, as Marlene Dietrich so often did in the Hollywood studios, lit her own portrait. If only it was that easy on every assignment.

The modern movie star is no longer tied to one studio like a Greta Garbo or Joan Crawford, whose bosses effectively owned them. The studios built the stars, they ran their lives. When told they had to do a portrait for publicity, the "talent" had no choice. Publicity men such as Harry Reichenbach of Metro and Howard Strickling, later at MGM, were more powerful than the director; if they wanted a photograph taken, then the movie had to wait. Nowadays, if a movie is over budget, the first thing that gets cut is the publicity spend. That is why newspapers and magazines make do with copies of duplicates of film stills to illustrate their film reviews and articles - and are the poorer for it. Reichenbach and Strickling must be seething in their graves. Since the collapse of the studio empires following the advent of television, the stars are mainly freelance and often run their own publicity campaigns with the aid of PR people (sometimes helpful to journalists, sometimes not), and they tend only to do interviews and pictures for magazines if they choose to and "have the time".

Vanity Fair has never had any trouble in lining up the stars it wants. Although based in New York, it has always had Hollywood heroes staring out of its pages. The magazine started up in 1914 at almost the same time as the silent studios and in the 500 issues it has published since has always been seen as the perfect vehicle for exposure. It even has an annual Hollywood Issue, and the Vanity Fair party at the Oscars is the one to be seen at. As Maureen Dowd of the New York Times says, "Getting your own photo shoot in Vanity Fair is the premier achievement in our celebrity-mad culture."

Two photographers have dominated the photographic sessions for the magazine, Edward Steichen, the father of portrait photography, and Annie Leibovitz, the mother of invention. They have never taken the "still" photographs of the kind that George Hurrell and Clarence Sinclair Bull took on film sets before the war. Bull's first job in Hollywood was in fact to hold the horses in silent westerns, but he went on to photograph Clark Gable and Hedy Lamarr and many others. The word "still" came about, according to John Kobal, the great fan and collector of early movie photographs, because of the long exposures needed by the early cameras and the fact that the star had to remain perfectly motionless. Ironically the still men were often the most active on the set.

The work of the early studio photographers was often very well known, their photographs of stars such as Jean Harlow and Katharine Hepburn were seen all over the world, becoming classics. But the photographers themselves were mostly anonymous - until now, ironically, when their work is treated as art. In the early days, they took their pictures in makeshift studios on the corners of the film sets or actually on the stages, lit by the best cinematographers in the world, hence that "look". Later, they moved into elaborately appointed galleries, which the stars had to attend for their photo sessions.

The studio photographers must have felt aggrieved when Steichen, the celebrity photographer from New York, swept into town for his shoot for Vanity Fair. He had the run of the lots and the stars did whatever he wanted. Leibovitz has that mantle now; in fact, she's at least as big a star as most of the people she photographs, for she is the star maker. No other photographer has her power and, given the additional clout of Vanity Fair, the stars give her time and carte blanche to do with them whatever she wills. Tony Curtis and Jack Lemmon, long after their drag turn in Some Like It Hot, dressed up in underpants and nightie and held hands in full make-up for her. She constructs and plans her pictures and ordains the pose with an army of assistants, shooting mainly in colour. The results have more in common with the old-style film stills than straightforward portraits: they are perfect moments frozen in time.

The famous photograph of Whoopi Goldberg in a bath of milk, taken from above, is a classic. Black woman, white bath, huge fun, brilliant. The photographs are opulent and heroic and everybody always looks exquisite - just what Vanity Fair wants. Only time will tell whether Leibovitz's pictures will last as well as the early Hollywood greats.

Newspapers have a rather different agenda from Vanity Fair, and the biggest stars are less ready to be photographed by them. However, Warren Beatty surprised me recently when he agreed, through his army of lawyers and publicists, to do a photograph for our profile page in Saturday Review. I arranged for Robert Yager, a photographer I use in California, to do the job. A Beatty minion insisted that I send him the finished pictures for approval; I reluctantly agreed as I was glad to corral the great man. We were told we could not publish without Mr Beatty's agreement. Time was passing and the thought of having to turn out in an LA court if we published regardless did give me the odd sleepless night.

Just as we were sending the picture for printing, Beatty's lawyers were on the phone screaming, "Do not publish the picture." Nobody in LA liked it. Admittedly, the portrait did show a little flesh around the neck nestling on the top of a polo-neck sweater, but it was not bad for a man of 60-odd. As the paper went to press, I had to bluff my way through a few more phone calls from people who claimed to have the say-so. It all went quiet for a few days. Then I heard Warren Beatty loved the portrait - he, of course, had never been shown it during the rows across the Atlantic.

There must be something about age, movie stars and high-profile writers, and polo-neck sweaters. A couple of years ago, I went down to Naples to photograph Gore Vidal. He lives 30 miles or so down the coast, reached by the most torturous route you could imagine. I got there car sick and anxious about meeting one of the legendarily tough ones. I made my way through three locked gates and along a path of a quarter of a mile, and there was this great house set in a rock. He opened the door in a baseball jacket and cap. I had my picture. But no - he asked to be excused and came back wearing the most vivid white polo-neck sweater and a blazer. My heart sank. He, too, was worried about his flabby neck and, as a former American footballer, he felt he had got a bit loose around the jowls.

Later that evening, we went back through the gates and had a few beers in a bar where no money seemed to pass hands. Then we shared a bottle of Scotch and he became deliciously indiscreet about the Kennedys and Monroe. I wish then I'd had a tape recorder instead of my camera.

As a newspaper photographer, I rarely get more than half-an-hour with any star, and I may be the fifth one wheeled in that day to try and get a reaction from someone who is by now bored with the whole thing. The one aim of the studio photographers, given all the time they wanted, was to make their subjects look glamorous, otherwise the publicists would not release the photographs. For me, flattery is not the issue; my aim, like the interviewer's, is to try and show the real person behind the gloss, and I find it helps, creates a dynamic, if they look straight into the camera. As the photographs are rarely taken in people's homes, there are no relevant props; hotel rooms are soulless: the close-up is often the only way out.

Jane Bown has always worked for the Observer and she, too, says working for newspapers is different from private commissions. "I don't have a studio, so each sitting is at a different venue, with a different set of practical problems. My photographs are instinctive - I don't always know how to get it right, but I do know when it feels right. I don't use lights or flash or even a meter - that means I travel light and don't waste time setting up."

Even when the star has agreed to a photograph, it can still be a relatively unrewarding experience. A couple of years ago, I photographed Juliette Binoche for the Guardian. We met at the Almeida Theatre in Islington and I asked her to pose by some funky-looking brickwork down a stairwell, lit by a convenient spotlight. "No," she said, but agreed that I could photograph her while she was being interviewed over lunch. Grateful for small mercies, I set myself up with a longish lens, so as not to be too intrusive, and started taking a few pictures in between disappearing forkfuls of rocket salad.

After a few minutes, I noticed she never looked towards the camera. I left it a few minutes more and interrupted the conversation she was having with the interviewer, and asked her if she could look into the lens for a few shots. "NO!" she said. "You can only photograph me looking at your colleague." That's the way it was: I had "look-away-while-I'm-eating rights" with Juliette Binoche. It turned out that a Daily Telegraph photographer had been in the day before and he got "looking-at-the camera-while-I'm-in-a-good-mood" rights - but not in my stairwell.

I am not alone in this club; even the great photographers have their tough days. David Bailey, for example, remembers the actor Tommy Lee Jones arriving at his studio with the usual Hollywood entourage. He sat in the corner without saying a word - he was not going to play ball and Bailey knew it. Bailey said: "Right, I'm ready." Jones stood on his mark in front of the camera; Bailey started clicking, but there was no reaction from Jones. "What now?" asked Jones. Bailey replied, "Knock yourself out some more!" Tommy Lee smiled and Bailey got the picture. The shoot was over.

Oliver Stone, the film director, marched into Bailey's studio, passing a rail of jackets on hangers, and made his position clear: "I am not a fashion model and won't wear silly clothes." (Something Bailey has never done with portraits, by the way.) He turned to Bailey: "I hear you are as quick as Avedon." Bailey, sharp as ever, replied, "Yeah . . . quicker, but maybe not as good." Stone sat in front of the camera, Bailey clicked once: "Right, got it." Stone, taken by surprise, said, "Oh, I've got a bit more time than that", was won over and stayed for hours, eventually leaving wearing the clothes provided by the magazine which commissioned the shot.

I had problems of a different sort with Michael Winner. The interviewer and I arrived at his plush house in Holland Park and were shown around his private cinema and his amazing bedroom, featuring a huge bed on a raised platform, a kind of bachelor seduction special from the 70s; but it was the Hollywood-style staircase that was lit like a dream by some huge windows that gave me some hope.

Winner complied, simply requesting that I shoot him from above his eyeline. Well, he's the great director, I thought, there must be something in it. We moved up and down the stairs, I got a few shots, and then he started yelling at me: "Above my eyeline." "Oh sorry," I muttered, "tripod must have slipped." "No it hasn't," he yelped. "You've deliberately gone below my eyeline."

I knew I hadn't, but he was having none of it. I spent the next 20 minutes high above him, straining over my camera with tripod legs akimbo, getting pictures of the top of his head. He was happy, but I got absolutely nothing.

Drink seems to be one of the best ways of creating a relaxed atmosphere before shooting some stars. Steve Pyke, best-known for his extreme close-ups, is interested in the landscape of the human face; like Bailey, he never uses the sitter's hands in his pictures. He recalls getting to Paris early one morning to photograph Roman Polanski. "I got to this very plush restaurant that Polanski uses at about eight o'clock and was asked if I fancied a drink - I don't know why, but red wine seemed the perfect thing, even at that hour. Soon after, the great man arrives and I think to myself, this doesn't look very good. He notices my glass and says, 'Ah! you drink the same blood as me.'" Pyke got some great stuff that day.

Pete Postlethwaite: now there's a name, and what a star. He didn't mind what I did, close up, wide angle, pictures of him smoking, drinking, laughing, looking tough, anything. But then, with a face like that, I guess he works on the principle, nobody could do it any harm. The first thing he said to me was "Do you fancy a drink?"

Sometimes, no drink, no joke, nothing will help. Oskar Werner, who starred in Jules et Jim with Jeanne Moreau, was one movie star Bailey never got a picture of. Werner arrived at the studio and immediately complained about the pop music that an assistant had put on; he demanded Bach. There was none in the studio, but some other classical music was found. When asked to sit on the stool, Werner, like Stone, said he was no fashion model: "You can't tell me what to do."

"I think we had better forget the picture," was Bailey's reply, and Mr Werner left.
