The photographs are opulent and heroic and everybody always looks exquisite - just what Vanity Fair wants. Only time will tell whether Leibovitz's pictures will last as well as the early Hollywood greats. Newspapers have a rather different agenda from Vanity Fair, and the biggest stars are less ready to be photographed by them. However, Warren Beatty surprised me recently when he agreed, through his army of lawyers and publicists, to do a photograph for our profile page in Saturday Review. I arranged for Robert Yager, a photographer I use in California, to do the job. A Beatty minion insisted that I send him the finished pictures for approval; I reluctantly agreed as I was glad to corral the great man. We were told we could not publish without Mr Beatty's agreement. Time was passing and the thought of having to turn out in an LA court if we published regardless did give me the odd sleepless night. Just as we were sending the picture for printing, Beatty's lawyers were on the phone screaming, "Do not publish the picture." Nobody in LA liked it. Admittedly, the portrait did show a little flesh around the neck nestling on the top of a polo-neck sweater, but it was not bad for a man of 60-odd. As the paper went to press, I had to bluff my way through a few more phone calls from people who claimed to have the say-so. It all went quiet for a few days. Then I heard Warren Beatty loved the portrait - he, of course, had never been shown it during the rows across the Atlantic. There must be something about age, movie stars and high-profile writers, and polo-neck sweaters. A couple of years ago, I went down to Naples to photograph Gore Vidal. He lives 30 miles or so down the coast, reached by the most torturous route you could imagine. I got there car sick and anxious about meeting one of the legendarily tough ones. I made my way through three locked gates and along a path of a quarter of a mile, and there was this great house set in a rock. He opened the door in a baseball jacket and cap. I had my picture. But no - he asked to be excused and came back wearing the most vivid white polo-neck sweater and a blazer. My heart sank. He, too, was worried about his flabby neck and, as a former American footballer, he felt he had got a bit loose around the jowls. Later that evening, we went back through the gates and had a few beers in a bar where no money seemed to pass hands. Then we shared a bottle of Scotch and he became deliciously indiscreet about the Kennedys and Monroe. I wish then I'd had a tape recorder instead of my camera. As a newspaper photographer, I rarely get more than half-an-hour with any star, and I may be the fifth one wheeled in that day to try and get a reaction from someone who is by now bored with the whole thing. The one aim of the studio photographers, given all the time they wanted, was to make their subjects look glamorous, otherwise the publicists would not release the photographs. For me, flattery is not the issue; my aim, like the interviewer's, is to try and show the real person behind the gloss, and I find it helps, creates a dynamic, if they look straight into the camera. As the photographs are rarely taken in people's homes, there are no relevant props; hotel rooms are soulless: the close-up is often the only way out. Jane Bown has always worked for the Observer and she, too, says working for newspapers is different from private commissions. "I don't have a studio, so each sitting is at a different venue, with a different set of practical problems. My photographs are instinctive - I don't always know how to get it right, but I do know when it feels right. I don't use lights or flash or even a meter - that means I travel light and don't waste time setting up." Even when the star has agreed to a photograph, it can still be a relatively unrewarding experience. A couple of years ago, I photographed Juliette Binoche for the Guardian. We met at the Almeida Theatre in Islington and I asked her to pose by some funky-looking brickwork down a stairwell, lit by a convenient spotlight. "No," she said, but agreed that I could photograph her while she was being interviewed over lunch. Grateful for small mercies, I set myself up with a longish lens, so as not to be too intrusive, and started taking a few pictures in between disappearing forkfuls of rocket salad. After a few minutes, I noticed she never looked towards the camera. I left it a few minutes more and interrupted the conversation she was having with the interviewer, and asked her if she could look into the lens for a few shots. "NO!" she said. "You can only photograph me looking at your colleague." That's the way it was: I had "look-away-while-I'm-eating rights" with Juliette Binoche. It turned out that a Daily Telegraph photographer had been in the day before and he got "looking-at-the camera-while-I'm-in-a-good-mood" rights - but not in my stairwell. I am not alone in this club; even the great photographers have their tough days. David Bailey, for example, remembers the actor Tommy Lee Jones arriving at his studio with the usual Hollywood entourage. He sat in the corner without saying a word - he was not going to play ball and Bailey knew it. Bailey said: "Right, I'm ready." Jones stood on his mark in front of the camera; Bailey started clicking, but there was no reaction from Jones. "What now?" asked Jones. Bailey replied, "Knock yourself out some more!" Tommy Lee smiled and Bailey got the picture. The shoot was over. Oliver Stone, the film director, marched into Bailey's studio, passing a rail of jackets on hangers, and made his position clear: "I am not a fashion model and won't wear silly clothes." (Something Bailey has never done with portraits, by the way.) He turned to Bailey: "I hear you are as quick as Avedon." Bailey, sharp as ever, replied, "Yeah . . . quicker, but maybe not as good." Stone sat in front of the camera, Bailey clicked once: "Right, got it." Stone, taken by surprise, said, "Oh, I've got a bit more time than that", was won over and stayed for hours, eventually leaving wearing the clothes provided by the magazine which commissioned the shot. I had problems of a different sort with Michael Winner. The interviewer and I arrived at his plush house in Holland Park and were shown around his private cinema and his amazing bedroom, featuring a huge bed on a raised platform, a kind of bachelor seduction special from the 70s; but it was the Hollywood-style staircase that was lit like a dream by some huge windows that gave me some hope. Winner complied, simply requesting that I shoot him from above his eyeline. Well, he's the great director, I thought, there must be something in it. We moved up and down the stairs, I got a few shots, and then he started yelling at me: "Above my eyeline." "Oh sorry," I muttered, "tripod must have slipped." "No it hasn't," he yelped. "You've deliberately gone below my eyeline." I knew I hadn't, but he was having none of it. I spent the next 20 minutes high above him, straining over my camera with tripod legs akimbo, getting pictures of the top of his head. He was happy, but I got absolutely nothing. Drink seems to be one of the best ways of creating a relaxed atmosphere before shooting some stars. Steve Pyke, best-known for his extreme close-ups, is interested in the landscape of the human face; like Bailey, he never uses the sitter's hands in his pictures. He recalls getting to Paris early one morning to photograph Roman Polanski. "I got to this very plush restaurant that Polanski uses at about eight o'clock and was asked if I fancied a drink - I don't know why, but red wine seemed the perfect thing, even at that hour. Soon after, the great man arrives and I think to myself, this doesn't look very good. He notices my glass and says, 'Ah! you drink the same blood as me.'" Pyke got some great stuff that day. Pete Postlethwaite: now there's a name, and what a star. He didn't mind what I did, close up, wide angle, pictures of him smoking, drinking, laughing, looking tough, anything. But then, with a face like that, I guess he works on the principle, nobody could do it any harm. The first thing he said to me was "Do you fancy a drink?" Sometimes, no drink, no joke, nothing will help. Oskar Werner, who starred in Jules et Jim with Jeanne Moreau, was one movie star Bailey never got a picture of. Werner arrived at the studio and immediately complained about the pop music that an assistant had put on; he demanded Bach. There was none in the studio, but some other classical music was found. When asked to sit on the stool, Werner, like Stone, said he was no fashion model: "You can't tell me what to do." "I think we had better forget the picture," was Bailey's reply, and Mr Werner left.

webTitle: Julie Burchill: Whip to be square

fields.headline: Whip to be square
fields.standfirst: The appropriation of leather, rubber and revealing clothing was one of those fin-de-siècle symptoms that turned out to be not so fin at all
fields.trailText: The appropriation of leather, rubber and revealing clothing was one of those fin-de-siècle symptoms that turned out to be not so fin at all.
fields.body:
I don't know about you - and knowing what culturally upright people you stern-but-fair Guardian readers actually are, I think it's quite unlikely that you listen to pop radio at all - but there's always at least one, current hit record which is so rotten that I will stop anything, and I mean anything, in order to cross the room and turn it off. Recent culprits have been anything by the vile U2, Music by Madonna - and now, I'm afraid, Holler, the Spice Girls' comeback record.

But it's worse this time - far, far worse. Even though I was irritated by the Madonna record, I didn't find the idea of Madge dancing with her bay-bee nauseating or anything. But when I hear the Spice Girls' record, I am victim to a host of lurid visions that I neither want nor need in my life. Apparently, they're going to take us to their "fantasy room" and "we're going to like it there". After which it will be no time at all before they're making us "holler holler" and, allegedly, scream their names.

My main problem with this is that I am both too worldly and too prim, and so any of the ways of interpreting this threat/promise upsets me. The obvious thing they're going to do to you in their fantasy room is give you a blowjob. But what sort of fantasy is that? Everyone's got oral sex coming out of their ears, these days; it would actually be quite exotic to meet someone who wouldn't go south - you'd think they were really kinky. If this is what they're singing about, I find it quite pitiably pedestrian.

Then my imagination starts to run riot. Face it, the Spice Girls are grown-up, experienced women. They're not going to be singing about doing the oral as though it's a cure for cancer. So it must be something more extreme. If they've got a special room for it, it would have to be. Would that be a dungeon, then? With like . . . waterproof sheeting on the floor? Oh, no! Horrible visions of Scary relieving herself on the innocent bodies of her paying public come to mind. No wonder Geri got out while she could.

Then I tell myself not to be so silly. No way would the Spice Girls be peddling a record to their tiny fans that advocated the joys of urophilia. But then, they've encouraged tiny children all around the country to sing about their lovers (Wannabe) and wearing condoms (2 Become 1). Would it really be such a big jump to crooning about the joy of watersports? And if so, will they be round to bestiality by Christmas?

On balance, I think that Les Spices are singing about S&M - a very M&S type of S&M, but S&M all the same. There's a lot of it about these days. The appropriation of leather, rubber and extremely revealing clothing - once the province of the sweaty suburban swinger and then the hardcore clubber - by wholesome mainstream celebrities such as Davina McCall (who arrived at the Q Awards brandishing a whip last week) was one of those fin-de-siècle symptoms which have turned out to be not so fin at all. On a more cerebral level, look at the enduring appeal of the cruel Mrs Thatcher to Tory MPs, or the latest excruciatingly cutting string to Anne Robinson's bow.

Yes, fun and games at the Commons last week when, using an "arousal monitor", scientists were surprised to find that 80% of MPs and peers got more aroused by being shown photographs of Mrs Thatcher than they did by pictures of semi-naked models, a lesbian kiss or Denise van Outen in a skimpy dress. Amusingly, party allegiance made no difference to the results, though the one (anonymous, male, Labour) MP who reacted most strongly to a photo of Tony Blair was "very surprised and a bit embarrassed". Peter, sweetie - don't worry about it.

Outside of Parliament, conventional stimulus ruled. But are even we civilians immune to the dark appeal of the dominatrix? Surely a good 80% of the appeal of the BBC's new smash hit show The Weakest Link is the stony-faced severity of Anne Robinson, and the heartlessness - even brisk enjoyment - with which she despatches her victims to take the long walk of shame past the camera: think about it, it wouldn't be half as compelling with Henry Kelly or Jenny Powell grinning and soothing at the podium. Tellingly, the show is the brainchild of a doctor (who tend to be sadists) and a comedian (who tend to be masochists).

Commenting on the show's imminent sale to more than a dozen countries, BBC Worldwide said that Johnny Presenter-Foreigner would have to maintain the tone set by Robinson: "Foreign broadcasters are mesmerised by Anne. They are amazed at how tough and forthright she is, and that people are willing to be put through the mill by her. They've never seen anything like it before."

No doubt the spread of The Weakest Link will generate lots of simple-minded smut from our European friends about our collective desire to be dominated by ill-tempered women, coming so soon after the Mrs T shocker. Let them laugh; I have a theory that those countries which have a good record for winning wars don't mind their menfolk being seen as submissive, while those countries where the men are unwilling or unable to fight would prefer them to be seen as sadists for the sake of their own self-respect. That's why the French have got the Marquis de Sade and The Story Of O and we've got Anne Robinson and Mrs T.

This was part of the reason I felt unable to join my liberal colleagues in weeping a tear for poor ickle Lord "Spanker" Holme when he lost his cushy billet as chairman of the Broadcasting Standards Commission a couple of weeks ago. As Spinal Tap found out during the "Smell The Glove" fiasco, there's a thin line between sexist and sexy. Looking back to his line to his lover quoted in the News Of The World story: "Remember every minute after 5 o'clock adds six hard strokes. Think about it and tremble", indeed! I suppose that my contempt for Lord Holme is a close, better-behaved relation to my contempt for Eminem (and I bet that's the only time those two will ever be bracketed together): in a world where women are subject to such a massive amount of harassment, hate crimes and domestic murder (two a week) at the hands of men, isn't fantasising about hurting women, too, a little lousy? And try as we might to be enlightened about these things in theory, I bet that even the most liberal of men would feel uneasy if his own sister, mother or daughter became involved in a sadistic relationship - just as many men approve of prostitution so long as it's not their daughters, mothers or sisters out there turning tricks. It's not only the right which has sexual double standards.

fields.headline: Mind the GATS
fields.standfirst: When the Death Star of the WTO exploded with the protests in Seattle, GATS was the hatch-pod in which Darth Vader made his escape
fields.trailText: When the Death Star of the WTO exploded with the protests in Seattle, GATS was the hatch-pod in which Darth Vader made his escape.
fields.body:
A little-known trade agreement looks set to mobilise global protests in coming months. Two days ago, under the banner "Whose rules rule?", the World Development Movement launched the UK campaign against GATS - the General Agreement on Trade in Services. When the Death Star of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) exploded with the protests in Seattle, GATS was the little hatch-pod in which Darth Vader, disguised as a local riot-cop, made his escape. GATS unleashes transnational corporations to roam the planet and buy up any public services they fancy. Everything from hospitals, post offices and libraries to water and education. Any electorates who try and hang on to these services will get slapped with non-negotiable trade sanctions until their economy screams.

Leaked WTO documents show them currently working out a list of what will be acceptable as a "legitimate" government objective for any regulation of services under GATS. That of "safeguarding the public interest" has already been rejected. If GATS goes ahead, warns economist Susan George, "then Europe can kiss goodbye its public health services". But even though that's just the start of the disaster, there has been no parliamentary debate or news coverage about GATS. (It's way too important for that.) The British government's official line is that there's nothing to worry about anyway. The DTI claims GATS won't apply to the NHS or education here because "non-commercial services" are exempt from the fiat . But GATS says that if you've got just one tiny part of a public service that's even an iddy-biddy-bit commercial then THE WHOLE THING IS UP FOR GRABS.

Massive though GATS is, it's important to remember that it's only one more link in a longer chain locking in domestic populations to stuff they won't like and never voted for. The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA), for example, locks Mexico into neo-liberal reforms in order to protect profits from what NAFTA's planners termed "the danger of a 'democracy opening' in Mexico". IMF Structural Adjustment Programmes, written in Washington, lock developing countries into "liberalisation" policies over and against the wishes of their own people. And we were locked into the Financial Services Agreement (FSA) by the Chubb Corporation! "The FSA," proclaimed the International Insurance Group, "is like taking back the neighbourhood. We can't have governments behaving in thuggish ways."

On taking back the neighbourhood of Chile, Henry Kissinger famously said: "I won't stand by and see a country go communist because of the stupidity of its own people." And there is this kind of "Kissinger-logic" swimming like a virus throughout the whole toxic alphabet soup of GATS, NAFTA, SAPS, FSA, IMF. As the Washington Centre for Strategic and International Research puts it: "In the final analysis, what really matters is how effectively the surrender of governments to the global markets is carried out." (Tony Blair waved his white flag, telling a business audience: "I still bear the scars of the public sector on my back." Note the past tense. He doesn't see himself as working in the public sector any more.)

But to say that GATS is an agreement made by, and for, transnational corporations who just drew up a wish-list and handed it to politicians is not accurate. The actual phrase used by then minister of trade Peter Mandelson and the International Chamber of Commerce was "request-list". His 1998 letter promised them: "our negotiating priorities on the GATS 2000 agenda" will be "business priorities". Nor did the US Council of Service Industries (CSI) simply hand trade representative Charlene Barshevsky a GATS "wish-list", either. She got a 31-page document outlining what US government policy would be. The CSI singled out the European health services, which, they grumbled, "have largely been the responsibility of the public sector [making it] difficult for US private sector health care providers".

The central tenet of neo-liberalism is that there is no conflict between corporation and citizen. A hairline fracture in this iron logic might be the 6,000 maintenance workers laid off since rail privatisation. Another might be the highly revealing quote in this month's Corporate Watch from a Biwater's manager, who explains why the company pulled out of an African water privatisation project: "From a social point of view, these kinds of projects are viable but unfortunately from a private sector view they are not."

Although, that's about to change, too. After water privatisation in Bolivia, people had to get special permits just to collect rainwater in roof-tanks, even though water-bills were a third of average wages. Mass protests in Cochabamba then forced the government to end its contract with Bechtel. But, under GATS provisions, Bechtel is suing Bolivia for scrapping water-privatisation. Thanks to private power, these kinds of projects have just got financially viable again.

 Alexander Chancellor is away.

webTitle: The wholesome magic of pumpkinseed oil

fields.headline: The wholesome magic of pumpkinseed oil
fields.standfirst: If you're a fan of infused oils, you haven't lived until you've tried pumpkinseed oil. And guess what, it simply oozes good health
fields.trailText: If you're a fan of infused oils, you haven't lived until you've tried pumpkinseed oil. And guess what, it simply oozes good health.
fields.body:
Even if you rely on extra-virgin olive and dabble with hazelnut, walnut and sesame oils, it is unlikely that your larder contains Styrian pumpkinseed oil. But arcane as it may sound, this little-known speciality is currently in vogue in New York and it can only be a matter of time before UK foodies wake up to its potential.

People with a healthy mistrust of gimmicky flavoured vinegars and infused oils might be tempted to dismiss pumpkinseed oil as a fleeting food hall fad. Don't. With its 200-year pedigree, it's one of Europe's little-known food treasures, still made by endearingly traditional methods.

An oil with a stunning flavour, full of health-promoting nutrients, pumpkinseed oil is also beautiful stuff to look at. In the bottle it looks black. Against the background of a white plate the first droplets look deep red, but as the oil spreads more thinly, it displays a bright limey-green hue at the edges. The flavour is compulsive, deeply nutty with an engaging wholefoodie quality to it, like eating ultra-fresh, lightly toasted pumpkin seeds. If you're looking for a natural product with the original "good mouth feel", then this is it: buttery, viscous and exceptionally unctuous.

Although pumpkinseed oil is also produced in Slovenia, Yugoslavia and Hungary, it is Austria's pride and joy. (You can get it in the UK under the Merchant Gourmet label, £3.99 for 250ml, in Sainsbury's Special Selection or Waitrose. Tesco is stocking it from mid-December). Step into any quality food shop in Austria though, and you can expect to see an entire display of what's been dubbed locally "the black-gold of the green region", the latter being Styria, the verdant eastern province of Austria. The oil comes from Cucurbita pepo, also known as "the naked-seed pumpkin", a variety unique to central and eastern Europe. It differs from other pumpkins in that it is grown not for flesh but for seeds. These have only a thin edible membrane, not a woody outer hull, so they are entirely edible. First they are dried, very lightly roasted, then cold-pressed. It takes about five pumpkins to yield one litre of oil. All the Styrian oil comes from small-scale, artisanal producers sharing some 70 communal mills, and much of it is organic.

The health profile of pumpkinseed oil is impressive. Not only does it have a high content of unsaturated fats, it is also rich in vitamin E and useful but sometimes elusive minerals such as selenium (both thought to be protective against heart disease and some cancers). It's loaded, too, with zinc, which, in combination with vitamin E, helps fertility. In Austria, pumpkinseed oil is also used medicinally to boost the immune system and treat enlarged prostrate. Pumpkin seeds have been shown to relieve bladder and urinary problems, too.

The classic way to use pumpkinseed oil on its home turf is as a dressing for brawn. That may sound revolting, but it can be excellent, especially in the hands of a top chef such as Helmut Osterreicher in Vienna, whose celebrated restaurant Steirereck (Styrian Corner) serves shin of slowly-boiled Styrian beef set in a light jelly made from reduced stock, surrounded with fresh herbs, light vinegar and a drizzling of the fascinating oil.

Increasingly, however, Austrians use it as a salad dressing and like to partner it with apfel (cider) vinegar. Trendy Austrian chefs are now using it as a subtler alternative to sesame oil, teaming it up with Asian ingredients such as glass noodles and soy. Pumpkinseed oil will burn if heated and lose its beneficial nutritional properties, so it's used cold and stored in the fridge. Its big, rounded personality means that you use it sparingly. It has an affinity with peppery greens (watercress, rocket, mustard greens), baby spinach, and bitter leaves such as endive. Both balsamic and cider vinegar are natural partners, but it can stand up to broad-shouldered sherry vinegar, too. Complimentary add-ins might include crumbled feta or Roquefort, toasted pumpkin seeds or pine kernels, and freshly cracked nuts or something sweet, such as pears or beetroot. Try it.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcom Gluck unearths more bargain vins.
fields.body:
You might just as well try to count the bubbles in a glass of the stuff as to fathom why Tesco should consider it necessary to reduce, until January 9, 2001, its own-label Cava to £3.49. This is a deliciously dry Spanish bubbly with deftly interwoven fruit and acid rating 15.5 points out of 20. Frankly, if I was throwing a New Year's eve (new millennium's eve, by Jove!) party for a large rabble then I would stock up on this bargain immediately. While we're in the store, I should also draw your attention to Tesco's nonvintage Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon (16 points, £3.49) which is another thumping great bargain. It offers chocolate with raspberry, a hint of earth and blackcurrant on the finish. This really is a terrific wine to be liberal with when entertaining.

Tesco also has various other wines on offer until November 29. Australian Brown Brothers Dry Muscat 1999 (15 points, down to £4.49) is lemon sherberty, yet dry, with a hint of ripe muscat grapes on a finish which is slightly exotic and spicy. This is a delicious aperitif wine. Also from Australia is Hardys Stamp Chardonnay Semillon 1999 (15 points, on offer at £3.49) which has a very gentle toffeed edge, almost like butterscotch, along with compensating lemony acids. Rosemount Sauvignon Blanc 2000 (15 points, down to £4.99) is deliciously ripe yet fresh with that tight sauvignon tang of minerals and gooseberries. There's an echo of lime in there, too. Chilean Cabernet Sauvignon Reserve 1999 (16 points, on offer for £3.99) has a hint of coffee and cream to the blackcurrant as it quits the throat. Corbieres Reserve La Sansoure 1999 (15 points, now £3.99) is soft with ripe fruit. And Oxford Landing Cabernet Sauvignon Shiraz 1999 (15.5 points, down to £4.49), from Australia, shows a rich texture, good layers of fruit, warm friendly tannins, and overall a lushly impactful structure which is ripe without being raucous. It s an adult Shiraz of great charm and persistence. Other discounted wines worth their weight at Tesco are two Aussie reds. Banrock Station Shiraz/ Mataro 1999 (15 points, buy six for £19, which runs out at around £3.17 per bottle) is juicy and ripe and richly textured, not very subtle, but a superb performer with Middle Eastern food, one reason being that it has a touch of coriander to it. Rosemount Estate Shiraz Cabernet 1999 (15.5 points, buy six for £32.49, or £5.42 a bottle) is hugely friendly, an archetypical Aussie Shiraz that defines what this grape means at this price for so many drinkers.

Tesco has some special-occasion wines, not on offer, that you might like to bear in mind for any festivities ahead. Valdivieso Cabernet Franc Reserve 1998 (17 points, £8.99), from Chile, has deep savoury riches which tantalise the tongue and tighten the throat as the tannins ooze down. Thelema Mountain Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc 1999 (17 points, £12.99), from South Africa, offers a perfect herbaceous undertone to beautifully multi- layered fruit of luxury and quiet charm. Montes Alpha Chardonnay 1998 (17.5 points, £9.99) from Chile is a marvellously couth, great burgundy-style chardonnay with creamy textured richness of some sensuality. Kumala Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (16.5 points, £8.99), from South Africa, is compellingly well concentrated and classy with great generosity of fruit.

If anyone can upstage Tesco's cheaper wines, it is Angie's Bargain Basement (vulgarly known as Somerfield, whose wine buyer, Angela Mount, is a cut-price genius). Her current descents into toothsome absurdity include a vintage 2000 South African Dry White (15 points, £1.99 until November 14), Domaine du Bois Viognier 1998 (15.5 points, £3.49 until November 28), Domaine St Agathe Chardonnay 1998 (16 points, £3.29 until November 28), and Vina Cana Rioja Crianza 1997 (16 points, £3.49, also until November 28). Each is incredible value for money; balanced, sanely fruity, and highly quaffable. The Cape white is a conventional melon and lemon duo. The viognier, an increasingly chic white grape, is dry and subtly peachy. The St Agathe (horrifically martyred by mammalian section, you will recall) is remarkably elegant and gently buttery. The red rioja is lovely, with a hint of milk chocolate softening the tannins.

fields.headline: On the rack
fields.standfirst: How to buy wine in Calais
fields.trailText: How to buy wine in Calais.
fields.body:
The typical Guardian reader, or at least the typical Superplonk correspondent, always opens with a congratulatory slap on the back. I've had many years of this delicious epistolary massage, but have learned that it is more often merely the softening up before a curt "but", or a casual "however", or an innocent "be that as it may", and then I'm pinned to my chair and required to explain what tannin is, or why must I campaign to eliminate duff corks when the alternatives will ensure destruction of every Imperial eagle in Spain.

Many readers, who slurp in silence, might be astonished to learn of my secret life, carried on for 11 years now, in which I am a vinous agony uncle. Be that as it may, my back is unbent. I have replied to every letter and still intend doing so, in spite of being now able to go public on these matters in the belief that a good deal more readers than the one who asked the question are interested in the answer. I resolved to begin this first column with the first letter I opened today, and so it is that Mr J Waugh, of Oxford, has the honour of inauguration, even though he is far from typical. He not only offers no prefatory slap but encloses a stamped addressed envelope (which ensures more dash from me than any slap can). "Could you please," he wastes no words in broaching, "give me some advice about buying wines in Calais?"

Well, leaving aside the British outlets in littoral France, whose wines are already covered (albeit with higher prices) in the Superplonk column, the most popular and the cheapest alternatives in Calais are the French hypermarkets such as Mammouth, Continent, Prisunic and Intermarché.

Buy only French wines at these places - unless there are New World wines you already know. Do not buy any Burgundies, or expensive Bordeaux, except reds from the unfashionable areas such as Fronsac, Côtes de Blaye or Bourg, and Côtes de Castillon. Buy only southern Rhnes (red or white) from the villages of Lirac, Vacqueyras, Rasteau, Beaumes-de-Venise (red), Sablet, Vinsobres, Valreas and Seguret. Buy only Loire reds (not whites), Chinon and Bourgeuil. Never touch the champagnes. Buy bubblies such as Crémant d'Alsace, Crémant de Loire and Crémant de Bourgogne. Wines from the Languedoc are terrific, but the shrewdest buys are the whites from the large wineries such as Val d'Orbieu and Skalli. The best value wines, are all to be found among these appellations.

The last time I bought wine in a French hypermarket, I carried out an informal tasting in the car park, carefully spitting out in to a handy nearby drain, and on the basis of this decided which were the best to buy in bulk. The opened bottles were recorked and many tasted even better in London many hours later. This latter phenomenon will, of course, be the subject of a future column.

Next week: For how long should a wine be left to breathe?

fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Hopf Weisse
fields.trailText: Hopf Weisse.
fields.body:
Hans Hopf owns a wheat beer brewery in Miesbach in Bavaria and hasn't had to pay a penny to PR consultants for his dream name, for Hopf is just two letters short of hopfen, the German for hops. His Hopf Weisse - pale wheat beer - has won the gold medal of the German Agricultural Society for 15 consecutive years.

Using pure Alpine water, German and French malts and local hops, Herr Hopf produces a refreshing and complex beer with an aroma and palate of bananas, spices and bubblegum, and a long finish with a creamy vanilla note. The character of Bavarian wheat beers is the result of yeast strains that produce phenols and guaiacols similar to the compounds found in the tropical tree sap used to make Juicy Fruit. Hopf wheat beer (5.3%) is distributed in Britain by Cains brewery in Liverpool and sells in bars in the north-west at £2.07 a pint, or £1.39 for a 50cl bottle. Cains hopes to have nationwide distribution in place by the new year. For stockists, contact Linda Boyle on 0151-709 8734.

webTitle: Eating out: the Fat Duck, Bray

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: The Fat Duck, Bray
fields.trailText: The Fat Duck, Bray.
fields.body:
Crab risotto. Fine. Red pepper cassonade. Not exactly a traditional Italian combination, but I'll go along with it even if I haven't a clue what cassonade is. Crab ice cream . . . now, hang on a second . . . and passion fruit jelly. Passion fruit jelly! I say, what is going on?

What is going on is Heston Blumenthal at full throttle at the Fat Duck, at Bray. When I first reviewed the Fat Duck some years ago, Blumenthal, self-taught wunderkind, was putting out classic bourgeois French food of such élan that it made glossy stars out of domestic dishes. It was ever so toothsome, and people remarked on it. Since then, he has left the decencies of home cookery far behind. Technically, his cooking now has as much to do with chemistry and physics as it does with boiling and basting.

His crab biscuit and roast foie gras, crystallised seaweed and oyster vinaigrette and cuttlefish, cannelloni of duck, maple syrup, parsley and perilla broth have passed into legend. Since their arrival, his inventive spirit has taken him further along his chosen, esoteric path. Tea and lime sour came at the beginning of lunch to clear away the palatal cobwebs; then followed consommé of pigeon with pea purée and crab juice; the crab risotto; ballotine of foie gras, smoked eel and jasmine with a jelly of mead and Sichuan; saddle of lamb cooked at low temperature, roast onglet, coffee and garlic dentelle, a purée of onion and star anise; garlic purée and coffee jelly; millefeuille of pain d'epices, pineapple and chilli jelly. And that was before O'Hara and I finished up with two lots of petits fours that included in their midst crystallised pepper jelly; beetroot jelly; chocolate infused with pipe tobacco and caramel infused with bacon.

This is unlike any other cooking in the UK. It is inspired by the extreme genius of Ferran Adria from that place of pilgrimage for the more lively-minded British chefs, El Bulli, 100 miles north of Barcelona, where the creations are deliberately designed to challenge our notions of taste and texture.

However, if the dishes at the Fat Duck were simply exercises in food philosophy and fantasy, you would tire of them rapidly. In the past I have found some of the more recherché creations unbalanced and therefore unlovely. Such cooking walks a precarious line between the delicious and the daft, and, because it is pushing at the accepted boundaries of what we think of as restaurant food, it is a balancing act without a safety net.

But if, on paper, it seems poised on the edge of self-parody, these dishes resolve themselves brilliantly on the palate. Each mouthful calls into action a range of sensations through the interplay between hot and cold, sweet and sour, fruit and savoury, one texture and another. To get really fancy for a moment, and to go back to the crab dish, you can immediately see the contrast between the heat of the crab risotto and the coolth of the ice cream (and yes, it really does taste of crab), but they are linked by the flavour of the shellfish. There's also the contrast between the firmness of the rice in the risotto and the creaminess of the ice cream.

Now crab has a certain fruity sweetness to it if you think about it, and if you haven't Blumenthal certainly has, because the streaks of red pepper purée and cassonade (all right, it's a kind of powder) pickup that sweetness of the risotto and develop it into another, fruitier dimension, while the more acid passion fruit jelly at room temperature links to the ice cream.

Not that I came up with all this at the time, you understand, because conversation with O'Hara was in full flow. But so harmonious was the result of each mouthful that it only added to the pleasure of our discourse rather than distracted us from it. My thoughtful analysis is the product of rumination, of pleasure recollected in tranquillity. I won't bore you by detailing the almost endless list of felicities of each dish. This is supremely considered cooking of awesome technical accomplishment.

What is more, for those of us who treasured the Fat Duck in its previous incarnation, but who had reservations about some of its resources, there is the additional pleasure of finding the lavatories situated upstairs rather than at the end of a sometimes rain-soaked dash across the back yard.

In fact, the Fat Duck has emerged from a thorough decorative going over a much cosier, more comfortable place than before, but with the same modest, knowledgable and efficient service to cosset you through the gastro-extravaganza.

The price? I'd almost forgotten in my excitement. There's a three-course lunch at £24.50 and a three-course dinner for £55. Before you leap from your chair with distress at the cost, I should point out that while Blumenthal may be a whizz at the chemistry of food, he can't count. Between the dishes you choose, he interposes any number of his own, so you can end up with, oh, eight courses without too much problem.

At a time when most ambitious food in Britain is subserviently French or ludicrously omni-cultural, Blumenthal strikes at distinctly personal and individual, not to say idiosyncratic, notes. I overheard someone say at another table that this was "very highbrow food". So, I suppose, it may be, but in this instance you can love the body as well as the mind.

In the past I have found some of the more recherché creations unbalanced and therefore unlovely. Such cooking walks a precarious line between the delicious and the daft, and, because it is pushing at the accepted boundaries of what we think of as restaurant food, it is a balancing act without a safety net. But if, on paper, it seems poised on the edge of self-parody, these dishes resolve themselves brilliantly on the palate. Each mouthful calls into action a range of sensations through the interplay between hot and cold, sweet and sour, fruit and savoury, one texture and another. To get really fancy for a moment, and to go back to the crab dish, you can immediately see the contrast between the heat of the crab risotto and the coolth of the ice cream (and yes, it really does taste of crab), but they are linked by the flavour of the shellfish. There's also the contrast between the firmness of the rice in the risotto and the creaminess of the ice cream. Now crab has a certain fruity sweetness to it if you think about it, and if you haven't Blumenthal certainly has, because the streaks of red pepper purée and cassonade (all right, it's a kind of powder) pickup that sweetness of the risotto and develop it into another, fruitier dimension, while the more acid passion fruit jelly at room temperature links to the ice cream. Not that I came up with all this at the time, you understand, because conversation with O'Hara was in full flow. But so harmonious was the result of each mouthful that it only added to the pleasure of our discourse rather than distracted us from it. My thoughtful analysis is the product of rumination, of pleasure recollected in tranquillity. I won't bore you by detailing the almost endless list of felicities of each dish. This is supremely considered cooking of awesome technical accomplishment. What is more, for those of us who treasured the Fat Duck in its previous incarnation, but who had reservations about some of its resources, there is the additional pleasure of finding the lavatories situated upstairs rather than at the end of a sometimes rain-soaked dash across the back yard. In fact, the Fat Duck has emerged from a thorough decorative going over a much cosier, more comfortable place than before, but with the same modest, knowledgable and efficient service to cosset you through the gastro-extravaganza. The price? I'd almost forgotten in my excitement. There's a three-course lunch at £24.50 and a three-course dinner for £55. Before you leap from your chair with distress at the cost, I should point out that while Blumenthal may be a whizz at the chemistry of food, he can't count. Between the dishes you choose, he interposes any number of his own, so you can end up with, oh, eight courses without too much problem. At a time when most ambitious food in Britain is subserviently French or ludicrously omni-cultural, Blumenthal strikes at distinctly personal and individual, not to say idiosyncratic, notes. I overheard someone say at another table that this was "very highbrow food". So, I suppose, it may be, but in this instance you can love the body as well as the mind.

webTitle: Dulcie Domum: dirty weekends and filthy lucre

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: dirty weekends and filthy lucre
fields.standfirst: 'There he goes again, wooing me with attractive concepts beginning with P'
fields.trailText: 'There he goes again, wooing me with attractive concepts beginning with P'.
fields.body:
'Dulcie? This is Fred. I was wondering if you might fancy a weekend in St Ives?" At last he rings with an invitation. So he does want to see me after all. One can never tell with middle-aged, once-married bisexuals. My heart gives a little skip. But to tell you the truth, my erotic anticipation is already fixed elsewhere - on Aunt Elspeth's gift of a cheque, at present reposing in an envelope in my cardigan pocket. Unopened.

"I thought," Fred goes on, "you might like the paradox of being in St Ives at the darkest time of the year." There he goes again, wooing me with attractive concepts beginning with P. The very first time he spoke to me, at the gay barbecue, he distracted me with poignancy. Now it's paradoxes.

And yet - the real paradox is, now I've got my bulging envelope, its exact contents as yet a mystery, I can't be quite so easily fobbed off with mere words, even those beginning with P. Although I am aware - poignantly, perhaps - that in my previous poverty a delight in words and concepts offered a pleasure of unsullied purity, I'm happy to postpone the pleasure of further p-words while I give in to galloping greed and drool over my patrimony. Or perhaps, since it's the aunt's, it should be antimony.

It's not that I am indifferent to a weekend with Fred, it's just that I have not yet made the night wanton with my cheque. And size may not be important in bed, but in the bank account it's crucial. I have been in a feverish conjecture about the size of aunt's cheque since she presented me with the sealed envelope, which, though it was only about 20 minutes ago, seems somehow more like a fortnight.

"Mum?" Harriet bounces up, ignoring my phone call. "Should I wash my turquoise socks with the whites or the darks?"

"Turquoise is neither of the whites nor of the darks," I pontificate, suddenly authoritative in aesthetics where previously I would flounder and flap. The Newlyn School, here I come. "If in doubt, select synthetics. Sorry, Fred, that was Harriet. She sends her love." Harriet departs with a raised eyebrow.

"Oh, give her mine. But, Dulcie - this time I'd rather we left the teenagers out of it, if you don't mind."

"Oh quite." Become aware that aunt is hovering and listening in hall, and Ex-spouse in dining room. How easily, by some injudicious remark, I could slide from sainthood to tarthood. Though I think the aunt understands instinctively that Ex-spouse and I are not in any sense an item nowadays, she could easily turn to granite were I to flaunt a peccadillo.

"Oh, I'd love to meet your mother, Fred," I suddenly launch into fiction. "And your new boyfriend. Giorgio! What a lovely name!"

"Ah, so we've got an audience," purrs Fred. "Would you like me to talk dirty to you? I long to plunge into your marshmallow thighs, etcetera? I'm dying to make the beast with two backs whilst the sea roars beneath our window." Just as long as it's below the window. I didn't like that programme about tsunamis. Maybe we should make the beast with two backs on the summit of Mount Ararat.

But to be honest, the business of sex, which so preoccupied my younger years, now seems but the bizarre juxtaposition of charcuterie. At least compared with the urgent attractions of my throbbing envelope. But marshmallow thighs? I know it's in a Kate Bush song, but it's in that grey area between compliment and insult, surely?

"Mum! Where do I put the Comfort?" Ring off having promised to spend next weekend with my lover, initiate Harriet into the mysteries of the Comfort-disposing drawer, then escape to the bathroom, rip open envelope, and discover to my amazement that the aunt has given me £50,000. Enough for a house in the Languedoc and some discreet thigh restructuring. A comfort-dispensing envelope if ever I had one. Am still reeling when there is a knock on the bathroom door.

"Dulcie, dearr? I'm sorry to disturrb you, but I think I can smell something unusual in my wardrobe."

"Coming, Auntie!"

I may have got the poverty and chastity licked but I think I might have a bit more of a problem with the obedience.

fields.headline: How to
fields.standfirst: Fish
fields.trailText: Fish.
fields.body:
The definition of an angler is a man who prefers British weather at its worst to his wife at her best. Angling is the biggest participation sport in this country. In fact, the only nonparticipants are the fish themselves who find the whole sport a bit beneath them (or above them, to their way of thinking).

It is a point of honour for anglers to have a vast amount of kit and then to carry it all on an aging bicycle so that they look like a member of the British Motorcycle Display team practising a pyramid formation minus the rest of the team. The rod for the fisherman is the equivalent of a beach towel. Its main purpose is to tell other anglers which bit of the bank has been reserved. Its secondary role is to tell the fish where to avoid.

Anglers also have a huge net that looks as though it should be hanging over the side of a deep-sea trawler. This is to give the impression that a massive haul of fish is expected. In fact, all these nets are connected underwater to other anglers so they can shuttle round the one little tiddler that's been caught during the day.

Many anglers will have a big plastic bucket full of wriggling maggots. This is usually an aid to interaction between anglers who are notoriously deficient in the conversation department. Comparing wriggliness of maggots is an easy and noncontroversial way of getting into conversation. The maggots are also the last historical evidence of the one and only time the wife provided a packed lunch.

Serious anglers spurn sparkling highland trout streams as this is like casting into the fish counter at your local supermarket. Instead they choose the most polluted, stagnant stretch of water, the theory being that the fish will be as keen to get out of it as the anglers are to get them out of it.

Fly-fishing is an advanced form of angling where you cast your line into midair and hope to catch a fly. It sounds difficult but there is as much chance of catching a fly like this as there is of catching a fish in your average British river. Fly-fishermen often wear hats covered with coloured lures. This shows just how often other anglers have cast directly into their hat and explains why fly-fishing is often classified as a dangerous sport.

You can often see anglers in pubs telling animated stories with their eyes wide and their arms flailing. That's because 90% of anglers have never actually seen a fish and are enormously surprised when it doesn't come up in a thick, crispy batter.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Ricki Lake
fields.trailText: Ricki Lake.
fields.body:
Ricki Lake, 31, was brought up in New York State. She was 18 and at college when she landed her first major film role in John Waters' Hairspray. She moved to Hollywood and became a regular in the TV drama China Beach, before being dropped in 1990. Her career was resurrected in 1993, with her debut as a talk show host. She is married with one son.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
My life right now - great husband, a great son, a great job. What is your greatest fear?
An untimely death. Which living person do you most admire?
Susan Sarandon. She uses her celebrity to speak out on important causes. What vehicles do you own?
A Volvo stationwagon. What is your greatest extravagance?
I recently bought myself a knock-out, dead-gorgeous ring. What objects do you always carry with you?
The knock-out, dead-gorgeous ring. Where would you like to live?
Italy - some day. What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My weight. What is your favourite smell?
The smell of my son's skin and breath. What is your favourite word?
Mommy. What is your favourite journey?
A bike trip through the Dordogne with my husband. What is your favourite book?
The Lorax, by Dr Seuss Do you believe in capital punishment?
No. Do you believe in monogamy?
Of course. What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My husband. What is your greatest regret?
Not finishing college. When and where were you happiest?
Being pregnant. How do you relax?
I go to the spa, get a massage and a facial. How often do you have sex?
Not often enough. What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Losing the last 10 pounds! What would your motto be?
If I can do it, anybody can. Do you believe in life after death?
I would like to. How would you like to be remembered?
As a warm, honest person and a good mother. What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
To be compassionate.

fields.headline: This Island Earth
fields.standfirst: The secret world of the allotment
fields.trailText: Amid the urban sprawl, there's a rural idyll where the daily grind is replaced by the quiet toil of working the land.
fields.body:
Just off the A41, past Cricklewood and Golders Green, there's a shard of horticultural heaven piercing the urban girdle of north London. It is a strange landscape after the incessant rows of neat Tudor teapot houses because, alongside the almost medieval patterning of earthy rectangles, grassy paths and tidy row upon row of vegetables, you will glimpse the ramshackle assortment of makeshift sheds and greenhouses, animated by flapping sheets of plastic that catch the sunlight.

The scene speaks of an industry at odds with the urgent tenor of cars on the Tarmac a few hundred yards away. Exchange the desperate race to beat the lights, to get from A to B in the fastest time possible, for the regular rhythm of dig, turn, rake and plant; mobility for staying put; the gnawing crescendo of the kids squabbling on the back seat for the chatter of rooks arguing in the trees.

The Golders Green Allotment Association has been here since 1913, when this part of London was just an old hospital and a tiny airfield. You still get a sense of the original villagey-ness the place must have had in the early part of the last century from the quaint silhouette of the electricity substation edging the allotments, its roof supporting a wood-encased clock tower. While other council-subsidised allotments have been eaten away around London - sold to developers for vast sums - Barnet Council still keeps the 196 allotments here going, charging their keepers £33 per year for the right to till the soil, including access to water for irrigation purposes.

John Wingate, 82, worked his plot for decades with his wife until her death six years ago. A former manager at a Mother's Pride bakery, he still keeps the 120ft long rectangle neat and tidy, mixing vegetables with a flower garden to her memory at one end. He now runs the little allotment shop - two garden sheds stuck together - which forms the hub of the allotment community. Inside, rows of bagged potatoes of different types - Cara (which has, according to the species guide nearby, "large attractive tubers"), Rocket ("an early bulking variety"), Desiree ("an established favourite"), Kestrel ("old-fashioned flavour"), Catriona ("an excellent show potato") - sit proudly on wooden shelves, the product of many hours of devotion. Seed packets, pest control weaponry and gardening tools are lined up with precision labelling.

John keeps a tidy notebook in which the careful transactions between the allotment keepers are recorded. A comforting earthy smell pervades the tiny space. Outside, the local Catholic priest, Father Haines, who also has an allotment here, has rolled up in his car to purchase a few bags of potatoes. It is a million miles away from the smart bars, the terrifyingly-chic restaurants, the merciless urban flow.

You detect how the people who work these allotments regard them as a sanctuary. Perhaps this is because digging away at the sticky earth and piling in the manure allows for solitary contemplation, but one driven with a clear creative purpose. The community here is polyglot, and something of the plot-holders' cultural origins can be traced in the plants they choose to grow: Greeks, Cypriots, Italians and the Portuguese go for the garlic, leeks, red onions, tomatoes, sweet corn, runner beans and strawberries. The Greeks like to grow their beans up a single pole, while the rest use the grouping method. The English and Irish display a fondness for potatoes, while an Indian allotment keeper has gone for herbs, big time.

While the majority of the gardeners are men, there are more than 40 women among them, and you will find people working their allotments early in the morning before work and first thing in the evening, although the weekends are understandably when things are at their busiest. Some of them put their best fruit and veg into large local horticultural shows, such as the one held at Friern Barnet during the summer months. The Golders Green Association members regularly win first prizes in their selected category.

The shows are now over, but the work does not stop. There's the smell of bonfires in the air as rows of bean sticks, tomato stakes, trimmings from fruit bushes and blighted plants ,or those too woody to compost, are cleared out of the way. The more organised plot-holders are digging and manuring the soil for next spring, and staking out dead-straight seed drills with string and pegs for winter plantings. Autumn is when garlic cloves go in the ground, as well as tulip bulbs, broad beans and peas. Herbs and young sweet peas are moved under glass and the allotment version of plant protection comes into its own - cold frames made from old windows, ancient cloches of panes of glass held together with clips, or rows of cut-off plastic bottles.

Vegetation is rotting after recent rain, making a muddy backdrop for pumpkins and squash, the last cobs of sweetcorn and a spattering of reddening apples on a small tree. It's the time of year when plot-holders scale down, and maybe take their last chance to earth up Brussels sprouts, protect cauliflower curds from frost, and mulch rhubarb and globe artichoke crowns before the weather gets too cold and uninviting.

Thanks to good organisation, the allotment keepers of Golders Green escaped the worst of the recent storms, the rain being channelled away. "Over the last three or four years, we've been renewing the earth drains, so we haven't had any problems," says Mr Wingate.

For all their individual shyness to a stranger with a notebook, the allotment keepers display an obvious companionship between themselves. Husband and wife team Donato and Carmen Sabatino manage two plots side by side. Donato left the family farm back in Italy to pursue a different career path, but, he says, "as soon as I saw the allotments I knew I had to have one".

Relative newcomers, Chinese couple the Hys only started work on their allotment in the past year. In between putting up their greenhouse, they have already had a harvest of pak choi and other oriental vegetables. Next door to the Hys, a middle-aged English couple sit in their greenhouse, clad in Wellies and padded jackets, eating a salad lunch out of plastic boxes. They explain how they live on the seventh floor of a council block in Swiss Cottage. "This allotment is our garden, it's where we escape to." They talk excitedly of watching foxes and water rats while they work.

Eli Bagdady, an Israeli truck driver, drove past the allotments several years ago, fell in love with the place and immediately secured himself a plot. He's erected a slightly alarming-looking Swiss chalet-style shed at one end of his allotment, complete with lacy curtains, plant pots and even a barbecue. A former worker on a kibbutz, he identifies closely with the communal ethic and is a passionate grower of a huge range of vegetables and fruit. "It's the taste that makes all the difference," he says.

In summer, he says, he doesn't need to buy vegetables from the supermarket. While he and many of his allotments colleagues very occasionally use a pesticide when necessity demands it, most of the food is grown using organic methods. "I challenge you to eat something grown here with something from Tesco's and not tell the difference immediately."

Looking around at the ramshackle buildings, it's hard not to compare the openness of allotment culture, the way the jerry-built sheds have no locks, with the prim toy-town neatness of the suburban garden shed. Then you get a sense of how oddly repressive the latter can be. Keeping an allotment may not be everybody's cup of tea, but, as Eli states with passion, the allotments are "a kind of paradise, somewhere you can escape from reality. It's better than going to the doctor."

Herbs and young sweet peas are moved under glass and the allotment version of plant protection comes into its own - cold frames made from old windows, ancient cloches of panes of glass held together with clips, or rows of cut-off plastic bottles. Vegetation is rotting after recent rain, making a muddy backdrop for pumpkins and squash, the last cobs of sweetcorn and a spattering of reddening apples on a small tree. It's the time of year when plot-holders scale down, and maybe take their last chance to earth up Brussels sprouts, protect cauliflower curds from frost, and mulch rhubarb and globe artichoke crowns before the weather gets too cold and uninviting. Thanks to good organisation, the allotment keepers of Golders Green escaped the worst of the recent storms, the rain being channelled away. "Over the last three or four years, we've been renewing the earth drains, so we haven't had any problems," says Mr Wingate. For all their individual shyness to a stranger with a notebook, the allotment keepers display an obvious companionship between themselves. Husband and wife team Donato and Carmen Sabatino manage two plots side by side. Donato left the family farm back in Italy to pursue a different career path, but, he says, "as soon as I saw the allotments I knew I had to have one". Relative newcomers, Chinese couple the Hys only started work on their allotment in the past year. In between putting up their greenhouse, they have already had a harvest of pak choi and other oriental vegetables. Next door to the Hys, a middle-aged English couple sit in their greenhouse, clad in Wellies and padded jackets, eating a salad lunch out of plastic boxes. They explain how they live on the seventh floor of a council block in Swiss Cottage. "This allotment is our garden, it's where we escape to." They talk excitedly of watching foxes and water rats while they work. Eli Bagdady, an Israeli truck driver, drove past the allotments several years ago, fell in love with the place and immediately secured himself a plot. He's erected a slightly alarming-looking Swiss chalet-style shed at one end of his allotment, complete with lacy curtains, plant pots and even a barbecue. A former worker on a kibbutz, he identifies closely with the communal ethic and is a passionate grower of a huge range of vegetables and fruit. "It's the taste that makes all the difference," he says. In summer, he says, he doesn't need to buy vegetables from the supermarket. While he and many of his allotments colleagues very occasionally use a pesticide when necessity demands it, most of the food is grown using organic methods. "I challenge you to eat something grown here with something from Tesco's and not tell the difference immediately." Looking around at the ramshackle buildings, it's hard not to compare the openness of allotment culture, the way the jerry-built sheds have no locks, with the prim toy-town neatness of the suburban garden shed. Then you get a sense of how oddly repressive the latter can be. Keeping an allotment may not be everybody's cup of tea, but, as Eli states with passion, the allotments are "a kind of paradise, somewhere you can escape from reality. It's better than going to the doctor."

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Wing it: chicken stock, part 1
fields.trailText: Wing it: chicken stock, part 1.
fields.body:
The subject
The mystical commingling of chicken and water, as mystical cooks might say. Water in which chicken is heated until its sapid compounds and gelatine are extracted, as Knowledge-type geeks might say. Fond de volaille, as the French and the pretentious might say.

The basics
Dozens of cookbooks write the perfect prescription for chicken stock - though they never agree, of course, on what constitutes perfection. And why should they agree, when it's so charmingly easy? Fact: you can cook successful chicken stock in around 8,000 different ways as long as you follow four basic rules. One: never let the water boil. Its surface should experience nothing more violent than a gentle breaking of bubbles. Two: do not rely solely on cooked chicken. Much of the flavour's gone, gone, gone. Three: if using other ingredients, don't let them dominate. Chicken stock should taste mainly of chicken. Four: use any edible part of the bird except the liver, which makes cloudy, yucky stock.

The details
Put chicken scraps - wings, necks, backs, etc - in a pot. Add water to cover by an inch or two, and heat till you've got a steady, gentle simmer. Continue like this for a couple of hours, or longer if it suits you. At some point, skim off the frothy scum that appears on the surface. When you find that the chicken no longer has any taste (because it's all migrated to the H 2 O), strain the liquid. Get rid of the fat. You have made chicken stock. It was about as difficult as blinking. If you chose to add secondary flavourings, it was as difficult as blinking and breathing at the same time.

Where to buy
Chicken scraps are ignored by supermarkets, plentiful chez le boucher (as we say in Pretench). Beg, borrow, steal or even buy a huge supply, then make enough to fill the freezer. Result: you're set up in the stock market for many months. Warning: some cookbooks solemnly inform us that stock shouldn't be frozen for longer than two months. Warning: they are solemnly mistaken.

The easy way out
You just read it. Things get interesting next week, in Chicken Stock: La Deux.

webTitle: Leader: verbal sniping in the US Elections

fields.headline: Snollygosters at war
fields.standfirst:
A new mot juste for snipers and snarlers

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A new mot juste for snipers and snarlers
fields.body:
Be warned. In pubs, on street corners, in bedrooms and boudoirs, even in primary school playgrounds, wherever people start wrangling, we shall soon be hearing the cry: "You don't need to get snippy about it". That is what Al Gore said to George W Bush during that tense and historic phone call, hitting with faultless instinct on a word which, blending snappy with chippy, triumphantly said it all. This, though, is no new transatlantic concoction. In 18th century England it meant stingy or covetous; by the mid 19th century it had edged much closer to the sense in which Mr Gore used it: fault-finding, snappish, supercilious.

A word which, like this one, not only conveys its own meaning but hints at other related ones, is doubly blessed. And few groups of words are as useful for verbal snipers, those who sneer, snap and snarl, who resort to the snide, sniffy, snarky, snooty and snotty, as those which begin with an s and an n. That is not to say that all belong exclusively to the world of vituperation. Snug and snuggle are cosy agreeable concepts. So is snow, except when it's clogging the roads and blocking the railways. (So even is sny, rarely employed nowadays, which means taking an upward curve.) But it must be some sign that words beginning s-n mean trouble that the novelist William Faulkner awarded a horrid family which haunts his pages the surname of Snopes.

Given the present tensions, it seems a fair bet that Democrats and Republicans will be snip-snapping away at each other - ie indulging in smart repartee, speaking in a snappy manner, clipping with a snipping sound (rare) - for weeks. By Thursday one or other may be invoking the snallygaster, a mythical monster supposedly found in Maryland (though perhaps now in Florida too). At which those so assailed may denounce their detractors as snollygosters (US: a shrewd unprincipled person, especially a politician of this class.) Just wait till concepts like that get into the playground.

fields.headline: Freight 'cancelling out' warming curbs
fields.trailText: International trade growth, with more use of aircraft and lorries, is making a mockery of attempts by world leaders to curb global warming, according to economists.
fields.body:
International trade growth, with more use of aircraft and lorries, is making a mockery of attempts by world leaders to curb global warming, according to economists.

A report published today reveals uncontrolled growth of greenhouse gas emissions from international freight. According to the report, entitled Collision Course, emissions from the transport sector will cancel out the benefits of reducing green house gas emissions by more efficient use of fossil fuels elsewhere.

The report comes out two days before 160 nations meet in the Hague to negotiate reductions in greenhouse gas emissions, and in the same week that the chancellor cut fuel duty to buy off lorry drivers.

The report says that greenhouse gas emissions from transport are among the fastest growing contributors to climate change. Road freight and aviation, the most polluting methods of moving freight, are increasing dramatically.

The situation is worse in the EU, where demand for more freight is growing faster than the economy, and railways, inland waterways and coastal shipping are losing out to road transport and air freight. Just-in-time deliveries mean more lorries running empty - in fact, up to 30% of all journeys.

Andrew Simms, co-author of the report, says the world economy is hooked on fossil fuels, an addiction that is taking a heavy toll on the environment.

"Just like normal addicts, our politicians and economists construct elaborate excuses to justify their destructive addiction," said Mr Simms. "We have to return to a scale of economic activity that is humanly and environmentally sustainable."

He added: "If the projected 70% rise in international freight transport materialises by 2004 the resulting increase in greenhouse gas emissions will make a mockery of both the reduction targets set for industrialised countries and the current exclusion of international freight from climate controls."


What a Waste

Kiwifruit Carried by plane from New Zealand to Europe; 5kg of carbon dioxide pumped into the atmosphere for every 1kg of fruit carried.

Asparagus 1kg of asparagus from California uses 4kg of aviation fuel. If grown in Europe, 900 times less energy would be used.

Apples Importing South African apples rather than growing them within 20 miles of the selling point causes 600 times as much nitrogen oxide pollution.

Strawberry yoghurt Delivering full glasses of yoghurt to Germany involved a total journey of 5,000 miles for the ingredients.

Orange Juice 80% of orange juice drunk in Europe comes from Brazil. For every tonne consumed at least 25 tonnes of materials are used up. Blackcurrant juice produced in Europe would be just as nutritional.

webTitle: Blair looks to future, but rains still fall

fields.headline: Blair looks to the future, but the rains still fall
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The prime minister was barracked by flood victims yesterday as fresh warnings of heavy rain threatened to end a brief respite for thousands living near swollen rivers.
fields.body:
The prime minister was barracked by flood victims yesterday as fresh warnings of heavy rain threatened to end a brief respite for thousands living near swollen rivers.

Protesters hounded Tony Blair in Chichester, West Sussex, where the Lavant has inundated central streets, six years after causing £2m damage to homes and businesses. Mr Blair left to shouts of "It's all right for you in your warm office, but we've waited six years."

He later toured defences on the Severn, in Gloucestershire, and announced an inter-agency task force to respond to the aftermath of the floods. One issue for the group, which will be headed by the countryside minister, Elliot Morley, will be new flood defences, spotlighted at Chichester by the paralysis of plans for a huge flood barrier.

The chairman of the environment agency, Sir John Harman, spoke yesterday of unease about "a series of Berlin walls across Britain". Speaking in North Yorkshire, where he inspected the vast temporary lake along the Ouse near Selby, Sir John said that new defences "should not be a matter of pouring huge quantities of concrete everywhere".

"We're going to have to work with nature, not against her, using washlands to let water escape and soft buffers - landscaped dykes - rather than concrete walls."

The Chichester scheme has been stalled by residents' ob jections to the scale and size of the work, which is due to be followed by a further £51m of flood barriers. Mr Blair told the protesters: "The money is there and the scheme is prepared. We want to do everything we can."

Gloucester and the lower Severn valley were nervously waiting for fresh rain forecast for today, which threatened to coincide with the river's tidal bore from the Bristol Channel. Adam Leavy, of the environment agency, said: "Levels in some areas of the Severn are already several inches higher than they were last week."

Five severe flood warnings were in place on the Severn last night, five in the midlands, two in the south-east, five in Wales and eight in Yorkshire and the north-east. A breach in flood barriers south of Selby allowed millions of gallons into fields around Howden and Knedlington.

Sir John warned that tighter planning restrictions might be necessary along rivers such as the Ouse. He said: "A defence system designed to deal with one major flood every 100 years may not cope if they happen more frequently. We already object to developments if we have concerns about flooding - a total of 1,000 last year - and this could increase."

The Met Office said rain in the south-east too would continue well into today, with showers tomorrow. The environment agency warned residents in all recently flooded areas to be vigilant and said waterlogged ground meant that no swift end to the flooding was in sight.

webTitle: Haemophiliacs share 'safer' blood to beat rationing

fields.headline: Sufferers share 'safer' blood to beat rationing
fields.trailText: Evidence is emerging of a "black market" between patients offered different treatments for haemophilia because of where they live.
fields.body:
Evidence is emerging of a "black market" between patients offered different treatments for haemophilia because of where they live.

Campaigners for those suffering from the condition are increasingly worried by reports that patients who get laboratory produced blood products on the NHS are sending part of their supply through the post to others who are receiving human derived material instead.

The practice is almost certainly illegal and the Department of Health warned it could also be extremely dangerous. A growing number of patients who cannot get alternatives to the human product are also believed to be doing without clotting factors at all, because of concerns over safety.

The Haemophilia Society, while not condoning such actions, said the government must act immediately to remedy the "scandalous" situation, saying "grossly unfair" prescribing policies were depriving 600-700 patients in England from access to drugs which were freely available to children throughout Britain and to adults in Scotland and Wales.

It knew of patients in the west midlands and in Newcastle who were refusing the human derived product, and callers to a helpline who indicated they were taking similar steps. The health minister, Lord Hunt, has agreed to meet society leaders over the issue and local health authorities are likely to be called into discussions.

Two years ago the government ordered the import from other countries of most blood plasma products, because of the theoretical risk that British products could transmit the human form of BSE. It also made all health authorities provide recombinant alternative for children under 16. Those in Scotland and Wales extended the provision too.

Karen Pappenheim, director of the Haemophilia Society, said a local health authority in one case "seems happy to let him do his own thing as long as it is not costing the NHS anything. It is scandalous. If he was living in Wales or Scotland, he would be getting recombinant [genetically engineered clotting product]". She added: "We do not recommend that anyone withhold treatment from themselves because they could put their lives at risk. However, the haemophilia community is in a no-win situation."

Some people had moved home to get to an area where recombinant was available.

Although blood products were probably now safer than they had been, the haemophilia community has been devastated by the HIV and hepatitis C contaminations. Those with weak immune systems already may be more susceptible to attack by other viruses that still defeat blood treatments. A Department of Health spokeswoman said last night: "We don't advise any patient to take any medication not specifically prescribed for them. It can be extremely dangerous."

webTitle: Move to lend back Elgin marbles

fields.headline: Move to lend back marbles
fields.trailText: MPs campaigning to return the Elgin Marbles to Greece have opened a new front at the Council of Europe in Strasbourg to put pressure on the government.
fields.body:
MPs campaigning to return the Elgin Marbles to Greece have opened a new front at the Council of Europe in Strasbourg to put pressure on the government.

A plan has been put forward to hand the sculptures - kept in the British Museum since being removed from the Parthenon in 1816 - to the trusteeship of the British School at Athens so they can be displayed in Greece's new archaeological museum next to the Acropolis.

The proposal was tabled at Strasbourg by Labour MPs Edward O'Hara and Thomas Cox and has attracted the support of MPs from Spain, Ireland, Germany, Cyprus and Greece. Eight other Labour backbenchers, including Paul Flynn, Ann Cryer, Lawrence Cunliffe and Rudi Vis, have backed the proposal.

The Council of Europe has no powers to direct governments, but makes recommendations regarding Europe's cultural heritage. The motion says the UK has the technical and legal means to display the sculptures in Greece without conceding their ownership.

webTitle: Anger of haemophiliac who waits for post

fields.headline: Anger of victim who waits for the post
fields.trailText: Andy, 36, waits for the packages in plain brown envelopes to arrive in the post. Over four months he has had around 20 deliveries, containing bottles of white powder and sterilised water to make the solution that he injects when the bleeding into his joints becomes too severe to endure.
fields.body:
Andy, 36, waits for the packages in plain brown envelopes to arrive in the post. Over four months he has had around 20 deliveries, containing bottles of white powder and sterilised water to make the solution that he injects when the bleeding into his joints becomes too severe to endure.

He uses these covert, free supplies of genetically engineered recombinant clotting factor instead of the human derived equivalent that is all his health authority will pay for. "There is an underground network. There are concerned families who get recombinant and don't want to see other haemophiliacs exposed to unknown viruses. They are cutting back on their own supply to supply people like me."

He does not get as much of the drug as he would like, but finds it more effective than the one he has dis carded. He has reduced the times he treats the pain. "I use it only for severe bleeds into my ankles and knees, when it is almost impossible to move." He says he is saving the authority over £9,000 a month by not using the NHS product.

Fifteen years ago Andy was infected by HIV and hepatitis C through contaminated clotting factor. He says it cost him his marriage, the ability to have children and his job, and he refuses to accept assurances that he will not be infected by other viruses from the human product. "There seems to be an attitude, 'Well, you have got everything already so why should we give recombinant to you'. "

The health authority concerned said it followed government guidance on access to recombinant. Its policy was based on "good evidence that the risks (from human product) are not as great as those perceived by the patients".
