fields.headline: 'Must keep smiling' - Rosie's diary charts a week cut off by the deluge
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Rosie Hicks, 50, a retired teacher, has been cut off for a week by the swollen Ouse in Yorkshire. She and her partner David, 44, get around the hamlet of Ryther, near Selby, by canoe. A few miles upstream David's daughter Kathryn lives on the first floor of her flooded home in Naburn. Here is Rosie's Diary of the Great Flood.
fields.body:
Rosie Hicks, 50, a retired teacher, has been cut off for a week by the swollen Ouse in Yorkshire. She and her partner David, 44, get around the hamlet of Ryther, near Selby, by canoe. A few miles upstream David's daughter Kathryn lives on the first floor of her flooded home in Naburn. Here is Rosie's Diary of the Great Flood.

Mon Oct 30 Wild day, cold, blowing a gale and snowing sideways. Decorators here to finish glossing bedroom windows, which have to be left open to dry - snow blowing in. Grey, soggy, cold, and foreboding.

Tues Oct 31 Wake to find lanes of water running across fields towards us. River rising alarmingly, barometer dropped to its lowest possible. Kathryn phones: "Hi Rosie, you and Dad OK? Isn't it great, we're totally cut off!" The joy of youth.

Wed Nov 1 Decorator finishes and dashes off to escape rising water at front gate. The moggies catching dozens of mice trying to escape from the fields.

Thurs Nov 2 Begin to feel anxious. Water still rising, five-bar gate is now two-bar gate and we can't get to it. Pumps arrive to clear gardens, garages and drains in village. Dyke now a lake: dark, deep water - spooky, frightening. Must keep smiling but can't really; it's depressing. Helicopters fly over on regular basis. I've a sinking feeling. Keep on Radio York, it's a lifeline - helplines, river reports, sandbags, evacuation. Is it a war zone? Army, police, environment agency, green goddesses - it's beginning to really worry me, do they know we are cut off? I feel disorientated; the land's now the sea.

Fri Nov 3 Still raining, still rising. Electricity off; light open fires, must keep warm.

More floods on TV - Alan Titchmarsh advises not to walk on lawns to clear leaves. Well Alan, our leaves float!

Sat Nov 4 At last rains stop. My spirits are lifted, then drop when I hear forecast. It's all consuming, my mind is strewn with new flood vocabulary: overtopping, peaks, high and low tide times, evacuation procedures.

Feel a bit desperate.

We get out the inflatable canoe and go up to village. Back home, septic tank disappeared under water, drains are backing up to house and rising. Can't use toilets, sinks or baths - find portable camping loo in the garage, put it in bath in case it leaks. Charming. Kathryn phones: "We got to Tesco by ferry!"

Sun Nov 5 We won't be lighting our bonfire, it's in the new lake. Radio forecasts heavy prolonged rain - no end in sight. We must get out somehow, so head for Cawood in car. Water deep at Button Hill, but car jet-skis through. Eyes closed and fingers crossed as the water flows over the bonnet. Co-op has no bread, shelves depleted; stock up with tins, packets, candles, firelighters, longlife milk, and batteries. Head home as fast as possible. Made it, just.

Mon Nov 6 Grey, cold, and pouring down. Despondent. Garage floods. Five-bar gate gone, totally submerged, must be over 4 ft deep in inky black scary stuff.

Tues Nov 7 Pouring. No refuse collection, burning what we can. Try to walk to Cawood, reach Button Hill - no chance, must be 3 ft deep. David says: "Let's walk along top of metal flood barrier." "What if it's only few inches wide? Must be mad." "Don't look sideways." I do, and my arms fly out and stomach loops. Home to see army evacuate elderly neighbour and little special needs boy minutes before Button Hill totally impassable.

Dark outside, lights blown, quiet except for 24-hour roar of pumps and driving rain.

Wed Nov 8 Feel very alone, only the six homes together, totally cut off. Civil defence guys arrive with boat to reassure us. They inform us we are now "monitored" and Ernie erects sign: No Road - Water 5 ft deep. David's dad phones to say we've been on the radio: "You're officially cut off."

Thurs Nov 9 Checked the tree trunks in the water, level fallen 8 inches. Down is good, not raining is good. Walk to river, remains stubbornly high. Back home, check gas tank: nearly empty; turn down heating. Kathryn phones: "Carpets are soaked and stink, what shall I do?"

Friday Nov 10 Glorious sunshine, not used to this; but water's still here. Long range forecast says force 11 gales, severe storms running up to Christmas. Start Xmas shopping list hoping I will get to a shop one day - priorities: wet suits, thermals, chainsaw, generator, pumps with very long pipes, torches and plenty of medicinal liquid, not water.

webTitle: 'Torso killer' granted bail by appeal court

fields.headline: 'Torso killer' granted bail by appeal court
fields.trailText: A convicted double murderer at the centre of one of Britain's longest running miscarriage of justice cases has been released from jail after the court of appeal granted him bail.
fields.body:
A convicted double murderer at the centre of one of Britain's longest running miscarriage of justice cases has been released from jail after the court of appeal granted him bail.

Robert Maynard, 61, was sentenced to life in jail 25 years ago for the murders of Billy Moseley and Micky Cornwall, crimes he has always denied.

The case became known as the "torso murders" when parts of Moseley's body were washed up on the banks of the river Thames.

Maynard and his alleged accomplice Reg Dudley were convicted of murder at the Old Bailey in 1977 and had an appeal dismissed in 1979. Dudley was given parole in 1997. The pair have always protested their innocence.

Their cases were recommended for review by the criminal cases review commission, which spent three years examining the evidence.

The prosecution said Maynard and Dudley killed Mr Moseley either because he was having an affair with another criminal's wife or because he had accused Dudley of being an informer.

Mr Cornwall was murdered because he knew the killers' identities and vowed to avenge his friend, the juryheard.

From the outset campaigners were concerned about the safety of the convictions. There were no witnesses to the murders, nor forensic evidence.

The prosecution relied heavily on the the testimony of an armed robber, Tony Wild, who said he overheard Maynard and Dudley boast about the killings when they were at Brixton prison, south London.

But Wild, a born-again christian, admitted that he had lied because he wanted a lighter sentence for a robbery charge.

Mr Dudley said: "He has been in for 25 years now and that is quite enough for an innocent man. This also gives a great boost to our appeal." The appeal is expected to be heard in the spring.

fields.headline: Terrorist 'has alibi' for Lockerbie
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: A Palestinian terrorist accused by the defence team in the Lockerbie trial of responsibility for the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 has an alibi for the night of the atrocity, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A Palestinian terrorist accused by the defence team in the Lockerbie trial of responsibility for the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 has an alibi for the night of the atrocity, a court heard yesterday.

In a move designed to scupper defence plans to lay the blame for the mass murder at the hands of Palestinian terrorist organisations, the crown yesterday called Abu Talb as its last crucial witness.

Egyptian-born Talb is serving a life sentence in Sweden for a bombing attack. At the start of the trial the defence lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming Talb, members of the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command (PFLP-GC) and other Palestinian terrorists for the bombing.

Talb's appearance had been delayed for several weeks as defence lawyers sought to investigate new evidence which claims to detail how the bomb was made and how it got on board the Pan Am jumbo.

The evidence, widely seen as originating from Syria, is said to be crucial to the special defence. Lawyers for the two Libyans accused of the bombing, Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, had asked for Talb's evidence to be delayed further to allow Syria time to respond to court requests for information.

As he took the stand yesterday Talb, 46, admitted he was a member of the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front (PPSF) and said he had been active in the struggle since 1974.

The investigation into the Lockerbie bombing initially focused on Palestinian terrorist groups, including the PPSF and the PFLP-GC. Intelligence officials believed the attack was a reprisal for the destruction of an Iranian airbus by the USS Vincennes in the Gulf in 1988.

But the Scottish court in the Netherlands heard that Talb was at home in Sweden a few hours after flight 103 blew up over Lockerbie on December 21 1988, killing all 259 passengers and crew on board and 11 people on the ground.

Asked by advocate depute Alastair Campbell QC where he was when his wife's sister-in-law had a baby in the early hours of December 22, Talb said: "The women went to visit the hospital and I stayed at home to care for the young children."

The crown also sought to destroy expected defence claims that Talb was in Malta shortly before the bombing.

The bomb is alleged to have been planted on a plane in Malta, before it was transferred to flight 103 at Frankfurt. Stamps on Talb's Swedish travel documents showed he had left Malta on October 26.

The trial was adjourned until Tuesday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Taxi driver on medal charge
fields.body:
Taxi driver on medal charge

Taxi driver Terry Sandford, 41, of Bexleyheath, south-east London, appeared at Uxbridge magistrates' court yesterday charged with the theft of rower Matthew Pinsent's Olympic gold medal. The case was adjourned until December 11.

Radio comedy actor dies

Hugh Paddick, the actor best known for his contribution to the 1960s radio comedy Round The Horne, has died aged 85, his manager confirmed yesterday. Paddick was one half of camp comic duo Julian and Sandy alongside Kenneth Williams in the BBC Light Programme's Sunday show.

New judge for Ulster inquiry

A Canadian judge, William Esson, has been appointed as a reserve member of the Bloody Sunday inquiry tribunal. The tribunal's public hearings are due to resume in the Guildhall, Londonderry, on Monday after a summer recess.

Ex-convict wins book award

Edward Bunker, a former convict who starred as Mr Blue in the movie Reservoir Dogs, yesterday took the Macallan Dagger crime writing award for a memoir of his life.

Museums get £46m

Government sponsored museums and galleries are to receive an extra £46m over the next three years, it was announced yesterday.

fields.headline: Police car pursuit deaths up 50%
fields.trailText: The number of people killed in high-speed police chases rose by more than 50% last year, prompting serious concern about the skill and judgment of some drivers, according to the police complaints authority.
fields.body:
The number of people killed in high-speed police chases rose by more than 50% last year, prompting serious concern about the skill and judgment of some drivers, according to the police complaints authority.

Its study showed that officers ought to race to incidents only where lives were in danger, said the authority, and the public should not be "put at risk in defence of property".

Sir Alistair Graham, the PCA chairman, refused to be more specific or say there should be an outright ban on speeding except in certain situations. The study, published yesterday, also showed there was a record number of complaints of racism against the police last year; the authority investigated 579 cases, up 75% from 1998/1999. In the same period the number of people who died in custody fell from 36 to 19.

According to figures, 22 died in accidents involving police cars last year. Sixteen more were seriously injured. In one incident, an 83-year-old man was killed when a police car following a vehicle crashed into him; the police driver has been committed for trial charged with causing death through dangerous driving.

The report said only 16 of the 44 forces in England and Wales had implemented the 1998 Lind report recommending improved pursuit driver training. "There is worrying evidence the skill and judgment of some police drivers are open to question and criticism," said Sir Alistair; "...excessive speed can seldom be justified, except where life is endangered or where there is some other serious physical threat.

"We do not feel the public and officers should be put at risk in defence of property. While the law permits officers to breach traffic regulations, this should only be when it is justified by the risk of the emergency." The report welcomed the Met's decision to fit aircraft-style black boxes in patrol cars, and hoped it would set a precedent. Overall, the authority received 17,932 complaints against officers, including 182 of serious assault, 64 of sexual assault, and 78 of corrupt practice.

Sir Alistair said the increase in racial complaints may have been an effect of the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, published in February last year. "It may reflect a greater willingness by members of the black and minority ethnic community to register a concern about how they feel they have been treated."

Commenting on the report, the Commission for Racial Equality said discrimination in the police service was at a worrying level and a matter of "extreme concern".

webTitle: Bison farmers beef up supply with imports

fields.headline: Bison farmers beef up supply with imports
fields.trailText: Britons' search for more exotic tastes is heading westwards to the prairies. Farmers who have already begun raising bison for consumers on our smaller pastures say demand is outstripping supply.
fields.body:
Britons' search for more exotic tastes is heading westwards to the prairies. Farmers who have already begun raising bison for consumers on our smaller pastures say demand is outstripping supply.

They now intend to launch the British Bison Meat Company later this month to import the meat from Canada and are hoping to interest supermarkets and restaurants.

Enthusiasts say bison meat is better for consumers than the conventional alternatives. The handful of British herds only have between 200 and 250 animals in total.

Lord and Lady Seaford, among the prime movers behind the company, have been selling bison meat to private customers for about 10 years from their farm at West Knoyle, Wiltshire.

"It is like best quality Scotch beef without the fat and cholesterol. It is much healthier," said Lady Seaford. "The majority of people we have sold to over the past few years have been first timers, but then they have come back again and again."

Her husband started the herd "because he had always wanted to since he was a boy". "They are gentle little things. The breeding bull is big but the cows are smaller than the average Friesian."

The meat is sold as sausages, burgers and rump, sirloin or fillet steak, and was sold at a premium price. The new arrangements with a firm in Calgary, Alberta, would allow unlimited supply. "We will import as much as the market will hold," Lady Seaford said. "At the moment we don't have enough to supply supermarkets or anything like that. If we are going to start importing more we are going to have to be more professional selling to restaurants and bigger chains."

The couple also farm deer and wapiti, better known as elk.

Ruth and George Wakeling, partners in the business, have about 40 bison on their farm at Nether Broughton, near Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire. "People are buying as a novelty but coming back for more," she said. "Bison is sweeter than beef. Although it is more expensive, people are more aware of what they are eating and what goes into the animal. These are on grass and molasses.

Bison can be dangerous and need wild animal licences, "but if you leave them alone, they are quite happy".

Owners in Britain have to comply with BSE rules that apply to all cow-like animals. But they are angry that they get no EU compensation, unlike traditional beef and dairy farmers.

The food standards agency said last night: "As long as the meat is safe to eat it is a matter of consumer choice."

The search for exotic foods in this country does not have a happy history. In the wake of the BSE crisis entrepreneurs have tried widening the market for ostrich, alligator and kangaroo, with limited success and complaints from vegetarian and animal rights groups.

webTitle: Bangkok prince orders takeaway - from Warwickshire

fields.headline: Bangkok prince orders a Thai takeaway - from Warwickshire
fields.trailText: Any restaurant would be delighted to receive a royal seal of approval. But one establishment in Stratford-upon-Avon was stunned when the future King of Thailand ordered an airmail consignment of its speciality, Thai food.
fields.body:
Any restaurant would be delighted to receive a royal seal of approval. But one establishment in Stratford-upon-Avon was stunned when the future King of Thailand ordered an airmail consignment of its speciality, Thai food.

Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn, 49, ordered 350 parcels of the delicate, traditional raw ingredients - not cooked dishes - including pork balls and salads, to be flown almost 6,000 miles to his palace in Bangkok.

A "gobsmacked" spokesman for the Thai Kingdom restaurant, which imports many of its ingredients daily from Thailand, said the order was placed after the prince dropped in for lunch during a private visit to England last month.

Staff from the London embassy travelled to Warwickshire to pick up the raw food and dispatch it on a 12-hour Thai Airways flight. Yesterday the embassy was diplomatic about what could only be described as taking coals to Newcastle. "It's not very happy for us to comment, because he was making a personal, private visit," said a spokesman. Asked if it seemed peculiar to spend so much, he responded: "I don't know, but perhaps the restaurant was offering a new menu. We haven't tasted the food ourselves."

A spokeswoman added: "I don't know if he ordered them to cook to have himself, or to give to his friends and relatives to try. This is certainly the first time that we have had these sort of instructions."

The Thai Kingdom restaurant was almost as reticent. "It's a great honour for us, but the embassy has asked us not to talk about it. We have to be tight lipped," said the British owner, who preferred not to be named. "He ordered 350 items which were not dishes but a selection of classical Thai ingredients. We're not talking about containerloads of food; they were small, delicate items - like most Thai food.

"It may seem a long way to fly food, but I suppose that what the prince likes, he gets. If he's happy, everybody else is happy. It's a great honour, especially for the staff. They are gobsmacked."

Yesterday the embassy was diplomatic about what could only be described as taking coals to Newcastle. "It's not very happy for us to comment, because he was making a personal, private visit," said a spokesman. Asked if it seemed peculiar to spend so much, he responded: "I don't know, but perhaps the restaurant was offering a new menu. We haven't tasted the food ourselves." A spokeswoman added: "I don't know if he ordered them to cook to have himself, or to give to his friends and relatives to try. This is certainly the first time that we have had these sort of instructions." The Thai Kingdom restaurant was almost as reticent. "It's a great honour for us, but the embassy has asked us not to talk about it. We have to be tight lipped," said the British owner, who preferred not to be named. "He ordered 350 items which were not dishes but a selection of classical Thai ingredients. We're not talking about containerloads of food; they were small, delicate items - like most Thai food. "It may seem a long way to fly food, but I suppose that what the prince likes, he gets. If he's happy, everybody else is happy. It's a great honour, especially for the staff. They are gobsmacked."

fields.headline: On the road to ruin
fields.trailText: I was interested in the suggestion from a road haulier (Letters, November 8) that "the small operators and particularly the owner-operators could collectively agree minimum prices below which they would not bid for work".
fields.body:
I was interested in the suggestion from a road haulier (Letters, November 8) that "the small operators and particularly the owner-operators could collectively agree minimum prices below which they would not bid for work".

Although not wishing to minimise the problems he faces, I should point out that forming a price-fixing cartel would lead to the additional problem of an investigation under the Competition Act 1998 and potential fines of up to 10% of turnover.
Adrian Walker-Smith
Director, Cartel investigations, Office of Fair Trading

 I was amused to see on TV a truck driver complaining about a "police state" because he might be arrested for breaking the law. I don't think he has got the hang of this non-violent direct action thing - people who build tree houses and dig tunnels to protest against road building accept that they are acting illegally but are willing to accept the consequences because they have a higher purpose. I wonder how the same trucker would react to the suggestion that they should not be arrested?
Thomas Baldwin
Berwick-upon-Tweed
thomasjbaldwin@hotmail.com

fields.headline: We're still counting
fields.trailText: It's grossly unfair to blame the Green party for Gore's apparent defeat (Letters, November 9) when it is the electoral system itself that is clearly at fault. If the US had adopted the system we used in London to elect the mayor, this mess could have been avoided.
fields.body:
It's grossly unfair to blame the Green party for Gore's apparent defeat (Letters, November 9) when it is the electoral system itself that is clearly at fault. If the US had adopted the system we used in London to elect the mayor, this mess could have been avoided.

People who voted for me as their first choice could happily put Ken Livingstone down as their second choice without any danger of letting Steve Norris in. Ken and myself are visiting Washington in January so perhaps we can explain it to them.
Darren Johnson
Leader of the Green Group, London Assembly
darren.johnson@london.gov.uk

 The Florida CBS exit poll has been vilified. But isn't it now apparent that that poll was more scientific than the real thing: the voters told the pollsters how they thought they had voted.
Gerry Bond
Reading
gwbond@ntlworld.com

Tim Venner
Chorleywood, Herts

 Stephen Hawking has predicted the end of the world. Could he calculate the more likely cause, an asteroid hitting the Earth in 30 years, or George W Bush becoming president?
Sam Elfer
Keele, Staffs
samelfer@hotmail.com

 And we thought that messing up the Grand National was embarrassing.
Toby Dykes
London
toby_dykes@hotmail.com

Bush and Gore should have a penalty shoot-out.
Martin Davidson
London
DavidsonMR@aol.com

Street, Somerset

webTitle: Letters: Novel ways of product placement

fields.headline: Whisky galore revisited
fields.trailText: Bill Fitzhugh is to be congratulated (To sell out takes a lot of bottle, Media Guardian, November 6), for succeeding in turning placement for Glenlivet whisky in his new novel into a news story. However, contrary to the claims made in his article, he is not the first writer to do this.
fields.body:
Bill Fitzhugh is to be congratulated (To sell out takes a lot of bottle, Media Guardian, November 6), for succeeding in turning placement for Glenlivet whisky in his new novel into a news story. However, contrary to the claims made in his article, he is not the first writer to do this.

Placements for whisky in novels must be one of the oldest tricks in the writer's book. I'd noticed as a teenager that certain authors continually referred to specific brands of whisky in their novels. So when I wrote my first book, Pure Mania (published in 1989), every time a character had a drink I made sure it was 100 Pipers Scotch. Once the book was back from the printers I got the publisher to send a copy to 100 Pipers, and almost by return post I received a crate of their delightful blend.

Another issue over which I differ with Fitzhugh is his choice of a smooth Speyside malt as something truly worthy of placement. Personally I prefer fiery island malts and the Islay whisky Laphroaig is heavily plugged in a new novel of mine to be published next summer.

Despite the fact that the Laphroaig distillery are an official whisky supplier to Prince Charles, I'm sure it will please them to be plugged in my book, called 69 Things to Do With a Dead Princess.
Stewart Home
London

webTitle: Letters: Tears for the International Brigade

fields.headline: Tears for the old brigade
fields.trailText: Your tribute to the British volunteers in the International Brigades in Spain on Remembrance Day is more than deserved (They shall not pass, November 10). However, by not mentioning their counterparts, the dozens or hundreds (for obvious reasons it wasn't easy to find many claimants to the honour, post-1945) of British volunteers who fought for fascism on Franco's side, you help to perpetuate the understandable but inaccurate postwar fiction that virtually the only fascists in Britain before the war had been the Mosleys and Lord Haw Haw.
fields.body:
Your tribute to the British volunteers in the International Brigades in Spain on Remembrance Day is more than deserved (They shall not pass, November 10). However, by not mentioning their counterparts, the dozens or hundreds (for obvious reasons it wasn't easy to find many claimants to the honour, post-1945) of British volunteers who fought for fascism on Franco's side, you help to perpetuate the understandable but inaccurate postwar fiction that virtually the only fascists in Britain before the war had been the Mosleys and Lord Haw Haw.

Some of them, like Peter Kemp, were secure enough in their social position to write their memoirs of the civil war without fear of opprobrium, but none of them ever explained how they felt about fraternising and fighting side by side with Nazis and Italian fascists from 1936 until March 1939, and then coming home and being sent to war against their fellow believers six months later.

It would be as ludicrous to doubt the courage and convictions of most British people in fighting totalitarianism after 1939 as it is to disguise the fact that, before then (and in line with most western countries), a very large proportion of the same sectors of society that then and now read the Daily Telegraph were keen on the spread of fascism - a fact reflected in government policy. Franco would not have won the civil war had it not been for the active support of the British government. By instigating the non-intervention farce, they made it possible for Hitler and Mussolini to do whatever they wanted in Spain, and deprived the legitimate (and democratic) Spanish government of the right to buy arms to defend itself.
G Gil
London

 As one of your grumpy but loyal readers, who wishes there was public funding for newspapers so she wouldn't have to endure quite so many pages full of yards of advertising as she hunts through for the good stuff, yesterday I found myself suddenly and unexpectedly rewarded.

As I read G2's profiles of the International Brigaders my eyes filled with tears. That these profiles of this extraordinary and heroic group of men and women were put together with sensitivity and skill by such a large team of journalists, was in itself a tribute from one generation to the deep political insight and courage of another.

Although Spain fell, not least because of the failure of the rest of democratic Europe to support her, the courage of the Brigaders inspired others to know they must fight. I recollect my father, whose pacifism was not untypical of his generation, telling me that it was the brutal defeat of Spain and the selfless heroism of the Brigaders which led him to take the badge of the broken rifle off his lapel. The defeat of fascism demanded a willingness to bear arms.

Thank you for making it possible to honour the last of the Brigaders while they are still with us.
Prof Hilary Rose
London
H.Rose@open.ac.uk

 I became quite depressed on noticing the number of senior citizens reading the Daily Mail at their morning coffee break from shopping. I made the connection, rightly or wrongly, that it was no wonder that the Daily Mail-reading person from the south of England seems to care little for the less well off among non-professional workers. The generally favourable reports of the demands of selfish hauliers and farmers further dampened my spirits.

And then I read of the survivors of the International Brigades. These outstanding men and women possessed values and ideals which should be an inspiration to all of us. The accounts of their heroism and desire to further democracy and the brotherhood of man (and woman) brought tears to my eyes and restored my faith in the goodness and kindness of man and woman - in these cases almost invariably the man and woman from the working classes.
David Griffith
Iver, Bucks

 The interviews with the last British survivors of the International Brigade were fascinating, moving and inspirational. They are the best thing I have ever read in the Guardian and doubly pleasing as I had given up newspapers for a while due to the overwhelmingly depressing nature of most of the news.
Daniel Neville
London

 As an independent film-maker currently developing a documentary on British volunteers in Spain, I found your G2 special moving and timely. As people gather this weekend at memorials to the two world wars, Guardian readers might like to know that there are poignant memorials to British International Brigade volunteers, erected with the support of councils and trade unions, in many of our cities and towns. They are well worth seeking out.
David Leach
London
dleach@globalnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Remember this
fields.standfirst: Time to consider both past and present
fields.trailText: Time to consider both past and present
fields.body:
At 11am today, the eleventh day of the eleventh month, the Royal British Legion is urging us to pause for two minutes and stand in silence. If we don't do it today, we will have another chance tomorrow, Remembrance Sunday. Either way, says the Legion, we ought to do it. It is our duty to fulfil that near-sacred promise: "We will remember them".

The Legion is pushing at an open door. For Britons already do remember those who fell in wartime, remembering the men killed between 1914 and 1918 with an intensity which has caught both veterans and historians by surprise. The Legion's own figures have nearly three in four Britons observing the silence last year, just four years after the campaign for its reintroduction.

Today's date relates, of course, to the 1918 armistice, with the success of the silence just one illustration of our burgeoning interest in that war. Bestselling novels by Pat Barker or Sebastian Faulks have struck a national chord with their evocations of life and death on the western front. The Oscar-winning director Sam Mendes chose to mark his return to the West End with a new play set during the closing days of the first world war. Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon remain staples of the national curriculum, while military archivists report a boom in inquiries, often from young people keen to learn what their great-grandparents did in the Great War. That conflict still makes news, too - whether the recent row over the upkeep of war graves or the inclusion in tomorrow's ceremony, for the first time, of those who were shot for desertion or mutiny.

What explains this surge of interest in a war that ended 82 years ago? The military historian John Keegan places great emphasis on the boom in family history and the teaching of the war poets - but these are symptoms rather than underlying cause. Others note that only a handful of veterans are left: as memory slips into history, we want to hear their stories first hand. But that explanation too is far from complete. Neither the Napoleonic nor Crimean wars were commemorated in this way, decades after they were done.

What makes this one different? Part of the answer lies with those who fell: this was not a professional army, but a conscript force drawn from every town, village and extended family in the land. Everyone has a connection to it. Moreover, 1914 feels very much like the end of the 19th century and the beginning of our own era, or at least of the 20th century. To understand it is to begin to understand our own time. For years, it also served a more ideological purpose: it stood as a parable of class war, with ordinary working lads led to their deaths by heartless, incompetent officer toffs - "lions led by donkeys".

Some new historical work has sought to revise that view, to note that the veterans hardly saw their service that way: many were proud of what they had done and were keen to remind later generations that they had, after all, won the war. The new historians note, too, that the lead general, so-called "Butcher" Haig, got a hero's funeral, attended by huge crowds, when he died in 1928. So there are myths as well as memory in the air this remembrance weekend. We should bear that in mind: that what we choose to remember often says less about the past than about the present. Armistice day used to be an occasion for spirited public debate about war and peace - which makes the two-minute silence all the more appropriate. Each one of us can use it in our own way, to remember the past - or to resolve to make a different future.

fields.headline: Bully off
fields.trailText: Teachers and schools are accused of ignoring the problem of bullying, doing nothing to prevent pupils suffering from the cruel aggression, verbal and physical, of their contemporaries. And yet Jane Thynne (Bully for you, November 8) is ashamed that her child "told the teacher".
fields.body:
Teachers and schools are accused of ignoring the problem of bullying, doing nothing to prevent pupils suffering from the cruel aggression, verbal and physical, of their contemporaries. And yet Jane Thynne (Bully for you, November 8) is ashamed that her child "told the teacher".

She says that to "turn them into a snitch" is worse than encouraging retaliatory aggressive behaviour. Teachers and schools can do nothing if they are not "told". We should be encouraging an open society rather than one which buries dirty secrets in pacts of silence.
Valerie Bird
Havant, Hampshire
valerie.bird@virgin.net

 Self-assertiveness training is an important part of modern psychotherapy. It is time that teachers started to encourage children to assert themselves with bullies instead of punishing them for hitting back.
Dr SE Browne
Dartford, Kent

webTitle: Letters: anonymity for male rape suspects

fields.headline: Crime with no name
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins (Anonymity in sex crimes, November 6) has, for once, surely missed the point. In deriding Paul Weller's call for the law to grant male rape suspects the same anonymity as that given to their alleged victims, he asserts that, in the interest of open justice, an alleged rapist has no more claim to anonymity than an alleged thief, murderer or fraudster.
fields.body:
Marcel Berlins (Anonymity in sex crimes, November 6) has, for once, surely missed the point. In deriding Paul Weller's call for the law to grant male rape suspects the same anonymity as that given to their alleged victims, he asserts that, in the interest of open justice, an alleged rapist has no more claim to anonymity than an alleged thief, murderer or fraudster.

However, in such cases, the prosecution's primary burden of proof is based on independent evidence or witnesses whereas, in many rape trials, the prosecution's evidence inevitably depends mainly on the believability or otherwise of the victim.

Given this unique distinction, which the law already acknowledges by its different treatment of a rape complainant, does not justice require us to follow the practice of some other countries and allow equal anonymity to complainant and accused alike, revealing the latter's name only in the event of a rape conviction?
Stephen Lucas
London

 I do not understand how denying anonymity to those charged with rape ranks as "one of the hallmarks of a democratic society". A balanced justice system is one that has the strength to protect victims and accused. Marcel Berlins fails to acknowledge that allegations of rape and sexual abuse are perceived differently to other crimes. As such, publicity has tended to provoke violent vigilantism rather than a respect for the democratic principles of "innocent until proven guilty". In the current climate, where the majority of people seem to believe that a sex offender is lurking on every street corner and media scaremongering is the norm, those who stand accused must be granted the special protection of anonymity prior to conviction.
M Salkeld
Pinner, Middx

webTitle: Pop Art is making a return to the capital

fields.headline: Popping back into fashion
fields.standfirst: Stewart Dalby discovers that Pop Art - with exhibits ranging from Marilyn Monroe to Mickey Mouse - is making a return to the capital
fields.trailText: Stewart Dalby discovers that Pop Art - with exhibits ranging from Marilyn Monroe to Mickey Mouse - is making a return to the capital.
fields.body:
The Pop Art movement is indelibly linked in most people's minds with the 1960s. Unlike popular music, say, it did not maintain its initial high level of interest and for a while went out of fashion. Now, however, there is a chance to look at what the phenomenon was all about and to buy some pieces.

Like the proverbial number 6 bus, nothing seems to come along for ages and then three turn up at once. On November 1 Christie's held an auction called Prints Go Pop, where an array of work from influential pop artists working in print was on sale.

On Wednesday Bonham's, as part of its Entertainment, Rock and Pop sale, displayed items which can be construed as pop art. From November 8 to December 8, there is an exhibition of work by Clive Barker, described as the most important sculptor of the British Pop Art movement at the Whitford Fine Art gallery, 6, Duke Street, London SW1 Y 6BN.

Although linked with the 1960s, pop art originated in the 1950s but like Rock and Roll it exploded into life a decade later. Christie's says: "The basic concept of the Pop Art movement was that of mass popular urban culture shared by all, irrespective of professional skills. Films, advertising, science fiction, pop music and American mass produced consumer goods were taken as the materials of the new art.

The items on sale at the Bonham auction were really entertainment items rather than mainstream Pop Art, according to Alexander Crum-Ewing, the specialist at Bonham's. There was a silkscreen print of Marilyn Monroe from the estate of Marilyn Monroe, though not by Andy Warhol, which was estimated at £100 to £200; a 1980s autograph of Darth Vader or, rather, the actor who played him in the Star Wars films, estimated at £80 to £100; and a bronze head of singer Joan Baez, estimated at £800 to £1,000.

The Christie's sale, by contrast, consisted of genuine 1960s prints. Their expert Murray Macauley feels that in Britain and America, which gave birth to the most influential strains of pop art, prints took pride of place.

Moreover, the 1960s saw the print trade flourishing with many of the best technical printers and studios at their commercial zenith. There were 150 prints at the sale, of which 88 per cent sold and most items reached their estimates with some doing very well.

One, The Museum Tour Suite by Bridget Riley, was estimated at £2,000 to £3,000 but sold for £8,225. Bridget Riley is undergoing a bit of a renaissance at the moment. But another by far less fashionable these days Alan Jones, called Life Class, was expected to fetch between £1,400 and £1,600 but in fact made £4,700.

A third print by Richard Hamilton called Adonis in Y-Fronts was priced at £1,500-£2,000 and sold for £2,820. Murray Macauley says: "Pop Art prints have been unfashionable for a long time. The reason we held this sale was that we felt there was a field of art which was under-utilised."

What the sale probably showed was that there is a renewed interest and demand, but that items are still modestly priced. You would not, for example, buy a David Hockney painting for £2,115, but this is what his print Melrose Avenue, part of his Hollywood series, fetched.

But if anyone charts the popularity, decline, then revival of interest it is probably Clive Barker who made a great stir in the 1960s. He had been to art school briefly but got bored and at the age of 19 left and worked for 18 months on the assembly line at the Vauxhall car factory in Luton. Barker remembers being impressed by the sight of enormous skips filled with chrome-plated lamps and the pleasure of seeing new cars lined up on the parking lot.

In retrospect Barker recognised that this spell in the factory was one of his most formative influences. Barker was unusual for a pop artist of the time in that he concentrated on sculpture. He turned everyday objects like coke bottles, paint boxes, pieces of old rope and a bucket into glamorous objets d'art by casting them in bronze and coating them in chrome.

In 1968 the avant garde art dealer Robert Fraser gave Barker his first one-man show, which gave Barker instant fame and was the beginning of a working relationship which lasted until Fraser's death in 1986.

There were many other exhibitions, but gradually he faded from view. The current show is his first for 18 years. There are 27 pieces, all work done since 1998. The prices are reasonable. An item called Mickey Mouse, a Bronze, is priced at £6,000, The Maltese Falcon and a Magnum is priced at £5,500. The cheapest pieces are Agent 007 at £1,400 and Lollipop at £1,250. This is not an auction so the prices are fixed, but I reckon there will be considerable interest.

 For further information telephone Whitford Fine Art, 020 7930 9332, or Caldell Douglas 020 7439 2822. Bonham's 020 7 393 3900 , Christie's South Kensington, 020 581 7611 or visit www.christies.com.

webTitle: Money matters becomes class subject at last

fields.headline: Money matters becomes class subject at last
fields.standfirst:
Personal finance teaching is being included in the national curriculum. Jill Papworth reports

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Personal finance teaching is being included in the national curriculum. Jill Papworth reports.
fields.body:
Parents concerned that their children are likely to leave school with little or no knowledge of money matters will welcome the news that, for the first time, personal finance has been included in the national curriculum.

Under the new curriculum introduced this autumn, "financial capability" is one of the topics teachers are expected to tackle in lessons devoted to "personal, social and health education" issues. And from August 2002, elements of personal finance will be covered when the new foundation subject of "citizenship" becomes part of the statutory curriculum at Key Stages 3 and 4 for 11 to 16-year-olds.

This doesn't mean your children are now going to get a thorough grounding on everything from investing for capital growth to choosing the right pension fund and come out of school as financial gurus. After all, it would be unrealistic to expect teachers, already coping with the demands of covering a jam-packed curriculum, to fit in more than the bare basics.

But at least it signals an attempt on the part of the Department for Education & Employment to see that children leave school better equipped to manage their personal finances and make choices as informed consumers.

Keen to promote personal finance on the curriculum, some financial services organisations are producing classroom resources for teachers and contributing funds to PFEG (Personal Finance Education Group), the independent charity set up to promote and facilitate the education of all UK school pupils about financial matters.

PFEG, which runs a useful website for teachers, including a wealth of information on available resources and case studies of classroom personal finance projects that can be readily downloaded, this week launched a quality mark for personal finance education resources.

PFEG chief executive Wendy van den Hende says: "Effective teaching of personal finance will be easier now that teachers can rely on the PFEG quality mark to identify resources that they can use in the classroom with confidence."

To gain the quality mark, providers have to meet a set of rigorous criteria and abide by a code of practice. The main principles underpinning the standard are:

 Resources are developed in partnership with teachers and tested in schools

 There is no promotion of branded products

 Educational benefits are of prime importance with resources linked firmly to the new curriculum

 Providers are committed to keeping PFEG informed about the availability of resources, many of which can be ordered directly through PFEG's website

 Providers agree to regular reviews

Of the four resources already awarded the quality mark, two are from ProShare, the organisation which promotes share ownership. ProShare's National Investment Programme, now in its ninth year and sent free this week to every secondary school in the UK, aims to teach students about the stock market by giving them a "virtual" £100,000 to build a portfolio of shares via an online game.

Classroom activities are designed to teach pupils about business and finance, how the City works and making investment decisions. There is a £2,000 prize for the school which increases the value of its portfolio the most by the end of the competition next April. Last year's winners were a team from Haberdashers' Aske's School for Girls in Borehamwood, Hert fordshire which increased the value of their portfolio from £100,000 to £800,000 in just three months.

ProShare's other kite-marked resource, Your Money Be Wise, is a handbook for teachers linked to the three secondary school key stages covering 11 to 19-year-olds. It is photocopiable and free to schools.

Money Counts, published by Beam Education on behalf of the Financial Services Authority (FSA), covers structured classroom activities at Key Stages 1 and 2 for 5 to 11-year-olds. The book is photocopiable and free to schools with extra copies £13.53 each.

Britannic Street, produced by Education and Youth on behalf of Britannic Assurance, is a multi-media resource pack consisting of video, CD Rom, website, student materials and teachers' guide. Covering financial capability issues at Key Stage 4 for 14 to 16-year-olds, the pack is free to schools with extra packs costing £5 each.

Next up for assessment is a range of "Face 2 Face With Finance" modules for sec ondary pupils from the NatWest Financial Literacy Centre for Education & Industry at the University of Warwick, and Mega Money, a set of activities for primary school pupils.

fields.headline: The school that can make a difference
fields.standfirst: Attending the School for Social Entrepreneurs has helped many disillusioned managers change their lives. James Smith explains why
fields.trailText: Attending the School for Social Entrepreneurs has helped many disillusioned managers change their lives. James Smith explains why...
fields.body:
British managers work the longest hours in Europe, are the most stressed out executives in the world and have poor work/life balance. What can be done to change this?

Ask Bertram Leslie, who for 30 years had worked for, and managed, construction companies around the world before he discovered the School for Social Entrepreneurs (SSE) in 1997.

He wanted to do something different - specifically for the public good rather than private profit. He applied for jobs in the voluntary sector but prospective employers were unwilling to accept that his extensive business management experience was relevant.

After a year with the SSE in London's East End, Bertram now develops projects in the voluntary sector on a freelance basis, working with a variety of organisations. He is currently working on a proposal for the £100m millennium awards endowment which is down to a shortlist of three.

SSE is the brainchild of Lord Young of Dartington, one of Britain's foremost social entrepreneurs, founder of the Consumers' Association and inventor of the Open University. It was set up in 1997 to identify, support and encourage entrepreneurial capacity among organisations and individuals working for public benefit. It provides year-long action learning programmes for would-be and existing social entrepreneurs to develop their talents.

The programme is bespoke, so it helps people move forward from any starting position. Bertram's classmates ranged in age from early 20s to early 70s. Some, like him, had experience in a business setting. Others were already working in the public, voluntary or community sectors but were looking to adapt their approach to work to become more entrepreneurial.

Others were individuals with an idea of how to improve society - such as Paul Collins, who was a personal fitness instructor before coming to SSE. He is now managing director of a new social business to promote and provide clinical exercise to people with medical conditions. The benefits of carefully prescribed exercise in rehabilitation and in chronic disease management are well documented. But how many doctors know where to send their patients for expert help in PE, primary care and other community-based settings?

How does SSE help someone like Paul? It provides advice on all aspects of setting-up and developing an organisation, such as fundraising, business-planning, organisational and charity law, dealing with the media and other useful business management skills. It gives access to social and commercial entrepreneurs who attend as guest speakers to talk about their experience.

SSE provides mentoring, Action Learning Sets and other help with the tough challenge of personal development, adapting one's own attitudes and behaviour to achieve success. And, perhaps most of all, it provides a ready-made network of peers similarly engaged in social entrepreneurship.

Tessa Dugmore, who has developed a community space, including a café and training rooms in a foyer project with Providence Row Housing Association, says: "I love the inter-connectedness and broad span of the school. The range of experience and contact my fellow students bring is a treasure trove in itself, especially for someone like me who is still at the beginning of a career.

"The concept of social entrepreneurship is crucially about our freedom to engage with society and try to change it for the better. It is participative democracy at its best, when people do not wait for the government, the local authority or someone else to come and solve their problems. As Nicholas Albery, of the Institute for Social Inventions, told SSE students: "When I face a personal problem I ask myself how can I tackle this problem in such a way that it solves similar problems for others in the future?"

Another speaker at SSE was successful social entrepreneur Julia Middleton, who set up Common Purpose to provide learning programmes for future leaders on all aspects of the operation of cities. Her words of wisdom? - "If you can raise the money, you can do anything. Some of today's most exciting and creative work is being done by social entrepreneurs, who are driven by vision not profit."

Which fits nicely with my favourite definition of entrepreneurship. Taken from business literature, but with no mention of profit, it says that an entrepreneur is someone who pursues opportunities without regard to resources currently under their control - that is someone who persuades someone else to pay for it. Add social and you define the opportunity as something of social, public or community benefit.

Didn't someone say that philosophers have interpreted the world in various ways, the whole point, however, is to change it. If you agree sign up, the School for Social Entrepreneurs is currently recruiting for its next National Programme starting in January 2001.

 James Smith is director of the School for Social Entrepreneurs , 18 Victoria Park Square, Bethnal Green London E2 9PF. Tel: 020 8981 0300.

fields.headline: The great escapist
fields.standfirst: He has been everywhere, seen everything and written books that have become classics - all with minimal formal education and a background as a car dealer, wedding photographer and spy.  Nicholas Wroe finds him at 92 still a master of travellers' tales
fields.trailText: He has been everywhere, seen everything and written books that have become classics - all with minimal formal education and a background as a car dealer, wedding photographer and spy. Nicholas Wroe finds him at 92 still a master of travellers' tales
fields.body:
The opening scene of Norman Lewis's autobiography features him as a young boy being pushed into the arms of an elderly aunt. She had just had bandages removed from burns on her face and he recalls having to select a smooth surface on her cheek, "among the puckerings and the ridges", where he could kiss her. It is a graphic and disturbing scene and, as such, entirely in keeping with his work as a whole. In it he deploys the same unblinking forensic accuracy that he did as a novelist and travel writer depicting scenes of humanitarian outrage in the Amazon jungle, bloody chaos during the second world war or the studied brutalities of the Mafia.

With this in mind it can be somewhat incongruous to see Lewis at his home in rural Essex. His village is chocolate-box pretty with a neatly lush green, duck pond and church. His home, the Old Parsonage, is equally picturesque with parts of it dating back to the 15th century. Lewis has said that his talent is an ability to fit in everywhere he goes, but not to really fit in anywhere.

He is now aged 92 and although still generally healthy and alert, he is a little deaf and sometimes needs prompting to recall some of his books and his travels. As he sits in an armchair, he could be any other retired gentleman and listening to him talk about himself in his slightly drawly estuary accent he certainly seems as if he belongs in these bucolic surroundings. "But I don't really know much about England at all," he says. "I've barely been to the north of England at all. I suppose this place is pretty traditional, but I think in various ways I have made it less English."

Hung under the timbered beams of the entrance hall is the ornate back panel of a Sicilian cart decorated with a picture of the crusades. "All the carts used to be like this, but if you see one now you should stop the owner and bargain with him until he sells it to you." There are sinister-looking puppets from Panama and metal carvings of thin figures in boats from Benin. He has hung vividly coloured South American cloths on the walls. As he explains the narratives displayed on them he seems increasingly less like a typical figure from an English village. The naïve images are strangely powerful, packed with representations of native spirits.

"In this one the man throws vaginas at the tree to get food and the woman throws penises," he explains. He not only praises the craft that went into their production, "you must remember that these people live in the most extreme hardship and danger," but also seems to connect with their meanings.

Lewis has been writing for over 60 years and has produced 13 novels, 14 travel books, two volumes of autobiography and countless pieces of journalism. Graham Greene wrote, "I have no hesitation in calling Norman Lewis one of our best writers, not of any particular decade but of our century." Cyril Connolly claimed that Lewis, "could write about the back of a bus and make it interesting." VS Pritchett said he, "really goes in deep, like a sharp polished knife". But for all this distinguished praise, fellow travel writer and novelist Colin Thubron says Lewis is still underrated. "In a way he's not been praised enough. He's not written about like some other travel writers are but he is very much esteemed and quite a doyen."

Lewis's latest book, In Sicily, sees him return to the island. His links there are strong. His father-in-law was Sicilian, and after visiting for the first time during the war Lewis has returned regularly ever since. He probably knows this place, and in particular its violent culture, better than any other outsider. His classic 1964 depiction of the Mafia, The Honoured Society, was published in its entirety in six massive extracts in the New Yorker magazine, and his accounts of the Mafia trials in the 1980s were classics of their kind. In Sicily is partly a memoir, looking back at his long relationship with the island - he is saddened that his friends there seem to be dying on him - but is also alert to the mores of modern-day Sicily.

He has always been a master of ferreting out detail. Peter Crookston, his editor at both the Sunday Times and the Observer and a friend for nearly 40 years, explains how he does it. "There was once a television documentary about Norman which included some shots of him standing by a car that had just been bombed by the Mafia. He looked just like any other, slightly bemused bystander. You'd never know he was a journalist but he is the sharpest guy you could possibly meet and he doesn't miss a thing."

Lewis says, "I'm the only person I know who can enter a room, stay there five minutes, and then leave without anyone having noticed I was there. It goes back to my childhood. I learned to keep my head down. There were such appalling things happening."

Norman Lewis was born in 1908 in Enfield, North London, where his father was a chemist. The family had originated from South Wales and the legend has it that his grandfather introduced tea to the locals, thereby making his fortune, after purchasing a cargo of ruined stock from a ship that had sunk in Swansea docks. The Welsh influence was great and as a child Lewis was sent to the family home town of Carmarthen, to be looked after by three aunts including the burns victim, during a macabre family crisis. His three elder brothers had all died of unknown illnesses - "a bit mysteriously", says Lewis - and his panic-stricken parents decided to move young Norman away. "The aunts were not spectacularly mad, but they were slightly mad," he remembers. The title of his autobiography was The Jackdaw Cake [it has been published in paperback as I Came I Saw] because of the weekly cake his aunts baked for the birds. "They by no means underfed me, but the cake they baked for the jackdaws was a slightly better cake than I ever got," he says.

His contention that, "if I am one of the world's great escapists it is due to my childhood", is hard to argue with, particularly because when he eventually returned to Enfield he found that his father had become a spiritualist medium and his mother a healer. "My father was a lonely, rather retiring man, but he had congregations of 200 people in our garden shed who came to listen to his nonsense about spiritualism."

Lewis says he enjoyed school because he was good at it. He won a junior scholarship while at Enfield Grammar and was given £60, "an incredible amount of money then. It should have paid for my education and books and things, but I bought a motor bike and scraped through everything else."

During his life he has had several serious motor bike crashes and nearly killed himself in his only car race at Brooklands, in 1939: "I was flat out, and when I got to the banking on the corner I realised I couldn 't hold it. Everyone who ever went over the banking had been killed. When I was at the top I could look over the edge down this sheer drop to the fields, but in the end I missed the edge by three or four foot."

Although he won a place at university he didn't take it up, because his parents couldn't afford to keep him. Instead he went into business. "I assume it was somewhere near by; France was too civilised for me, so it was probably Spain. Thereafter a place could not be too remote."

His nomadic urges were understood by his first wife, Ernestina. She was from a Sicilian family living in London and was a cosmopolitan figure herself who had lived in most of Europe. Their marriage was unorthodox. They agreed there would be "no ties or sanctions", Ernestina would keep her name and they would both be free to part without any claim on the other. "We were both earnest students of the doctrines of Bertrand Russell," explains Lewis. They had one son, Ito, now in his mid 60s, who was, in a strange echo of his father's life, an executive in a large package holiday firm.

Lewis's career as a writer started when he was asked by the British secret services to go and photograph Yemen in 1937. He says he was happy to accept their invitation. "I always wanted to escape and this was another channel. I was with a man called Ladislas Farago, a Hungarian Jew. God knows why they sent him. He had been a spy in the Abyssinian war and wrote a very good book about it. He was a very interesting man although a fantastic liar." Farago went on make a reputed £1m when he hoaxed the world's press with the story that Martin Bormann was in South America. More importantly, "and with disastrous consequences," Lewis adds, Farago became an adviser on Vietnam to Richard Nixon.

Although denied entry to Yemen, Lewis travelled around the region and published his first book, Sand And Sea In Arabia in 1938. His encounter with Arabic - he is a gifted linguist, speaking French, Spanish, Arabic, Russian, German, and Italian - promp-ted him to enrol for a course at London University's School of Oriental and African Studies. When war was declared he was in Cuba with Ernestina. He returned to England and agreed to enlist in the intelligence corps because of his Arabic. He spent the first seven and a half months cutting lawns with a table knife in Winchester before he was eventually posted to North Africa with a brief to make links with leaders of local tribes.

As a member of Field Security rather than Intelligence - "they got their boots dirty" - Lewis was issued with a pass that bore the legend, "The bearer is entitled to be in any place and wearing any uniform he chooses. All persons subject to military law are required to give any assistance he needs." He was later posted to Italy. "This was his magic card," says Peter Crookston "an open sesame to everything. His job was to tell the generals what was happening in the civilian population and what was happening ahead of the troops, so he just went wherever he liked. It allowed him to get all the material he would later use in writing Naples '44."

This extraordinary account of life in the ruined city following the Allied invasion of Italy has been described as Goya-esque in its depiction of horror. Lewis says he re-read it recently. "I thought it was rather good. I had forgotten most of it." During the war he was in charge of returning 3,000 Russians - "mostly eastern tribesmen. I greatly admired their artistic abilities and got on with them very well" - back to Russia. Afterwards, he was sent to search for war criminals in Austria.

He was obviously as temperamentally able to cope with the chaos that surrounded him as he has been with the horrific things he has witnessed since. He jokingly says, "the war against the Germans was no more terrible than the war waged against some of my mad relations in Wales," before adding - more seriously- "I am ashamed to say it, but I enjoyed every minute of the war. It was endless variety and excitement."

His readjustment to civilian life after the war was made more difficult by the break-up of his marriage to Ernestina. She had spent the war in Latin America and when he went to Guatemala he was not surprised to find that she was in a long-standing relation ship - with a relation of the president. The marriage was ended shortly afterwards via a quickie divorce in Mexico. Lewis returned to England where he stayed with his in-laws, with whom he always maintained good relations, particularly his father-in-law.

Lewis is still unsure whether Ernestina's father was a member of the Mafia or not. "I suspect he was. He was smuggled out of Sicily to America with a group of people camouflaged as corpses and sent in coffins. His wife got drunk one night and said the day he left Sicily he had been shot at. While he didn't admit to anything he did say he was a member of the Unione Siciliana, which he said was an organisation that looked after the newly arrived Sicilians in America. There were also rumours that he was deported from America, but I got on with him immensely well."

Lewis then moved to Tenby in South Wales, where he rented a fort which had 16 rooms in four turrets, a banqueting hall, a life-size marble statue of Queen Victoria, and the skin of a 12-foot grizzly bear. In 1947 he moved to Spain to live in the small fishing village of Farol. Nearly 40 years later, when Farol had been transformed from an almost medieval community into just another part of the Costa Brava, he got out his notebooks of his time there and wrote his book Voices Of The Old Sea.

Back in England, Lewis married a Scottish army nursing officer, Hester, and had two further children with her. He regularly sees his daughter, Karen, who is a nurse in Cornwall but has lost touch with his son, Gareth, who now lives abroad. He then married his current wife, Lesley, in the late 1950s. They have three children; Kiki, 40, an illustrator, Gawaine, 37, a fund manager, and Samara, 30, a doctor. Lewis has 11 grandchildren.

Lesley, who is Australian, met Lewis soon after she moved to London in the early 50s when working as a ground steward for BOAC. She took the job because of the perks of cheap travel and so was immediately sympathetic to Lewis's own globetrotting. She is briskly sociable and open and friends say she has been hugely supportive of Lewis over the years. Although the family never travelled with him when he was working for newspapers she says, "we did spend all our spare money on travel with the children to places like Sri Lanka. And since the children have grown up I have started going with him to places like India." Lewis's 1991 book, A Goddess In The Stones, is a chronicle of his journey through some of poorest areas of the sub continent packed, as ever, with his acute eye for extraordinary detail, such as the tribe where 10-year-old boys are married off to 30-year-old women.

Throughout the 50s and 60s he travelled the world and wrote books about Vietnam, Burma, Cuba, Latin America and Indonesia. He praises his wife for taking the domestic strain during his prolonged absences. "It can't have been that easy for her and I don't suppose it was very good for the children that I was away so much." He claims never to have been homesick because what he was doing "was so gripping, and I was so involved in it that it occupied all my thoughts."

He had bought the family home in Essex in the early 60s - "it was empty and exceedingly cheap" - but soon moved the family to Italy, where he hoped the children would have a less parochial education. They lived just outside Rome and, in one of those macabre Lewis coincidences, an older student at the children's school was Paul Getty III, who was abducted and had his ear cut off by his kidnappers. After the abduction Lewis says, deadpan, "a few of the richer parents decided at this point it might be prudent to send their children to school elsewhere".

When the family moved back to Essex he began to trawl through the notebooks he had written on his travels. He has invariably followed this pattern of delayed reminiscence and dozens of pocket-sized booklets are piled up in cupboards. They are full of tiny, scrawled, and apparently illegible handwriting with pieces of text pasted in. In one, from his time in Italy, he has stuck sections of Herodotus: "I went everywhere in the war with Herodotus," he says, "All read in English translation I'm ashamed to say. But it was like having a livelier version of the bible with you - which I've also had a jolly good bash at. I read it as a work of literature." There are some wartime notebooks he hasn't looked at yet, having only just considered one set about a journey he made through Spain just as the civil war broke out, which he intends to be his next book.

He says he has only recently begun to reflect on his lifetime fascination for excitement and danger. "And I still can't really explain it. When I recently heard that my friend Donald McCullin was in Nigeria, my first thought was that when he comes back I'd love to persuade him to go somewhere terrible with me." McCullin says Lewis was, "the one writer who always brought out the best in me". They worked together on several assignments in Latin America. McCullin treasures memories of Lewis, lying in a hammock after a day's work, drinking vodka with a squeeze of lime juice. "What really impressed me about Norman was how meticulous his approach was. I used to think he had uncanny powers of prediction, but in reality he just knew a lot."

It was with McCullin that Lewis says he wrote his best story. In 1968 he learned that the people who were supposed to be protecting the Amazonian Indians from the depredations of civilisation were actually in league with the people who were massacring them. "These were things that just weren't known about then. I felt I had a mission to tell the world what was happening in terms of the fearful destruction of the rain forest and the murder of Indians."

His 12,000-word article was the longest piece ever published by the Sunday Times and led to changes in the law in Brazil. His subsequent book, The Missionaries, was also widely praised. "This work always seems to me to have been the most effective episode of my life," he says. "Of course there was a touch of the ulterior motive. It was a jolly good story as well."

L ewis is in a great tradition of British travel writing but he is unusual among front rank writers in not being upper class and in having contacts wherever he goes. Bill Buford, as editor of Granta literary magazine, is widely credited with launching a golden age of travel writing in the 1980s. He published Lewis and says he has been, "important in carrying on a tradition of English travel writing that goes back to the 19th century. He makes that tradition stay alive, and the fact that he is not an old Etonian or from Oxbridge revitalises the whole form. He doesn't do it as a representative of an old empire, he does it for adventure."

James Fenton, whose eye-witness account of the end of the Vietnam war, The Fall Of Saigon, is widely seen as one of the defining pieces of travel writing from this era, introduced Lewis to Buford because he was so impressed with Lewis's book about 1950s Vietnam, A Dragon Apparent. "Everybody who worked in Vietnam really appreciated reading it. People used to say at the end of the Vietnam war that Graham Greene's novel The Quiet American had foreseen everything that would follow. But Lewis was there before Greene and you wonder whether Greene had read Lewis's book and thought 'this place sounds interesting'."

Greene and Lewis are often bracketed together. They mined the same locations of South East Asia and Latin America, although they never met. Apparently, once when Lewis was in Hanoi he got off a plane Greene was getting on. "And when in Cuba, I stayed in the hotel in which he was writing Our Man In Havana, but I never spoke to him,' says Lewis. The little criticism that Lewis attracts is also tied up with Greene. One reviewer noted that, "whereas Greene's sweltering landscapes can be read as projections of the interior life of his characters, the landscapes of Lewis always remain the landscapes of a travel writer, quintessentially of the surface".

Lewis did meet another literary giant in Cuba, Ernest Hemingway. The publisher Jonathan Cape had asked him to sound out Hemingway, Cape's biggest selling writer, who had not delivered a promised book. "Hemingway had this coterie of people who followed him," recalls Lewis, "but by this time he was a broken man. He drank far too much and did silly things to draw attention to himself. I saw him get this crayfish and chew it so he crunched up the shell. All this blood would run down his chin. Ridiculous. He had a number of mistresses; film stars and all that, but by this time he was obviously completely impotent." The promised book never was written. "And a couple of weeks later he blew his brains out," records Lewis.

None of this put Lewis off writing fiction, and for many years he was better known as a novelist than as a travel writer. He had published his first novel, Samara, in 1949 and went on to write 11 more. VS Pritchett, rather precisely, described him as, "one of our very few capable experts in the novel of the exotic and revolutionary setting". Lewis's greatest success in this specialised genre came with his 1957 novel The Volcanoes Above Us, based on the Mayan Indians - "who I was extremely sympathetic to" - and including a hefty dig at CIA involvement in third-world affairs. It was an international best seller, with the Soviet Union publishing 6m copies, "of appalling quality". Lewis received no cash royalty from Moscow but was invited there as a guest of the authorities, given transport to anywhere he wanted to go, and a dacha on the Black Sea.

He eventually asked himself what he wanted to say in fiction that he couldn't say in travel writing. "After that I stopped writing fiction. I think there was some sort of submerged morality that struggled against the falsity of fiction. It wasn't quite life as I saw it and experienced it."His writing does exude a sense of trustworthiness. Bill Buford, now an editor at the New Yorker, acknowledges his commitment to accuracy, but also notes that, "there is also a tiny element of embellishment. Perhaps there is a little area that may not entirely survive the New Yorker fact-checking department, but is perfectly acceptable to everybody else. There is a fundamental veracity in everything he does, that comes from his own experiences, they don't come from third-hand experiences. He is a great observer."

Colin Thubron agrees that Lewis, "does like being the most anonymous person in the room. And he has a very cool and sceptical eye. He is no romantic but he is a born traveller, it really is in his bones. I remember someone talking about an obscure state in Africa and his eyes lit up. 'Oh yes,' he said, 'that's a real collector's piece.' He really does relish the strangeness of places."

"Norman's great gift is that he is a natural storyteller," says Buford. "What characterised the travel writing of the 80s was that the good stuff was old-fashioned storytelling. Norman collects stories the way other people might collect books, or sea shells, or bottles of wine. You have a sense that he has lived through all these bizarre and extreme experiences and has filed them away with the intention of returning to them to use them properly. If he never did another thing, and lived to be 500, he could keep entertaining us with his stories."

Life at a glance: Norman Lewis

Born: June 28 1908, Enfield, north London.

Education: Enfield Grammar.

Married: Ernestina (one son, Ito); Hester (one son Gareth, one daughter, Karen); 1958 Lesley (two daughters, Kiki and Samara, one son, Gawaine).

Career: Photography shop owner; Army Intelligence Corps 1939-45.

Fiction writing includes: Samara 1949; A Single Pilgrim 1953; The Day Of The Fox 1955; The Volcanoes Above Us 1957; A Small War Made To Order 1966; The Sicilian Specialist 1974; The German Company 1979; A Suitable Case For Corruption 1984.

Travel writing includes: Sand And Sea In Arabia 1938; A Dragon Apparent 1951; Golden Earth 1952; The Changing Sky 1959; The Honoured Society 1964; Naples '44 1978; Cuban Passage 1982; Voices Of The Old Sea 1984; The Missionaries 1988: An Empire Of The East 1993; In Sicily 2000.

 In Sicily is published by Chatto & Windus at £14.99.

I suppose this place is pretty traditional, but I think in various ways I have made it less English."
