They are full of tiny, scrawled, and apparently illegible handwriting with pieces of text pasted in. In one, from his time in Italy, he has stuck sections of Herodotus: "I went everywhere in the war with Herodotus," he says, "All read in English translation I'm ashamed to say. But it was like having a livelier version of the bible with you - which I've also had a jolly good bash at. I read it as a work of literature." There are some wartime notebooks he hasn't looked at yet, having only just considered one set about a journey he made through Spain just as the civil war broke out, which he intends to be his next book. He says he has only recently begun to reflect on his lifetime fascination for excitement and danger. "And I still can't really explain it. When I recently heard that my friend Donald McCullin was in Nigeria, my first thought was that when he comes back I'd love to persuade him to go somewhere terrible with me." McCullin says Lewis was, "the one writer who always brought out the best in me". They worked together on several assignments in Latin America. McCullin treasures memories of Lewis, lying in a hammock after a day's work, drinking vodka with a squeeze of lime juice. "What really impressed me about Norman was how meticulous his approach was. I used to think he had uncanny powers of prediction, but in reality he just knew a lot." It was with McCullin that Lewis says he wrote his best story. In 1968 he learned that the people who were supposed to be protecting the Amazonian Indians from the depredations of civilisation were actually in league with the people who were massacring them. "These were things that just weren't known about then. I felt I had a mission to tell the world what was happening in terms of the fearful destruction of the rain forest and the murder of Indians." His 12,000-word article was the longest piece ever published by the Sunday Times and led to changes in the law in Brazil. His subsequent book, The Missionaries, was also widely praised. "This work always seems to me to have been the most effective episode of my life," he says. "Of course there was a touch of the ulterior motive. It was a jolly good story as well." L ewis is in a great tradition of British travel writing but he is unusual among front rank writers in not being upper class and in having contacts wherever he goes. Bill Buford, as editor of Granta literary magazine, is widely credited with launching a golden age of travel writing in the 1980s. He published Lewis and says he has been, "important in carrying on a tradition of English travel writing that goes back to the 19th century. He makes that tradition stay alive, and the fact that he is not an old Etonian or from Oxbridge revitalises the whole form. He doesn't do it as a representative of an old empire, he does it for adventure." James Fenton, whose eye-witness account of the end of the Vietnam war, The Fall Of Saigon, is widely seen as one of the defining pieces of travel writing from this era, introduced Lewis to Buford because he was so impressed with Lewis's book about 1950s Vietnam, A Dragon Apparent. "Everybody who worked in Vietnam really appreciated reading it. People used to say at the end of the Vietnam war that Graham Greene's novel The Quiet American had foreseen everything that would follow. But Lewis was there before Greene and you wonder whether Greene had read Lewis's book and thought 'this place sounds interesting'." Greene and Lewis are often bracketed together. They mined the same locations of South East Asia and Latin America, although they never met. Apparently, once when Lewis was in Hanoi he got off a plane Greene was getting on. "And when in Cuba, I stayed in the hotel in which he was writing Our Man In Havana, but I never spoke to him,' says Lewis. The little criticism that Lewis attracts is also tied up with Greene. One reviewer noted that, "whereas Greene's sweltering landscapes can be read as projections of the interior life of his characters, the landscapes of Lewis always remain the landscapes of a travel writer, quintessentially of the surface". Lewis did meet another literary giant in Cuba, Ernest Hemingway. The publisher Jonathan Cape had asked him to sound out Hemingway, Cape's biggest selling writer, who had not delivered a promised book. "Hemingway had this coterie of people who followed him," recalls Lewis, "but by this time he was a broken man. He drank far too much and did silly things to draw attention to himself. I saw him get this crayfish and chew it so he crunched up the shell. All this blood would run down his chin. Ridiculous. He had a number of mistresses; film stars and all that, but by this time he was obviously completely impotent." The promised book never was written. "And a couple of weeks later he blew his brains out," records Lewis. None of this put Lewis off writing fiction, and for many years he was better known as a novelist than as a travel writer. He had published his first novel, Samara, in 1949 and went on to write 11 more. VS Pritchett, rather precisely, described him as, "one of our very few capable experts in the novel of the exotic and revolutionary setting". Lewis's greatest success in this specialised genre came with his 1957 novel The Volcanoes Above Us, based on the Mayan Indians - "who I was extremely sympathetic to" - and including a hefty dig at CIA involvement in third-world affairs. It was an international best seller, with the Soviet Union publishing 6m copies, "of appalling quality". Lewis received no cash royalty from Moscow but was invited there as a guest of the authorities, given transport to anywhere he wanted to go, and a dacha on the Black Sea. He eventually asked himself what he wanted to say in fiction that he couldn't say in travel writing. "After that I stopped writing fiction. I think there was some sort of submerged morality that struggled against the falsity of fiction. It wasn't quite life as I saw it and experienced it."His writing does exude a sense of trustworthiness. Bill Buford, now an editor at the New Yorker, acknowledges his commitment to accuracy, but also notes that, "there is also a tiny element of embellishment. Perhaps there is a little area that may not entirely survive the New Yorker fact-checking department, but is perfectly acceptable to everybody else. There is a fundamental veracity in everything he does, that comes from his own experiences, they don't come from third-hand experiences. He is a great observer." Colin Thubron agrees that Lewis, "does like being the most anonymous person in the room. And he has a very cool and sceptical eye. He is no romantic but he is a born traveller, it really is in his bones. I remember someone talking about an obscure state in Africa and his eyes lit up. 'Oh yes,' he said, 'that's a real collector's piece.' He really does relish the strangeness of places." "Norman's great gift is that he is a natural storyteller," says Buford. "What characterised the travel writing of the 80s was that the good stuff was old-fashioned storytelling. Norman collects stories the way other people might collect books, or sea shells, or bottles of wine. You have a sense that he has lived through all these bizarre and extreme experiences and has filed them away with the intention of returning to them to use them properly. If he never did another thing, and lived to be 500, he could keep entertaining us with his stories." Life at a glance: Norman Lewis Born: June 28 1908, Enfield, north London. Education: Enfield Grammar. Married: Ernestina (one son, Ito); Hester (one son Gareth, one daughter, Karen); 1958 Lesley (two daughters, Kiki and Samara, one son, Gawaine). Career: Photography shop owner; Army Intelligence Corps 1939-45. Fiction writing includes: Samara 1949; A Single Pilgrim 1953; The Day Of The Fox 1955; The Volcanoes Above Us 1957; A Small War Made To Order 1966; The Sicilian Specialist 1974; The German Company 1979; A Suitable Case For Corruption 1984. Travel writing includes: Sand And Sea In Arabia 1938; A Dragon Apparent 1951; Golden Earth 1952; The Changing Sky 1959; The Honoured Society 1964; Naples '44 1978; Cuban Passage 1982; Voices Of The Old Sea 1984; The Missionaries 1988: An Empire Of The East 1993; In Sicily 2000.  In Sicily is published by Chatto & Windus at £14.99.

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.trailText: Steven Poole looks at Rogue States by Noam Chomsky, a short introduction to logic and Borges' lectures on poetry
fields.body:
Rogue States

Noam Chomsky

(Pluto Press, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

The indefatigable Chomsky has been denouncing American foreign policy for so long that it appears the world has got bored of him: now leftists have trendier fish to fry. One might reasonably ask, though, just how deserving of our anger are Gap or McDonald's compared with the violent depradations of a superpower that alone vetoed a Security Council resolution calling on all states to observe international law? That's right: the biggest rogue state is the US itself, often accompanied, as in the illegal bombing of Belgrade, by its sweating lapdog, Britain. Chomsky's prose is not without a dry wit. For America to call itself the "global policeman", he writes, is an insult to policemen everywhere, "who are supposed to uphold the law, not tear it to pieces".

Logic: A Very Short Introduction

Graham Priest

(Oxford, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

This new addition to the VSI series makes a splendid fist of warming up logic for the general palate. You still have to learn a few symbols, but the pleasure in following Priest's mind-bending puzzles about dividing amoebas, or refuting, with his guidance, a famous refutation of the existence of time, will be worth it. Would also make a fine remedial course for Chris Woodhead.

This Craft of Verse

Jose Luis Borges

(Harvard, £15.95)
Buy it at BOL

Anything written by Borges glows, as you know, with an unearthly light that transforms the world into a plushly furnished drawing room crammed with knicknacks and dusty, leather-bound volumes of arcana. Here is the newly transcribed series of lectures that Borges gave at Harvard in 1967 and 1968, in which he ranges from Plato through Shakespeare, De Quincey and Keats, Norse myth, Byron, and of course Don Quixote. Almost every casual aside from Borges suggests a book of its own; this one is a wondrously limpid testament to the pleasures of reading.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.standfirst: Harriet Porter reviews Joseph Roth's Job, William Sutcliffe's The Love Hexagon, Winifred Watson's Miss Pettigrew Lives For A Day and Knowing Max by James Long
fields.trailText: Harriet Porter reviews Joseph Roth's Job, William Sutcliffe's The Love Hexagon, Winifred Watson's Miss Pettigrew Lives For A Day and Knowing Max by James Long
fields.body:
Job
Joseph Roth
Granta
£ 6.99
Buy it at BOL
Roth's fictional world, the shtetls of Central Europe and its cosmopolitan cities, are forever linked with an uneasy nostalgia for what two world wars destroyed. This is the deceptively simple story of Mendel Singer, an "an entirely commonplace Jew" whose belief in his God is weakened, almost fatally, when he emigrates from Tsarist Russia to New York. But the humour and humanity of the story cannot in the end escape the weight of history. Roth captures essential truths about faith, hope and despair within his reworking of a Biblical story. His writing is rich without being dense, and has a fable-like directness.

The Love Hexagon
William Sutcliffe
Penguin
£5.99
Buy it at BOL

Smarter by far than the competition, Sutcliffe's "six characters in search of a meaningful relationship" doesn't pretend to care much for the plot or the people involved. Guy, Lisa and their friends are cardboard cut-outs of Londoners stranded between university and marriage, going nowhere in jobs or love. Imitative of a well-worn genre, The Love Hexagon is redeemed by an acid dislike of self-obsessed relationship-hunters and a pitch-perfect ear for inane dialogues on the subject of love and sex traded across sandwich bars and pub tables. Who cares whether the game of musical chairs ends in happy ever after when you can enjoy Sutcliffe's barbed comic take on his contemporaries?

Miss Pettigrew Lives For A Day
Winifred Watson
Persephone Books
£10
Buy it at BOL

Why has it taken more than half a century for this wonderful flight of humour to be rediscovered? Probably because it is high entertainment, not serious social comment or great literature. Watson mostly wrote of northern women's struggles to succeed, but this, her fourth novel, allows a shabby temping governess to taste for one magical day the starlet lifestyle via the delightfully amoral Miss La Fosse. Pure Cinderella fantasy farce with beaus, bounders, negligées and nightclubs, it is a period piece with the original illustrations - and Miss Pettigrew's blossoming is a delight to observe.

Knowing Max
James Long
HarperCollins
£5.99
Buy it at BOL

This story of a young man's efforts to piece together from the contents of his trunk the truth about Max Birkin Owen - sometime race-car owner and player in the fast set before and after the war - fascinates in parts but mostly annoys. "It's not Shakespeare," says one character towards the end of the novel. Her point - that fate, that neat casting-off for plot-lines, just doesn't work in real life - means that the protagonist's quest to unravel Max's life only produces more curious facts and adds up to rather lame biographies for both. Interesting diversions along the way, though, about cars and boarding school.

The General Of The Dead Army
Ismail Kadare
Harvill
£10.99
Buy it at BOL

What remains at the end of war but corpses? One side will tell of its heroism in battle, the other would prefer its defeat to lie undisturbed. That is the way of things between Albania and Italy until an Italian general is dispatched to Tirana. His job is to unearth bodies, attach names and stories to their bones and return the remains to their families. Kadare's novel, first published in 1963 and now revised, is a classic story about the aftermath of war and a portrait of his native Albania that both celebrates nationalism and censures rigid tradition. Kadare's sonorous style is immediately gripping and portends a difficult but inescapably necessary journey.

Isobel Montgomery
Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan
Edmund Morris
HarperCollins
£8.99
Buy it at BOL

If Clinton is wise, he will carry this book in his heart as a warning of where not to go. You sanction a fulsomely written tribute (or, if you are Reagan, your family does it for you); you witness the million-dollar publishing deal and watch the years tick by. Then suddenly, you discover that this great, marbled edifice to presidential prowess is a bizarre post-modern joke. You are expected to share your life with a fictional version of your biographer: the Kennedys might have understood this a Boswellian device, while the Reagans were always likely to consider it merely undignified. But, then, who today can tell fact from fiction, especially where American presidents are involved?

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Vera Rule reads of hell in the Whitehouse in Lincoln: A Foreigner's Quest and puritanism in The Real American Dream
fields.body:
Lincoln: A Foreigner's Quest

Jan Morris

Penguin £7.99
Buy it at BOL

Washington DC, some time in the not-too-distant past. Pigs truffle in mud, British Embassy staff qualify for hazard pay because of typhoid from Potomac river water, Gentle Annie Lyle's place is doin' ace business in the whores' quarter . . . Lincoln moves into the White House (an "unsuccessful hotel") and writes: "If there's a worse place than hell, I'm in it." The Civil War begins his first day in office . . . Morris's mini-biog matches Abe for plainness, then catches at the enlargement of the man through presidency until he could hone the 265 words of the Gettysburg address, up to which ain't no successor lived.

The Real American Dream

Andrew Delbanco

Harvard, £12.95
Buy it at BOL

God, Nation and Self: through these, writes Delbanco in these essays (so brief, yet so pertinent), the citizens of the US have given their lives meaning to ward off melancholy, that "logical belief in a hopeless future". Puritan Calvinism seems benign next to consumerist Calvinism. That's Calvinism as in Calvin Klein, where the free individual - the US's great gift to the world - is "marooned in a perpetual present, playing alone with its baubles", and the "ache for meaning goes unrelieved". But Delbanco's wit is itself the measure of the land of the free.

fields.standfirst:
Random House, 180mn, £8.99
Buy the book at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: The stage, the screen and all the bust-ups too
fields.body: Waterman discloses a talented south London family: elder brother a successful boxer, one sister a Bluebell dancer, and the rest keen am-drammers. Stage school was his obvious salvation when he fluffed the 11-plus. His early adolescence was studded with extraordinary stage and screen roles, including a West End juvenile lead to Ralph Richardson at the tender age of 16. Waterman breezes through this with a nice insouciance. He emerges as a deeper talent than his TV hits, big though they are, might suggest. To satisfy the prurient, there's plenty about his relationship breakdowns, the last disaster delivered in detectably bitter tones.

webTitle: Small press corner: Landor: A Biography of Walter Savage Landor, by Jean Field

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: Landor: A Biography of Walter Savage Landor, by Jean Field
fields.body:
Landor: A Biography of Walter Savage Landor

Jean Field

Brewin, £17.95

Landor (1775-1864) furnishes an interesting link between Romantic and Victorian poetry (see his blank-verse epic Gebir for instance), although he also wrote a good deal of prose, including two books of Imaginary Conversations between literary or historical figures (such as Elizabeth and Mary Tudor). This new life concentrates on his Warwickshire background (where it makes some discoveries) and his friendships with better-known writers such as Southey, Dickens (who portrayed him as Boythorn in Bleak House) and the Brownings (who looked after him in old age in Florence).

A lively, if quarrelsome character (Field makes a good case for him being more pleasant than previous biographers allow), his exploits included firing off a shotgun in his Oxford rooms, and various affairs and libel actions.

 ISBN 1-85858-167-2; distribution by Portland Books, 01926 888776, or email martyn@portlandbooks.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Review:  The Faber Book of Smoking

fields.headline: Faugh! Pah! Whewgh!
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  is all lit up by The Faber Book of Smoking
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard is all lit up by The Faber Book of Smoking
fields.body:
The Faber Book of Smoking

ed James Walton

334pp, Faber

£17.50
Buy it at BOL

Smokers, if not now persecuted, then at least made to feel uncomfortable about themselves, huddle together in comforting conspiracy. Our bonds are sympathy and generosity. I once met the editor of this volume outside the London Library; fagless, I asked him for one, and he obliged. Which smoker would not offer their last under almost any circumstances? Well, their second last. In Captain Corelli's Mandolin , Velisarios the Greek places a cigarette in the dead Carlo's mouth; earlier, they had forgotten they were enemies and smoked together. You might not do that if you were in prison, as a lengthy quotation from Porridge reminds us.

My wife and daughter disapprove of my habit. There is a chapter here called "Women and Smoking" and it would appear that the relationship between the two has been problematic for some time. It is not just that the odour of smoke compromises the very domesticity of a home, but that women, for a long time, were not meant to smoke. After a time it became unclear whether this was the cause or the effect of their not liking the stuff as much as men. Here's this, from Jerrold's Mrs Caudle's Curtain Lectures, a work that predates yet deserves to stand shoulder to shoulder with The Diary of a Nobody (in it, an almost imperceptibly errant husband suffers tirades from his scandalised wife, on a number of subjects): "Faugh! Pah! Whewgh! That filthy tobacco-smoke! It's enough to kill any decent woman. You know I hate tobacco, and yet you will do it. You don't smoke yourself? What of that? If you go among people who do smoke, you're just as bad, or worse. You might as well smoke - indeed, better. Better smoke yourself than come home with other people's smoke all in your hair and whiskers." And so on. Mrs Caudle is, sadly, not in this book: understandable, as it had not yet been reprinted while Walton was compiling his anthology. (It is, though, out now at a very reasonable £8.99 from the unfortunately named Prion Books.)

Walton's book can be read, if you like, as a kind of history of the weed, with a bit on snuff thrown in too. There has to be, for the ground version supplanted the combustible one for a long time indeed. Smoking's residue may be a mildly toxic or irritating ash but snuff's, as I recall when I tried it, is a day-long river of streaky snot and incessant sneezing. Strange how John Arbuckle could write, in 1719 "With Snuff the beauteous Celia hides her face,/ And adds a foil to every obvious grace." Was Christopher Hitchens thinking of this when he wrote, in his great 1992 essay "Booze and Fags", "smoking is, in men, a tremendous enhancement of bearing and address and, in women, a consistent set-off to beauty"? Another quotation from this piece is in Walton's work.

V G Kiernan, whose book Tobacco: A History Hitchens was reviewing, asked whether, as non-smokers multiplied, the creation of literature would still be possible; and it is true that I have been happy to observe a correlation between tobacco intake and creativity. The world, as P G Wodehouse once remarked, is our ashtray (remark not in book, but other very good Wodehouse quotes are, such as the advice to doctors to try to give up killing cats by placing nicotine on their tongues. "Conquer the impulse for the after-breakfast cat, and half the battle is won").

It is difficult to imagine any serious writer giving this book a bad review. I have pointed out a couple of omissions, cheekily blowing a smoke ring through Walton's much more substantial one. I salute his efforts with this book, although any anthology struggles against its form; the readers' needs, if I may paraphrase Martin Amis, both are and are not being met. But that, too, was inevitable. The book is exquisite, and it leaves one unsatisfied. What more can one want?

In Captain Corelli's Mandolin , Velisarios the Greek places a cigarette in the dead Carlo's mouth; earlier, they had forgotten they were enemies and smoked together. You might not do that if you were in prison, as a lengthy quotation from Porridge reminds us. My wife and daughter disapprove of my habit. There is a chapter here called "Women and Smoking" and it would appear that the relationship between the two has been problematic for some time. It is not just that the odour of smoke compromises the very domesticity of a home, but that women, for a long time, were not meant to smoke. After a time it became unclear whether this was the cause or the effect of their not liking the stuff as much as men. Here's this, from Jerrold's Mrs Caudle's Curtain Lectures, a work that predates yet deserves to stand shoulder to shoulder with The Diary of a Nobody (in it, an almost imperceptibly errant husband suffers tirades from his scandalised wife, on a number of subjects): "Faugh! Pah! Whewgh! That filthy tobacco-smoke! It's enough to kill any decent woman. You know I hate tobacco, and yet you will do it. You don't smoke yourself? What of that? If you go among people who do smoke, you're just as bad, or worse. You might as well smoke - indeed, better. Better smoke yourself than come home with other people's smoke all in your hair and whiskers." And so on. Mrs Caudle is, sadly, not in this book: understandable, as it had not yet been reprinted while Walton was compiling his anthology. (It is, though, out now at a very reasonable £8.99 from the unfortunately named Prion Books.) Walton's book can be read, if you like, as a kind of history of the weed, with a bit on snuff thrown in too. There has to be, for the ground version supplanted the combustible one for a long time indeed. Smoking's residue may be a mildly toxic or irritating ash but snuff's, as I recall when I tried it, is a day-long river of streaky snot and incessant sneezing. Strange how John Arbuckle could write, in 1719 "With Snuff the beauteous Celia hides her face,/ And adds a foil to every obvious grace." Was Christopher Hitchens thinking of this when he wrote, in his great 1992 essay "Booze and Fags", "smoking is, in men, a tremendous enhancement of bearing and address and, in women, a consistent set-off to beauty"? Another quotation from this piece is in Walton's work. V G Kiernan, whose book Tobacco: A History Hitchens was reviewing, asked whether, as non-smokers multiplied, the creation of literature would still be possible; and it is true that I have been happy to observe a correlation between tobacco intake and creativity. The world, as P G Wodehouse once remarked, is our ashtray (remark not in book, but other very good Wodehouse quotes are, such as the advice to doctors to try to give up killing cats by placing nicotine on their tongues. "Conquer the impulse for the after-breakfast cat, and half the battle is won"). It is difficult to imagine any serious writer giving this book a bad review. I have pointed out a couple of omissions, cheekily blowing a smoke ring through Walton's much more substantial one. I salute his efforts with this book, although any anthology struggles against its form; the readers' needs, if I may paraphrase Martin Amis, both are and are not being met. But that, too, was inevitable. The book is exquisite, and it leaves one unsatisfied. What more can one want?

fields.headline: An inner click . . . and she's off!
fields.standfirst: Dervla Murphy tells John Cunningham about life on two wheels
fields.trailText: Dervla Murphy tells John Cunningham about life on two wheels
fields.body:
It's 35 years since Dervla Murphy got on her bike in Ireland and got off it, several months later, in India. She's been pedalling ever since - not quite so fast now that she's 68, but even more furiously as she sees countries from South America to Asia despoiled by development and disfigured by western values.

Every trip makes a book and means months of hardship. Just as well she's hardy with a dry humour: her latest is titled One Foot in Laos for the simple reason that an injured leg had her limping through a magic land that only now is opening up after horrendous bombing during and after the Vietnam war.

Even as a girl in the Waterford village where she still lives, Murphy wanted to be a writer. But only after trying a couple of novels ("they weren't even worth typing") and following the deaths of both her parents ("they left me a house and an income in 1962 of £4.20 a week") was she free, in her thirties, go to India, which had fired her imagination.

That trip cost just £65 for six months. Hippies hadn't yet blazed a trail, so "between Istanbul and Kabul, I didn't meet one other westerner, or Australian". Travel writing wasn't a fashionable genre in the early 1960s; so Murphy followed the solitary stars of two wanderers whose work she admired: the Victorian Isabella Bird, and Freya Stark, who started writing in the 1930s.

Murphy is good at dropping the inessentials. Early on, religion (born Catholic; she's now a humanist); ironing (not necessary) and marriage (she's brought up her daughter alone) went out of the window. On the road, too, her kit is minimal. A bike and a beer are her best companions. However she has taken daughter Rachel; most recently to Cameroon, where they acquired a porter named Egbert - who happened to be a donkey.

Unlike other big names in travel writing, Murphy has stayed true to the form: she hasn't deviated into fiction; she doesn't intersperse her narratives with chunks of autobiography. She just tells a straight and steadfast tale, from day one through to the last. "I can't stand travel books that begin with some spectacular drama in the middle of the jungle," Murphy explains, "trying to catch the reader's eye on page one with someone coming into your tent and trying to murder you or rape you."

Murphy hates the hype that packages other travel celebs; doesn't do author tours or TV; won't take advances: "I don't want money for a book till it's written and accepted." She doesn't have an agent, and has always had with the same publisher, John Murray. Jock Murray [father of the present boss] was her mentor: on his advice, she abandoned two books. One, on Turkey, "they could have published; it was when I was well established, they would have covered their costs, but it wouldn't have done my reputation any good. I totally trusted Jock".

What drives Miss Dervla to choose a particular country is what she calls "my inner click": "It happens when for some reason I am suddenly determined to visit a country previously unconsidered." She was planning to go to to Sri Lanka when a friend mentioned that Laos was about to change for ever. Within an hour, Murphy had a new destination. After that, it was a random adventure: "I just love unpredictability. It's a great feeling to get up in the morning and not know where you'll be in the evening."

A typical day's cycling is about 60 miles, "but at my best I could have done 100 or 110". Often, she'll wake up in the hut of a village headman; set off before dawn to a town which locals warn is off-limits; carry the bike across a river; use sign-language on meeting tribes people; fall asleep in a forest; slake her thirst at a timely beershop, and accost a bewildered hunter who'll lead her a village to rest and write the diary she'll work into a book back in Waterford.

Her early books concentrated on landscape rather than people and problems. Now that she's green and angry at interventionist bodies such as the World Bank, the IMF, the World Trade Organisation and global corporations, serious homework has to be done: "You don't have to do any research to describe a mountain range; but you have to do a hell of a lot to explain why people there are living in misery."

In Laos, she was struck by "the immense skill of the farmers. They have 27 different varieties of rice, and they know exactly which to plant, according to the slope of the land or the rainfall. That's being undermined by us. Monsanto et al coming in with one variety, saying they must do it this way. What is that but the worst sort of imperialism - the disregarding of people because they're illiterate, even though they have this immense knowledge? The cheek of it!"

For the next few months or so, Murphy will be a homebody, rising at five, writing from six. The current project in the electric typewriter is about the Balkans; and it's "murderously hard going.", she says.

There are prizes and penalties for ageing authors. In Africa, white hair cast her as a respected elder; four months in the Balkans was frustrating because local people wouldn't believe that, with so many young officials from NGOs milling round, an Irish grandmother could have any business being there. Usually with her projects, the journey is the relatively easy; the writing more labourous. This time, both were tough going. Happily, there's a Murphy's law that says, come hell or high water, the book will be finished.

Buy One Foot in Laos at BOL

webTitle: Pick of the week:  A Cure for Gravity  by Joe Jackson

fields.headline: The success of failure
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on the autobiography of an  intelligent pop star, Joe Jackson's  A Cure for Gravity
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on the autobiography of an intelligent pop star, Joe Jackson's A Cure for Gravity
fields.body:
A Cure for Gravity

Joe Jackson

Anchor, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Joe Jackson, as you will recall, was the skinny, balding singer for whom you would settle if Elvis Costello was unavailable. He had hits with songs like "Is She Really Going Out With Him?" and ... um ...

I am being cruel, but not entirely inaccurate. His voice did sound eerily like Costello's; as did his band. That Costello could blow him out of the water lyrically must have been a grievous blow, considering that Jackson wasn't that bad. You guessed that he was just not angry enough; didn't have a sufficiently rigid or urgent idea of the image he needed to project.

There are a couple of tight-lipped references to Costello in this book - fewer, in other words, than there already are in this review - but at least they show that Jackson has what shrinks call insight into his own condition. And that happens to be one of the necessary characteristics of a good autobiography, which this book is.

For a man who came to relative fame on the coat-tails of punk, that notionally working-class musical movement, Jackson was the authentic article in a way that Joe Strummer wasn't: he was working-class himself, raised in boredom and general lack - asthmatic, geeky, different - in Portsmouth. He happened to have a great gift for music, and an intuitive understanding of it that mystified his family and peers; the first LP he ever bought was the Eroica. Eventually - and you can understand why he had to keep quiet about this for a few years - he was accepted as a student by the Royal Academy of Music. "I saw music as White Magic. Pure energy, pure emotion, pure spirit. I thought that musicians, regardless of what kind of music they played, were beyond reproach, like firefighters or nuns," he writes.

Not that much later on, he is describing some hair-raising gigs in pubs seething with drunken sailors, or a residency in a Greek restaurant, or his time as the keyboard player for the mesmerisingly ghastly double-act Koffee 'n' Kreme.

This is astute of him, and honest too: to concentrate on his childhood and years of dogged failure rather than include his time of celebrity; for that was never really substantial enough and besides, there are enough glib rock memoirs, barely worth the name, that earnestly record how horrible it is to be a rock star. And failure became him in a way real success wouldn't have.

The locus classicus of unsuccessful attempts to break down the doors of the music industry is Giles Smith's Lost in Music, as I keep telling everyone. (Picador, still in print, or it had better be.) Smith can really write, which is probably what keeps him from making the kind of wide-eyed pronouncements about music that I've quoted above; and everyone marvels at how Jackson can write.

I'm a bit more picky, and refer people to the paragraph here in which Jackson, sitting in some dreary lounge bar, is depressed by the way the seedy cocktail pianist appears to have convinced the audience that he is a musician. Jackson says he can't help noticing musical flaws, unnecessary frills, and other musical lapses of judgment; but he does insist that this doesn't make him a better person.

Similarly, I wince a little at some of the phrases that don't quite come off, and nearly all the exclamation marks (there aren't so many, though); but he still writes a lot better than we have any right to expect. After all, the book kept me glued to its pages. It's not actually artless, but charmingly close to it; a touching, intelligent and humane slice of someone's life.

fields.headline: Moody blues
fields.standfirst: Rick Moody's Demonology  shows  a great talent basking in adversity, says Alex Clark
fields.trailText: Rick Moody's Demonology shows a great talent basking in adversity, says Alex Clark
fields.body:
Demonology

Rick Moody

306pp, Faber

£10.99
Buy it at BOL

A tiny sentence nestles in a story in the middle of this collection, providing a brief forecast of the book's prevailing weather. "Here comes tragedy," intones the unknown narrator of "Hawaiian Night", as he prepares to recount the events that, far from lying in the future, have already preceded the gathering of comfortable suburbanites at which limbo dancing, spit-roasted pig and a flurry of leis will usher in the balmy summer night. The tragedy involves the aptly named Debby Grimm, whose absence from the evening and from the rest of the Grimm family's lives turns on an ill-fated jaunt on the Pretty Young Thing, a motor boat that ran out of control, pitched its passengers into the water and then "embarked on its repetitive circular course, leftward, sinisterly", eventually striking Debby "decisively" and crushing "a plurality of vertebrae".

In several of these 13 stories, tragedy comes leftward and sinisterly, casually selecting its random victims and leaving its survivors maimed by grief and guilt. Throughout Demonology, the persistently and almost pathologically inventive Rick Moody attempts to forge an aesthetics of loss. That the losses he describes are frequently metaphorical as well as actual is both strength and limitation; the stories succeed or fail according to whether their author pulls off the trick of blending the accidents, illnesses and deaths of their plot-lines with the psychological loss that not merely follows but also predates them. In other words, Moody's "incantation of worry" treads an exceptionally fine line between mawkishness - not necessarily in the most damning sense of that word - and a brilliantly conceived and realised universality to be found in the "narratives of things lost".

Two or three of these stories are in a class of their own: outstanding pieces that seem, on reading, to answer some of fiction's most pressing dilemmas. In the first of the collection, "The Mansion on the Hill", comedy and tragedy are effortlessly braided as a young man speaks to his dead sister, telling her of the life he has pieced together after she smashed her car up on the eve of her wedding. It is his car, of course, and its tyres are bald, because Moody's tragedies are nothing if not comprehensively devastating reproaches to the living. After a stint walking the pavement in a chicken mask persuading diners into the Hot Bird - a job endangered by his urge to lunge at children and tell them of their impending death - Andy finds employment at The Mansion on the Hill, a one-stop wedding factory where guests can arrange every aspect of their nuptials in a series of hermetically sealed, themed suites.

Andy's lengthy farewell to his sister is riddled with irony and fury, undercut by farce, and fuelled by muted, bewildered cries of pain. Believing himself to have lost everything, he is a willing spy in the house of love, relishing its commercialism and its idiocies, "the bondage, the violence, the excess of its cabalistic prayers and rituals", until he too finds himself undone by the risky imperatives of connection. His assessment of another character, who manages "to conceal her throbbing, sentimental heart beneath a veneer of contemporary discontent" is a neat encapsulation of many of Moody's characters, piloted by the twin drives of disdain and distress, and of the author's own position as he steers his battle-weary characters on a course between frantic efforts at recuperation and the siren songs of oceanic misery.

The "contemporary discontent" that has seen Moody hyperbolically tagged as "the voice of a lost generation" surfaces in his embittered sideswipes at America's banalities, on one occasion in the serial business failures of an Ohio loser trying his hand at breeding angora rabbits, yew trees to fight the local cancer cluster and, finally, ostriches, only to fetch up in a trailer park, brought low by the anal leakage caused by "a non-nutritive fat substitute". Elsewhere, a minor character loses his false teeth on the golf course, both teeth and ball ending up in a "humiliating sand trap". One suspects that Moody takes slightly too much comfort in setting up such sand traps: when the narrator who witnesses this incident remarks that it occurred "in a manner so vulnerable it provoked a yelp in me", one feels a shiver of sadism, a whisper of disingenuousness.

This tendency to bask in adversity is, at times, a weakness; it leads to the kind of bathos that can undo short fiction. There are a couple of terrible final sentences in Demonology , generic final flourishes that trade in a kind of ironised dying fall: "The girl in the tutu pirouetted by him on his bad side, and he knew now, indisputably, he was older." That smacks of a creative-writing class, as does the portentous "Somebody's cocker spaniel fetched a mossy tennis ball, left it at my feet, and would not be placated until I tossed it for him again. Moments later the hound was back". Paradoxically, these disappointing endings round off two of the most successful stories, "The Carnival Tradition" and "Hawaiian Night".

Aside from the pirouetting girl, "The Carnival Tradition" is a prodigiously talented piece, a diptych that sees us first in Hoboken as a wannabe bohemian ballet dancer is bested by marauding dogs while she attempts to gain access to her flat to organise the opening night of a gallery - whose unique selling point is that it is entirely empty. From this skit on boho chic, punctuated by the dancer's internal laments at her boyfriend's shortcomings ("He knew about Frege, Austin, Kuhn, but his evasions on home repair subjects were appalling"), we are catapulted into the story's second half, in which the feckless boyfriend recalls a teenage Halloween party.

Suddenly, the frenzied farce of the New York Street, its upturned trashcans and bickering inhabitants, is replaced by the deep peace of an exercise in memory. From a point in the future, beyond Hoboken and its "faux connubial bliss", Gerry returns to the dream-spaces of childhood, questing retrospectively for the moment that "idealism hitched a ride". The fractured narrative works fabulously: both halves of the story bear witness to "a delirium of stories" that are never reconciled, but never entirely sundered.

The dual narrative of "The Carnival Tradition" is only one of the textual tricks with which Moody has fun, or at least a rewarding lack of it. There is also a story composed of sleeve notes and track listings; a commemoration of the musical tastes of "the last WASP" in "Wilkie Fahnstock, The Boxed Set"; a study of romantic obsession detailed in a catalogue of off-the-wall books (naturally, in best postmodern style, it includes a novel by Rick Moody); and a Joycean study of gender relations - completed in one sentence - in "Ineluctable Modality of the Vaginal". There is parsed academic vocabulary, ungovernably ironic italicisation, the spectre of intertextuality. There is, in short, much cleverness: the kind of pissed-off display of intelligence that links Moody with writers like David Foster Wallace and Dave Eggers. It's brilliant and funny, but alongside the rawnesses on show elsewhere, it's nothing to write home about.

Which brings us to the title story, and the collection's end. "Demonology" is a pared-down account of the last day in the life of the narrator's sister. It comes to us by way of short, crucifyingly painful sentences. "Never any good without coffee." "She printed snapshots." "She was really small." "After the seizure, she went slack." The pain is unmediated, until the piece's very end: "I should let artifice create an elegant surface, I should make the events orderly, I should wait until I'm not angry - I shouldn't have to think the unthinkable, I shouldn't have to suffer." But we do suffer; better, at least, to let us have someone to record it.

That smacks of a creative-writing class, as does the portentous "Somebody's cocker spaniel fetched a mossy tennis ball, left it at my feet, and would not be placated until I tossed it for him again. Moments later the hound was back". Paradoxically, these disappointing endings round off two of the most successful stories, "The Carnival Tradition" and "Hawaiian Night". Suddenly, the frenzied farce of the New York Street, its upturned trashcans and bickering inhabitants, is replaced by the deep peace of an exercise in memory. From a point in the future, beyond Hoboken and its "faux connubial bliss", Gerry returns to the dream-spaces of childhood, questing retrospectively for the moment that "idealism hitched a ride". The fractured narrative works fabulously: both halves of the story bear witness to "a delirium of stories" that are never reconciled, but never entirely sundered. The dual narrative of "The Carnival Tradition" is only one of the textual tricks with which Moody has fun, or at least a rewarding lack of it. There is also a story composed of sleeve notes and track listings; a commemoration of the musical tastes of "the last WASP" in "Wilkie Fahnstock, The Boxed Set"; a study of romantic obsession detailed in a catalogue of off-the-wall books (naturally, in best postmodern style, it includes a novel by Rick Moody); and a Joycean study of gender relations - completed in one sentence - in "Ineluctable Modality of the Vaginal". There is parsed academic vocabulary, ungovernably ironic italicisation, the spectre of intertextuality. There is, in short, much cleverness: the kind of pissed-off display of intelligence that links Moody with writers like David Foster Wallace and Dave Eggers. It's brilliant and funny, but alongside the rawnesses on show elsewhere, it's nothing to write home about. Which brings us to the title story, and the collection's end. "Demonology" is a pared-down account of the last day in the life of the narrator's sister. It comes to us by way of short, crucifyingly painful sentences. "Never any good without coffee." "She printed snapshots." "She was really small." "After the seizure, she went slack." The pain is unmediated, until the piece's very end: "I should let artifice create an elegant surface, I should make the events orderly, I should wait until I'm not angry - I shouldn't have to think the unthinkable, I shouldn't have to suffer." But we do suffer; better, at least, to let us have someone to record it.

webTitle: Review:  America's Queen  by Sarah Bradford

fields.headline: First Lady of Camelot
fields.standfirst: Sarah Bradford's biography of Jackie O, America's Queen, shows  Mrs Kennedy's gift, says Andrew Rissik
fields.trailText: Sarah Bradford's biography of Jackie O, America's Queen, shows Mrs Kennedy's gift, says Andrew Rissik
fields.body:
America's Queen; The Life of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis

Sarah Bradford

600pp, Viking

£20
Buy it at BOL

Long before Diana Spencer, Jacqueline Kennedy was the world's ultimate fantasy princess. Her endlessly photographed and pored-over face was a screen onto which her emotionally hungry admirers projected their dreams of flawless refinement. Until she broke her own, extraordinary spell by leaving the United States and marrying Aristotle Onassis in 1968, she possessed, in the minds of most of the American people, a kind of stylistic perfect pitch.

A cool-headed socialite with aristocratic pretension, she began as an ornament to her millionaire husband's presidency, and ended by redefining it. Her elegantly petite figure and startled gazelle eyes, her familiarity with France, the 18th century and the finer points of dressage, lent a keynote of civility to the image of the Kennedy White House that the young president's freewheeling, technocratic glamour could not have provided alone. Then, in the traumatic days following his assassination in Dallas, by brilliantly echoing what had been said and done after Lincoln was killed 100 years earlier, she raised him in death to a pinnacle of nobility that he could almost certainly never have attained in life.

The elaborate state funeral she helped to plan, the solemn obsequies at Arlington, the eternal flame poignantly flickering in the freezing November twilight: these were her final, canonising gift to the husband who, though he had often betrayed and humiliated her sexually, had always hypnotised her imagination. Through a flawless sense of the dramatic fitness of things, and by the moving, healing stoicism of her publicly borne grief, she subtly magnified the nation's sense of the scale of the loss, and therefore of Kennedy's actual political achievement.

Sarah Bradford is right to spend two thirds of her quiet, lucid, well-written new biography on the years before the assassination. Between them, the Kennedys altered the whole tone of the modern presidency. Temperamentally, they had much in common and a shared "snobbery of style" united them, more enduringly than sex. Both of them had wanted to be writers, and both possessed qualities of coolness and detachment, of intellectual reserve and ironic cruelty - common in literary or artistic figures but exceedingly rare in the folksy, glad-handing, philistine arena of American political life.

For well over a century - since the days of the log-cabin President Andrew Jackson - the White House had been looking west. Increasingly it thought fit to identify itself with the down-home Mark Twain/ L Frank Baum aspect of the national character. Theodore Roosevelt, replacing the assassinated William McKinley in 1901, achieved unprecedented personal popularity by bringing explicitly cowboy values into his conduct of government. The Kennedy innovation was to restore to the presidency some of its old, east-coast elegance, to re-evoke, in appropriately modern guises, the spirit of Jefferson, Alexander Hamilton and the Founding Fathers.

It's easy now to be satirical about the Kennedy White House - those tales of naked girls scattering into the undergrowth like cats whenever Jackie's limousine brought her home unexpectedly still amuse - but one of the strengths of Bradford's book is that she does not underestimate its genuine, if mild enlightenment. In a dangerous age, it lacked cheap fanaticism.

The tone JFK created in those three short years set the moral agenda for the rest of the decade. His idea of the presidency was aspirational and literary, drawn from the 18th-century English Whigs. His tightly honed but grandiloquent rhetoric rang like gold on marble, even when it was covering gross political ineptitude. In public, at his side, Jackie's air of breathless sophistication, her chic cultural warmth complemented it perfectly. In private, she could be softly malicious, infinitely sceptical of those who jostled for influence, scurrilously funny, and full of the entertaining intolerance of those who are young, rich, beautiful and (as they think) impregnable.

Widowhood, and the relationship with Onassis, were to prove her mistaken. She lived on, massively famous but not especially admired, sad but no longer tragic, an icon of stylish jet-set reticence, a living image of tasteful conspicuous consumption, regretted most because she had proved, in the end, to be more psychologically ordinary than history had hoped or expected.

Outwardly, she dwindled the moment she left America, dwarfed by the shadow of a personal legend that she had now outgrown, finally fulfiling Charles de Gaulle's cynical prediction that she would "end up on some millionaire's yacht." Sadly, the second half of her life - much of it spent on beaches or in villas or palatial apartments, after the manner of the idle European super-rich - is little more than a transmutation of the theatrical pure gold of her historically approved widowhood into the base metal of mildly despised celebrity.

Ultimately, like most iconic figures, she remains eerily featherweight, more potent as an image than as any sort of rounded or recognisable personality, the reality of her life rendered insubstantial by the public self that replaced it. Probably no biography can convey what she was really like, although Bradford's seems a calmer and more authoritative account than usual. As Norman Mailer's impressionistic prose suggested long ago, the clear-cut certainties of the essayist tell us more about our own aspirations, and their inevitable disappointment, than they do about her.

It seems fruitless now to survey the casual detritus of her life and pronounce her vain, vapid or self-seeking; to call into question her much-vaunted ersatz-aristocratic good taste; or to accuse her of being, at heart, small-minded and avaricious. There's a morally tough common sense in such criticisms that the immaculate self-absorption of her public persona was always designed to elude or frustrate. Her virtues and their matching, mirroring vices belong less to history than to the world of Scott Fitzgerald, and, like so many of Fitzgerald's haunting and ambivalent characters, she was deliberately arrested and incomplete. She lived within the poetic fiction of her own impossible sensitivity, and was eventually doomed by it.

In any case, after the husky-sweet ingénue of the Kennedy years, the later, Mediterranean-island Jackie - dark, lustful, greedy, perverse - should come as a relief. It's good to see her turning at last from Audrey Hepburn into Sophia Loren, becoming candidly flesh-driven and obsessively materialistic, as if her hormones were in open revolt against the glacial, photogenic dignity in which she had been imprisoned for so long. She was surely never meant to be either a chaste or a particularly serious person. The small liaison with Bobby Kennedy - if it actually took place, which Bradford more or less accepts it did - certainly makes fine dramatic sense. So, too, does Bradford's psychologically plausible thesis that she was scared, all her life, of poverty because she felt she had sailed too close to it imaginatively too early on.

Nevertheless, once the layers of scandal and scandalous speculation are stripped away, we are left with certain observable, significant actions, and these mostly do her credit. She gave much more to JFK than he gave to her, and in public she neither betrayed him nor criticised him. When the nation needed her to act like an old Roman, and ceremonalise her private grief, she did so sparely and magnificently. She cared for and protected her children, surrounding them with a cocoon of privacy from which they clearly benefited. The rest - as Bradford's well done and essentially sympathetic account surely demonstrates- is of very little consequence.

webTitle: Review:  The New Penguin Book of English Verse

fields.headline: Our dearest dust
fields.standfirst: James Wood  hails a bold new anthology -  The New Penguin Book of English Verse
fields.trailText: James Wood hails a bold new anthology - The New Penguin Book of English Verse
fields.body:
The New Penguin Book of English Verse

ed Paul Keegan

1139pp, Allen Lane/ The Penguin Press

£20
Buy it at BOL

As the scorpion, in the famous fable, cannot help being a scorpion, so anthologies cannot help canonising. Even the anti-canonical ones canonise. The slightest anthologised poem has the blush of inclusion on it. Of course, it is not only the anthology's nature, but its task, to canonise. A major anthology such as Paul Keegan's fine new Penguin book, or Christopher Ricks's excellent recent Oxford selection, should first of all include enough of the canonical poets that an unversed reader, limited only to the anthology in question, would not starve amidst frail unknowns, but get a decent, representative sense of the centuries of English verse. The second, less important - if more interesting - task is that the anthology surprise us with the discovery or rediscovery of formerly uncanonical poems and poets.

Paul Keegan's selection acquits itself very well on the first front, and brilliantly on the second. It offers a fuller choice of the canonical poems than does Ricks's (it is a much bigger, almost unwieldy book). Readers will have their own fond and foolish complaints and delights. There are three marvellous selections from the 1611 Authorized Version of the Bible, from 2 Samuel (David's lament over the death of Jonathan), from Job ("Why is light given to a man, whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?"), and the famous passage from Ecclesiastes ("Remember now thy Creator in the days of thy youth").

An inevitable arbitrariness attends the Biblical selections, since there is such richness from which to choose. But a case can be made for the poetic status of the Psalms, and at the very least Psalms 39 and 90 should have been included. Psalm 90, from which Macbeth borrows some of his final soliloquy, resounds throughout English verse: "For a thousand years in thy sight are but as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night." Isaac Watts's familiar hymn, "Our God, our help in ages past", which Keegan includes, is a version.

Comparatively little of Shakespeare is here: a decision was clearly made not to excerpt very much from the plays. I would have liked more George Herbert (who is, curiously, missing from the index) and more Vaughan (no one ever includes his extraordinary poem "Distraction"), and would have traded more Browning for the extract from Webster's The White Devil. Keegan, like Ricks, omits Hopkins's poem "Felix Randal," so that, peculiarly, neither of our major new anthologies has one of the language's loveliest elegies. Like Ricks, Keegan includes only an excerpt of The Waste Land, which is a mistake, but one perhaps having to do with financial considerations: it is too expensive for anthologies to make fuller selections from contemporary work. Perhaps this is also the reason for the omission, in both books, of "The Whitsun Weddings"?

Keegan's book is rich with discoveries and reclaimings, however. Like Ricks, he includes Isaac Watts's "When I survey the wond'rous Cross"; unlike Ricks, he has chosen Charles Wesley's "Morning Hymn": "Christ, whose glory fills the skies." And Keegan has found an extraordinary anonymous inscription, from St Mary Magdalene Church, in Milk Street, from 1609:

Grass of levity

Span in brevity,

Flowers' felicity,

Fire of misery

Winds' stability,

Is mortality.

The book's jewel, for me, is a simple, heartbreaking epitaph by Katherine, Lady Dyer, for her husband, Sir William Dyer, dated 1621. In it, Lady Dyer imagines herself dying and merging with her dead husband. It begins, arrestingly: "My dearest dust," and ends yearningly (I have modernised the spelling):

Mine eyes wax heavy and the day grows old

The dew falls thick, my blood grows cold;

Draw, draw the closed curtains: and make room;

My dear, my dearest dust; I come, I come.

It is a beautiful lyric, a simpler version of Henry King's later "Exequy", and one of those poems that once encountered, forever modify one's sensibility. I did not know it; it appears to be one of Keegan's great discoveries: Ricks does not include it, and neither does Alastair Fowler in his New Oxford Book of Seventeenth Century Verse .

Keegan's innovation - which, he tells us, is actually an old method - is to arrange the poems not by author, but by year, moving chronologically through the centuries. The anchoring year is the date of publication. Thus, for 1640, we find Henry King's "Exequy", along with poems by Thomas Carew and Ben Jonson. Or in 1919, we read Laurence Binyon's war poem "For the Fallen" next to Yeats's "The Wild Swans at Coole" and Eliot's "Sweeney Among the Nightingales".

This is not a gimmick, but a bold and inspired mingling. The conventional approach, gathering poems by author, suddenly seems dry; Keegan's book, by contrast, sprinkles each poem with a little of the water of history. Writers are not formally compacted, but chronologically stretched: one will come across, naturally, several different Wordsworths or Yeatses over several decades. Keegan writes in his introduction that the effect is to make his anthology a thematic one, whose theme is chronology itself. He is right, of course, and the reader can see the language changing, and read it almost as if it were a musical score, with its curling dynamics.

But he is perhaps too modest. For he also pays great attention to the ways that poems echo and reprise each other, and his mode of selection allows us to do this in enlivening ways. For instance, if one wanted, after coming upon Lady Dyer's "dearest dust" (1621), to trace the use of this word as a religious metonym for mortality and the mortal body, one could move forward to 1633, and find Herbert's "Love bade me welcome: yet my soul drew back,/ Guiltie of dust and sinne". 1640 provides a variation: Henry King's elegiac phrase "For Thee (Lov'd Clay)"; and 1650 brings a poem by James Graham, Marquis of Montrose, with the line "I'm hopeful, once Thou'lt recollect my Dust". Charles Cotton, in 1689, has a poem called "An Epitaph on M.H.", in which he saucily elegises a seductive woman. He admits that his memory of her, and his poem, is masturbatory, almost necrophiliac in impulse:

And now her Memory pursue

With such a superstitious Lust,

That I could fumble with her Dust.

And so on, all the way to 1922, and Eliot's "I will show you fear in a handful of dust" from The Waste Land.

Needless to say, such travels are not themselves dusty in spirit, but are adventures on the paths of etymology. Keegan makes us picaros of poetry, and this very exciting, bold new book becomes our happy carriage.

fields.headline: Dreaming up the Doctor
fields.standfirst: John Mullan  sees how Boswell created our Johnson - and the idea of biography, in Adam Sisman's Boswell's Presumptuous Task
fields.trailText: John Mullan sees how Boswell created our Johnson - and the idea of biography, in Adam Sisman's Boswell's Presumptuous Task
fields.body:
Boswell's Presumptuous Task
Adam Sisman
392pp, Hamish Hamilton
£17.99
Buy it at BOL

Here is the invention of biography. Before James Boswell's Life of Johnson was published in 1791, there had been "Lives" aplenty, but nothing with the exactitude and impertinence that we have come to expect from the searching biographer. "Lives" were usually reverential narratives attached to bowdlerised editions of a dead person's correspondence; occasionally, and more entertainingly, they were acts of revenge by enemies or critics. In neither case, even if they contained "facts", could they actually be believed. Boswell set biography a new ambition: capturing the copiousness and quiddity of a personality - the self peculiarly revealed in odd quirks and, especially, in unpredictable, evanescent talk.

Boswell's Presumptuous Task is an account of this invention of biography. It is not a life of Boswell, nor even the story of his relationship with Johnson, though the outlines of both are rapidly provided. Instead it is a study of Boswell's making of the Life of Johnson, and his efforts to trump rival Lives of his hero. Johnson dies on page 73, with Boswell already in his mid-forties. The meat of the book is concerned with Boswell's seven-year struggle (often against his own indolence or self-doubt) to complete the work that friends and rivals all expected from him. "Ages may revolve before such a man shall appear again," Boswell was to pronounce, but his memorial was not mere homage. He told his readers of Johnson's scars, convulsions and terrible table manners. He let them sense Johnson's touchiness and his black melancholy. "Everything relative to so great a man is worth observing".

That inclusiveness, which biography-hungry readers now take for granted, angered many of Boswell's contemporaries. His records of "private conversations" were thought to be undignified or even morally repugnant. His pursuit of the "authenticity" that he vaunted nettled many who appeared in the Life or its prequel, his wonderful Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides with Johnson. Edmund Burke could not forgive him for publishing Johnson's observation that Burke "never once made a good joke" (the hurt made worse by a long footnote in which Boswell tried to compensate by recording some of Burke's weak jests). Several of those who had locked horns with Johnson during his journey with Boswell through the Highlands were aggrieved to find themselves bested again on the printed page. With a background in publishing, Sisman is appropriately appreciative of Boswell's capacity to offend, and the improvement of his work's sales by this.

Yet Johnson had himself coined a now familiar word - "clubable" (sic) - to describe Boswell (who typically quoted the compliment in the Life ). Boswell's powers of ingratiation were crucial to the creation of his magnum opus, for he had to squeeze from Johnson's acquaintances their recollections and, often enough, their correspondence. Johnson had known that Boswell would undertake this on his death and that he was making a record of their conversations. Indeed, he had encouraged Boswell to keep his journal, as a monitor of his vanities and weaknesses. Meanwhile, he drew the line at some revelations, and was careful to destroy his own diary.

"In making Johnson a hero, Boswell made sense of his own life," says Sisman. Boswell was ever a hero-seeker and, as Thomas Carlyle put it, "a hunter after spiritual Notabilities". As a teenager, he managed to arrange a meeting with the actor David Garrick, whom he adored "as a heathen god". He arrived at the doorstep of Rousseau's Alpine retreat and inveigled his way in. He flattered Voltaire into an "interview". When he finally met Johnson in the back of Thomas Davies's Covent Garden bookshop, he was bagging another lion: "about seven came in the great Mr. Samuel Johnson, whom I have so long wished to see". He had already met him in his books; he already knew what he was after.

He soon became renowned as Johnson's recording shadow, and was not often admired for being so. In his Life, he depicts himself as kindler of Johnson's wit and often its butt. He stirs the great man with provoking enquiries and suffers his rejoinders. However, Fanny Burney noted how he was also an unconscious echoer of his master: "He had an odd, mock solemnity of tone and manner, that he had acquired imperceptibly from constantly thinking of and imitating Dr Johnson." Boswell's replication of Johnson's very accents is just Sisman's theme and, like some other admirers of the Life before him, he is little interested in Johnson's writing. He is curiously incurious about what made Johnson, as he puts it, "a dominant literary presence", limply supposing that contemporaries found his word "reassuring". Only Johnson's importance to Boswell is important.

Yet Sisman's approach has its virtues. His work in publishing shows in a good way, as the drama that he captures best is that of the nitty-gritty making of a book: the evasion of deadlines, the corner-cutting and self-censorship, the final hectic scramble with proofs as the author kept trying to find places for new minutiae. Boswell was helped, but we should more truly say "superintended", by Edmond Malone, who had also co-edited the Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides. Malone was an editorial genius: even while he was prodding or restraining Boswell, he was working on what was to be the most influential edition ever of Shakespeare's works. Boswell read his first draft aloud to Malone, marking his comments for later emendations. As Sisman makes clear, his "nice correction" of the Life involved not only innumerable stylistic changes, but also the rewriting of quotations into "what Malone - a scholar skilled at recovering authentic texts - believed that Johnson was most likely to have said". Johnson had to be created as well as remembered.

Boswell's Johnson was "a hero who defied oblivion". Boswell himself was possessed of a terror of self-extinction. This was revealed most clearly in his terrible fascination with those close to death. He befriended the Keeper of Newgate Prison and procured interviews with condemned criminals. He was an inveterate attender at public executions, closely observing how men and women looked death in the face. And when his friend, the philosopher David Hume, was on his deathbed, Boswell haunted his Edinburgh apartment. Boswell was waiting to see if the notorious sceptic and supposed atheist would finally recant his disbelief (he did not), and was importunate with questions about Hume's feelings in the face of his imminent extinction.

In a sense that Sisman does grasp, the whole of Boswell's "journalising" was a fending off of oblivion. He quotes Boswell's Shandean thought that "I should live no more than I can record, as one should not have more corn growing than one can get in". By making Johnson live he was proving his own vitality. Indeed, without any particular cheating, he managed to give the impression that he was part of the very fabric of Johnson's life, even though Johnson was 53 when they first met and subsequently spent only brief periods, usually each spring, in Boswell's company.

By narrowing his gaze to Boswell's "heroic expression of Boswell himself", Sisman has produced a sharp-edged portrait. It is not a work of research; everywhere it relies on the unsung Boswell scholars who, over half a century, have made the Yale edition of the Boswell papers one of the great editorial achievements of modern times. Yet it teaches any expert a lesson in the art of narrative.

fields.headline: Dead elves and private eyes
fields.standfirst: Steve Aylett's  Atom shows  a writer living up to his gifts, says  Phil Daoust
fields.trailText: Steve Aylett's Atom shows a writer living up to his gifts, says Phil Daoust
fields.body:
Atom

Steve Aylett

137pp, Phoenix House

£9.99
Buy it at BOL

Remember the scene in Sleeping Beauty where the good fairies bless the baby princess, bending over her cot to bestow wit, grace and freedom from halitosis? Something like that must have happened after Steve Aylett was born.

Runyon, Chandler, Eluard, Vian and Dali all dropped by with kisses for mum and gifts for the baby: Stripper Barbies and Bookie Kens; toy revolvers and Junior Private Eye badges; bags of blue oranges; and book after book of fairy tales in which wolves shave off their fur and marry Little Red Riding Hoods, or ugly ducklings turn into mean-tempered lobsters.

Since 1994 and his debut work The Crime Studio, Aylett has been messing around with those gifts. His playpen is an American city called Beerlight, a lawless, bullet-sleeting Gotham whose denizens vie to commit the most outrageous crime. "Well," the saying goes, "these bullets ain't gonna fire themselves." TV stations forecast riots rather than weather; life is as cheap as a second-hand condom; liberty is what's left when the cops can't be bothered to stitch you up.

Now, in his fifth book, Aylett seems to have worked it all out. Atom is a jaw-droppingly dark and funny work. At the novel's heart is a private eye called Taffy Atom, lover of a weapons specialist and owner of a wisecracking mutant fish. Mystery shrouds his past, present and future. His father may have been a clown who died in a miniature-car pile-up, or an architect who vanished in one of his own physics-defying buildings. According to Beerlight's chief of police, Atom once built a tugboat out of dead elves, "because they said it couldn't be done". His behaviour is ruthless, disproportionate, unpredictable; his weapons bend time and reality.

When someone blows up the city's brain-storage facility, our hero finds himself searching for Kafka's frozen headcheese, hassled by the police, rival crime bosses and a mad professor who wants to hand the world over to the insects. Bombs go off, hostages are taken, innocent bystanders chopped down like meerkats at a lawnmower rally ...

Meanwhile, as if comic relief were needed, another drama is being played out in the news. A president is caught up in a spiralling sex scandal involving first a dog, then a lizard, then a squid and finally a python.

The plot, though, matters far less than Aylett's merciless, hardnosed wit. Characters spark off one another like flints in a spin drier. Out spew images as shiny and as perfect as new-minted coins: one villain "comes apart like a soaked loaf"; another is "as inconspicuous as a pig in a minefield". How, you wonder, did we ever do without these phrases?

After a while, you may find yourself becoming jealous, as Aylett shuts down your own opportunities for verbal brilliance. One thought should console you: after this, his next book is sure to be a let-down.

fields.headline: Terms of imprisonment
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer  on  Turlough  by hostage Brian Keenan
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer on Turlough by hostage Brian Keenan
fields.body:
Turlough

Brian Keenan

332pp, Cape

£16.99
Buy it at BOL

Despite its setting in 17th-century Ireland, the key features of Brian Keenan's first novel - its claustrophobic atmosphere, its depiction of the horror of civil slaughter, and its portrayal of a protagonist in whom ordinary perception is displaced by spiritual vision - spring from the writer's imprisonment in the 1980s by Shi'ite militiamen in Beirut. Turlough O'Carolan, the legendary blind Irish bard, came as a vision to Keenan in his solitude, camping with him in his tiny cell, spinning him stories and protecting him from madness. After his release, Keenan reckoned he owed "a debt of honour to a man who saved my sanity and enriched my soul", and undertook years of research into the patchy historical data and fervent eyewitness statements surrounding him. The resulting fictionalised account is a faithful portrait of a musical genius, drunken lout, spiritual healer, liar and clown.

Blinded by smallpox as a young man, Turlough turned to the harp and played his way into history, charming the old aristocracy in their crumbling houses and serenading the starving poor in their stinking hovels. Keenan paints him as a man with Janus as his idol, a devotee of both the modern religion and the ancient spirits, a sightless seer who, staggering through the tragic ruins of his once-great land - crushed by its enemies, wet with the blood of its brave young men, God-worshipping yet God-forsaken - belts out songs of joy and peace.

This is Ireland in the grip of ethnic cleansing, stretched on the rack of new penal laws, its ancient nobles reduced to pushing ploughs, its bishops burying murdered boys and blessing the corpses of starved mothers with their dead babies clustered round them.

Amidst this hell on earth, O'Carolan has to look for the light, preach of peace and chase the face of God. He must turn towards the future and yet at the same time learn to evoke the lost beauty of his tortured country, drawing on the old music and recreating her magical, heroic past - embodying Ireland's cultural soul, the one part of her that can not be raped and starved and battered into submission.

Keenan in his cell must have felt like Turlough: blind, incapacitated, imprisoned, surrounded by confusing enemies, trying desperately to find his way out into the light, in the end having to seek it inside his own head and heart because there were no other doors available to him to open. Keenan wrote a best-selling book about his imprisonment, An Evil Cradling. This first work of fiction is also surely the story of his terrible imprisonment and triumphant survival.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit gets a thrill from 24 Hours by Greg Iles, Pomona Queen by Kem Nunn and Patricia Highsmith's The Cry of the Owl
fields.trailText: Chris Petit gets a thrill from 24 Hours by Greg Iles, Pomona Queen by Kem Nunn and Patricia Highsmith's The Cry of the Owl
fields.body:
There is always pleasure to be had from the terrorisation of the smug and prosperous middle classes, and in 24 Hours (Hodder and Stoughton, £10) Greg Iles's kidnap plot ensures that the parents of the abducted girl are suitably complacent. But beyond that, the characters display little more than the stripped-down feel of people in a movie, with physical and mental complications there only to serve a push-button plot: diabetes, guilty conscience, simple-mindedness, wonder drug (assemble accordingly). While 24 Hours has the kit-like efficiency of a script, a hurried style that mixes good writing with bad, and takes pleasure in its cinematic references, it never transcends the films from which it borrows: The Desperate Hours , in which Humphrey Bogart invaded Frederic March's home, and Cape Fear with Robert Mitchum.

Buy it at BOL

Kem Nunn's Pomona Queen (No Exit Press, £6.99) unfolds like 24 Hours in a single burst, which starts with a vacuum-cleaner salesman on his rounds and some hours later sees him cowering in the back of a speeding truck, witness to the numinous sight of the naked, dead body of Buddy Brown as it accidentally departs the vehicle. It is thrown clear of the ice-packed freezer in which it is being kept, and "for one magical moment appeared simply to hang there, amid the glare of lights, the shards of flying ice and glass, as if poised for flight". In lesser hands Pomona Queen could have been one of those glib, David Lynch-type stories of innocence abroad and cardboard villainy in the dark suburbs of the heart. But Nunn wrote the great surfing novels Tapping the Source and The Dogs of Winter , which is recommendation enough. Pomona Queen is also heavily influenced by movies, but Nunn, unlike Iles, absorbs his sources, particularly Chinatown, with its similar story of a history's corrupt legacy, and he has a real feel for the kind of dementia that depends on getting the balance of drugs and alcohol just right.

Buy it at BOL

Several Patricia Highsmith novels are currently reissued, including one of her best, The Cry of the Owl (Vintage, £6.99), first published in 1962. Highsmith's crafted suspense is extraordinary for the way it sticks so ruthlessly to the ordinary, demonstrating how daytime anxieties are only a step away from the full-blown waking nightmare. Her writing is the opposite of escapism, and no one else demonstrates so remorselessly how easy it is to, say, bash someone's brains in with an ashtray, and why one might enjoy it, and how, from the tiniest flaws, emerge situations where the only impossibility is extrication.

Buy it at BOL
