fields.headline: George W who?
fields.trailText: • As we await the traditional judges' spats in the aftermath of the Booker Prize, controversy so far has centred on the "live TV" announcement that wasn't. As nervy publishing staff crowded round flickering Soho TV sets to await the moment of truth, the movers and shakers at the Guildhall were already flocking to Margaret Atwood's table to assure her and publishers Bloomsbury that the judges had got it right. Meanwhile, those logging on to the Booker Prize website also received the news "early". The delay in Channel 4's transmission was, of course, down to extended news coverage of the US election, but that hasn't mollified outraged publishers keen to denounce the evening as "a sham" and "a disgrace". Quite right, too: what's a little bit of politics compared to the weighty stuff of literature?
fields.body:
 As we await the traditional judges' spats in the aftermath of the Booker Prize, controversy so far has centred on the "live TV" announcement that wasn't. As nervy publishing staff crowded round flickering Soho TV sets to await the moment of truth, the movers and shakers at the Guildhall were already flocking to Margaret Atwood's table to assure her and publishers Bloomsbury that the judges had got it right. Meanwhile, those logging on to the Booker Prize website also received the news "early". The delay in Channel 4's transmission was, of course, down to extended news coverage of the US election, but that hasn't mollified outraged publishers keen to denounce the evening as "a sham" and "a disgrace". Quite right, too: what's a little bit of politics compared to the weighty stuff of literature?

 The seared tuna was a bit dull, but the sticky toffee pudding was well worth waiting for: the most important verdict of Tuesday night's proceedings concerned Gordon Ramsay's lavish dinner. Those little piggies who went without their roast beef got to dash madly between various publishers' parties either congratulating or consoling. Peculiarly, this year saw two competing publishers team up - Picador and Penguin threw the most stylish gathering, but were rewarded by a mass exodus to the Bloomsbury bash after the announcement of Margaret Atwood's victory. The smart money wound down at the chilled-out Faber do, at which Kazuo Ishiguro was remarkably gracious in defeat, but those hoping to drop by and chat to Brian O'Doherty were in for a disappointment - in a puzzling move, Arcadia held their party the night before.

 Meanwhile, Bloomsbury staff were enjoying the icing on the cake of their annus mirabilis. Atwood's editor, Liz Calder, is preparing to step down as editor-in-chief after a year in which, as one acolyte excitedly told the Loafer, Bloomsbury was named Publisher of the Year, Harry Potter triumphed, and Calder herself published novels by Michael Ondaatje and Will Self. But another employee was rather Eeyoreish. "That's it now," she mused mournfully. "Things will never get this good again."

 A horrifying vision from Self himself, who was in conversation with Rick Moody at the Festival Hall last weekend. Asked by an impertinent member of the audience whether he regretted not being more "experimental", Self replied "Would I like to create a whole new literary form? Yes. I'd also like to be a woman. Is it likely? No." That might take the smile off Liz Calder's face.

 Sign of the times: students visiting Sussex University Bookshop to stock up on set texts will soon be able to buy peppermint foot lotion and facial scrub. The first Body Shop department in a bookshop is on its way.

webTitle: Spankings do the trick and clean sheets come at last

fields.headline: Spankings do the trick and clean sheets come at last
fields.standfirst: Ron's on the warpath
fields.trailText: Ho ho ... I'm back! ... when Ron puts his foot down ... people sit up and take notice! Apologies to everyone who missed the column last Saturday ... didn't read it myself!
fields.body:
Ho ho ... I'm back! ... when Ron puts his foot down ... people sit up and take notice! Apologies to everyone who missed the column last Saturday ... didn't read it myself! ... Then midweek Mrs Manager discovered that the Sports section actually opens out ... What an eye-opener! ... seems like everybody's a football pundit nowadays! ... What a load of Guff! ... Ho ho, you couldn't make it up! ...

... Take lowly Charlton ... languishing at the foot of the table ... walloping lowly Bradford ... freak weather conditions ... Michael Fish in his pomp! ... A mighty poplar crashes through the roof at the Valley ... what are the press interested in? ... a cheap laugh at Stan Collymore and his wisdom teeth! ... at least they're not taking a pop at the weather girl!

Well Sven, that's what you're up against ... hmm? ... marvellous!

... Look at Bryan Robson! ... Middlesbrough languishing at the foot of the table ... calls for his head! ... but it's an old head on er ... middle-aged shoulders and he'll soon have them singing again at the Riverside! ... "Oop the Boro! ... the Boro's going oop!"

"Out of favour" Hamilton Ricard asks for a move ... does Bryan bat an eyelid? ... couldn't if he tried! ... tells him "Put it in writing!" ... canny! ... hmm? ... it kept Gazza there for months! ...

Dr Willi Railo! ... worked with Eriksson for 20 years ... Will the press go for him? ... He knows how to get results! ... Give him a striker who's lost confidence ... Willi hands him a pen and paper! ...

"Draw me what you see when you take a penalty!" ... He sketches a small goal and a massive goalie! ... hah! ... simple! ... it's all in the mind! ... Dr Willi works his tricks ... three months later ... the striker draws a yawning net! ... and ... Bang! ... bottom corner!

It's the magic in your mind! ... isn't it? ... Confidence tricks! ... reminiscent of Eileen Drewery in her pomp! ... ask Glenn! ... ho ho ... Psycho! ... isn't it? ... not Glenn! ... Stuart Pearce! ...that abject penalty miss at Italia 90? ... a few sessions round Eileen's crystal ball and he swaggers back up to the spot ... a mighty thump! ... hits it perfectly ... Bang! Takes a wicked deflection off a big rabbit called Harvey ... Boof! ... row Z!

Right ho! ... time for ... Ron dips his toe in the Nationwide ...

Alan Smith's "lazy sloppy whingers" at Palace give Wednesday a good spanking! ... Paul Jewell ... does he mind? ... "The league's our bread and butter ... a kick up the backside is what we needed!" ... ho ho ... marvellous! ... that's the murky waters of the Nationwide!

... er ... Back to the Premiership! ... Monday night and another manager "under the cosh" ... Jim Smith! ... Jim's multi-national Derby side taking on West Ham ... quality teams! ... languishing at the foot of the table ... goalless nonsense! ... but a great result for Bald Eagle ... first clean sheet this season!

And ... first outing at Pride Park for Lilian Martin! ... eh? ... hint of desperation? ... hmm? ... but no, he's a man! ... er, and I'm not a fan of "outing players" ... but reading "Bogus Irishman" Cascarino's shocking admission that he dyes his hair? ... set the alarm bells ringing! ... on the phone to Ken Bates, hoping to smooth over last week's slight "faux-pas" over Ken and Abel Xavier ... and let me repeat ... they are not related! ... but a sudden thought occurs! ... Abel's "barnet" might not be its natural colour ... and Blow me! ... Ken is actually a red-head! ... much like 80s heart-throb Rula Lenska! ... ho ho! ... quite a week!

I had hoped to take in that early morning Leeds-Liverpool game last Saturday ... but travelling up on the train with Big Norm the night before ... a furious game of Happy Families ensued ... leaving me utterly drained ... ... Norm's reluctance to concede possession of Mr Bun the Baker resulting in a fierce tussle which continued in our hotel bar long into the night ... at some point sheer fatigue causing me to slide off the seat in a deadly torpor! ... didn't even make it to my bed! ... Come the morning... I was stilllanguishing at the foot of the table ... still ... first clean sheet this season!

And here's one for ... Ron's England Dream Team!

You've heard the critics ... hmm? ... no left-sided players ... Owen ... no left foot? Beckham ... no left foot? ... Guff! ... it was a criticism often levelled at myself in my playing days ... Ron Manager ... no left foot! ... made me hopping mad! ... if you're looking for stability in the side ... Paulo Wanchope! ... born leader! ... leader of the ganglers! ... two left feet! ... solve England's imbalance at a stroke!

And just time for a Reader's letter! ... Mr Mark Pitts of Chiswick writes: "What's happened to the atmosphere at futeball? ... I was at Old Trafford ..."

... All right, Mark, that's enough ... I think we'll finish with my one to watch! ... Paul Merson! ... every day's his cup final! ... if Sven wants the England squad singing from the same hymn sheet ... playing happy families ... "Born-again" Merse is the man ... he's hit a purple patch! ... pulled himself up by the boot-laces! ... takes a game by the scruff of the neck ... er ... is that it?...

Ron Manager was talking to H'Angus the monkey over a prawn sandwich and a game of Mah-Jong at the Priory. © Paul Whitehouse and Jim Reilly 2000

fields.headline: The second stage groups
fields.standfirst: Those groups in full, and how they square up
fields.trailText: Those groups in full, and how they square up.
fields.body:
Group A

Valencia 10-1
Domestic league position 1st
Champions Cup best Runners-up 2000
Prospects Winners of the weakest qualifying group, but Hector Cuper's squad are full of self-belief after last season's heroics and a dynamic start to the domestic season.

Sturm Graz 80-1
League position 6th
Champions Cup best First phase 1998, 1999
Prospects Weird route to this stage after two 5-0 defeats, but the Austrians are likely to raise further eyebrows only for their stadium (Schwarzenegger) and their goalkeeper (Schicklgruber).

Manchester United 4-1
League position 1st
Champions Cup best Winners 1968, 1999
Prospects Only scraped through in what should have been a comfortable group, but well capable of stepping up a gear, if indeed they need to, having again struck lucky. Jaap Stam's absence is their main concern.

Panathinaikos 50-1
League position 2nd
Champions Cup best Runners-up 1971
Prospects The Greeks' mainly homegrown squad should not have the quality to trouble the top sides, but must be respected after knocking out Juventus.

Group B

Milan 6-1
League position 13th
Champions Cup best Winners 1963, 1969, 1989, 1990, 1994
Prospects Too busy promoting breakaway leagues to worry about actually winning the thing for the past five years. Packed with stars as ever, but the San Siro cabbage patch will not help them.

Deportivo La Coruna 16-1
League position 3rd
Champions Cup best Never previously qualified
Prospects Amazingly, the only team unbeaten in the first group stage. Like Valencia, successfully challenging Real Madrid and Barcelona at home means they will fear no one.

Paris St-Germain 25-1
League position 2nd
Champions Cup best SF 1995
Prospects Lots of fun going forward (if Nicolas Anelka can be classed as 'fun'), not so clever at the back. Qualified comfortably, but always vulnerable and there are no soft touches in this group.

Galatasaray 50-1
League position 5th
Champions Cup best SF 1989
Prospects The Uefa Cup holders cannot be lightly dismissed, especially in Istanbul, as Milan will recall from their humiliating defeat there last season. Hagi, even at walking pace, is still an entertainment in himself.

Group C

Bayern Munich 9-1
League position 2nd
Champions Cup best Winners 1974, 1975, 1976
Prospects All is not well in German football and even mighty Bayern are not immune. Cannot be discounted, but if they go out it will be the first year since 1993 there has been no German representative in the last eight.

Arsenal 6-1
League position 2nd
Champions Cup best QF 1972
Prospects Immaculate home form in both Premiership and Champions League is a solid base in a moderate group, but must resolve goalkeeping uncertainty if they are to go much further.

Spartak Moscow 66-1
League position 1st (winners)
Champions Cup best SF 1991
Prospects Eastern Europe's only representatives will have the usual disadvantage of playing high-pressure ties during and just after their winter break. Unlikely to annoy Uefa by qualifying.

Lyon 50-1
League position 10th
Champions Cup best 3rd qual round 2000
Prospects Arsenal have painful memories of Tony Vairelles from his Lens days and, with Marc-Viven Foé and Sonny Anderson, he may worry a few defences. But Lyon are untested at this level and hardly setting the league alight.

Group D

Real Madrid 9-2
League position 7th
Champions Cup best Winners 1956, 1957, 1958, 1959, 1960, 1966, 1998, 2000
Prospects The holders have an unmatchable European pedigree, were the top scorers in the group stage and they've got Luis Figo. What could possibly go wrong?

Anderlecht 33-1
League position 2nd
Champions Cup best SF 1982, 1985
Prospects Surprise group winners above Manchester United, but their 5-1 defeat at Old Trafford may be a better guide to their chances.

Lazio 5-1
League position 5th
Champions Cup best QF 2000
Prospects Among the favourites, but unconvincing both against Arsenal and in the league so far. And the manager may start getting distracted in March.

Leeds 25-1
League position 8th
Champions Cup best Runners-up 1975
Prospects Dealt another fearsome group, but they will go into it without fear after disposing of Barcelona. The return of Kewell and Bridges in the spring will help.

Match days: Nov 21-2, Dec. 5-6, Feb. 13-4, March 6-7, March 13-4

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Enter another Isa age
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: We're only 18 months into the new era of tax-free saving and Gordon Brown has already decided to give individual savings accounts (Isas) a facelift.
fields.body:
We're only 18 months into the new era of tax-free saving and Gordon Brown has already decided to give individual savings accounts (Isas) a facelift.

Much of what he had to say was good. He has decided that the introductory annual limit of £7,000 on the amount people can invest in Isas will be retained for a further five years. And he is extending tax-free saving to 16 and 17-year-olds. But there were also one or two hidden nasties lurking within his revamp.

Money put into Isas can be invested in cash, stocks and shares, and/or life insurance. Individuals can take out one "maxi" Isa, or up to three mini-Isas, a year. The annual allowance was due to fall to £5,000 in April but the Chancellor has kept it at £7,000 (including up to £3,000 in cash) until April 2006, a move widely welcomed.

Also praised was the decision to bring the rules for Peps - which were replaced by Isas last year - into line with those for the new accounts. This will give the millions of people with Peps access to a much wider range of investment opportunities because it ends the geographic restrictions on where Pep money can be invested. As the Revenue says, Pep investors will now be able to invest in the listed shares of companies based anywhere in the world and will also have access to a wider range of investment funds.

"Currently Pep-holders are largely restricted to investing within the European Union, but as of next April they can take advantage of the Isa regulations which allow investment worldwide," says the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds (Autif).

Also, the distinction between general Peps and single company Peps will disappear, which means people with single company Peps who are keen to transfer to a less risky collective investment fund will be able to do so from April, says independent financial adviser Bates Investment Services. Currently they can only move their investment to another single company Pep.

As part of its drive to encourage people to start saving earlier, the government said that from April, 16 and 17-year-olds can open a cash Isa. The move extends tax-free investing to 100,000 under-18s who work and pay tax.

But buried in the small print was the revelation that in many cases, this tax-free saving opportunity will not apply to pocket money or any other cash given to the teenager by their parents, which is then put into an Isa. The Revenue says that if a parent gives their child money to invest in an Isa, and the investment income arising on all gifts from that parent to their child during the year is more than £100, this money will be treated as the parents' income for tax purposes and will be taxable. In other words, if you put in money from a Saturday job, that's OK, but if you put in cash given to you by your parents, it's possible you could fall foul of the taxman. It's no wonder some experts, such as Anne Redston at accountants Ernst & Young, are saying it is going to be very hard to police.

It was also revealed that around 85,000 people have broken the rules on how many Isas they are allowed to hold, perhaps by unwittingly taking out both a maxi and a mini-Isa in the same tax year. There had been calls for the government to grant an "amnesty" for these people but the Revenue has rejected this idea.

As a result, if someone took out a cash mini-Isa and then invested in a maxi Isa during the same tax year, the second of these accounts will be closed down and the investor will get their investment back, plus probably a tax bill for any relief they have had.

fields.headline: A new tie that won't suit you
fields.standfirst:
Brown lends banks a foot up in pensions market

Money Unlimited
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Slipped into this week's pre-Budget report were proposals that have stunned financial advisers, writes Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Is your bank manager the right person to sort out your pension, investments and insurance? Slipped into this week's pre-Budget report were proposals that have stunned financial advisers and which are likely to lead to a transformation in the way financial products are sold.

The proposals, condemned by consumer groups and financial advisers alike, are being widely tipped as giving the big banks enormous new muscle in the market for pensions and investments.

Until this week, the financial advice market was split into two distinct camps; tied agents and independent financial agents. The tied agents only sell the products of one company, while the IFAs are obliged to sweep the entire market to find the best product for you.

The big four banks, plus Abbey National and Halifax, are all tied agents. For example, walk into a branch of Lloyds TSB, and the person behind the counter can only sell you a pension from insurer Scottish Widows, which Lloyds TSB bought last year. Barclays is tied to Barclays Life, Halifax to Halifax Life, and so on.

But from April next year, under changes announced by the Treasury this week, the banks will be able to become "multi-tied". For example, Lloyds TSB could start offering pensions from a panel of insurers, such as Legal & General, Norwich Union or even Virgin and Marks & Spencer.

Treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson believes savers will be the winners from the new regime. She said: "Enabling tied agents to offer a wider choice of savings vehicles will pave the way to provide more real choice for consumers and help to encourage the savings habit."

The banks have also reacted positively to the changes. But others say it is little more than a "panic move" by the Treasury to boost sales of stakeholder pensions when they become available in April next year, and which will result in higher charges and, ultimately, worse choice for savers.

Leading the opposition is the Consumers' Association, which calls the proposals "half-baked and misguided." Senior money researcher Mick McAteer says: "We cannot understand the thinking behind this. The government says it will enable banks to offer better products. But if they want to offer genuinely better products, all they have to do is to ditch their tied arrangements and become independent. It is, after all, what they were doing only 15 years ago before they became tied or bought up life insurance companies."

Many fear a repeat of the scramble to tie up banks in the early 1990s, which resulted in huge commission earnings for the banks, but which some argue contributed significantly to the mis-selling of personal pensions and endowments. John Lappin, editor of Money Marketing, the weekly newspaper for IFAs, says: "Banks are the big winners from the move to multi-ties, but the history of banks' involvement in financial advice is that they tend to mess up. The banks were among the worst at selling personal pensions to people in occupational schemes and pushing endowments, and several have been fined for mis-selling."

Until the end of the 1980s banks such as NatWest and Barclays were independent advisers, but found that giving independent advice was less lucrative than either tying up with an insurer or setting up their own insurance company.

To win the tie with a bank, the insurance companies dangled big commission deals, which were subsequently passed on in higher charges. The expectation now is that the same process will happen again, as insurers fight each other to get on to the banks' panels.

Daniel Godfrey of the Association of Investment Trust Companies says: "This move is likely to lead to a new round of increased incentives for those who offer distribution and therefore a rise in charges for the very consumers that this move is intended to benefit. It is likely to fail the consumer once again by increasing costs and reducing the availability of truly independent advice."

But is this special pleading by the groups and associations that depend on IFAs? The treasury believes it can avoid the impact of higher charges by limiting multi-tied products to just stakeholder pensions and CAT-market Individual Savings Accounts. Under the stakeholder and CAT rules, annual charges cannot exceed 1% a year, so even if the insurers tempt the banks with big commissions, they will find it difficult to pass the extra costs on in charges for consumers.

However Mr Lappin adds: "What is remarkable is that for the first time consumer groups and IFAs are in agreement. They both firmly believe that multi-ties are bad news for consumers."

As the insurance companies fight for a place in the banks' branches, only the giant ones with big pockets will win, predicts Mr Lappin. He says it is therefore almost inevitable that multi-tying will lead to rapid consolidation among insurers, possibly resulting in just three or four giant insurance companies. "Having a choice of just three or four companies rather than 30 or 40 is not going to help anyone. The Treasury says this multi-tying will lead to more choice, but it is just as likely to lead to less choice," he warns.

fields.headline: Time to help the aged
fields.standfirst:
Raising pensioners' benefits has not silenced the Chancellor's critics, who say that a greater reliance on means testing will stop many from claiming, reports Phillip Inman

Money Unlimited
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Raising pensioners' benefits has not silenced the Chancellor's critics, who say that a greater reliance on means testing will stop many from claiming, reports Phillip Inman.
fields.body:
The government was accused this week of bamboozling pensioners with a complicated scheme designed to top up the state pension with means-tested benefits.

Chancellor Gordon Brown announced a rise in the state pension of £5 to £72.50 for single pensioners, in his Pre-Budget statement. Pensioner couples were awarded a rise of £8 taking their basic weekly total to £115.90.

He also said pensioners would benefit from a rise in the winter allowance from £100 to £200, payable from next week, rather than the £150 already slated by the government.

The rises were widely welcomed among pensioner groups as the first above-inflation boost in the state pension in 20 years.

But the charities Help the Aged and Age Concern claim the Chancellor has devised a complicated system based on means-tested benefits that many low-income pensioners would fail to claim. And the National Pensioners Convention says the rises would "do nothing to dampen pensioners' anger" and repeated the call for pensions to be linked to earnings.

Last April, the state pension increased by 75p to £67.50. The decision to stick with the inflation-linked rise proved an embarrassment to the government and Mr Brown was accused of being out of touch. Protesters rallied against the government, culminating in a lobby of Number 10 led by former Labour minister Barbara Castle and Cherie Blair's father Tony Booth.

Since coming to office in 1997, the government has re fused to link rises in the state pension with rises in earnings. Instead, it has brought in a minimum income guarantee, which replaced income support, that will rise to £100 a week for single pensioners and to £154 for couples in 2003. Pensioners must fill in a 40-page form to claim income support up to the level of the guarantee. Claimants must give details of any other income from savings or private pensions, which are offset, pound for pound, against benefits.

This week, social security secretary Alistair Darling set out details of a pension credit that will allow pensioners to keep 60p in every pound of their other income up to a limit of £135. The credit, which will take effect from 2003, is designed to encourage people on low incomes to save without all their savings being offset against benefits.

Critics argue that raising pensioner living standards using means-tested benefits has proved excessively complicated and the credit only adds to the confusion.

Mervyn Kohler, Help the Aged head of public affairs, says: "The concept of the Pensions Credit is vital to the government if its strategy of targeting the poorest pensioners through the minimum income guarantee is going to have any credibility. But it is far too complex and over-elaborate. It is clever, but is it right? It inevitably draws more pensioners into means-testing, which many will resent, and so far the take-up rate for the MIG is far from impressive.

"We need a system which is simple, understandable and which accords a proper dignity to pensioners."

Shadow social security spokesman, David Willetts, says the benefits scheme for pensioners is a passable imitation of the Hampton Court maze. The Conservative party has pledged to fold the winter allowance, free TV licences for the over 75s and benefits that make up the minimum income guarantee, into the state pension.

"Our uprating would give all pensioners under 75 £9.50 a week if they are single and £13 a week if they are married," says Mr Willetts.

Mr Darling promises that form-filling will be massively simplified and says the scheme will make 5.5m pensioners better off, almost half the retired population.

Director General of Age Concern, Gordon Lishman, says the complex use of benefits is already proving hard to sell. "Up to three-quarters of a million of the poorest older people do not claim the income support they are entitled to, either for a lack of information or fear of stigma.

"Six months into the £15m government campaign to encourage more pensioners to take up income support, only 5% have claimed successfully. With these results, we cannot be confident that the increased income support will reach the pensioners."

How the new scheme will work

 What is the pension credit?

It is designed to allow pensioners to keep their benefits as well as some of their income from savings or private pensions when they retire. It takes effect from April 2003.

At the moment, pensioners are entitled to benefits under the government's minimum income guarantee. The guarantee takes a single pensioner from the state pension level of £67.50 to £92.15. But a pensioner who has accumulated savings or a private pension that pays £20 per week will be refused benefits - their extra income will be offset pound for pound against the income support benefit payments. The result will be that someone who failed to save during their working life will receive the same income as someone who put small sums of money aside in a pension or savings.

 How much of my savings can I keep?

This week the government said in 2003 the minimum income guarantee will be £100 for single pensioners and £154 for couples. The pension credit will allow them to keep 60p in every pound of their benefits up to a ceiling of £135 and £200 for couples.

This will mean extra cash on top of the basic state pension - sums of between £1 and £23 a week, says the government. For a pensioner with an occupational pension of £20 a week, the credit would leave them £15 a week better off.

 Is there a catch?

Form filling will be the order of the day. The government has promised to simplify the forms needed to claim income support and the pension credit. But pensioner groups reckon the forms will still be difficult for many pensioners to work out. The assumption by the Inland Revenue that pensioners can get a ludicrous 20% return on their saving will be scrapped, says Secretary of State for social security Alistair Darling. He also promises that as part of the credit, the government will raise the qualifying capital limits for the first time in 10 years from next April and scrap them from 2003.

That means pensioners who are told their savings generate 20% income, whether they draw on it or not, can keep saving until they are older and take the benefits on offer when they retire, delaying the day when they need to use the pension credit.

fields.headline: The van, the cigarettes and the Wardrobe
fields.standfirst:
Alan Skidmore Quartet
Wardrobe, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Alan Skidmore Quartet
Wardrobe, Leeds
****
fields.body:
A cock-up on the transport front almost reduces British jazz veteran Alan Skidmore to tears this evening, as the saxophonist arrives to play the penultimate date of a "dream come true" British tour that has teamed him with South African percussion virtuosos Amampondo.

The bone-crunching grooves conjured by the scantily clad rhythm warriors would certainly have shaken the foundations of this cosy jazz venue; but tragedy has struck, and the mighty Amampondo find themselves stranded in Brighton, victims of that most prosaic of English musical disasters - a broken Transit van. Skidmore and his faithful quartet look heartbroken to have arrived in Leeds without their prized entourage; even so, it rapidly becomes clear that this razor-honed outfit is perfectly capable of raising quite a few goosebumps on their own.

After three decades of liaisons with such legends as Herbie Hancock and Georgie Fame, Skidmore only really needs his smouldering saxophone to get us all drooling. As usual, he massages and then assaults our ears with the kind of heady, devotional jazz that leaves even the non-smokers in the audience gagging for a cigarette.

His set comprises music written by John Coltrane, and the band is obviously at home evoking his slow-burning dreamscapes and his fiery crescendos. As they strike up, with Resolution, you would swear that Elvin Jones, Jimmy Garrison and McCoy Tyner were in the room too, so authentic are those swelling sheets of sound.

The quartet gives an intense reading of Spiritual, and Skidmore spends the time between his exalted solos sitting stage right, crabbily rolling cigarettes and gradually allowing his grief to melt away into the band's gathering maelstrom. His sweating cohorts display the sort of bionic musicianship that would make your average instrumentalist want to pack it all in and pursue something with less fearsome competition.

In the more blazing passages of Wise One, pianist Steve Melling delivers a devastating barrage of chords, Arnie Somogyi's supple bass thrusts and heaves, and Steven Keogh belies his own blank-faced stare with a display of Olympian skin-bashing.

Tonight Skidmore should take comfort from the fact that his band have whipped up a stirringly soulful musical feast in the face of disaster. And, you know, looking at the Wardrobe's tiny stage, it's hard to figure out where Amampondo would have sat if they had made it to Leeds. In the audience perhaps? The noise would have been more than terrifying.

At the Queen Elizabeth Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), on Monday .

fields.headline: Hallé/Pesek
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.body:
The three generations of Czech composers represented in last Thursday's concert span a period of over a century. Yet their works have much common ground, and, to an extent, all three - Dvorak, Suk and Martinu - shared similar concerns. Their conscious adoption of a national voice, using the distinctive melodic and rhythmic contours of Czech folk music, had political overtones that ranged from the benign to the impassioned at various points in each composer's career, never becoming strident but maintaining an insistent presence.

Suk's early Serenade in E flat for strings is an example of the benign, even elegant, side of the Czech musical character. Pesek's finely judged and understated guidance drew much grace and warmth from the Hallé. This was not a performance that strove to overwhelm the audience with its passion; it evoked something far gentler.

Martinu's Oboe Concerto was composed near the end of his life for the oboist Jiri Tancibudek - the work's dedicatee and first performer. Tancibudek's response was not uncritical; although the concerto is scored for chamber orchestra, he found the textures overwhelming, and the solo part is mercilessly difficult. It has earned an unduly negative reputation as a result; the music itself is as fine as anything Martinu wrote. With sensitive conducting and virtuosity, any problems of technique or texture were scarcely noticeable. Simon Dent, who must be one of the world's most charismatic oboists, rose to all Martinu's challenges with apparent ease.

The concerto is not without its darker side. Although the first movement has those familiar moments of radiance that permeate nearly all Martinu's music, the second has an ambivalent, and at times unearthly, quality. Its overall character is strangely elusive; textures and harmonies shift constantly from dark to light. The finale is Martinu at his most unashamedly jolly; Pesek and Dent were ideal partners in a performance bubbling over with bounce and verve.

Pesek and Dvorak's Ninth Symphony are old friends; this was a performance full of warmth and understanding. There may have been more exciting performances of this work, with faster tempi and more extravagant dynamics, but Pesek simply did not feel the need for special pleading. The Hallé, entirely at ease with his approach, responded well; the cor anglais's wistful beauty in the famous second movement solo captured the essence of Pesek's approach perfectly.

Simon Dent, who must be one of the world's most charismatic oboists, rose to all Martinu's challenges with apparent ease. The concerto is not without its darker side. Although the first movement has those familiar moments of radiance that permeate nearly all Martinu's music, the second has an ambivalent, and at times unearthly, quality. Its overall character is strangely elusive; textures and harmonies shift constantly from dark to light. The finale is Martinu at his most unashamedly jolly; Pesek and Dent were ideal partners in a performance bubbling over with bounce and verve. Pesek and Dvorak's Ninth Symphony are old friends; this was a performance full of warmth and understanding. There may have been more exciting performances of this work, with faster tempi and more extravagant dynamics, but Pesek simply did not feel the need for special pleading. The Hallé, entirely at ease with his approach, responded well; the cor anglais's wistful beauty in the famous second movement solo captured the essence of Pesek's approach perfectly.

fields.headline: London Philharmonic/ Daniel
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Bruckner's Sixth is the most compact of his symphonies and, along with the Seventh, is the most blissfully free of arguments over which version of the score is most authentic. Bruckner never revised it, and well-meaning friends never tried to "improve" it after his death. The Sixth was never performed publicly during his lifetime (Mahler gave the premiere, heavily cut, in 1901) and it remains a comparative rarity in the concert hall, lagging well behind the Fourth, Eighth and Ninth in popularity.

When Christoph Eschenbach withdrew from the advertised concert at the Festival Hall on Thursday, Paul Daniel conducted the Sixth and his approach to the first Bruckner symphony he had ever tackled was bold and direct. Daniel was never afraid of allowing the work's brassier climaxes to punch their weight (though the sound of the LPO's horn section in particular was a little more brazen than necessary) and he ensured clarity of detail in the accompanying textures, which are far more rhythmically intricate than many would give Bruckner credit for. Above all, any temptation to bathe the symphony in warm and homogeneous sonorities was resisted.

Some sections, especially the opening of the slow movement, could have done with a bit more air around the great paragraphs. However, the combination of the rather wan-sounding strings and the Festival Hall's acoustics would never have allowed the sound to blossom and linger as the composer envisaged.

This was an unsentimental account, which still managed to uncover the tragedy lurking beneath the surface of the slow movement and to bring grandeur to the blazing triumph of the finale's last few pages.

One of Mozart's violin concertos had provided the hors d'oeuvre to Bruckner's red meat. Christian Tetzlaff was the soloist in the Fifth, in A major K219. His playing was clear and perfectly focused, with a hint of steeliness in his tone. It wasn't the most loving of performances - the gusto with which Tetzlaff and Daniel launched into the "Turkish Music" that interrupts the otherwise gentle final minuet was more convincing than their moulding of the slow movement - but it was a thoroughly civilised and musical one.

fields.headline: Warren Mitchell, the tyrant of taste
fields.standfirst:
Art
Wyndham's Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Art
Wyndham's Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
I've no wish to sound ageist but the new cast in Art, celebrating its fourth West End birthday, at times makes nonsense of the text. When Warren Mitchell's Marc announces he's an aeronautical engineer you begin to wonder, not for the first time, about the reliability of the French aircraft industry. Even the revelation that he has been friends with John Fortune's Serge for 15 years prompts speculation that they might have met on the Gallic equivalent of a Saga holiday.

It has always struck me as a modern version of Molière's Misanthrope, and it says much for Yasmina Reza's play that it survives the arrival of such mature performers. Serge's purchase of an expensive, supposedly monochromatic painting becomes a springboard for a battle between truth and hypocrisy. On a third viewing, it also reminds me of the French definition of marriage as "égoïsme à deux". Marc is a domestic bully and tyrant of taste who is deeply wounded by his chum's declaration of independence. Serge goes into a prolonged sulk when his assertion of freedom is decisively rejected. Like The Odd Couple, this is a piece in which male friendship acts as a metaphor for heterosexual marriage.

The best part, however, remains that of the conciliatory man-in-the-middle, Yvan. Even though it's a little hard to believe in Ken Campbell as a mother-dominated bridegroom, his performance is genuinely hilarious. Employed as a stationery salesman, he announces, "I'm groping my way into the world of vellum" as if it were some arcane, masonic mystery. And when Serge goes off the deep end, Yvan wildly parodies him by covering his head with a pullover and capering around like Jonathan Miller essaying a Shakespearean loon in Beyond the Fringe.

Campbell is the star of Jennie Darnell's re-creation of Matthew Warchus's original production. But, although the current cast brings a wealth of experience to the play, I think next time they should go for three actors who are in the first flush of middle age.

This cast appears until January 21. Box office: 020-7369 1736.

fields.headline: Sexy Beast
fields.standfirst:
London film festival
****
fields.trailText:
London film festival
****
fields.body:
Ray Winstone as a retired villain on the Costa del Sol? Do me a favour. Sexy Beast, on paper at least, has a ring of been-there-done-that. The tale of the English mobster in Spain leaned on by nasties over from Blighty has been done before, in Stephen Frears's memorable 1984 film The Hit. So the debut feature from Jonathan Glazer - the commercials whiz behind the famous Guinness horses - needed to bring something new to the table. And, against all odds, it does.

What is different here is not so much the story as the treatment, and the frequent changes of register make Sexy Beast consistently surprising. The mood jumps from tenderly grotesque social comedy to Pinter-toned menace to full-blown heist extravaganza, with trimmings of nightmare surrealism at the edges.

Winstone is endearingly vulnerable as Gal, a hard man turned big blubbery softie, first seen basting himself like a well-oiled turkey under the blazing sun. The heaven he shares with his wife Deedee (Amanda Redman) is soon disrupted, first by an outrageous bit of stage-managed trickery in the opening moments, then by the arrival of the much-feared Don Logan. He is played by Ben Kingsley in a performance that sandblasts away any residual scrap of Gandhi sanctity, putting the fear of God into you the moment he strides on in his crisp, short-sleeved shirt, gimlet glare reducing all comers to jelly. Kingsley doing a number on a hapless airport official is a tour de force - you never knew the actor could be this funny, or this scary.

The invasion of Gal's cosy nest could easily have fuelled the whole film. Glazer, and writers Louis Mellis and David Scinto, take a risk by opening the story out into the second half's elaborate heist. But the effect is so jarring that it works, and the film-makers avoid the usual gangland geezerisms by concentrating on the grim cosmology of the crime universe - the fact that above one hard man, there is another, then another, until you get to the prince of darkness himself, here played by Ian McShane with a curiously prissy walk that only adds to the menace.

Some of the usual genre echoes are here (James Fox's languid cameo calling to mind Performance) but Sexy Beast is not the routine, self-conscious recycling job. It is darker, wittier and altogether more human than any of the current British crime cycle. The sense that Glazer and co are trying to cram too much in only adds to the exuberant mischief.

At the Odeon West End 2, London WC2, tonight. Box office: 020-7928 3232.

fields.headline: View from the split level looking good
fields.standfirst:
The yield from the income shares on certain investment trusts can top 25%. As Tony Levene reports, it's onshore and it's legal Tony Levene reports

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The yield from the income shares on certain investment trusts can top 25%. As Tony Levene reports, it's onshore and it's legal Tony Levene reports.
fields.body:
Regular as clockwork, income cheques top the list of client demands at most independent financial advisers as falling dividends on equities coupled with lower interest rates on bank and building society accounts bite ever harder.

But savers can find yields of over 25% - from legal, onshore regulated investments.

These come from the income shares of split level investment trusts. This week Gartmore launched its new offering, the split level Absolute Growth & Income Trust. This holds out the promise of an 8.6% annual return to basic rate taxpayers - 9.5% when held in an Isa - from its "ordinary income" shares.

The fund itself is a "barbell" - some 60% of the fund will go into growth stocks, while the balance will be invested in income producing securities.

The managers of this and other similar income orientated investment trusts make no promises - investors can lose their money and the income is not guaranteed.

But unlike the corporate bond funds, which promised so much stability to investors and then largely disappointed, these trust shares do not need to hype returns as stock is bought and sold through stockbrokers and savings schemes, rather than through IFAs.

In their simplest terms, income shares work by diverting all the yield on a large fund to holders of just part of the capital.

A basic trust might start with £10m from income seekers and £10m from those looking for capital growth. The dividends from the entire £20m go to income share holders, while portfolio gains go to capital share holders.

There are a number of variants - some trusts are financed by zero dividend shareholders, while others have raised bank loans to boost the fund's size. These investors rank first if the trust's investment performance is disappointing.

Split level shares have a limited life - on expiry, income shares are usually paid back a fixed sum, while capital holders divide out what is left over.

The highest yield currently available is 29.5% from Archimedes Income, managed by Investec. That is closely followed by 27.7% from Aberforth Split Income,

"If you get very high income, some of this is bound to be a return of your capital," says investment trust analyst Simon Moore at stockbrokers Teather & Greenwood.

"But this is balanced off by the higher yield - investors should never forget that there are advantages to getting money back early rather than later. You can get a wide variety of returns and time frames," he adds.

The details are vital. The Archimedes income share is currently selling around 135p. But when the trust is wound up in September 2003, income shareholders will only receive 25p plus a small "revenue reserve." Anything else goes to capital shareholders.

The high income balances a guaranteed loss.

Aberforth income shares trade at 54p - close to their low for the year. When that trust terminates in June 2004, investors should receive 10p.

Derby income shares - again close to their 12 month low at 85p - yield 27%. When it winds up in December 2003, holders should end up with 25p.

Trusts at this level are effectively short term annuities, but with income levels far higher than any on offer from insurance companies.

Among less spectacular yields, Framlington Income & Capital which runs until September 2008, yields 10.8%. Currently valued at 51p per share, the winding up should give 30p - investors are swapping a 21p a share loss over the next eight years for a higher than average return.

Again, this might be preferable to an annuity - and they can be used in inheritance tax planning. There are obvious risks, but they are clear.

But despite these possibilities, income shares of split capital investment trusts fail to appeal to IFAs who stress potential problems, although cynics might argue that the biggest problem for IFAs is they offer no commission.

This contrasts with the hidden risks in the highly hyped corporate bond funds.

Last month, CGU Monthly Income Plus fund, one of the largest and most widely sold by IFAs, cut its return to investors by a fifth without prior warning.

The CGU product had been marketed under the slogan "A consistent monthly income to keep you going."

IFAs Bates Investment Services said earlier this year that the fund was "suitable for retired investors who want a dependable higher incomer to supplement their pension."

The CGU fund turned out to be neither consistent nor dependable.

Now new research from Virgin Direct shows that two thirds of the 41 funds in the UK Corporate Bond sector - mostly sold as safe homes for building society money by advisers - have high volatility.

Needless to say, Virgin's own bond fund is one of the least volatile. But others offering a less than roller coaster ride include M & G Corporate Bond, Fleming Select UK bond, Legal & General Fixed Interest, Save & Prosper High Income, BWD Corporate Bond and Threadneedle UK Corporate Bond.

At the other end of the risk spectrum are funds from NatWest, Sovereign, Singer & Friedlander, Canada Life, Clerical Medical, Invesco and Scottish Equitable.

Over three years, the higher risk funds have underperformed their less volatile rivals.

webTitle: Pre-Budget review: 5m families benefit from child tax

fields.headline: 5m families benefit from child tax credit boost
fields.standfirst:
Pre-Budget proposal a step towards new integrated child credit within three years

Money Unlimited
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: The government intends to boost the value of the new Children's Tax Credit that is scheduled to start from April next year.
fields.body:
The government intends to boost the value of the new Children's Tax Credit that is scheduled to start from April next year. Around five million families will benefit from an increase in the new tax credit from £8.50 to £10 a week.

The tax credit, which replaces the Married Couple's Allowance, is payable to any parent who has a child under 16 living with them. Basic rate taxpayers will get the full £520 a year, but higher earners' credit is reduced on a sliding scale.

If the Chancellor delivers on his pre-Budget proposal, from next April a married couple bringing up three children on a combined income of £20,000 will get £520 in Children's Tax Credit but lose £300 with the abolition of the Married Couple's Allowance. However, they will continue to receive child benefit.

The move to the child tax credit is, however, only a transitional step to a new integrated child credit planned for 2003. This will bring together the means-tested income support rates for children, the new children's tax credit and the element of the in-work benefit for children in the working families tax credit.

In a separate measure, out-of-work single parents and long-term jobless adults will be the main beneficiaries of the next stage of the government's welfare-to-work programme. From next April £23m has been earmarked to encourage 150,000 lone parents, who at present do not claim income support, back into work, over three years.

More than 66,000 of the lone parents on the New Deal scheme have already moved into permanent jobs. The pre-Budget report this week pointed out that only half of lone parents here work - compared with 70% in the US and 80% in France.

The Chancellor also announced a "more intensive approach" to finding work for the 25 to 49-year-olds who have been without a job for 18 months. The New Deal for that age group starts next April and those covered by it face loss of benefit if they refuse to participate.

They will be expected to agree to an initial four-month coaching period, having their problems sorted through regular contact with a personal adviser.

This will be followed by a "compulsory, intensive activity period" - lasting from 13 to 26 weeks - covering basic employability training, support to become self-employed, "access to a wage subsidy" for those moving into employment.

The pre-Budget report also proposed a separate £9m job-transition package, spread over three years. The idea is to reduce the adverse impact of large-scale redundancies by assisting fresh jobless people to move into new jobs and help employing organisations to overcome skill shortages.

The service, to start next year, will operate in areas that face factory closures and cuts and which are dependent on a sole industry or where unemployment is already high.

For details on Children's Tax Credit, call the government's helpline on 0845 300 1036. Lone parents wanting to take advantage of the new deal should contact their local job centre.

webTitle: Failed Swedish bid opens LSE to rival offers

fields.headline: Failed Swedish bid opens LSE to rival offers
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rival bidders could emerge for the London Stock Exchange despite yesterday's widely expected failure of a near £1bn offer from Swedish technology group OM Gruppen.
fields.body:
Rival bidders could emerge for the London Stock Exchange despite yesterday's widely expected failure of a near £1bn offer from Swedish technology group OM Gruppen.

OM, which secured acceptances of just 6.7%, is now barred from bidding again for another 12 months unless a rival offer emerges.

America's Nasdaq, Euronext - the merged Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam exchange - or Germany's Deutsche Borse have all been suggested as possible partners for the LSE, although it insists it is not up for sale.

OM fell far short of the 50.1% it needed to win, even though it was offering a 30% premium over the LSE share price.

Per Larsson, OM's chief executive, said he was disappointed by the result. "It shows that LSE shareholders need more time to decide the future of the LSE." OM had won the rational argument but had not had time to overcome "the emotional argument".

But the result is seen in the City as more of a failure for OM rather than a success for the LSE's board which had fought to see off what it regarded as a totally unwelcome and opportunistic bid.

The LSE board has been forced to address strategic and structural problems exposed by the Swedish intervention as well as to pay more attention to its retail brokers.

fields.bodyText: Rival bidders could emerge for the London Stock Exchange despite yesterday's widely expected failure of a near £1bn offer from Swedish technology group OM Gruppen. OM, which secured acceptances of just 6.7%, is now barred from bidding again for another 12 months unless a rival offer emerges. America's Nasdaq, Euronext - the merged Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam exchange - or Germany's Deutsche Borse have all been suggested as possible partners for the LSE, although it insists it is not up for sale. fields.headline: Eliza Carthy goes pop
fields.standfirst:
Eliza Carthy
Manchester University
***
fields.trailText:
Eliza Carthy
Manchester University
***
fields.body:
The path from folk to pop can be a very tricky one. Get it right, commercially - like the Corrs - and the folk suddenly seems to be playing second fiddle to your eyeliner. Get it wrong, and you risk alienating your core audience, who may shout "Judas!" at you.

This is the dangerous path being negotiated by Eliza Carthy. Things haven't gone exactly to plan since she released her major-label "pop" album Angels and Cigarettes. The critics liked it, but sales have been slow, and the accompanying dates (set for last month) were postponed when her angel voice gave way to laryngitis (not cigarettes).

Faced with a meagre crowd, Carthy is nevertheless singing and quipping. "This one is by my favourite singer-songwriter," she says, introducing songs by no fewer than three "favourites": Paul Weller (a sublime Wildwood), Ben Harper (a gorgeous Walk Away) and, bizarrely, Bad Manners (a barmy Walking in the Sunshine).

At this point in her career, it's a testament to blue-haired Carthy that she can throw in such curve balls (there's also a "Rock" brooch on her coat, which will alarm folk purists); but they reinforce an impression of a mild identity crisis. She has largely abandoned traditional folk but doesn't seem ready to embrace pop fully. The Bad Manners moment aside, she pointedly omits Perfect, her most obvious potential hit, and seems uncomfortable with the notion of being a commercial artist. "We're supposed to be doing the new album thing," she mock-sighs at one point, turning to her band. "Um...where's me pedal?" This endearing amateurism might do her career few favours but it's undeniably funny.

Her warmth and humour are infectious, and beneath the breezy melodies lies remarkable candour. She is becoming expert at exploring the carnage of fleeting, passionate relationships. Poor Little Me is ostensibly about an abortion, although she refrains from performing the harrowing, sexually explicit The Company of Men, which may be one lyric about "blow jobs" too many for a mainstream audience.

Awkward compromises and mixed identities aside, Carthy frequently delivers glimpses of the fabulous crossover artist she can become. The soaring Lazy Angel is the pick of her own songs, although it's hard to dispel the impression of her grinning through Walking in the Sunshine while disgruntled folkie purists grumble through their beards.

Eliza Carthy plays the Platform, Morecambe (01524 582815), tonight, then tours.
